column1: Thiruvengada Nagar
column2:
Spurned, engg student stabs classmate  CHENNAI: An engineering student on Thursday stabbed his classmate on their college campus in Surapet near Puzhal because she had broken off their relationship.  While Kavya, a 22-year-old final year ECE student of Vellammal Engineering College, is recovering in hospital, her assailant, Sakthivel, is now lodged in prison. 
Around 10.30am, Ambattur police inspector P Stephen said, Sakthivel stabbed Kavya at least six times while she was standing outside their class.  He had brought the knife covered in a sheet of paper and tucked in his belt, police said after talking to some students who had witnessed the attack.  He was soon overpowered by security guards and handed over to police. 
College authorities rushed Kavya, who sustained injuries on her chest, hands and in the stomach, to a private hospital in Ambattur.  She was later shifted to the hospital owned by the group which runs the college. 
Soon after the attack, when reporters wanted to get the version of the college authorities, they were shooed away by security personnel who said media would not be allowed on the campus.  Later, TOI visited the Ambattur police station where Sakthivel was detained.  He appeared to show no remorse for his action.  He was later remanded in judicial custody. 
Police said Sakthivel of Nagapattinam and Kavya of Ranipet in Vellore had known each other for more than three years and that Kavya had severed ties with him a few days ago. 
A classmate of Kavya, who did not wish to be named, said that he kept calling her over phone which she ignored.  “She said she had been let down and did not want to continue their relationship anymore.  However, Sakthivel did not want to let go of her,’’ the classmate said. 
Some of his friends with whom Sakthivel shared a room in Thiruvengada Nagar near Surapet said he had even tried to visit her at the hostel where she stayed but failed.  “He became desperate and said he would go after her and that if he couldn’t get her none should,” said a friend. Dream Houses Galore Driven by the demand from buyers, property developers have begun to shift from the beaten path on these two stretches that run parallel to each other and past some of the city’s prime property.  The OMR is already well-known for its high-rises and realtors are now looking at creating villas.  Meanwhile, the landscape off the ECR, with all its beachside bungalows, is now dotted with multi-storey buildings. 
Rajiv Gandhi Salai (popularly known as OMR) now has at least 15 villa projects coming up and ECR, known for its sprawling bungalows with high security, is witnessing the construction of many multi-storey buildings as well. 
C.  A.  Benoy, an OMR resident, who has booked a villa in Karapakkam as an investment, says the value of this property is appreciating well.  “The villa I have chosen is priced very reasonably and I am also getting half a ground of land.  I chose OMR because it is a very different kind of road.  Along with IT and ITES, other industries too are coming up too,” he says. 
R.  Kumar, managing director, Navin Housing and Properties Pvt.  Ltd. , explains that the narrow roads off OMR are seeing a boom in construction of villas.  “People are also looking for facilities including club houses, swimming pools and lawn spaces.  Villas are like developed colonies with a lot of open spaces, which is their USP.  By paying just a little more, the buyer gets these advantages,” he says. 
While OMR’s development is typically necessity-driven, ECR has always been the choice of those who look for great lifestyles and want to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city. 
Gaurav Sanghvi, director, Olympia Merlin, says that a lot of buyers are from the IT and ITES industry.  They want to work on OMR and live on the ECR with its great ocean view and greenery.  There is very less pollution here and the road is also being widened, so you can travel faster,” he says.  Around 20 per cent of buyers are local investors and another 20 per cent are NRIs, who are used to a lifestyle with amenities and a view of the ocean, he adds. 
However, the high-rise run on ECR may not last long as the Directorate of Town and Country Planning recently modified norms for multi-storey buildings and restricted building height on that stretch, explains N.  Nandakumar, CREDAI President (Tamil Nadu).  Now it has been limited to stilt + 4 floors. 
The development on ECR has been possible with multiple land owners coming together along with builders to develop vast tracts of land, he says adding that between apartments and villas, the choice is for the latter.

column1: Patrakarpuram
column2:
Control room to manage 115 city crossings  LUCKNOW: New parking spots, stricter and more traffic police personnel and a modern control room is what it will take to cure the city’s traffic menace.  Preventing protesters from gathering at Vidhan Sabha and clearing encroachments on roads are also major challenges. 
The CM's directives to improve the city’s traffic situation are forcing agencies concerned to work overtime.  The police’s traffic cell has made a list of five key points under its purview for better management. 
The most ambitious step is to synchronise vehicular movement across the 115 crossings in the city with an advanced control room.  On December 10, the chief minister had directed the divisional commissioner to chart out a comprehensive traffic plan. 
There are traffic signals at 40 crossings but half of these do not work.  The remaining are maintained by the Lucknow Municipal Corporation and are rarely put to use to regulate motorists. 
Additional superintendent of traffic cell GP Chaturvedi said the 75 crossings without a signal include Polytechnic, Patrakarpuram, Ravindralaya, Paper Mill Colony, Natha Tiraha, Chirraiya Jheel, Lohia Hospital, Ismailganj, Chowk, and Butler Palace, among others. 
“We will take control of the existing 40 crossings and increase the network of signals across the 75 additional crossings.  The traffic flow at main crossings will be monitored by the control room through cameras.  The time to go green will be adjusted, just the way it is done in metro cities,” elaborated Chaturvedi on the ambitious plan. 
Errant motorists and parking offenders will be taken to task as registration plates will be covered under the e-surveillance scheme.  “Challans will be sent to vehicle owners via post,” added Chaturvedi.  Multi-pronged approach Besides managing crossings, the cell’s remaining key points include:
1) 13 parking spots: Near Lal Bahadur Shastri Bhawan, Patrakarpuram, Faizabad Road in Indiranagar, Qaiserbagh, Aishbagh, Medical College, Hewett Road, Naka, Kapoorthala, Nakkhas, Chowk market, Rakabganj, Vivek Khand
2) More traffic personnel: There is a need to induct an additional 200 trained cops to manage traffic.  The department faces a shortage of about 25% against its sanctioned strength
3) Improve road engineering at 34 places: In the survey, 34 crossings and intersections in various parts of the city have been identified for immediate overhaul.  Road engineering and road safety measures across these crossings need to be augmented.  Nahariya and Tedhipulia crossings are two major challenges
4) Shifting dharna sthal: The Charbagh-Nishatganj route gets choked due to protests opposite Vidhan Sabha.  After the chief minister’s rap, city police have cornered protesters to other locations such as Laxman Mela ground.  A vacant plot in Bangla Bazar has been identified as a permanent solution
Official’s view: DM Raj Shekhar said a traffic improvement committee at the district level had been constituted to ensure that immediate goals are achieved.  Lack of coordination between agencies has resulted in faulty planning and poor road design.  Shekhar said, “Meetings will be held regularly.  Its members are the DM, SSP, secretary of the government department, municipal commissioner and PWD executive engineer.  The SP traffic will be the member secretary.  Inputs of all agencies concerned will be considered while executing infrastructure projects.  needed”.  Other goals: a) Clearing encroachment and roadside parking: Police and administrative officials will jointly clear encroachments.  Owing to work on Lucknow Metro, Kanpur Road and Krishnanagar will be targeted in the first phase.  After that, the around Charbagh station, Naka and Bansmandi will be cleared of encroachment and roadside parking of private or public vehicles. 
b) Timing of schools: Schools within an area will get over at intervals of 10-15 minutes from one another.  This will ease sudden pressure of school vehicles on roads.  School management will assist in traffic management of 50-100 sq m of area around school at the time of start and end of school. 
c) Increasing length of dividers: Road dividers at Burlington crossing and near IT crossing will be elongated further as traffic here is unregulated.  About 15 unauthorised cuts in the road median between Alambagh and Hazratganj will be plugged. 
*) Enforcing one ways: People head towards Bara Birwa, Nahariya in wrong direction from road opposite Vijay Gas Service and Badnaam Laddu in Alambagh.  From Capitol crossing, people head towards Bapu Bhawan in opposite direction.  Further ahead, from Shakti Bhawan people reach Nawal Kishore road in wrong direction. 
*) Shifting road medians: The road medians at some places will be shifted.  Median between Burlington and Rana Pratap crossings and that towards Narhi just ahead of Hazratganj crossing has been earmarked for attention.  Charbagh-Nishatganj carriageway will turn wider if that happens.  Long-term solutions There is a plan to acquire space near IT crossing to increase carriageway width and build a flyover and elevated corridor.  Ring Road at Tedhipulia has been cited among the most chronic points when it comes to traffic chaos.  Dewa Road trisection is another point where traffic jams and accidents have been on the rise.  Flyover/underpass across Nahariya crossing near Alambagh are also termed important. 
On the lines of metro cities, card-based penalties will be issued to traffic violators with help of an advanced traffic control room.  Driving licences will be punched and repeat offenders will be issued stricter penalties.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Broke traffic rule? e-challan is on its way  LUCKNOW: On the lines of metrocities, Lucknow can now boast of an e-challan system too.  Having rolled out the pilot run in the past fortnight successfully, traffic wing of city police has already sent notices to 32 motor vehicle owners caught flouting rules on camera. 
With this development, Lucknowites may look forward to reduced chaos on streets and improved traffic discipline.  Additional superintendent of traffic police Brajesh Kumar Mishra said his team was trying to follow the Bengaluru traffic management model.  The IT city has the best enforcement statistics related to traffic offences in the country and technology is the key. 
Closer home, the traffic cell is issuing tickets under many sections of Motor Vehicle Act which was so far rarely put to use.  For instance on Monday a car owner from Ruchi Khand in Aashiana was identified as an offender with help of cameras installed near Patrakarpuram crossing in Gomtinagar. 
The fine would be issued under sections 122 and 126 which amount to causing inconvenience to other road users by parking vehicle dangerously and leaving the vehicle stationary on road for hours.  “No tickets have been issued for such offences in the past,” added a traffic cop. 
With the help of cameras installed around prominent crossings in the city, modern control staff goes through live feeds at Gomtinagar located police command centre.  Through registration number, address of vehicle owner is traced and notice served. 
“The notice also carries printscreen (snapshot) of the vehicle flouting rule.  After that, 15 days time is given to deposit the fine amount at traffic police office located in Sadar.  The owner has to bring original documents and driving licence to the office.  In case the needful is not done, 15 days later we will lodge a criminal case and confiscate the vehicle with court’s permission,” said senior superintendent of police Yashasvi Yadav.

Vodafone’s ‘angel stores’ celebrate World Women’s Week  LUCKNOW: To celebrate International Women’s Week, Vodafone India- the leading telecom player has decided to roll out more of its unique ‘Angel Stores’ across UP which has only women staff working right from the backend jobs, housekeeping, security, administration to marketing.  The concept was thought of one and a half years ago to support women empowerment in country. 
Kavita Nair, the national retail head of Vodafone India said the company intends to open more such stores in future as they are being successfully run by women force.  “Women are able to handle Vodafone stores with as much efficiency as men.  In fact at times, women customers are more comfortable sharing their queries with female staff.  We are planning to roll out more such stores in next year”, she said. 
Vodafone runs about 34 Angel Stores across 21 circles in the country.  In UP East, there is only one such store at East End Mall in Gomtinagar, Lucknow.  Pankaj Thapliyal, Business Head, Uttar Pradesh (East), Vodafone India said, “We are planning to open more such ‘Angel Stores’ in cities like Kanpur, Allahabad and Varanasi in future. ”
The company is also aiming to revamp most of its old stores on global design pattern.  Thapliyal said that the company would expand its footprint in the state from present 18 stores to about 29 this year as UP is an important market for them.  “Most of the new stores would be opened on global design patterns so that customers are able to experience same services across globe.  Even few of the older ones would also be revamped based on international designs”, he added.  Such global format stores are already operational in Aliganj, Patrakarpuram and Chowk areas of Lucknow. 
The company launched a new global design store in Aminabad on Friday.  The global stores are targeted at cities with potential customers’ population above one lakh.  These stores will have dedicated smart crew to assist people in understanding the services and plans, an experience zone where they can operate live phones, self-service kiosks where people can recharge and pay bills and a red box for easy transfer of data from one mobile to another.  Vodafone is currently operating about 9500 big and mini stores across India.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Quake tremors and Bada Mangal bhandara add to commotion on streets  LUCKNOW: Ranjan Kumar was heading to his shop on his bike around 12.40pm on Tuesday after having lunch.  He saw a large number of people standing on the road near Gomtinagar railway station. 
âI could not understand what had happened.  It felt very unusual,â said Ranjan, who runs a stationery shop near the railway station. 
A short distance away was a Bada Mangal bhandara under a tent but nobody from the crowd moved towards it.  Meanwhile, cars were piling on the stretch as the carriageway got blocked due to the huge crowd.  Drivers had no option but to honk continuously to turn towards Patrakarpuram. 
It was a struggle for Ranjan and many others negotiating the roads.  Apart from the devotees who throng Bada Mangal stalls, vehicular movement across the city took a hit on Tuesday noon for at least 30 minutes. 
Many families were out on the streets fearing more tremors.  Jaywalking and criss-crossing kept commuters on toes.  Bottlenecks were reported across the inner roads of Gomtinagar, Indiranagar, Vikasnagar, Aliganj, Chowk, Qaiserbagh and Aminabad, among others. 
Hazratganj was worst hit.  The tremors shook the city around the time many people head out of office to have lunch.  School hours also end around the same time.  Coupled with Bada Mangal festivities, jams were witnessed across Rana Pratap Marg, Mahatma Gandhi Marg, Sapru Marg, Shahnajaf Road, Meerabai Marg and Ashok Marg. 
âTraffic was moving at a snailâs pace on Meerabai Marg.  I kept honking but nobody paid heed.  People kept chatting with each other and I got late for a meeting,â said Jiyamau resident Gaurishankar Mishra.  Traffic superintendent Brajesh Mishra said congestion lasted for a brief duration in places where a large number commercial buildings exist.  âBut vehicular movement was normal once people were indoors,â he added.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Unannounced diversions turn Gomtinagar streets chaotic  LUCKNOW Unannounced traffic diversions are leading to chaos on roads leading to Gomtinagar for the past three days.  Due to construction work, barricades have been put up at the Gomtinagar end of the railway overbridge and around Patrakarpuram crossing. 
As a result, thousands of commuters were caught unawares have to make sudden U-turns or ply in the wrong direction.  While work on the PICUP building-RML hospital flyover has stalled traffic movement on the road from Gomtinagar to Polytechnic, repair work on the road leading to Husadia from Patrakarpuram is compelling motorists to ply in the wrong direction. 
Lack of coordination between the traffic cell of Lucknow police, civic bodies and agencies executing the construction work has come to the fore yet again.  There are no signboards or warning boards at either site to guide first time visitors on alternative routes. 
“While Gomtinagar residents are aware of the routes in other localities, people coming from other parts of the city are badly hit.  Relatives coming to meet us for Eid decided to head back to Saadatganj instead of visiting us,” said Faraz Ali, a resident of Vijay Khand I. 
Ali’s relatives were among hundreds of commuters who plied all the way to Polytechnic and made a U-turn to reach Gomtinagar only to realize they had reached the same spot.  At Patrakarpuram, instead of taking internal routes, commuters had to ply in the wrong direction.  A big trench had been dug up at CMS Gomtinagar crossing just few days ago and had caused a lot of inconvenience to people.  However, the families staying around the crossing used their clout and the trench was levelled on Monday. 
SP traffic said the situation would improve from Friday. 
“We would ask executing agencies to deploy a person or use signage to guide first-time road users here,” he added.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  The burning issue is we are not fire-ready  LUCKNOW: Monday night’s fire in basement shops of Janpath Market once again highlights the unpreparedness of city markets to deal with such incidents
Aminabad
The busiest and most crowded market of the city is not prepared to handle any fire emergency.  In Mohan Market, only a few shops are equipped with fire extinguishers.  However, most do not have any ventilation or emergency exit.  Vice president of Mohan Market Anurag Grover said, “None of the shops here have fire safety equipment, as it is costly to maintain them.  We had requested for fire tenders at Jhandewala Park but they were stationed for a week.  All that while, street vendors obstructed them. ” The power department has initiated work of underground wiring to avoid instances of short circuit.  Wires dangle at several places. 
Kapoorthala
More than 5,000 people visit the Pragati Market in posh Kapoorthala everyday.  The commercial hub has over 250 shops but there is not a single fire extinguisher or fire bucket in the market.  There is no emergency exit or fire escape and windows are obstructed by advertisement hoardings.  Shop owner Mohan Merani said, “The last time a fire broke out, we had to drag a fire hose from the adjacent Sahara building. ” Vikram Chaurasiya, a committee member, said, “Within five months, we will place fire extinguishers. ”
Sri Ram Tower
A reality check at Sri Ram Tower, a hub of electronic gadgets, reveals that the wiring in the building is exposed and maintenance is dismal.  With an average footfall of 3,000 everyday, the risk in case of a fire is very high.  There was not a single fire bucket.  Unfazed by the poor emergency facility, HC Kapoor, the maintenance in charge of Sri Ram Tower, said, “We will bring sand lying outside (in case of fire)”. 
Patrakarpuram
Shop owner Asharaf Alam Khan said, “This is a collective responsibility of the storekeepers and the management, but no one seems interested”.  Girash Bhargava, the chairman of the market association, said, “I have requested builders many times to install fire control and prevention mechanisms but they have turned a blind eye. ” Open wires across the ceiling portray the crucial need of maintenance.  TOI tried to contact Aarohi Builders but they were unavailable.  So was Devendra Gupta, the chairman of the market association. 
Bhootnath
Over 3,000 staff and visitors are present in Bhootnath Market at any given time.  There were no fire extinguishers and the two entry and exit routes were clogged by hawkers and vehicles, making it impossible for a fire tender to approach.  “Law says there should be space for a fire tender to enter a market but that’s not possible here,” a shopkeeper said.  Basic precautions such as sand buckets and alarms were missing.  Several eateries were using cylinders in the basement.  Devendra Gupta, the chairman of the market association, remained unavailable. Ruckus at private hospital in Gomtinagar  LUCKNOW: Parents of a youth who had died at a private hospital in Gomtinagar started protesting against the hospital administration late on Sunday.  The kin of the child alleged death took place due to medical negligence while the hospital administration cited complications for sudden deterioration of the youth’s health. 
Motorcycle borne Girdhari Lal (22) had met with an accident at Deva road, Chinhat.  Lal was rushed to the hospital that is located near Patrakarpuram crossing in Vikas Khand locality of Gomtinagar. 
His kin alleged that Lal died around 5pm but the hospital administration took two hours to share the news.  Upset with the youth’s death, the relatives and kin created a ruckus outside the hospital.  The angry group had reached Gomtinagar police station by late Sunday night.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Traffic jams as cops take festive break  LUCKNOW: As police personnel took the Rakshabandhan off en mass, traffic movement took a beating and there was congestion at half a dozen places in the city with a large number of families stepping out to indulge in festivities.  Several home guards and policemen were on leave leaving a small number to man the streets. 
Dozens of motor vehicles were parked around 1090 crossing and before the Hazratganj crossing as families enjoyed ice creams or eatables and descended on the streets at the same time.  Though traffic movement was not hit, congestion was felt in Hazratganj, Bhootnath Market, Patrakarpuram, Kapoorthala, Powerhouse, Chandannagar and Barabirwa.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Timed traffic lights at 17 crossings from next week  LUCKNOW: Drivers in the city would now know when exactly to turn the engine off and start again at busy traffic crossings.  An exhaustive survey carried out jointly by traffic wing of city police and Lucknow Municipal Corporation concluded on Monday and it was decided that synchronised traffic signals would be functional at 17 intersections in the city next week.  Most of the crossings covered in the first phase would fall on the Polytechnic-Nishatganj-Charbagh route and gradually 23 more traffic signals would be equipped with timers on the lines of metro cities. 
A trial run is on at Hazratganj crossing and traffic is being regulated with the help of time-based signals for eight hours in a day.  Additional superintendent of traffic police, Habibul Hasan said Lucknowites need to respect the rules and not take it lightly.  âAt metro cities, motorists wait for signal to turn green even if no traffic cop is deputed.  In Lucknow, people follow rules only if policemen are deputed and break rules some times even in their presence,â said Hasan. 
With the help of cameras, errant motorists would be identified and e-challan issued.  In the next phase, traffic directorate of UP police is planning to set up dozens of kiosks across the city to collect fine.  Same method is followed by Bengaluru, Delhi, Pune and Mumbai traffic units. 
In the survey, two-wheeler and four-wheeler-borne traffic cops plied between Polytechnic, Badshahnagar, Sikandarbagh, Hazratganj, Charbagh, Alambagh to Shahid Path crossing in Sarojininagar route for five days last week.  Usual time spent on each signal had been recorded.  The synchronisation of the entire route had been done in accordance. 
The only hurdle in proper implementation of the system is VIP culture.  Though the designated VIP route is AmausiâBarabirwaâJail roadâCanttâBandariyabagh, top politicians, governor and judges often crisscross in the city via Hazratganj crossing.  âWe are left with no choice but to regulate the crossing manually then,â said an officer who did not want to be named. 
The places where syncronised signals would be placed in the first leg are Sikandarbagh, Sapru Marg turn, Power corporation building, Hazratganj, Bapu Bhawan, Burlington, Hussainganj, KKC trisection and two places opposite Charbagh railway station, Alambagh among other busy crossings up to Amausi airport.  Gradually, Patrakarpuram, Munshipulia, IT crossing, Parivartan Chowk would be included. 
ENGINE IDLE TIME
80 seconds to motorists on NishatganjâCharbagh route
60 seconds to motorists plying towards Hazratganj from Christ Church College end and vice versa and to those heading towards Ashok Marg from Christ Church college
40 seconds to motorists heading from Ashok Marg towards Hazratganj main market and to those heading from Capitol towards trans-Gomti
Three places where digital timers have to be put up â Badshahanagar, Sapru Marg and Pandariba Charbagh Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Lucknow cop kicks elderly steno off cycle track, pics go viral  LUCKNOW: Reckless act of a sub-inspector generated a lot of flak for city police on Saturday.  Thousands of online users from all over the country, expressed anguish over photographs in which sub-inspector Pradeep Kumar, posted in Hazratganj police station was seen misbehaving with an elderly man.  The victim, 65-year-old Krishna Kumar is seen in the pictures standing with folded hands trying to plead his case with the cop.  Support for Kumar and call for punishment against the cop, poured in from all over the country.  Actress Parineeti Chopra, film critic Rajeev Masand and former VJ and comic artist Jose Covaco retweeted the overwhelming images that went viral on social media. 
All Kumar wanted was that the Rs 5,000 worth typewriter survives wrath of the cop.  But that did not happen.  âHe was violent and kept abusing us.  I said, I would not sit near the cycle track in the future and to forgive me this time.  My requests did not work.  He threw the typewriter on the road and kicked it several times,â said Kumar. 
Kumar resides near Patrakarpuram in Gomtinagar along with wife, son, daughter-in-law and granddaughter.  Kumarâs son runs a roadside grocery store.  The family of five survives on less than Rs 10,000 a month.  Kumar makes about Rs 70 to 100 a day and had spent three decades typing applications, letters and affidavits near General Post Office. 
On instructions of #UPCM @yadavakhilesh DM and SSP immediately visited Kishan Ji and handed over a new typewriter pic. twitter. com/180heCf8hd — CM Office, GoUP (@CMOfficeUP) September 19, 2015
Officiating in charge of secretariat police outpost, Pradeep ran riot for 20 minutes around noon near GPO in Hazratganj.  Along with a constable Pradeep reached DSO chauraha (near Rajbhawan and GPO building) on motorcycle and within moments of getting off the bike, went on the rampage. 
SSP and DM Lucknow met Kishan Ji and apologized for the unethical behavior of the policeman pic. twitter. com/dmmCdTBnE4 — CM Office, GoUP (@CMOfficeUP) September 19, 2015
Pradeep knocked down a utensil filled with milk and scattered eatables the tea vendor had kept on road.  Kumar had bought the typewriter three years back for Rs 5,000 in exchange of the old one.  He is senior most among five typists who sit near GPO.  âEveryone gathered in my support.  Men in uniform have no regard for the poor,â added Kumar. 
Though it was not clear what prompted Pradeep to react in this manner, two theories were doing the rounds.  Pradeep wanted to extort more money from roadside vendors or had been pulled up for allowing vendors to encroach over cycle tracks.  As per sources, VIP movement was scheduled around the stretch and Pradeep wanted to clear it. 
#UPCM @yadavakhilesh has instructed SSP Lucknow to suspend the Lucknow cop who had beaten up an innocent wage earner at Lucknow GPO.  — CM Office, GoUP (@CMOfficeUP) September 19, 2015 Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Schoolgirl found near Gomtinagar, kidnap alleged  LUCKNOW: Student of a prominent school located in Vishal Khand in Gomtinagar, who appeared for exam on Monday was found along Gomti bandha around 1.30pm under highly mysterious circumstances.  The girl's mother filed a police complaint accusing two unidentified bike-borne miscreants of ‘kidnapping’ her. 
The class XI student left her house in the morning for school along with her younger brother who is in class IX in the same school.  Residents of Vivek Khand-III see the two minor siblings commute on Honda Activa, as they did on Monday.  The two were appearing for an exam. 
Her mother said the girl was heading back home in an auto rickshaw when two bike-borne miscreants gagged her and abducted her while she was walking home after getting off the auto rickshaw.  The miscreants had allegedly taken the girl all the way up to the bandha road in Gomtinagar Extension.  Some residents of Saraswati apartment spotted the girl in distress and alerted cops. 
Policemen reached the spot and a manhunt was launched to spot the culprits.  The girl was taken to Ram Manohar Lohia hospital for medical examination and her parents were informed.  “After talking to her, the girl’s mother told us there was no need for thorough check up.  A contusion was seen on the girl’s head,” said circle officer of Gomtinagar police station DySP Satyasen Yadav.  FIR under IPC charges 363 (kidnapping) and 308 (attempt to culpable homicide) was registered against the miscreants. 
The girl left with her parents.  Her grandfather Shyam Narayan who runs a jwellery shop in Gomtinagar told TOI, “She is shocked and extremely disturbed.  We are also unaware of the exact sequence of events and at this point we are only waiting for her to recover completely,” said Prasad.  The girl’s father is general manager of a sugar mill in Gujarat. 
BOX
Police probe shows otherwise In police investigations, it turned out that the 16-year-old was caught cheating in the exam hall on Monday morning.  Though the exam was to end at 12 noon, the girl left the classroom under the pretext of relieving herself.  “The school cameras caught her leaving the compound around 11.22am,” said officer-in-charge of Gomtinagar police station sub-inspector Shyam Babu Shukla. 
A resident of Saraswati apartment V K Singh had called police around 1.35pm on spotting the girl moving aimlessly next to the bandha road.  Police were trying to probe what transpired in the two hours with the help of cameras installed at Patrakarpuram and other locations in Vishal Khand-II. 
The duo allegedly abducted the girl and hit her on the head before dumping her at the bandha, as per complaint.  Police were trying to piece together the sequence of events with the help of CCTV cameras and were waiting for the girl to give her statement.  CCTV cameras are installed at the institute's entrance/exit.  Cameras are also installed at a police outpost nearby.  Police have also sought academic records and performance of the girl, to check if she was under duress over grades.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Asked to pay Rs 20 bus fare, goons whip out guns  LUCKNOW: Traffic came to standstill at Dalibagh and local residents ran for cover as a rowdy group of about 10 barged inside a city bus near Narmada Bhawan on Tuesday noon.  Two middle-aged men had boarded the bus from Ashok Marg at 11.30am.  The bus (registration number UP 32 EZ 4737) plying on route number 11 (Scooter India to BBD university via Alambagh, Charbagh, Patrakarpuram) was packed with daily commuters. 
The duo wanted to get off at Tilak Marg.  The bus conductor asked for the fare, but the two were ready to pay only Rs 10 instead of Rs 20.  An argument broke out between them and the bus conductor Dharmendra Verma. 
The men were carrying rifles and walkie talkie (wireless radio) and summoned more men.  As the bus reached near Narmada Bhawan, around 10 men charged at the conductor and bus driver Imtiyaz Ahmed brandishing their guns.  The violent group attacked the bus staff and threatened to kill them. 
Panic struck commuters ran outside the bus apprehending exchange of gunshots.  Meanwhile, commuters which included uniformed college students and passerby ran for cover fearing for their lives.  The group assaulted the bus staff physically waving firearms and quickly ran inside a street. 
As the news of city bus staff being attacked spread further, city bus drivers plying on route number 11 started rushing to Dalibagh.  By noon at least 10 buses were parked on the Dalibagh road and traffic movement was hampered. 
A witness of the incident tea stall owner Ranjeet said, “The group was very violent and was ready to pump bullets.  We were apprehending a gangwar like we see in movies. ” As per witnesses, the violent group which brandished firearms seemed to be either policemen in plainclothes or aides of some mafia.  DGP office was also located close by.  Police said that they were trying to identify and trace miscreants on the basis of description given by the eyewitnesses. 
Police pacified the angry city bus drivers and got the stretch cleared up to restore vehicular movement.  Officer-in-charge of Hazratganj police station inspector Vijaymal Yadav said FIR would be registered against the unidentified group.  The attacked staff members are expected to provide more details, added Yadav.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Woman run over by tractor trolley in Indiranagar  LUCKNOW: A 55-year-old woman was run over by a tractor trolley on Monday morning.  A resident of Fareednagar locality in Takrohi, Hameeda was heading back home from her son-in-law’s house in Amrahi on Monday morning and her son-in-law Faheem was riding the motorcycle. 
A tractor trolley hit the motorcycle near Takrohi market.  The woman died on the spot while Faheem has been undergoing treatment.  The kin of the deceased demanded the driver’s arrest.  Cops tried to pacify the angry group but they did not budge and scores of commuters had to face inconvenience.  Cops went through CCTV footage and managed to nab Guddu, the driver of the tractor.  Women caught stealing jewellery: Gomtinagar police arrested a woman who was caught red-handed stealing jewellery items from a shop in Patrakarpuram market.  A group of three women went into the shop and asked the salesman to show necklaces, rings and earrings.  As Amarnath Gupta and his attendant showed the items, the trio stole some rings from the box.  As they were leaving without buying anything, Gupta realised saw the rings missing and managed to detain Mamta Verma a resident of Barra, Kanpur while the other two women escaped. 
Workshop on banking fraud: A workshop was conducted to inform public about latest techniques and modus operandi used by online frauds to execute bank frauds.  SP crime Gyaan Prakash Chaturvedi along with senior bank officials and cyber experts shared tips with policemen and a large number of people who had gathered at Mahanagar police lines on Monday noon. 
Five injured: Residents of Mohammadpur Ghadi village in Gosainganj clashed on Monday over a bucket of water.  A resident Babloo waiting to fill water from a handpump objected to a neighbour washing clothes there.  Some women joined the fight and five persons were injured as the clash got violent.  Cross complaints were filed with police and Babloo his neighbour Anand, Savitri, Komal and another person were named.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Commuters fac

column2:
As polls near, corpn speeds up flyover work  CHENNAI: Contrary to popular belief, Corporation of Chennai can move at extraordinary speed — when it’s required to.  With the assembly elections likely around May 2016 and the election notification date round the corner, the corporation is going at full steam to complete delayed grade separator and flyover projects worth more than Rs 2,000 crore. 
Under fire for not doing anything to reduce traffic congestion, the civic body has decided to build six new flyovers and rail over-bridges of the 12 it promised earlier. 
The corporation has not build any new flyovers in the city since AIADMK took charge of the council but completed those on which the civic body under the previous DMK regime had started construction.  The present council’s plan to widen key stretches has also come to naught because of problems with land acquisition even though motorists continue to struggle on increasingly crowded and narrow stretches. 
Of the six proposed projects, the civic body is likely to first float tenders for a proposed Rs 118-crore rail over-bridge to connect Ennore High Road and Manali High Road.  It will follow that with a Rs 60-crore rail over-bridge connecting Villivakkam and Kolathur. 
Corporation officials said they will in the next corporation council place a proposal for a grade separator connecting Anna Salai and Mahalingapuram by integrating the Usman Road flyovers.  They have completed detailed project report for the corporation’s longest flyover, a Rs 1,320-crore structure that will connect Ega Theatre and Valluvarkottam and that experts from IIT-M will soon vet. 
Officials said they have prepared an interim report for a flyover that will in the first phase connect Sardar Patel Road flyover and Rajiv Gandhi Salai (the IT Expressway).  The officials said they would, in the second phase, connect OMR and Adyar with another flyover but are still undecided on the details of the plan. 
The civic body also proposes to construct another grade separator connecting Velachery Aquatic Complex and Guru Nanak College on Velachery High Road. 
Civic officials said they scrapped a 3.25km flyover to connect Vadapalani bus depot and La Chatelaine School on Arcot Road because of the proposed mono rail project.  They’ve also abandoned plans for a grade separator near Crowne Plaza Chennai (formerly Hotel Park Sheraton) and another on Gandhi Mandapam Salai in Kotturpuram on the advice of a consultant. 
The corporation also binned a proposal for a flyover in Mandaiveli junction near Mandaiveli bus stand after residents opposed the project and postponed two flyovers — one on Bharathi Salai and another connecting Adhithanar Salai, Pantheon Road and Dr Rukmani Lakshmipathy Road — because of metro rail work. 
Experts have pointed out to the civic body that flyovers most often do not ease traffic congestion. 
“The flyovers in Adyar and T Nagar have shown that flyovers only cause congestion at certain points while relieving traffic at other points,” former Anna University urban engineering professor K P Subramaniam said.  “Many developed countries are now demolishing flyovers as it gets choked because of too much vehicles. ” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  40K homes show way to clean Chennai  After empty claims and false starts, the city's efforts at segregation of waste at households (source segregation) seem to be slowly yielding results.  Five days after the corporation did a soft launch of source segregation on Gandhi Jayanti, TOI has found that North Chennai, which is considered `dirtier', has done a better job than the southern part of the city when it comes to separating dry waste and biodegradable waste. 
Of the 85.66 tonnes of dry waste collected from the city in the first two days, Central Chennai which consists of Thiru-Vi-Ka Nagar, Ambattur, Anna Nagar and Teynampet collected the maximum with 37.6 tonnes. North Chennai (25.62 tonnes) came second, ahead of South Chennai (16.72 tonnes). 
Corporation officials said residents in North Chennai which consists of Thiruvottiyur, Manali, Madhavaram, Tondiarpet and Royapuram have shown more interest than the southern neighbourhoods of Valasaravakkam, Alandur, Adyar, Perungudi and Sholinganallur.  “Now about 40,000 households are doing it,“ said an official. 
Though the civic body has collected just 1% of the segregated waste of the total garbage the city generated in two days, experts say it is a good start.  If 50% of homes do segregation, the solid waste going into the two dump yards ­ Kodungaiyur and Perungudi ­ will be reduced to half.  Whenever the city corporation and NGOs tried to spread awareness about source seg regation of waste, a majority of residents had excuses not to fall in line.  Some said unless it is imposed across the country , it will be of no use since garbage collectors would anyway mix the waste segregated at some homes with the rest of the trash. Some others found it to be a time-consuming exercise amidst their busy schedule.  Yet others complained of none coming to collect segregated waste at their doorstep. 
A few neighbourhoods have remained an exception, segregating waste for several years without any support from the corporation.  Now, with the corporation's latest effort looking promising -some 40,000 households do source segregation -the example set by people like Nalini Ravendran has gained a bigger purpose.  Ravendran, a resident of Lakshmipuram, not only separates wet and dry waste, but also composts the biodegradable part using three-tier terracotta pots called `khambas'.  “I've been doing it for 12 years,“ she said.  “Kham bas is a simple way to convert organic waste into manure.  This is affordable and requires little space. “ She said everyone in the city should segregate waste before complaining about littered streets.  J Bhagavathy , 66, a resident of Maheswari Apartments in Valluvarkottam says the residents' association has provided two big containers for families to dump waste.  “It's not a Herculean task.  We are glad that the corporation is now extending it to other parts of the city .  It should now ensure that workers collect garbage regularly from houses,“ said Bhagavathy . 
The corporation's data shows a majority of houses are yet to follow suit.  “Conservancy inspectors in many zones are yet to enforce it.  Some people are unaware of it, some just don't care.  We hope the attitude changes in the coming days,“ said an official. 
The corporation has set up at least one composting plant in each of the 15 zones.  The aim is to increase the number of such plants to 45.  In Kodambakkam zone, it has started giving 5kg manure as an incentive for those who give segregated garbage.  In Madhavaram, civic officials source rotten vegetables and fruits from nearby supermarkets.  The civic body will also reward conservancy inspectors who collect the maximum dry waste from residents.  “We are also identifying vacant plots, parks, burial grounds and group bins as dry waste-sorting centres, said the official.  The civic body is in talks with scrap dealers to buy recyclable waste. Plastic waste will be used for road laying. 
Environmentalist Dharmesh Shah said the civic body should involve more residents.  “Many people are unaware about the corporation's source segregation plan as they are yet to engage them,“ Shah said. Govt responsible for flood disaster: Ex-mayor  Flooding of Chennai was the result of keeping a directionless, inept administration in office for more than four years, said former mayor of Chennai M Subramanian in an interview to TOI.  Excerpts from the interview: Do you think the flood disaster could have been mitigated? Natural calamity cannot be prevented.  But the magnitude of the disaster could have been avoided.  That is the job of the government.  People suffered because the government failed in its duty.  About 1,450 crore worth drainage projects, started in 2010 and scheduled to be completed two years ago, are not yet over owing to poor supervision by mayor and officials, and extortion by avaricious councillors.  The corporation has not initiated any step to construct drains in the expanded areas till now.  The capacity of the existing drains shrunk by 90% due to not desilting.  Our mayor Saidai Duraisamy does not know the difference between sewerage and storm-water drains.  What do you think should have been done? Going by the experience of handling floods in 1985, 1995 and 2005, we should have been better prepared.  It is government’s mistake that it did not take the forecast of unprecedented rains seriously.  Adequate warning was not given to people to move to safe places before releasing water.  As per your estimate what is the death toll? This government does not speak the truth.  The government’s figure of 350-odd deaths is fudged.  The actual toll could be much more in Chennai alone.  Some deaths were registered only after the victims’ relatives threatened to stage agitations.  Aren’t successive governments responsible for encouraging housing projects in low-lying agricultural wetlands which were once flood course of reservoirs and lakes? As population of the city increased, people had to be accommodated.  Many parts of the present-day Chennai city like Spurtank road and Valluvarkottam were once lakes.  Isn’t DMK also responsible for encouraging slums on river banks? The DMK government rehabilitated more than 70,000 families living along Chennai waterways.  The previous DMK government tied up with Singapore government to beautify Cooum river.  Three stretches of Cooum banks were cleared and developed as parks by us.  But, like many other projects initiated by us, the river restoration work also was put on hold by the AIADMK government.  If you were the mayor, what would be your top priorities now? This is the right time to remove all encroachments along rivers.  Many educational institutions have encroached upon rivers and lakes.  All of them should be evicted without any mercy.  A councillor at Manapakkam has encroached upon a lake bed and constructed 21 houses.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Chennai today Religion

Officials said the sanitary workers were from eight blocks of Vellore district – 50 each from Arakkonam, Nemili and Kaveripakkam blocks, 35 from Arcot, 44 from Madhanur, 14 from Alangayam, 40 from Gudiyatham and 37 from Pernambut blocks. 
“The workers have been sent to take up garbage clearance works in Valasaravakkam, Kolathur, Valluvarkottam and Choolai.  They were sent to Chennai in six special buses,” an official said. 
He added that they will be sending another 500 sanitary workers to the flood-affected areas of Chennai on Tuesday.  Traffic diversions on Kodambakkam High Road As Chennai Metrowater has scheduled maintenance work for the next few days on Kodambakkam High Road, the Traffic Police has announced traffic diversions on the stretch. 
Accordingly, Metropolitan Transport Corporation buses plying from Kodambakkam flyover to Anna Salai via Kodambakkam High Road beyond Valluvarkottam have to take a right turn at Valluvarkottam junction and proceed towards Thirumalai Pillai Salai - GN Chetty Road and reach Anna Salai via Anna Rotary. 
Two-wheelers and light motor vehicles coming from Kodambakkam flyover and intending go to Nungambakkam High Road will have to take a left turn at Josiar Street intersection and proceed towards Thirumoorthi Nagar Main Road to reach Nungambakkam High Road. 
Two wheelers and light motor vehicles coming from Kodambakkam flyover can proceed on Kodambakkam High Road up to Josiar Street intersection and those proceeding to Anna Salai can take a right turn at Cathedral Garden Road junction and proceed to G. N Chetty Road junction (Service Road). 
Vehicles proceeding from Anna Salai towards Kodambakkam will be diverted on to the wrong side at Kodambakkam – Nungambakkam High Road junction and can use the regular route on Kodambakkam High Road after Josiar Street.  Simbu fans voice their support for actor Members of Chennai Simbu fan clubs associations said on Monday that it was unfair to target the actor when he had not released the controversial ‘Beep’ song himself. 
“When the song has been leaked, why is the actor being questioned and hounded,” they asked. 
The fans had initially planned a protest at Valluvarkottam without police permission but later assembled outside the actor’s house in T.  Nagar and spoke to the media, voicing their support for him. 
“We think that people working against him have taken advantage of this situation and have been unnecessarily targeting him,” said Sathish, head of the actor’s fans association for Chennai.  Simbu fans voice their support for actor Simbu fans voice their support for the actor

K.  Karunanidhi and M. K.  Stalin for the Chennai floods. 
During the meeting, the Mayor alleged that Mr.  Karunanidhi was responsible for the shrinking of the Adyar river to 59 metres near Nandambakkam and 83.3 metres near Saidapet in the city limits.  “In 1967, when he was the Public Works Department Minister, he brought workers from Thiruvarur as a part of Cooum beautification and allowed them to encroach upon the river banks,” he said, and added that that even a lake at Valluvarkottam was encroached upon by them. 
Responding to allegations about the excess discharge of Chembarambakkam water coupled with inaction by officials as the reason for flooding, Mr.  Duraisamy said the highest rainfall recorded in 100 years along with excess water from lakes and channels that had drained into the Adyar river caused flooding in most areas. 
“We had initiated enough preventive measures and informed people living near the river about the rising water level only after which the water discharge from Chembarambakkam began,” he said. 
Subhash Chandra Bose, Leader of the Opposition, said the Mayor was levying baseless allegations against their party leaders to divert attention from the real reasons for the flooding.  “If they had de-silted channels and waterbodies, and evacuated people, the effects of the disaster could have been largely avoided,” he said, after walking out of the meeting with the rest of the councillors. 
Chaos prevailed in the meeting after they engaged in a verbal altercation with the Mayor and AIADMK councillors, also stating that it had become a thanksgiving meeting for Chief Minister Jayalalithaa and that the real work by volunteers and NGOs in rescue operations was not recognised.  They left the premises of Ripon Buildings after shouting slogans against the Mayor and the AIADMK.

Police recovers idols, valuables stolen from Raghunathji temple in Kullu SHIMLA: In a major breakthrough, the Special Investigation Team has recovered all the idols, including the gold idol of Lord Raghunath installed in 16th century, and other valuables stolen from Raghunathji temple in Kullu in December last year, police said today. 
The SIT recovered the idol of Raghunathji from Bajaura on border of Mandi and Kullu districts while the idol of Lord Hanuman, a gold plated Narsinh Shila (stone), silver idol of Lord Ganesh, a gold locket and a chain, and some other articles of worship were recovered from Beasa Mor, ADGP (law and order) Sanjay Kundu said. 
The SIT had reliable information that the stolen idols and valuables were not taken out of Himachal Pradesh and had been hidden in different parts of the state. 
The high profile theft in Raghunathji temple had sent shock waves in Kullu region as Lord Raghunathji was presiding deity of 300 local deities and people pay obeisance to him during the historic Kullu Dussehra festival. 
The SIT had zeroed in on some suspects and intensive investigations helped in detecting the exact location of the places where the stolen idols had been hidden, Kundu said. 
The state police had sounded Interpol alert and announced a reward of Rs 10 lakh for providing credible information about the thieves and later sketches of some suspects were prepared on the basis of CCTV footage and released to the media. 
A prime suspect is reported to have fled to Nepal, he said, adding, more details about the modus operandi adopted by the police in cracking the case would be disclosed later. 
The idol of Ragunathji which was supposed to be thousands of years old was brought to Kullu from Ayodhya in sixteenth century and was installed in Raghunathji temple at Sultanpur in Rupi Palace of Raja of Kullu. 
The idols were stolen on the intervening night of December 9 and 10 last year.

column1: Kovilkadavu
column2:
A ‘marathon’ to deliver letters He is believed to be the only ‘Anchalottakaran’ (postal runner) in the State who can shed light on the postal system in the Anchunadu valley in the erstwhile Travancore. 
At his ramshackle house at Kanakkayamkudy, near the forest check-post at Kovilkadavu between Marayur and Kanthalloor, Chapli Kannan tries to piece together memories of those days.  He claims he is over 90. 
He was the postal runner connecting Kanthalloor and Marayoor, the two ‘oorus’ (villages) in the Anchunadu valley comprising Marayur, Kanthalloor, Karayoor, Keezhanthoor, and Kottagudy (now in Tamil Nadu). 
Holding a bell, his work would start at 6.30 a. m.  from his house at Kanakkayamkudy to the Kanthalloor ‘post office’ (a distance of 8 km).  From there, Kannan collected postal articles and would run to the Marayur post office and after handing over the articles and collecting materials from there would reach Kanthalloor (a distance of 32 km) and return home. 
Kannan said he started the work at the age of 17 and continued till India Post took over the services.  He had to leave the job sans any benefit. 
He said he had the right to confront anyone who prevented his way and used to carried a weapon.  The sound of the bell alerted the people about the movement of articles between the two villages. 
Kannan said he received Rs.31 a month though his salary was fixed at Re.1 a day.  “It was not a bad salary then,” he says. 
All important articles, including cash, were then handed over through the system, he said adding that the addressee had to collect the items from the offices as there was no one to deliver them. 
In The Facets of 100 Years’ Planting , published by Tata-Finlay Ltd. , there is a reference of the postal system in the British-ruled Munnar. 
As per the book, officials from the U. K.  posted at Munnar had to apply for leave through post and one had to wait at least a month to get sanction from the British East India Company’s headquarters there. 
An ‘Anchalottakaran’ sheds light on the postal system in Anchunadu valley Suspected yellow leaf disease hits areca nut crop Symptoms of what is believed to be yellow leaf disease is being witnessed in the Marayur region, raising fears that it will engulf the entire areca nut cultivation there. 
Last year, root-wilt disease with the same symptoms had spread among coconut trees in the area and experts’ opinion on controlling it proved ineffective.  Tender coconut on disease-affected trees withered and started decaying.  Once a plot was affected with the disease, it fast engulfed the entire area.  The farmers were left with no option but to destroy the trees. 
It is believed that the same disease has now affected the arecanut trees, with the leaf in the inner whorl yellowing and then spreading to the outer whorl of the crown.  The trunk breaks off at the top, and rotting of roots has also been reported.  The nut is reduced in size, the kernel turns black, the top decays, and finally the tree is killed. 
Experts said phytoplasma was the disease-causing agent, and the disease had already affected hundreds of acres of both coconut and areca nut palms.  The affected trees are mainly at Nachivayal, Anachalpetty and Kovilkadavu in Marayur and Chanalmedu, Missionvayal and Cheruvadu in Kanthallur. 
An official of the Agriculture Department told The Hindu on Monday that a wide area in Marayur had already fallen to the disease.  “Earlier we thought that it was a microplasm-like organism and directions were given to the farmers on counter measures.  However it was found that the controlling measures were ineffective and the disease fast spread to new areas,” he said. 
Farmers said coconut and arecanut palms on hundreds of acres were cut down in the last six months.   Uzhavil Jose of Nachivayal said after the outer leaves turned yellow, the top of the tree started decaying within a month.  “When the disease affected coconut trees, we applied pest control measures suggested by the Krishi Bhavan.  However, it proved ineffective and the disease fast spread to nearby areas,” he said. 
Agriculture Department officials said the failure to take continuous disease-control measures was the reason for the spread of the disease. 
Block technology manager Manikandan said a team of pathologists from the Kerala Agricultural University would visit the farms on July 20, 21 and 22 and interact with the farmers. 
It is also suspected that could be a new disease that has affected the area.  Kanthallur, Marayur lose out on paddy : Kanthallur and Marayur, which were once known as the rice bowl of Devikulam taluk, have lost their fame over the last two decades. 
Several factors played a role in the shifting of cultivation in the two areas — Kanthallur had become mostly a vegetable cultivating village and Marayur was under sugarcane cultivation.  Farmers say the shift in agriculture practices came about when paddy cultivation became unprofitable and there was shortage of labour. 
According to an estimate at the Marayur Krishi Bhavan, paddy cultivation had shrunk from 2,000 acres to a mere 25 acres.  In Kanthallur, it had fallen from  2,500 acres of land to 100 acres.  An official at the Krishi Bhavan told The HIndu that the two villages had been completely under paddy cultivation of many endemic varieties. 
The villain
Vegetable or sugarcane cultivation posed no environmental threat.  However, now a vast area in the two villages has been converted into grandis cultivation.  Grandis cultivation has caused depletion of groundwater in the two villages, sources said. 
In Kanthallur, areas like Masi, Keezhanthur and Kovilkadavu were under paddy cultivation till recently.  The main varieties were champa, Kuttalam and Vellanellu.  Though the panchayat provided the seed and fertilizers to promote paddy cultivation, it could not do much to help preserve paddy farming, said S.  Madhavan, grama panchayat president.  He said in a few years, paddy cultivation would be completely stopped. 
Keezhanthur Padasekhara Samithy is the only one of its kind in the panchayat.  Under the samithy, 43 acres of land were brought under paddy cultivation.  Earlier the Mahatma Gandhi National Ruiral; Employment Guarantee Scheme was utilised to promote paddy cultivation.  But, a bar on this during 2013-14 brought the entire effort in the reverse gear, said Mr.  Madhavan. 
According to the official of the Krishi Bhavan, it is difficult to resume paddy cultivation after the land is utilised for other cultivation. 
Scarce water
As water sources became scarce, farmers shifted to cash crops.  If paddy cultivation is to be restored, there should be a concrete plan to ensure that farmers do not suffer losses.  The soil and the climatic conditions in the two villages are best suited for paddy cultivation. 
Farmers shifting to grandis cultivation
Plea for plan to restore paddy cultivation

column1: Frejarpura
column2:
Maid held for theft, mom files counter plaint  WARDHA: Pratibha Gajbhiye, a resident of Laxmi Nagar, Wardha, on Thursday filed a complaint at Frejarpura police station, Amravati, against her former maid for allegedly stealing gold worth 2 lakh.  The maid’s mother filed a counter complaint against Gajbhiye at Sevagram police station on Friday night. 
PI of Frejarpura police station said the maid, Anita Vadhai, 23, a resident of Dhanora village, was arrested from her village on Friday.  He said 84gms gold was stolen from Gajbhiye’s residence in December last year.  Gajbhiye had stated in her complaint that Anita worked at her residence for three years before leaving the job a month ago for her marriage. 
Anita’s mother Nanda, who filed the counter complaint against Gajbhiye, said, “Before leaving the job, Anita had demanded her wages but Gajbhiye refused to pay a single rupee.  In fact, Gajbhiye threatened Anita that if she asks for money, she will send us to jail. ” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

column1: Panchal Ghat Durwasa Ashram
column2:
Four children drowned in Ganga at Panchal Ghat in Farrukhabad district  KANPUR: Four children drowned in Ganga at Panchal Ghat in Farrukhabad district.  They were identified as Phoolkali (9), Ranjit (8), Adesh (6) and Anshika (11), all natives of Talihar village in Shajahanpur district.  The police said the accident took place when the children had gone for a bath in Ganga at Panchal Ghat Durwasa Ashram. 
The incident took place in the morning hours when five kids Anshika (11) Makhanlal (10) Phoolkali (9), Ranjit (8) and Adesh (6), all natives of Talihar village in Shahjahanpur, who had come to Panchal Ghat Durwasa Ashram of Farrukhabad along with their elders to take part in a religious discourse, went for a bath in river Ganga.  Eyewitnesses said they entered into the main current of the river.  Within minutes, the five started to call out for calling for help as they struggled to stay afloat. 
Hearing the victims’ cries, the local shopkeepers jumped into the river and managed to rescue one Makhan Lal while the four others went missing.  They immediately alerted the Panchalghat police. 
The rescue team later pulled out Anshika (11) Phoolkali (9), Ranjit (8) and Adesh (6). 
" While Anshika, Phoolkali, Ranjit and Adesh were declared dead, Makhan Lal was shifted to district Hospital, where he is undergoing treatment.  They all were bathing with their elders at Panchal Ghat when they started drowning.  It is a tragic incident,"  said additional superintendent of police Rambhuvan Chaurasia.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

column1: Chellappa Gounder Street
column2:
Little progress in shifting out temples, shops from Gandhipuram The progress in shifting three temples and 100-plus shops from near the flyover construction site in Gandhipuram is at snail’s pace. 
Or, so it appears from what the officials tell The Hindu .  The Coimbatore Corporation, after rejecting the Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Department plea for alternative site near the prison grounds, has identified a land in Kattoor for shifting the Muniappan Temple, Siddhi Vinayagar Temple and Muthu Mariamman Temple. 
On this land near the Chellappa Gounder Street, the Corporation will provide around 2,400 sq. ft.  to each of the three temples. 
The Corporation has readied this and submitted the proposal to the authorities concerned for further action, the sources say and add that it is now for the Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Department to act.  The latest is that the proposal is under the consideration of the Commissioner of the Department. 
Likewise, the civic body has suggested two sites for shifting the 150-odd shops. 
The civic body was forced to find alternative sites after the lorry drivers at the parking area near the Power House and Coimbatore North Railway Station said that it would be difficult for them to give up the place. 
With the stretch of land near the Tangedco sub-station on Ukkadam By-pass Road as the first option and the stretch of land near the sewage treatment plant site on Nanjundapuram Road as the second option, the civic body has submitted a proposal to the authorities concerned for further action and are yet to hear from them. 
The sources say that the civic body has done its part by identifying alternative sites and it is for the authorities concerned to act. 
Meanwhile, the vehicles make slow progress in the Gandhipuram area as files move from one department to another.

column1: Swarlagondi
column2:
Bifurcation hits AIDS Control Society activities In the absence of new programmes, the Krishna district unit of the State AIDS Control Society (APSACS) is idling away precious time with a fond hope that the body will be bifurcated by March-end and activities will resume from the next financial year. 
Sources in the department say except for implementation of Deepika Smart Card for HIV+ patients in VAMBAY Colony in the city, no new initiatives could be introduced in the last several months.  The Smart Card covers five health aspects: addiction to smoking, drugs, etc; suspicion of tuberculosis; marital status, travel for long distances; any reproductive tract infections and sexually transmitted infections.  Designed as a self-evaluating system, people can fill the smart card, evaluate the grades and determine, on their own, if they are vulnerable to contracting HIV/AIDS. 
After a long gap, the authorities met at Visakhapatnam recently to review the progress of various initiatives.  The APSACS continues to be one body for two States, which is seen as the cause for many existing problems. 
Bifurcation of the State has resulted in slowing down of a series of programmes launched by the SACS to control the spread of the virus.  It was almost a norm to launch most of the pilot programmes of the AIDS Control Society either in Vijayawada or in Guntur.  But the ‘disturbance’ due to the bifurcation process has resulted in a lull in the activities. 
The Public-Private Partnership (PPP) mode embraced by the SACS to reach out to a wider section of population afflicted by the virus has, however, shown some positive impact in Krishna district. 
With a view to provide HIV prevention, care and treatment to sections that remained outside the realm of its services, the APSACS has roped in private hospitals and nursing homes.  Under the PPP model, the department would provide logistic support like HIV test kits and disposable delivery kits to the ‘positive’ patients visiting private hospitals.  It would also extend technical support in terms of capacity building, regular monitoring and evaluation. 
“This year, we have roped in 18 private hospitals in Krishna district.  The collaboration helps us conduct HIV tests and distribute HIV kits to those identified as ‘positive’,” says T. V. S. N.  Sastry, District AIDS Control Officer. 
“We have brought into our fold even the newly-opened Primary Health Centres (PHCs) in remote areas like Swarlagondi in Nagayalanka mandal and Edurumondi,” says Mr.  Sastry.

column1: Yusmarg
column2:
Single window clearance for tourism projects: Jammu and Kashmir CM Mufti Mohammad Sayeed SRINAGAR; Jammu and Kashmir Chief Minister Mufti Mohammad Sayeed today announced a " single window"  for project clearance in a time-bound manner to fast-track approvals for laying high-end tourism infrastructure in the state. 
" There is a need to promote 'Business with Ease' and the Single Window will facilitate creation of high-end facilities with global benchmarks,"  Sayeed said, chairing a high level meeting here. 
He said his government would remove hurdles to facilitate brand tie-ups so that high-end intake capacity of the state, which is presently low is substantially increased to draw overseas and top-class domestic visitors to the state. 
" A high-powered Committee will be framed that will facilitate creation of brand infrastructure to attract international tourist footfall to the state,"  he said. 
Asking for a concerted effort to promote J&K as a top-class golf destination with week-end and week-long packages, the Chief Minister called for an organized publicity campaign to promote golf tourism in the state. 
" We already have golf circuits at Srinagar, Gulmarg, Pahalgam and Sidhra.  We are exploring possibilities of laying new courses at Sonamarg, Sanasar and Yusmarg for which feasibility reports are being prepared,"  Sayeed said, adding Kashmir Golf Club, one of the oldest courses in the country, will also be refurbished to attract golf lovers. 
He urged the top stakeholders in tourism industry to employ local youth in their hospitality and human resource divisions, saying expansion of tourism infrastructure would create countless employment opportunities in the services sector. 
" Our youth are greatly talented in HR and Hospitality segments and I am sure they will do a fairly good job at the cutting-edge level,"  he asserted.  Opposition to Bojpathri firing range proposal gains momentum SRINAGAR: Adventure Tour Operators Association of Kashmir (ATOAK) and J&K Ski and Mountaineering Association (JKSMA) in a joint meeting held at Srinagar took a strong note of Army Firing Range proposed to come up at Bojpathri in Yusmarg area of Kashmir. 
We are dismayed to learn that the army is asking for the permission to build a firing range in the vicinity of world famous tourist resort of Yusmarg, a joint press communiqué said here today.  This virgin and pristine area will face enormously environmental degradation if such a plan is implemented. 
President ATOAK, Rauf Tramboo who presided over the meeting said the move will prove environmentally disastrous as this virgin place is very fragile, the Karewa land beneath this mountain range which is holding the entire weight of solid rock face of Pir Panjal Mountains will also get affected besides it will prove harmful to the water bodies, horticulture and agricultural land of this area thus directly affecting a large population living in this area. 
The move will also damage the tourism departments plans to promote this area for Adventure and Pilgrim tourism, the adventure tour operators who have been selling this area for different adventure activities for both summer and winter will face cancellations of current bookings and this area will be total loss for any future adventure tourism activities, beside Pilgrim tourism will also get blow as the area is famous for many revered shrines at Chari Sharief and Pakhar Pora, he said. 
Tourism and presence of army in the pristine areas for whatever purposes cant go together, ATOAK and JKSMA urges the government to desist from any such move as this misadventure can prove disastrous not only to society at large but it will affect environmentally and culturally to every other place of Kashmir valley. 
ATOAK and JKSMA together will fight tooth and nail if any such a plan is implemented at Bojpathri or any other place in Jammu and Kashmir, we have already suffered a lot and will not allow anyone to vandalise our ecology, environment and resources
Meanwhile, J&K RTI movement vociferously opposed the Government’s proposal to shift firing range to Bajpathri-Yousmarg. 
Founding Chairman JKRTIM and Chief Patron of Tossamaidan Bachao Front, Dr Shaikh Ghulam Rasool stated, we reject such a devastating move by the government, where human life and environment is under a constant threat. 
Dr Shaikh, in his statement said, we will launch a strong campaign against this decision and will support the Save Yousmarg campaign, to further deepen the mission. 
We fail to understand why is the government so adamant to make human life even more vulnerable, when the consequences of putting up a firing range in Tossamaidan, have been already witnessed.  Wherein, 65 people lost their lives and over 300 people are permanently disabled. 
Devastation of flora and fauna, biodiversity and various water bodies is so immense that it will continue to impact our future generations, he said. 
He added, shifting the firing range to Yousmarg, does implicate much devastation than was caused by TosaMaidan. 
Prima facie, it means threat to the thousands of families of Nomadic tribes and their livestock.  Second, it will have impact (ranging from severe to mild) on atleast six districts of J&K.  Third, the irrigation and drinking water schemes of Frasnag and Doodhganga will be contaminated and wrecked down in the long run.  And last but not the least, it means hammering down the Tourism industry, as many tourism destination stay nearby. 
The RTI activists harshly criticised government’s anti people policies and said, we will not allow Government/Army to ruin our people, our land, our forests and our Environment. 
People of Tosamaidan will also stand in close cooperation with the inhabitants of  Yousmarg, as every Kashmiri stood with them, when they fought the battle against Tosamaidan firing range, said Dr Shaikh. 
Be Part of Quality Journalism
Quality journalism takes a lot of time, money and hard work to produce and despite all the hardships we still do it.  Our reporters and editors are working overtime in Kashmir and beyond to cover what you care about, break big stories, and expose injustices that can change lives.  Today more people are reading Kashmir Observer than ever, but only a handful are paying while advertising revenues are falling fast.
