column1: Indira Dam
column2:
Flesh in Indira dam: Pollution board to test water  LUCKNOW Police started investigating on Wednesday to find the source of flesh found stuck in the regulator at the Indira Dam a day before, while UP Pollution Control Board will begin taking samples of the water to know the level of contamination.  The authorities at state irrigation department would initiate the exercise for the removal of the flesh from the water on Thursday. 
On Tuesday, an estimated 25 quintals of flesh was found floating near the regulator of Indira Dam.  The matter came to light when residents in Juggaur village complained of a pungent smell.  The sighting pressed alarm bells among people as the dam feeds Kathautha Jheel (via Sharda Canal)—a primary source of drinking water to more than 8 lakh homes in trans-Gomti area. 
Officials deployed at Indira Dam regulator have also expressed possibility of water in Kathautha Jheel getting polluted because of the flesh.  Authorities at Lucknow Jal Sansthan said there was no reason to worry. 
When contacted, jal sansthan general manager Rajeev Bajpai said: “There is no threat to drinking water supply in trans-Gomti area being contaminated as the direction of point where flesh was found was against the flow.  This would save contamination of water towards Sharda canal which feeds Kathauta jheel.  But, all necessary precautions are being taken. ”
Taking note of the matter, local police has initiated investigation to find out the source of flesh.  Meanwhile, police probe to find out the source of such a large quantity of flesh could not yield any information.  Chinhat station officer Shashi Shekhar Yadav claimed: “It is possible the flesh was thrown into Indira canal’s stretch that falls in Barabanki district and we are in touch with our counterparts there to trace the culprit. ”
Meanwhile, health experts have expressed concern over the matter besides prescribing caution.  Gomtinagar extension based general physician, Dr D P Mishra said contaminated water could lead to a number of gastro-intestinial diseases.  “Though most households have water filters, many are not equipped to fight with virus or bacteria.  Boiling water before consumption could help,” he stated.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

column1: Bangur Nagar
column2:
Trees hacked in Malad business hub  MUMBAI: The BMC registered a non-cognizable complaint with the police on Thursday in connection with trees being cut in Malad.  Parminder Singh Bhamra, a local corporator from the area, said some locals had informed him about the greenery being destroyed at Malad Link Road.  When he reached the spot, he saw trees were being cut by some people opposite Inorbit Mall. 
The area is a prime business hub, said Bhamra, a tree committee member in the BMC.  “I strongly feel a developer is involved in this case.  I immediately informed ward officials and they called the police to the spot.  We cannot let trees be cut such a way,” said Bhamra. 
Senior inspector, Bangur Nagar police station, Dnyaneshwar Jawalkar, said, “The BMC registered a non-cognizable complaint on Thursday in connection with trees being cut at Malad.  Further investigation is on.  The trees were on private land. ” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Youth held for cheating 10 women  MUMBAI: The Bangur Nagar police arrested a 25-year-old married man for allegedly duping more than 10 women of their valuables on the pretext of marrying after befriending them through matrimonial websites. 
An MBA graduate, Firoz Shaikh, ran out of luck when police started hunting for him after he recently duped a divorcee of over Rs 2 lakh.  Shaikh met the woman to tie the knot but fled away with her valuables, leaving her at a mall in Malad a week ago. 
Shaikh, a Jogeshwari resident, confessed to committing the offence to earn fast money after he was jobless.  “Shaikh is married, but in a bid to get fast money, he targeted women on matrimonial websites.  He has made three different profiles under various pseudonyms to trap the women,” said a police officer.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Citizens connect through Whatsapp for fair milk prices  MUMBAI: The battle against overcharging by milk retailers has found strong support from common Mumbaikars.  Scores have signed up for a WhatsApp group on the issue and roped in the department of weights and measures as well, leading to a winning partnership. 
The core group is also planning a PIL against milk firms and the distribution network. 
One member is a brand consultant while another is a Diva lawyer who arrives for every meeting in south Mumbai.  Yet another is an ALM member from Goregaon, who says, during this past fortnight, he has turned “from citizen to activist”. 
Even Sanjay Pandey, controller of legal metrology, who is spearheading this initiative against overcharging, is proud of this WhatsApp group.  Its members report unscrupulous vendors, conduct field research and argue articulately before aggressive dealers and dairy owners.  “They strategize, plan, volunteer and arrive for meetings at the cost of their work.  It is heartwarming to see their wholehearted participation,” says Pandey. 
Young Adesh Bhagat arrived all the way from Diva to voice his anger at Saturday’s public meeting called by the department of legal metrology.  “Every retailer who is overcharging has complaints with dairy farms or the government.  None of them has a grievance with the common man.  Why are they then venting their anger on us helpless people?” he said to applause. 
Fifty-year-old computer software entrepreneur Sanjeev Agarwal says he was inspired by the Jaago Grahak Jaago campaign on TV.  “I have been observing the price of petrol and diesel reduce several times over the past year but the cost of milk continues to rise.  And then to have to pay Rs 2 more than MRP is terribly unfair.  How can dairies and retailers justify this?”
Agarwal says milk is already too expensive for a basic commodity.  He says, “As we began to debate on the group, we discovered the MRP includes storage, refrigeration and transportation costs.  Residents of all areas highlighted instances of overcharging.  We also found retailers have genuine grievances because their margins have not improved in years.  The big fish are the dairies who have the bargaining power against farmers and retailers. ”
A WhatsApp member from Bangur Nagar, Goregaon, Abhijit Banerjee, says, “We plan to educate consumers and monitor the overpricing in our area.  We plan to collect in groups in the morning to check the distribution pattern as milk lays on the streets and chances are adulteration starts from here.  We will also inform buyers to pay only MRP and there are no refrigeration or transportation charges. ” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Housing society can end deal with slack builder: Bombay high court  MUMBAI: A housing society can terminate a development agreement with a builder for non-performance, the Bombay high court has said. 
According to Justice RD Dhanuka’s ruling last month, if Jal Ratan Deep Co-operative housing society in Bangur Nagar, Goregaon (West) has lost confidence in Kumar Builders Mumbai Realty, it cannot be forced to continue the contract. 
The court allowed the society to appoint another builder to redevelop its five buildings for 97 members.  “(Since) the buildings are dilapidated, it would be in the interest of justice that before any untoward incident takes place, the petitioner (society) be permitted to take steps to appoint another developer and go ahead with the redevelopment,” said the judge. 
In February 2010, the society passed a resolution at its special general body meeting to appoint a developer.  An agreement was signed with Kumar Builders in January 2011 for redevelopment.  The developer was required to obtain preliminary permissions to start construction within three months from the execution of the agreement, furnish a bank guarantee of Rs 18 crore, indemnity bond and payment of hardship compensation, etc.  The agreement stipulated that the developer complete the project within 29 months. 
When the builder delayed procuring permissions, the society granted an extension of 16 months.  No headway was made when the extension expired in September 2011.  Five months later, the developer told the society he would offer less area to the members in the new building on the pretext that the development control rule had been amended. 
The society told the court that the builder procured the basic building permission (IOD) in March 2013, a full 26 months after the agreement.  “The IOD was defective as it covered only flats for 56 members and not 97 members.  The IOD was in the name of Kumar Urban Development and not in the society’s name,’’ said the petitioner. 
The builder then served a notice on the society, asking its members to vacate their flats by end-December 2013, “completely ignoring the conditions of the development agreement”.  The builder’s representative also told society members about its financial problems, stating it would lose Rs 16 crore if more area was offered in the redeveloped property as promised in the agreement. 
In the general body meeting of November 14, 2014, society members unanimously agreed to invoke a clause in the development agreement to impose liquidated damages of Rs 18.8 crore on the builder.  They also recorded their dissatisfaction and hardship due to the delay. 
Last December, the society issued a notice on the builder, asking it to rectify the breaches within 30 days or risk cancellation of the deal.  The developer filed for arbitration.  The court appointed an arbitrator, and said the society must issue a 15-day notice to the builder if it decides to appoint another developer. 
“A perusal of the record prima-facie indicates the respondent (builder) committed various breaches and gross delay.  Though letter of intent was issued by the society to the builder in May 2010, no steps were taken by the builder to get flats vacated till the agreement was terminated,’’ said the court. 
However, the judge said the builder would be entitled to compensation in case it succeeds in the arbitration proceedings.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  ‘VVIP ward’ in SoBo has the fewest street dogs, Malad the most, RTI query reveals  MUMBAI: Malad, Malwani and Bangur Nagar in P-North ward have the most (7,451) stray dogs, as of March 2015.  The fewest (581) were in the ‘VVIP’ D ward, which includes Malabar Hill, Pedder Road and Kotachiwadi, and is where the chief minister, governor and municipal commissioner reside.  Activists have questioned the Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation’s “preferential treatment” to some localities during its drive to keep the city’s stray canine population in check. 
Activist Chetan Kothari had sought ward-wise details about strays and dog bite cases since 2004, through an RTI query. 
The reply stated that between January 2004 and March 2015, Mumbai recorded 7.5 lakh dog bites and 50 deaths due to rabies.  Since 2004, the most people to have died due to rabies is 13 in 2005.  This year, till March, one person has died. 
P-North ward is closely followed by K-East ward, with 5,540 dogs.  The ward includes Saki Naka, Sahar, Jogeshwari and MIDC. 
South Mumbai, in comparison, has less than half the number strays than those found in the suburbs.  D ward, which has the fewest strays, is followed by C ward, which includes Marine Drive, Kalbadevi and Zaveri Bazar, at 669. 
Indrani Malkani, trustee of the citizens’ group Together VCAN and resident of Little Gibbs Road in D ward, said that there are bins all over the ward.  “It has nothing to do being a VVIP ward, but it’s the concerted efforts of the civic authorities and the residents’ positive involvement. ”
Kothari said another reason for more strays in the suburbs could be large slum pockets.  “Stray dogs eat whatever is available.  Several slum pockets overflow with garbage, which attracts them.  At D ward, there’s regular cleaning, more so because the rich and influential have their homes there. ”
Activist Shyama Kulkarni, an AGNI (Action for good Governance and Networking in India) trustee, said, “I am shocked that there are very few stray dogs in areas such as D ward.  Does it mean they are being picked up? Such a vast difference in numbers is surprising.  There has got to be something beyond sterilization or cleanliness here. ”
Dr Padmaja Keskar, executive health officer, BMC, said they were doing their job in all areas. 
“From our side, we pick up dogs for sterilization and after that they are left in the same area.  As far as the difference in numbers is concerned I would need to check about it,” she said.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  28-year-old biker dies as bus rams him from behind  MUMBAI: A 28-year-old man was killed when a speeding private bus rammed into him on Malad link road on Wednesday night.  The incident happened around 8.45 pm, when the deceased, Rafatullah Shaikh, was driving home to Prem Nagar in Goregaon along the south-bound arm of the link road.  He was hit from behind by the bus at RL Pillai Chowk.  The bus was ferrying employees of a private company from Thane to their homes in the western suburbs. 
“The bus driver, Vimal Kumar Pal, was unable to control his speed and crushed the bike completely,” said investigating officer S Kole of the Bangur Nagar police station. 
The driver panicked and fled from the spot, abandoning his vehicle, following the mishap.  He later surrendered at the Bangur Nagar police station late on Wednesday after consulting the bus owner.  He was arrested.  Shaikh suffered severe internal injuries and he succumbed to them.  The bus passengers, who witnessed the accident, gave statements to the police against Pal.  Police officials said Pal, 22, might have been in a hurry to wrap up work and head home to Ghansoli in Navi Mumbai.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Teen arrested for raping five-year-old  MUMBAI: A five-year-old girl was raped by her 19-year-old neighbour in the Bhagat Singh Nagar slums in Goregaon west on Wednesday.  The accused fled the locality after committing the crime but was tracked down by the Bangur Nagar police and arrested. 
The girl is a Class I student, while her father works as a physiotherapist’s assistant.  The accused, Kishore Mandal, works for a sari printing workshop in Goregaon east.  The police said that a few days ago, Mandal had tried to lure the minor to his room.  When he tried to disrobe her, the victim got scared and fled.  But on Wednesday, he made another attempt and assaulted her, after which he ran away.  When the parents found out, they promptly rushed to the Bangur Nagar police and the girl was taken for a medical examination.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Two women steal Rs 2 lakh valuables of roommate  MUMBAI: Two small-time actors were booked on Tuesday for stealing cash and jewellery to the tune of Rs 2 lakh.  The Bangur Nagar police have registered an FIR for theft. 
The case was registered by a woman with whom the two were sharing a paying-guest accommodation.  At the time of going to press, the police had not made any arrests.  “The complainant and the two suspects had been residing in the same flat for several months.  According to the complainant, the two suspects entered the house in her absence and made away with her cash and valuables,” said senior inspector Santosh Bhandare. 
“The investigations are on.  We will verify details and record statements before taking action,” he added.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Pillion rider steals modelâs smartphone  MUMBAI: A pillion rider snatched model Arshi Khanâs high-end smartphone on Malad Link Road on Sunday.  Khan caught a glimpse one of the men on the bike and has lodged a complaint with the Bangur Nagar police station. 
Khan was travelling in an auto with her publicist around 9.30pm.  âI was anxious as my visa application for travelling to Pakistan had been rejected.  I wanted to go to Malad to send some emails.  When the auto approached a mall, two men on a bike came near us.  The pillion rider snatched my Samsung S6 Edge handset,â Khan told TOI.  The men left before Khan could raise an alarm.  âThe pillion rider turned back to see my reaction.  That is when I saw his face.  I hope the police go through footage captured by CCTV cameras at the junction,â she added.  Khan said that the phone had been sent to her from Oman by an acquaintance.  The Bangur Nagar police have registered a case of theft against two unidentified men.  Scanned documents for her visa application had been stored on her smartphone. 
Khan had hit the headlines earlier due to her ties with a Pakistani cricketer.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Malad resident found brutally murdered in flat  MUMBAI: A 34-year-old man was found brutally murdered in his flat at Evershine Nagar in Malad West on Tuesday night.  The deceased, Ronnie D'Souza, used to work on a rig.  He was alone at home at the time of the incident. 
" Two unknown men barged into D'Souza's apartment and stabbed him repeatedly with a knife.  He sustained seven to eight stab wounds.  He was later pronounced dead by a doctor.  Only a cellphone was stolen from the house.  The motive is not clear yet and we are examining all possibilities,"  a senior police official said. 
D'Souza lived with his mother and sister, who works as a cabin crew member in an airline.  Both of them were away at the time of the incident. 
The Bangur Nagar police have registered a case of murder under section 302 of IPC.  The police have lodged a manhunt for the accused.  D'Souza's body has been sent for an autopsy.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Assailants waiting in Malad flat stab man six-seven times  MUMBAI: Ronald D’Souza, 34, who was home on a break from his job on an offshore rig in West Asia, was murdered by assailants waiting inside his Malad (West) residence on Tuesday evening.  He was stabbed six-seven times with a sharp weapon and robbed of his gold chain and cell phone by two unknown persons.  Ronald’s mother Cecelia, 54, who discovered the body, was questioned for several hours by the Bangur Nagar police.  They will also be questioning a driver who worked for the D’Souzas.  Footage from a CCTV installed in the vicinity of the D’Souza’s society — it did not have CCTVs — has captured the two assailants walking away. Ronald, who was single, was working in Abu Dhabi for five years and used to come to Mumbai every alternate month.  In the city, he stayed with Cecilia and his sister Jenny at a rented flat in Evershine Nagar.  Jenny is a cabin crew member with a leading private airline.  Ronald and Jenny lost their father to an ailment a year ago. On Tuesday, Ronald and Cecelia went to Vasai where they own some property.  On their return to Malad, Ronald stepped out to meet a friend.  Around 8.30pm, he got a call from his mother asking what time he would be home.  She mentioned that she was out for a stroll.  Ronald dropped his friend and reached home around 9pm.  The assailants were waiting inside. “Ronald was stabbed thrice in his chest and thrice on his leg.  There were abrasions on his arm,” said a police official.  The watchman of the society saw the assailants come around 8.30pm and leave an hour later.  “They said they were going to flat 202 (where the D’Souzas lived) and were acquainted with the occupants.  I did not suspect anything amiss,” watchman Laltap Singh said.  At 10.15pm, Cecelia came home.  “Ronald wasn’t answering the door, so Cecelia opened it with her set of keys.  She found him sprawled on the bedroom floor in a pool of blood.  She rushed out and rang my doorbell,” said next door neighbour and their landlord’s daughter-in-law Shilpa Pai.  “I thought Ronald had been assaulted and offered to call the doctor.  But Cecilia told me he had been murdered.  I forbade her from going back into the house and informed my in-laws.  We dialled the cops who arrived in five minutes,” Pai said. Besides charges of robbery and murder, in the FIR the police have also applied section 202 of IPC (intentional omission to give information of offence to police by a person bound to inform).  The watchman of the society has given a description of the attackers to the cops and said he can identify them.  The police have already run some of the family’s acquaintances past him. The D’Souzas own a flat in another society, which is being redeveloped.  They have been Pai’s tenants for the past two years.  “Cecelia was not comfortable living alone when her kids were away on work.  Post-6pm, she would head to her friend’s place to spend the night,” said Pai.  “Ronald was sociable and his friends would visit him frequently whenever he came home,” she added.  Jenny, flying when the killing took place, rushed back on learning of the murder.  Ronald’s funeral will take place on Thursday evening. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Man dies after being knocked down by bike  MUMBAI: A 45-year-old pedestrian was killed after being hit by a motorcycle on the south-bound stretch of Malad Link Road around 9am on Wednesday.  The motorcyclist, Rohit Koli (22), who was also hurt, is in hospital.  The deceased, Ramesh Kanojiya, was crossing the road when he was knocked down.  The police said Koli was speeding and possibly lost control.  Kanojiya suffered grievous head injuries.  Kanojiya and Koli were rushed to Siddharth Hospital in Goregaon (west) where Kanojiya was pronounced dead at the hospital.  His body was sent for an autopsy.  Kanojiya, a shopowner, lived in Malad.  A case of negligence and rash driving has been registered against Koli at Bangur Nagar police station.  He will be arrested once he is discharged from hospital.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  `Malad murder a contract killing, theft not motive'  MUMBAI: The murder of Ronald D'Souza at his apartment in Malad West on Tuesday night was a contract killing, po lice said on Thursday .  At least one person has been detained in this connection. 
“The assailants robbed Ro nald's cellphone and gold cha in.  But we suspect that robbery was not a motive.  The accused had arrived with an intention to kill.  They had the keys to Ro nald's apartment and were ly ing in wait for him,“ said a poli ce official.  “The gold chain and cellphone were robbed only to mislead investigators.  The mo tive behind the killing was a personal grouse,“ the officia added.  The police also suspect that money had changed hands between the assailants and the person who gave a contract on Ronald's life. 
Two teams from the Bangur Nagar police station were sent to locations outside Mumbai to track down the assailants.  The police have been keeping tabs on Ronald's stolen phone num ber.  One of the teams returned to Mumbai late on Thursday , so urces said.  Meanwhile, Ro nald's mother Cecelia was qu estioned for the second conse cutive day at the Bangur Nagar police station.  She was not pre sent at Ronald's funeral at the Our Lady of Lourdes Church in Orlem, Malad, on Thursday evening. 
Ronald's friends told TOI that he was once married bu got separated from his wife three years ago.  The divorce ca se is going on at the family co urt in Bandra.  Ronald's est ranged wife attended his fune ral.  Ronald's sister, Jenny , a ca bin crew member with a leading private airline, was in consolable.  Nearly a hundred well-wishers turned up for the service.  “It has been a double blow for Jenny .  She lost her father six months ago and now she has lost her brother,“ her friend told TOI. 
Ronald last spoke to a fema le friend, who was abroad, on phone around 10.20 pm on Tues day .  CCTV footage from a neigh bouring bungalow shows his car entering his society around 10.30 pm.  The murder took pla ce between 10.30 pm and 11 pm The police have sealed Ronald's bedroom.  Relatives said he was to head back to his job on the rig before Christmas.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Woman held for son’s murder; hunt on for 2 more he Malad police on Friday arrested Cecelia D’souza (54) in connection with the murder of her son Ronald (31), who was stabbed to death in his Malad residence on Tuesday night. 
The police said that Ronald objected to her illicit affair with her former driver leading to the hatching of the murder plot. 
On Tuesday, Cecelia had called the police and told her she had returned home after her evening walk to find Ronald lying in a pool of blood in their second floor residence in Tai Mansion building in Malad. 
Post-mortem examination later revealed that he had been stabbed multiple times in the chest. 
His cell phone and gold chain were missing from the house, and the police had at the time registered a complaint of murder and robbery against unknown persons. 
“We examined Closed Circuit Television (CCTV) footage of cameras outside the building, and saw Cecelia standing outside the building during the time she claimed to have gone for a walk.  This discrepancy first pointed the needle of suspicion at her.  We then conducted some further inquiries, including checking her cell phone location.  We found out about her relationship with Ronald, after which we picked her up for questioning,” said an officer with the Bangur Nagar police. 
According to officials, after sustained questioning Cecelia broke down and confessed to have planned the murder. 
In her confession, she reportedly told the police that she had an affair with a 25-year-old man for over a year and a half.  Her husband had passed away a year ago, after which her paramour started visiting the D’souza residence frequently. 
This angered Ronald and was the cause of frequent fights between mother and son, and Cecelia allegedly decided to find a permanent solution to the problem, the police said. 
“On Tuesday evening, Cecelia stepped out saying she was going for a walk while Ronald was sleeping in the house.  Her paramour, along with a friend of his met her near the building, went to her house and killed Ronald.  We are still piecing together the exact sequence of events,” the officer said. 
Deputy Commissioner of Police Vikram Deshmane, Zone XI added, “Cecelia has been remanded to police custody till December 17.  Efforts are underway to trace and apprehend Cecelia’s paramour and his friend. ”
He was found stabbed to death

column1: Shyamtarai
column2:
Dhamtari villagers grapple with monkey menace After leopards, now even monkeys have began to torment human beings residing in the villages of Sorid, Jalampr, Dani Tola, Batena, and Shanti Colony.  According to the villagers, a band of around 50 to 100 monkeys have entered into the villages hooting, jumping and destroying their crops and households. 
However, as usual, the forest officials have turned a deaf ear to the repeated complaints of the villagers about the monkey menace and asked them to cope up with the animals and wait for the monsoon to arrive so that the monkeys retire to the jungles. 
According to sources, soaring temperature and scarcity of water in the jungles have forced these animals to move into the human habitats.  Even as the pack of monkeys continues to attack the fields and feed on vegetables and fruits, the farmers are left to deal with them in their own ways. 
Rajuram Sahu, a resident of Shyamtarai village said, “Earlier also monkeys used to enter into villages during summer but were not as danger as today. ” The roof tiles of his house have been damaged by these animals, he added. 
Renuka Dewangan of Panchvati colony said that the monkeys have started creating problem for the residents.  They take away the cloths and destroy other eatables kept outside.  Sizeable land parcels given for setting up industrial units The Chhattisgarh Government has released sizeable land parcels in five districts for use by industrial units in the State.  The land banks with Chhattisgarh State Industrial Development Corporation (CSIDC) are available in Raipur at Abhanpur ( 24.406 hectares), in Dhamtari at Shyamtarai ( 8.830 hectares), Janjgir-Champa (Pavna) ( 45.054 hectares) and (Keraakachhar) ( 58.633 hectares), Baloda-Bazar Bhatapara ( Chichpol) ( 37.339 hectares) and North Bastar (Markikhuna) ( 7.070 hectares), officials stated. 
Moreover, while simplifying the land allocation process for setting up industrial units in the State, the Chhattisgarh State Industrial Development Corporation (CSIDC) has facilitated online submissions of the applications through its website and the State government portal, they stated.  Officials stated that applications for allocations of land will be accepted online only.  The applications for allocation of land in industrial areas or outside  will also be accepted through its website and the State portal only. As per the policy of State Government, for making business easy for the people in the State, online application submission has been started.  The system of taking application in all offices of CSIDC has been ended , the officials informed.  The applications submitted in person in the CSIDC office after February 28 will not be processed, they said. 
On January 13, the Chhattisgarh Cabinet endorsed the State’s ‘New Industrial Policy 2014-19’.  The approval to the policy was accorded in a meeting chaired by CM Raman Singh at the Mantralaya.  The CM provided detailed information about the Cabinet decisions.  He said that the policy includes the provision of subsidy worth Rs5 crore for establishing an Industrial Park in the private sector. Provision of establishing ‘land Bank’ over 10,000 hectares for various industries has also been included in the policy, Singh stated.  To promote bicycle manufacturing, pharmaceuticals, electronic products, textile industries etc, these industries will be included as 'Priority' in the new industrial policy.  The prescribed limit for mega project will be reduced for these industries, so that they may get benefits of mega-project on lesser investment, he said. 
Under the new industrial policy, the Chief Minister Cluster Development Scheme will be initiated, under which the State government will provide Rs50 lakh as subsidy. Singh said that on the lines of 'Make in India', the State Government will implement 'Make in Chhattisgarh' policy under which manufacturing units of the related industries will be promoted with priority.  C'garh set to woo smaller investors in IT and Solar Energy The Chhattisgarh Government while looking for big ticket investments in the domain of IT and Solar Energy has also started stressing on the need to invite micro, small and medium scale investors in the two sectors. At the same time, the Government is now also stressing on inviting all sizes of investment in the Agriculture, Forest based products and Food Processing domains. The issue was discussed at length in the State-level review meeting of the Commerce and Industry Department chaired by State Industry Department Secretary Subodh Kumar Singh here on Thursday. 
In the meeting, Singh also asked the general managers of District Industries and Trade Centres to become a partner in the Government’s skill development initiatives for youth in their respective districts. He asked the general managers to remain in constant touch with the Industrial Training Institutes (ITIs) and livelihood colleges in their respective regions. Singh suggested that the general managers must get in touch with owners of local industrial units and know the type of manpower required by them suited to their line of industry and help train the youth accordingly for job creation. 
He also asked officials to take necessary steps for facilitating establishment of rice mills in Kawardha, Bemetara and Rajnandgaon regions. Singh also informed that under the Central Government’s Digital India Campaign, the work of the State Industry Department would be taken online from State to district level. He also told officials to ensure that no land being acquired for the industrial projects is disputed and the region has availability of all basic facilities such as power and water supply. 
Singh said that there will be immediate registration of applicants who would like to establish units in future with the District Industry and Trade Centres in the districts . Recently, Chhattisgarh Government released sizeable land parcels in five districts for use by industrial units in the State. The land banks with Chhattisgarh State Industrial Development Corporation (CSIDC)  are available in Raipur at Abhanpur ( 24.406 hectares), in Dhamtari at Shyamtarai ( 8.830 hectares), Janjgir-Champa (Pavna) ( 45.054 hectares) and (Keraakachhar) ( 58.633 hectares), Baloda-Bazar Bhatapara ( Chichpol) ( 37.339 hectares) and North Bastar (Markikhuna) ( 7.070 hectares), officials stated. 
Moreover, while simplifying the land allocation process for setting up industrial units in the State, the Chhattisgarh State Industrial Development Corporation (CSIDC) has facilitated online submissions of the applications through its website and the State Government portal, they stated. Officials stated that applications for allocations of land will be accepted online only and applications on paper will not be entertained in its office. The applications for allocation of land in industrial areas or outside will be also accepted through its website and the State portal only. 
Earlier, the applications were accepted in CSIDC's office and the after completing the process, land was being allocated. As per the policy of State Government, for making business easy for the people in the State, online application submission has been started.  The system of taking application in all offices of CSIDC has been ended , the officials informed.  Notably on January 13, the Chhattisgarh Cabinet endorsed the State’s ‘New Industrial Policy 2014-19’. 
The approval to the policy was accorded in a meeting chaired by Chief Minister Raman Singh at the Mantralaya.   After the meeting, the Chief Minister provided detailed information about the Cabinet decisions. He said that the policy includes the provision of subsidy worth Rs5 crore for establishing an Industrial Park in the private sector. Provision of establishing ‘land Bank’ over 10,000 hectares for various industries has also been included in the policy, Singh stated. 
Moreover, to promote bicycle manufacturing, pharmaceuticals, electronic products, textile industries etc, these industries will be included as 'Priority' in the new industrial policy.  The prescribed limit for mega project will be reduced for these industries, so that they may get benefits of mega-project on lesser investment, he said. Under the new industrial policy, the Chief Minister Cluster Development Scheme will be initiated, under which the State Government will provide Rs50 lakh as subsidy. Singh said that on the lines of 'Make in India' concept, the State Government will implement 'Make in Chhattisgarh' policy under which manufacturing units of the related industries will be promoted with priority. 
The domiciles of Chhattisgarh will be encouraged to set up their own enterprises and they will also be provided better employment opportunities, he said. Capital investment in the State will be promoted by making industry competitive in comparison to other states. Weaker sections of society such as Scheduled Caste, Scheduled Tribe, Disabled, Retired personnel, women and Naxal-affected families will be given preference under the policy.  The mineral, forest and other resources available in the State will be naturally conserved, Singh said

column1: Sarkara Devi Temple
column2:
Special stoppage for trains The Southern Railway has provided special stoppage at Chirayinkeezhu Station for Train Nos.  16650/16649 Parasuram Express and 16606/16605 Ernad Express, running between Nagercoil and Mangalore Central for one day, on March 23.  The special stoppage is provided in connection with Meena Bharani Festival at Sarkara Devi Temple, said an official release. 
School gets award
Bertrand Russell English Medium High School, Baikampady, has bagged the ‘Best Consumer Club’ award for the year 2014-2015 in the district.  The award was presented by Deputy Commissioner A. B.  Ibrahim here on Sunday during the observation of Consumers’ Day.  A release said the students were instrumental in creating consumer awareness by staging street plays, house visits, seminars, and visits to various government offices.  Besides participating in cultural competitions, the students also enlightened the public about judgments delivered by Consumer Forums.  Geetha, coordinator of the Club got the Best Coordinator award. 
Panels for National Athletics Meet
As many as 19 committees were formed on Monday for the smooth conduct of the National Federation Cup Athletic Championship scheduled between May 1 and May 4 in Mangaluru at a meeting chaired by district in-charge Minister B.  Ramanath Rai.  The committees comprise Mr.  Rai, Karnataka Athletics Association president G.  Parameshwara, Minister for Youth Empowerment and Sports K.  Abhayachandra Jain, Nitte University Chancellor Vinay Hegde, Alva’s Institutions Chairman M.  Mohan Alva, Yenepoya University Vice-Chancellor Abdulla Kunhi, SCDCC Bank president M. N.  Rajendra Kumar, legislators from the district and other eminent persons.

column1: Charaimoria
column2:
Idd-uz-Zuha celebrated with traditional fervour CorrespondentS NORTH LAKHIMPUR, Sept 25 - Along with the other parts of the country Idd-uz-Zuha, the festival of sacrifice of Muslims was celebrated with religious fervour and traditional gaiety.  Special prayers were held in mosques and idgahs for the victims of Haj stampede. 
In North Lakhimpur people could not pray the idd namaaz at the Town Idgah due to wet surface because of overnight rain.  Idd prayers were held in various mosques in North Lakhimpur town, Leelabari, Kadam, Katori Chapori, Bodhakora, Moidomiya, Angarkhowa, Sensowa, Dhakuwakhonia, Bilatiya, Phukanar Haat, Charaimoria, Bogoleejaan, Dejoo, Rampur, Silaneebari, Laluk, Nowboicha, Bihpuria, Harmutty and in Dhakuwakhona. Nagaon: A festive mood prevailed here and people gathered in different idgahs to offer Idd prayers. At Nagaon town Quari Ali Ahmed Foorkani led the special prayer and Hazi Azimuddin explained the significance of the day.  The people gathered prayed for world peace and harmony.  In other idgahs of the town special prayer for Idd-uz-Zuha was held where local people took part.

column1: Mappilaioorani
column2:
Efforts to prevent dengue Efforts launched by the district administration to prevent any outbreak of dengue continued in various parts of the district on Sunday.  Collector M.  Ravikumar along with Health Department officials took stock of preparedness by anti-larval operations at residential localities at Melakaranthai and Mappilaioorani. 
The team led by the Collector reached out to the residents under the Kovilpatti municipality limits and Mappilaioorani panchayat limits and educated them to be health conscious to lead a healthy life, according to a statement. 
Mr.  Ravikumar enquired with residents to know whether anybody suffered from dengue.  He appealed to them to ward off unwanted things such as worn-out tyres and plastic wastes and asked them to be safe and insisted on covering water containers to avoid mosquito breeding. 
The civic body authorities and local body representatives of panchayats had also been instructed to ensure public hygiene.  Kovilpatti Revenue Divisional Officer Kannabiran, Deputy Director of Health Services S.  Uma, officials from District Rural Development Agency and local body representatives also took part in the dengue awareness programme.

column1: Pallithottam
column2:
Renovated Kollam canal now a cesspool More than Rs.13 crore spent on renovating and reviving the Kollam Canal seems to have gone down the drain. 
The renovation work began in 2010 as part of an ambitious project to form part of the 78-km Kollam-Kovalam State Waterway, which has tremendous tourism potential. 
But even after five years, the work on the canal has not shown much progress. 
Except for the fact that about 950 houses on the banks of the canal were cleared and its inhabitants rehabilitated elsewhere under the Tsunami Rehabilitation Project, the canal does not reveal any remote sign of being revived. 
Renovation work
The renovation work had envisaged fencing and beautifying the banks, dredging of the canal from the Ashtamudi Lake to Pallithottam, and erection of side protection works from Ashtamudi Lake to Mundakkal. 
Dredging was carried out with interest but it turned out the work was a way to loot construction grade sand from the canal bed. 
While the people of Kollam city expected the canal to turn beautiful through the revival project, it has now become a health hazard with enormous mass of garbage being dumped into it from various locations. 
With the banks cleared of encroachments, garbage from various locations of the city is now being furiously dumped into the canal. 
The Inland Navigation Department, having jurisdiction over the canal, actively supervised the dredging programme but it now appears to have discarded the canal. 
During the past, the canal had served as one of the main trade channels in the Travancore part of the State. 
Transport
Huge freight houseboats ferrying various types of goods through the canal were a common sight those days. 
In Kollam, the Chamakada course of the canal served as a harbour for unloading the goods brought by these vessels to Kollam. 
It was also used for loading processed cashew from factories for export and other goods sold from the wholesale markets of Kollam. 
Encroachment
With the development of rail and road transport network, the canal became defunct and its banks were encroached upon. 
Dumping ground
Over the years, it became a dumping ground for garbage, hospital and abattoir waste, and even sewage. 
The canal now remains choked, and the much publicised revival project has done nothing to change its state.  Kerosene quota being denied: fish workers Fish workers here are planning to intensify agitation for their subsidised quota of kerosene for fishing vessels. 
This month, they say, they were totally dependent on black market kerosene for their livelihood.  The quantity offered through the quota is 129 litres a month at Rs.15.80 a litre.  But the quota for this month has not been released, forcing them to purchase kerosene from the black market at Rs.80 a litre. 
H.  Basilal, Kollam district president of the CITU-affiliated Matsya Thozhilali Union, said denial of kerosene quota was driving the traditional fishing sector to a crisis.  When the traditional fishing sector got motorised in the early 1980s, the monthly kerosene quota for each vessel was 600 litres.  Later, the quota was slashed to 450 litres, then to 350 litres, and now to 129 litres. 
Mr.  Basilal said the present quota did not meet even one-third of the fish workers’ monthly fuel requirement.  They were forced to depend on black marketeers for the rest.  Black marketeers were operating in all fishing villages.  The Kollam city fishing sector, from Pallithottam to Tangasseri, had 786 traditional crafts eligible for the subsidised quota.  This month’s quota had not been released, he said. 
The fact remained that there was no kerosene quota as such from the Centre for the fishing sector.  The quota they got was kerosene for domestic purpose diverted by the State government to the sector, he said.  Based on a report that almost all houses in the State, including those in the sector, had been electrified, the domestic quota was drastically slashed, he said. 
Quota for this month not yet released
Fish workers dependent on black market One held on charges of peddling drugs One person was arrested by the Chavara police on Wednesday from the defunct Premo Pipe Factory complex for allegedly carrying 150 packets of ganja.  The accused has been identified as Shahnavas alias Thalavan, 33, a resident of Mukkuthodu Lakshamveedu colony in Chavara. 
Sub-Inspector G.  Gopakumar who made the arrested said that Shahnavas, a long-time ganja peddler, was also involved in several motorcycle theft cases.  The packets contained 4 grams to 7 grams of ganja each which he sold for rates ranging from Rs.100 to Rs.200 a packet depending upon the financial capacity of his clients. 
Most of his clients were college students in Karunagapally, Kollam and Chavara areas and also some workers attached to the Neendakara fishing harbour.  The Karunagapally assistant commissioner of police, K. R.  Sivasudhan Pillai, recently got a tip-off about the peddler’s activities and followed it up through the Chavara police. 
Circle Inspector Binu Sreedhar said that 720 grams of ganja were seized from Shanavas at the time of his arrest.  He said that Shanavas was involved in about 40 motorcycle theft cases registered by the Kollam East, Chavara, Karunagapally and Kayamkulam police stations.  He is also an accused in five narcotic cases registered by the Excise Department.  Shanavas was produced before a magistrate court at Chavara and remanded to the district jail here.  Meanwhile, the Kollam West police arrested a 38-year-old man from the Thirumullavaram beach on Wednesday on charges of peddling ganja.  He was identified as Padmachandran alias Pappan, residing at Thirumullavaram.  He was arrested by Sub-Inspector N.  Girish on the basis of a tip-off received by City Police Commissioner P.  Prakash. 
A man was arrested by the Pallithottam police following the seizure of a large quantity of banner tobacco products from him on Wednesday.  Krishna Iyer memorial demanded The Kerala High Court Advocates’ Association has demanded a memorial for Justice V. R.  Krishna Iyer near the High Court premises.  In a resolution, the association urged Mayor Tonny Chammany and district administration to take steps to erect a memorial for the departed legal luminary. 
ICAI founding day
: The Institute of Chartered Accountants of India (ICAI) founding day will be celebrated by the Kollam chapter of the institute on July 1 at the ICAI complex at Pallithottam in the city.  Additional District Magistrate V. R.  Vinod will inaugurate the programme.  A blood donation camp will be held and food will be served to the residents of the Kollam Poor Home as part of the celebrations.  30 reserved divisions in Kollam Corporation Out of the 55 divisions in the Kollam City Corporation, 30 will come under the reserved category for the coming local body elections slated for November. 
Twenty eight of the reserved divisions are for women and the remaining two in the reserved general category. 
From the 28 reserved for women, two, Maruthadi and Vallikeezhu divisions, will be for candidates from the Scheduled Caste communities. 
The two divisions reserved for the Scheduled Communities in the general category are Kadappakada and Manakkad. 
The other 26 divisions reserved for women are Shakthikulangara, Meenathucheri, Kavanad, Thevally, Uliyakovil, Koikkal, Kallumthazham, Mangad, Amman Nada, Pallimukku, Ayathil, Kilikollur, Palathara, Valathungal, Thekkumbhagam, Eravipuram, Thekkevila, Mundakkal, Pattathanam, Cantonment, Udayamarthandapuram, Pallithottam, Port, Kacheri, Kaikulangara and Tangasseri.  Embankments of Arasalar develop breaches Embankments of Arasalar river in Karaikal developed breaches at a couple of places and the Public Works Department authorities swung into action to plug the breach. 
A vast area under ‘samba’ paddy in the district has been remaining submerged in water for the past few days. 
The district administration has set up a round-the-clock cell to monitor any eventuality. 
Accompanied by officials, Collector E.  Vallavan visited Meera Pallithottam, Arasalar, Nallambal eri, Kudumbagaram, Mathalankudi, Nandalaru estuary, Vadamattam, Keezh Nedungadu and other areas.  He said that all departments have been alerted to be ready to meet any emergency.  A special disaster management team comprising 35 personnel has arrived at Karaikal.  People in need of any assistance could contact the cell by dialling 1077 or 222025. 
He said the water level in Nallambal eri was being monitored.

column1: Alembic Ground
column2: Irfan, Munaf ignored for Baroda Ranji team  VADODARA: It seems to be the end of the road for Baroda cricketers Irfan Pathan and Munaf Patel this Ranji season.  The duo has again been left out of Baroda's next Ranji game against Madhya Pradesh that will be played in the city.  Once considered to be the backbone of Baroda team, both Irfan and Munaf failed to impress the Ranji selectors during a practice organized recently at Alembic Ground.  While Irfan played his last one day international (ODI) in 2012, Munaf played his last ODI in 2011.  Irfan has been playing in the Baroda Ranji squad but he has been in and out of the team for last couple of seasons due to injuries.  This season too he and Munaf opted out of the first two Ranji games due to injury.  Irfan did show readiness to play for the next two games but he wasn't picked up.  " Both of them were not up to the mark in the practice game kept for testing their fitness and bowling.  So it was decided to not pick them up for the next Ranji tie.  We have a good pool of youngsters who have been performing well and hence we decided to go for good winning combination instead of star value,"  said a senior BCA official.  " Ambati Rayudu, who is back from his national duty, has been made skipper of the team while Deepak Hooda has been made vice-captain,"  said Baroda Cricket Association (BCA) secretary, Snehal Parikh.  Pacers Murtuja Vahora and Sagar Mangalorkar have been dropped from the squad for want of performance while two youngsters, Rishi Arothe and Atit Sheth have been picked up for their good show in the junior cricket.  Baroda will miss services of all-rounder Hardik Pandya who is away for playing Board President XI matches. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

column1: Ammasa Colony
column2:
Pregnant woman dies of H1N1 in Puducherry  VILLUPURAM: A pregnant woman from Villupuram in Tamil Nadu died of H1N1 on Friday at the Jawaharlal Institute of Postgraduate Medical Education and Research in Puducherry, taking the number of flu-related deaths in Tamil Nadu and Puducherry to 11 this year. 
M Gowri, 36, who approached the gynecology out-patient ward in Jipmer complaining of breathlessness, was referred to the H1N1 isolation ward for treatment on February 18.  She tested positive for H1N1 on Friday and died later in the day, said Jipmer medical superintendent J Balachander.  This is the second H1N1 death in Jipmer. 
Balachander said a real time PCR test to confirm H1N1 infection takes 24 hours.  “We get samples from different hospitals and patients approach Jipmer for treatment.  With one or two incidents of death, we cannot conclude at this stage that H1N1 cases are on the rise.  Largely, the incidence is more during winter.  As the temperature rises, the number of cases will come down,” he said. 
13 people, including doctor test positive of virus
One more person from Puducherry tested positive for H1N1 on Friday.  I Umavathi, 52, from Nainarmandapam in the town limits, who was admitted to Jipmer, after she complained of throat pain, rashes and fever. 
A two-year-old girl M Thejesri from Pillaithottam was admitted to Jipmer on February 16 with fever and frequent bouts of coughing.  Her throat swab, which was sent for medical examination, returned positive on Friday. 
So far 13 people, including a doctor from Jipmer and his wife, tested positive for H1N1 this year in the Union territory.  One patient D Gomathi, 31 from Manamedu in Bahour in the outskirts of the town died on February 8. 
Ten patients, who recovered after undergoing treatment at Jipmer, were discharged.  Two patients were undergoing treatment at Jipmer, said deputy director (public health) of the directorate of health and family welfare services T Kumaravel. 
In Puducherry H1N1 cases have been reported in Vidhuthalai Nagar in Mudhaliarpet, Solai Nagar in Muthialpet, Jipmer quarters and Indira Nagar in Gorimedu, SMV Puram in Villianur, Nainarmandapam, Pillaithottam, Thattanchavady, Annai Teresa Nagar and Veema Nagar and Ammasa Colony in Karaikal. 
Health officials said the directorate sends medical teams to localities, where positive cases were reported, to administer Tamiflu to family members and neighbours, who might have come into contact with them as a precautionary measure to prevent spread of the respiratory disease in the territory. 
Jipmer which has the required laboratory facilities to test H1N1 cases has established an isolation ward to treat patients.  Puducherry government too has set up an isolation ward at the TB Sanatorium.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

column1: Navamukunda Temple
column2:
Thousands offer Bali Tharpan : Thousands of people performed Bali Tharpan in the Bharatapuzha at Navamukunda Temple, Tirunavaya, on Friday seeking moksha or redemption for their ancestors.  Tirunavaya Devaswom authorities said that over 50,000 people made the offering at the temple ghat. 
People from different parts of the State gathered at Tirunavaya from Thursday evening.  The Bali Tharpan began at 2.30 a. m.  and continued till afternoon.   Elaborate arrangements were made for the Bali Tharpan.  Sixteen priests arranged by the Devaswom led the rituals. 
Several boats were made available and precautions were taken to prevent accidents.  Life guards were posted at the ghat. 
Tirunavaya is one of the most prominent places for Bali Tharpan in the State. 
The presence of the temples of Vishnu, Brahma and Shiva on the banks of the Bharatapuzha adds significance to Tirunavaya, making it known as Kashi of South India. 
In Kalpetta
Our Staff Reporter writes from Kalpetta:
Thousands of people offered ‘bali’ to propitiate their forefathers on the occasion of ‘Karkkidaka vavu' on Friday in the district.  There was a heavy rush of devotees at the Mahavishnu Temple, Thirunelly and the Sree Rama Temple, Ponkuzhy on the Kerala-Karnataka border from the early hours of the morning. 
Nearly 18,000 devotees paid ‘Pithrutharpanam’ at the Papanashini River, where the Sre Maha Vishnu Temple at Thirunelly.  The district administration had arranged facilities for the devotees from Thursday night. 
Special arrangements had been made on the banks of the Papanashini River for the bali rituals. 
The rituals started at 2 a. m.  Temple Chief Priest I. N.  Krishnan Namboothiri performed special Poojas in the temple. 
Thousands thronged the banks of the Nugu River for offering ‘bali,’where facilities were arranged by the Sree Rama Temple authorities at Ponkuzhy, near Muthanga on the Kerala –Karnataka order.  Thousands take part in Bali Tharpan Braving intermittent rain, large number of faithful streamed into the famed Trikkannad Siva temple near Bekal to perform ‘Pithrutharpanam’ ritual to cherish the memories of the departed souls of their close family members on ‘Karkkidaka Vavu’ on Friday. 
The Bali Tharpan held on the Amavasi or no-moon day of the Malayalam month of Karkidakam has been considered auspicious.  It is believed that the Bali, a ritual performed by the relatives of the dead, will bring redemption for the souls of the dead. 
The famed Trikkannad Triambakeshwara temple, witnessed a surge of humanity who converged from early morning and performed the rituals in specially erected pandal on the beach till late in the afternoon.  They lined up to receive pooja items from the temple counter as the ritual began by 6 a. m. 
A sizeable number of them were girls and women, who took part in the ritual supervised by priests before symbolically making the offerings by taking dip in the sea under the close watch of Coastguard personnel. 
In Malappuram
Our Staff Reporter writes from Malappuram:
Thousands of people performed Bali Tharpan in the Bharatapuzha at Navamukunda Temple, Tirunavaya, on Friday seeking moksha or redemption for their ancestors.  Tirunavaya Devaswom authorities said that over 50,000 people made the offering at the temple ghat. 
People from different parts of the State gathered at Tirunavaya from Thursday evening.  The Bali Tharpan began at 2.30 a. m.  and continued till afternoon.   Elaborate arrangements were made for the Bali Tharpan.  Sixteen priests arranged by the Devaswom led the rituals.

Tirunavaya is one of the most prominent places for Bali Tharpan in the State. 
The presence of the temples of Vishnu, Brahma and Shiva on the banks of the Bharatapuzha adds significance to Tirunavaya, making it known as Kashi of South India.
