The rituals started at 2 a. m.  Temple Chief Priest I. N.  Krishnan Namboothiri performed special Poojas in the temple. 
Thousands thronged the banks of the Nugu River for offering ‘bali,’where facilities were arranged by the Sree Rama Temple authorities at Ponkuzhy, near Muthanga on the Kerala –Karnataka order.  Minister asks organisations to donate land to the landless Revenue Minister Adoor Prakash has called upon voluntary organisations and institutions to donate a part of their land for the landless people in the State. 
“Many institutions and organisations in the State have much unused land, and I have no qualms in asking that land for the landless people,” Mr.  Prakash said, while giving away land deeds to 130 families in Edavanna panchayat. 
The Minister said 1,40,693 landless families in the State were given land by the United Democratic Front (UDF) government in the last four years.  “This government hopes to give land for at least 2 lakh families before it completes its term,” he said. 
The 5.2-acre land bought by Edavanna Panchayat was distributed to 130 poor families.  Seven families of the Laksham Veedu Colony at Pannippara were also given title deeds. 
Panchayat president V.  Sherly said the owners would not have the right to sell the land, and they ought to return the land to the panchayat if they were not building a house there.  P. K.  Basheer, MLA, presided.  M. I.  Shanavas, MP, declared ISO 9001-2008 certification for the panchayat.  District Collector T.  Bhaskaran inaugurated online e-payment system. 
The Revenue Minister said all villages in the State would be made smart soon.  Minister for Power Aryadan Mohammed inaugurated Amarambalam as the first smart village in the district.  The Revenue Minister presided. 
P. V.  Abdul Wahab, MP, was the chief guest.  He said he would provide enough fund for air conditioning of Amarambalam smart village. 
At a different function, the Revenue Minister inaugurated the renovated Balitharpan Ghat at Thirunavaya Navamukunda Temple.

column1: Ansupa lake
column2:
Wildlife Week: Save biodiversity, save world As per legal definition, wildlife includes any animal specified in Schedules I -IV and found in the wild.  This is clarified in Wildlife Protection Act 1972.  Almost all the animals of Indian soil are included in this definition.  Practically, there is no Vermin in the nature which becomes a nuisance. From October 2 to 8 every calendar year is observed the Wildlife Week in India.  It begins with the birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi. 
Similarly October 4 is observed as World Animal Day to create awareness on preservation and conservation of animals.  So every individual should take the responsibility of protecting the wild animals.  Gandhi himself had told that every human being should be compassionate towards the animals. 
There are 15 geographical divisions where different races of animals, birds, amphibians, reptiles, rodents, carnivores, herbivores, omnivores and insectivores etc.  are found due to variable habitats and  habits.  (1) Tropical wet evergreen.  The plant and animal diversifications here are very rich.  (2) Tropical semi evergreen forest, where the crop composition is evergreen to semi evergreen in nature.  The diversification of animal and plant is as good as tropical wet evergreen forest.  (3) Tropical moist deciduous (Sal) forest.  Sal itself is a semi- evergreen plant and its associate plants are also deciduous and semi deciduous.  The soil profile is also very rich. 
Similarly, the biodiversity of the region is also equally rich like wet evergreen, and semi evergreen forests.  (4) Tropical moist deciduous forests with or without Sal trees.  The deciduous trees mean the trees that remain leafless for conservation of moisture in the plant bodies.  (5) Tropical dry deciduas forests.  In such forests the trees are completely deciduous and the soil is dry.  So the ground flora is not as rich as other four categories of forests.  (6) Tropical dry evergreen forests.  Such types of forests are found in semi hilly areas where the soil is not so rich as compared to other five types of forests.   Such types of forest are definitely better than dry deciduous forests and the plant and animal compositions are better than dry deciduous forest.  (7) Sub- tropical wet forests. 
The type of forest is a better habitat of plants and animals.  The forests are also found in Odisha.  (8) Sub- tropical dry forests.  The crop and animal composition are not rich like other types of forests.  (9) Tropical thorn forests.  (10) Sub – tropical pine forests.  (11) Wet temperate forests.  (12) Moist temperate forest.  (13) Dry temperate forests.  (14) Alpine forests.  Alpine forests are not found in Odisha.  So the wild lives of these bio- climatic zones are quite different than tropical zones.  The temperate and alpine zones have poorer bio- diversities compared to the tropical zone.  (15) The tidal forests of river mouths are extremely rich in biodiversities.  The river mouth forests or the tidal eco- systems are seen only in tropical lands.  So the most richly diversified ecosystems in respect of plants and animals are seen in tidal eco- systems. 
Other than 15 distinctive biological systems, there are coastal and peninsular eco systems.  As Odisha is a State of rivers, streams and ocean, they influence the climate of Odisha.  So the peninsular cum riverine ecological systems are prominent in the State.  Especially, different kinds of mammals of herbivores and carnivores are noticed in the regions. 
There are a large number of plant and animal communities in the ocean itself and also in the trans– zones of land and ocean.  These are mostly polluted and decayed due to pollution of river systems in Odisha.  A large part of plants and animals are noticed within the shallow parts of the sea than the deep sea.  Sadly, all the oceans in the globe are becoming mega garbage bins of human beings.  So the flora and fauna including the avifauna are under threat. 
The main peninsular wetlands of Odisha include Chilika lagoon, Bhitarkanika, Hadagarh, lakhari valley, Ansupa lake, Satkoshia, Chandaka – Damapada.  Among the peninsular hubs, the Chillika lagoon and the Ansupa lake are major eco- diversified spots.  These areas are very eco- sensitive which need preventive, protective and conservative measures under the principle of sustainable development. 
The large scale cultivation of prawn within the lagoon lands of Chillika is a threat to its very existence, which should be restrained very soon.  The Environment Protection Act 1986 and the Biological Diversity Act 2002 should be enforced strictly as curative measures in case of Chillika and Ansupa.  The Ansupa lake is shrinking very fast due to siltation and grabbing of lands for cultivations. 
The original shape of the lake is much reduced for improper management of the lake by the authorities.  So the sustainability of the lake is at stake. Indiscriminate waste disposal by the residents, industries and civic agencies have become a cause of concern for sustainable maintenance of river systems. 
All the Hindu festivals generally fall during winter months of the year.  The winter months are also the period of harvesting of different agricultural crops.  This is also the period of breading season of different birds, animals, amphibians and reptiles.  The idols of gods and goddess are immersed in the water bodies as a custom which pollute the water systems and water sources and pose a threat to the their ecosystems. 
(The writer is a former senior forest officer and an environmentalist.  Tel no 9937460649)

column1: Canoly Canal
column2:
New schemes to boost growth prospects : The comprehensive master plan for Kozhikode urban area is expected to give an impetus to the felt-needs such as transportation and the tourism sector. 
Besides, the adjoining grama panchayats of Olavanna, Feroke , Kadalundi and Ramanattukara, which have been added to Kozhikode city, will get more recognition with their rapid urbanisation.  Recently the State government decided to de-link the erstwhile Cheruvannur- Nallalam, Beypore and Elathur grama panchayats, which had been merged with the Corporation before the 2010 polls, to form three separate municipalities.  Even though the de-linking of the three sectors has become a political debate and now legally fought in the High Court of Kerala, the evolving urban characteristics of Cheruvannur-Nallalam, Beypore and Elathur remains unquestionable.  Further, the government has also decided to upgrade Feroke to a municipality. 
Thus the master plan, which has been approved by the joint planning committee, is now being sent to the Chief Town Planner for approval.  It has been prepared with a focus on the growth prospects of the city in the next 20 years, said K. V.  Abdul Malik, Regional Town Planner. 
The master plan has proposed to convert the existing market at Palayam into an indoor complex and develop a commercial complex at Valiyangadi (Big Bazaar) and establish an international convention centre on the premises of Kerala Soaps Ltd.  Another is rehabilitating the colonies at Nadakkavu, Kalluthankkadavu and EMS Stadium.  Focus has also been given to develop the large swathe of marshy lands lying in between Malapparamba-Paroppady and Kannadikkal into a fresh water lake.  The historic Sweet Meat (S. M. ) Street, Tali, Kuttichira, Thiruvannur, Bilathikulam, Thamarakkulam and Mananchira will be transformed into heritage centres.  The master plan also wanted the commercial S. M.  Street, Customs Road, Palayam- Tali and Moideen Palli Road free of vehicles.  A heritage walk has been planned between Varakkal temple to Canoly Canal.  An eco-tourism village at Kadalundi, waterfront tourism at Elathur, water cruise through Canoli Canal and creation of waterway network in the city are new schemes.  Another proposal is inland water transport for passengers and freight traffic from Elathur to Kadalundi using Elathur-Kallayi and Beypore-Kallayi canals and a connection to the mobility hub at Malaparamba. 
Model fishing villages have been envisaged at Mukhadhar, Puthiyappa and Chaliyam.  Other proposals are a swimming pool at Eranikkal, night shelter near Railway Station Link Road and a dry dock on the Beypore port premises.  Invasive weeds block flow of water in Canoly canal : With the delay in undertaking a government-funded cleaning drive, infectious weeds, including the swiftly multiplying African Moss, have begun to stall water flow in the city’s old Canoly Canal.  Around 5-km stretch of the canal on the Elathur side is now fully covered with African moss, where the flow of the water has almost stopped. 
Residents living close to the canal say the decayed waste dumped in various points of the canal have started emanating foul smell, which will increase in the days to come with the delay in undertaking a cleaning drive.  The flow of water from the Korappuzha estuary to the canal is declining day by day, which will worsen with the strengthening of the summer season, they point out. 
Residents allege that the funds so far spent for the cause are yet to show a visible growth though there has been a series of development programmes for Canoly canal to make it an attractive waterway.  As per official records, the district administration spent around Rs.7.5 crore between 1997 to 2010 on various schemes to de-silt the canal, but, the area still remains contaminated with degradable and non-degradable waste.  Though cleaning work costing Rs.  2.42 crore was carried out very recently, it also proved futile with the swiftly growing weeds inside the 11.4 km canal. 
Sajith Kumar, a resident of Elathur, points out that the canal is now nowhere in the radar of the much glorified development proposals.  Construction of paved footpath, seating arrangement along canal banks and gardens were some of the declared projects, but, nothing has been done so far.  He also points out that the canal, which was used as a popular inland waterway till 1950s, is hardly suitable for such a purpose now with the poor maintenance and apathy to carry out development projects in a time-bound manner.

column1: Hatibagan
column2:
Hawkers use rain excuse to grab more space  KOLKATA: With less than a month to go for Chaitra Sale, hawkers at Gariahat are extending their footprint on the pavements â in the garb of reinforcing the stall against rain â to woo more customers. 
Dismantling the existing bamboo structures and plastic sheets that âhave become weak and frayed with exposure to elementsâ, stall owners have pooled in resources to rebuild the stalls.  In doing so, most of them have grabbed a few extra feet, encroaching further on the already depleted pavements. 
âEach stall has paid Rs 500 for the reinforcement ahead of the rains.  While monsoon is some time away, unseasonal showers in March-April can wreak havoc as we take loans to stock up for brisk sales during the Bengali New Year.  Goods will get damaged if they get wet.  That can be devastating for stall-owners,â said Pratima Das, a hawker. 
Her fortified stall now encroaches on a buildingâs entrance, a small inconvenience that offices and businesses located in it must bear for âgreater goodâ, she explained. 
While this line of stalls has occupied half the pavement, up from the one-third compromise formula that heavyweight hawker union leader Shaktiman Ghosh had drawn up some years ago to allow room for pedestrians, the shades occupy more than three-fourth of the pavementâs width. 
Ghosh admitted that a large section of hawkers was flouting rules.  âWe donât support encroachment of pavements and want hawkers to coexist with citizens,â he said. 
Towards the Gariahat intersection, the entire skyline is covered by plastic sheets.  These stalls have not extended their wares but set up stools for customers to settle and check out saris and dresses. 
Biplab Chakraborty, who has also reinforced his stall, admitted that the plastic cover obscures the pavement from the road, block shop hoardings and are both an eyesore and a safety hazard. 
âWe are aware that if there is a fire, entire Gariahat will be up in flames due to the sea of plastic sheets.  But we have no option since the government has not done anything constructive,â said Chakraborty. 
He had a solution to offer.  âKMC can tie up with firms and set up semi-permanent steel structures on the footpath, a couple of feet away from the kerb so that those pedestrians who want to avoid hawkers can walk without impediment.  Towards the pavement, the stall can occupy five-seven feet while the fiber glass shade can extend a couple of feet more.  The rear of the stall can be used as an advertising board facing the road to garner revenue,â he suggested. 
Ghosh, the leader of the Hawker Sangram Committee, said the proposal was worth pondering over and even trying out on a pilot basis in congested belts like Gariahat and Hatibagan.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  ‘Telebhajawala’ proves too hot for TMC heavyweight  KOLKATA: It was a prestige fight between an eye specialist and a ‘telebhajawala’.  As counting came to a close on Tuesday evening, the verdict was out.  The 'telebhajawala' had beaten the doctor by a handsome margin of 1,633 votes in ward 17. 
Another twist, an interest one, in the story is that both have close ties with Trinamool Congress.  While Mohun Gupta, who owns a 'telebhaja' shop in Hatibagan area, defected from Trinamool recently and fought as an independent candidate, his competitor Partha Pratim Hazari was a mayor-in-council member. 
Now that Gupta is happy that he has been able to prove a point, he now wishes to go back to his family business, manning the counter of Lakshi Narayan Shaw & Brothers, his ‘telebhaja’ shop.  The shop was started by Gupta's father Lakshi Narayan Shaw 96 years ago.  It was he who started distributing free snacks to people on Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose’s birthday on January 23 every year since Netaji was one of the most valued customers of the shop during the Raj era. 
Shaw passed on the business to Mohun and his elder brother Kisto Kumar Gupta in 2000.  Unlike Kisto, Mohun was nurturing a dream of becoming a leader and concentrated on social work in areas of Bidhan Sarani, Grey Street, Chittaranjan Avenue and Beadon Street.  His work soon caught attention of Mamata Banerjee and Mohun alias Mana was taken in Trinamool Congress as a worker in north Kolkata.  Mana rose to prominence when his service to the people of ward 17 was recognized by Sashi Panja, a former MMiC and now a state minister. 
However, the rise brought with it intra-party rivalry with Hazari becoming the most vocal critic.  The political ‘enemity’ took an ugly turn when Hazari reportedly ensured that Mana was not granted a ticket for the KMC elections this time.  Mana decided to fight the civic polls as an independent, banking on his social works. 
According to Ratan Jain, Gupta’s campaign manager, Mana could win the polls as he was firmly grounded as a social worker and stood by the needs of the people.  Nirangshu Pal, son of legendary footballer Gosto Pal, said Mana was ahead of Hazari as a human being who takes his social work seriously.  “Mana may not be as qualified as Hazari.  But then he is sincere and committed to the cause of common people,” Pal said. 
Mana himself felt that now the war was won, he would go back to his party of choice.  “I was always mentally associated with Trinamool Congress.  Now if my party asks me to go back to its fold, I won’t think twice,” Gupta said.  Once termed as a ‘rebel’ Trinamool Congress leader, Gupta said his fight was with an individual and not with the party.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  KMC to offer free pathology tests  KOLKATA: Come October, citizens will have the option to get pathological tests done for free. 
All that they have to do is visit one of the malaria clinics run by the health department of Kolkata Municipal Corporation and get examined by a medical official there.  The medical officer will recommend the tests and the patients can give their blood for analysis there.  The samples will be sent to a dengue detection centre for the pathological exams but the patients can collect the reports from the malaria clinic. 
The free tests include serum cholesterol, serum creatinine, serum bilirubin, SGPT and some routine tests such as stool and urine.  The pathological tests will be done at five of the civic dengue detection centres that the KMC health department has decided to upgrade for such examinations. 
Funds had been sanctioned for the upgrade of five dengue centres into full-fledged labs, confirmed Atin Ghosh, member, mayor-in-council, who oversees the KMC health department.  âOur lab technicians at the dengue centres analyze blood samples for malaria and dengue.  For the new facility, these technicians from five of those centres have been trained to carry out the other tests offered by the health department,â Ghosh said on Saturday.  The five centres where the tests will be done are at Hatibagan, Haji Mohammed Mohsin square, Chetla, Layalka and Behala.  Ghosh said based on citizensâ response, the civic body would open more such labs in the next two years.  âInitially, we are introducing the facility based on the staff strength at five dengue detection labs.  We need to open more such labs once people start taking these tests,â he said, adding a drive was on to recruit more doctors to fill vacancies in some of the malaria clinics. 
The KMC also plans to introduce blood tests for diabetes.  âWe want to extend this crucial facility to citizens.  We have trained our doctors.  Diabetes expert T K Mukherjee, who is also an advisor to the KMC health department, may contribute to make the project a success,â a KMC health official said. 
Patients can give their blood for testing at a malaria clinic and the samples will be sent to one of the 5 dengue detection centres.  The tests include bilirubin, cholesterol, creatinine, SGPT and routine ones like stool and urine Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Kolkata: Woman loses hand, glare on cop delay  KOLKATA: The right hand of a 36-year-old woman was severed as she fell off a bus while alighting at a wrong spot and the vehicle, racing with another one, ran over her hand on Wednesday.  The doctors at Calcutta Medical College could have conducted a reattachment surgery and stitched the hand back, but the police—apparently unable to find the right person with whom they could have left the severed limb at the hospital—took it back with them and sent it to the morgue on Central Avenue.  Now, Sita Rauth has lost her right hand forever. 
The incident took place on Wednesday when Sita Rauth boarded the bus (route 240) at Hatibagan to reach a beauty salon office on Vivekananda Road where she works.  Around 11.50am, the bus stopped at a red signal at the Kailash Bose Street crossing and Rauth reportedly made to alight from the vehicle, even though it was not a designated bus stop.  The signal suddenly turned green, and with another bus on the same route following it, the driver started the bus with a jolt.  As Rauth stumbled down, the bus ran over her right hand, severing it, the police said.  The bus was not only racing with another one but also rushing to avoid an SUCI rally approaching the route. 
Raut lay on the road, writhing in pain for a while, before personnel from the Girish Park police station could reach the spot.  While the police transported Raut to Calcutta Medical College, they reportedly got stuck in the SUCI rally.  The police finally managed to get Raut to the hospital at 12.30pm. 
Immediately, doctors at the emergency started working on minimizing the profuse bleeding and trauma management, the only way they could have saved Raut.  Around 3.30pm, when Raut’s condition was finally stabilized and she could be taken to the operation theatre for the reattachment surgery, the doctors reportedly could not find the severed hand.  According to a source, no one was even sure if the police had at all picked up the severed hand from the road.  But the police claimed they brought it to the hospital in a plastic packet and shown it to doctors.  When they apparently did not get any response from doctors if the limb could be reattached, they took it back with them to the police station.  When the police finally located the limb to the morgue, a lot of time had been lost. 
“We looked everywhere for the detached limb.  We went to the emergency, to the orthopaedic ward and even to the police outpost near the emergency ward to check if the limb had been left somewhere, but found it nowhere.  The police should have submitted it to us, when they brought the patient in.  With today’s advanced technology, we can reattach severed limbs if we attend to the patient within six hours of an accident.  Now it’s too late,” said Dr Shekhar Chowdhury, attending Raut. 
Doctors subsequently conducted a micro-vascular surgery without the limb to curb further damage to the tissues, and Raut was wheeled out of the operation theater by 5.45pm.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Realty booms, so do syndicates  KOLKATA: A suburban civic body that barely existed 20 years ago, now boasts of apartment towers sprouting as concrete weeds, more than 20 markets, a sprawling mall at its doorsteps, five multinational fast food outlets and upscale showrooms selling from fragrances to fast cars. 
But amidst the blinding brightness of the swank outlets and highrises, there exists a dark and assertive suburban underbelly waiting restlessly to cash in on the rapid urbanisation threatening an urban-subaltern clash. 
Welcome to R…Gopalpur.  No, this is not a sequel to Shahid Kapoor and Sonakshi Sinha starrer R…Rajkumar, but the Rajarhat Gopalpur civic body has gained the moniker among the local politicians and administration for convenience. 
Situated around 15 kilometres from the city, Rajarhat Gopalpur is also known as the hot hub of syndicate and land mafia.  It triggered curiosity after its merger with Salt Lake to form the Salt Lake Municipal Corporation that will vote on October 3. 
“These elements which are associated with syndicates and land mafia will get a free run.  The goons associated with Trinamool will take over the entire area,” said former CPM MLA Robin Mondal who withdrew his candidature a few days ago.  He was coincidently blamed for heading the syndicates during the erstwhile Left regime. 
With a population of almost 4.25 lakh in its 30 wards, Rajarhat Gopalpur is bigger than Salt Lake.  It includes vast swathes of Baguiati, VIP Road, Chinar Park, Rajarhat Main Road and Tegharia. 
Though the municipality has been a Left fief since its inception, TMC wields the clout here.  Dampy Mondal, a candidate, is considered to be a vital associate of New Town MLA Sabyasachi Dutta. 
Land prices skyrocketed in this area in the late 90s when Hidco started acquiring land to build a township on the eastern fringes of Kolkata.  Unlike Salt Lake where the land is leasehold, the plots in Rajarhat Gopalpur are freehold which makes it far easier and profitable for the land mafia.  “These people have now exhausted their money and are eyeing to cash in on the impending urbanisation in the area,” said a former councillor of the municipality who is re-contesting. 
There was a flush of cash in the area when many people utilised the opportunity and sold off their land for high prices. 
A cross section of people TOI spoke to came up with various ideas of cashing in on the urbanisation with the potential of scaring anybody planning to move in one of the swank apartments being build here.  “There will be a huge demand for auto-rickshaws and cycle rickshaws.  We can swamp the area with them,” said Shahnawaz Biswas, who is associated with a “cooperative” that supplies construction materials to a residential project in the area. 
A sizeable population that makes up the municipality consists of two types of people.  One that moved in here from rented accommodations in the city and the other section is that moved in from far flung areas of North 24-Parganas and Nadia to stay closer to Kolkata where they work.  There is yet a third section that is waiting to pounce on the “plethora of opportunities” that is a bigger threat.  Tapan mondal, a TMC supporter, is planning to supply private security guards and domestic help in the households. 
“This also indicates a trend of the subaltern trying to occupy space with the urban and trying to play catch up.  The fear is that instead of eliminating the socio economical contrast this may give rise to conflicts within the two sections,” said a political scientist. 
Many people are planning to block the roads for traffic and turn them into a bazar in the morning and put up food stalls in the evening.  “See the beautiful arrangement in Hatibagan and Gariahat.  We will replicate it here,” said Ananda Dali, who is currently employed and devoting his time to campaign for a Trinamool candidate. 
The inconsistency in the nature of landholding in Salt Lake and the parts of the corporation is another dichotomy.  In Rajarhat Gopalpur, the owner of a piece of land can sell off their land without paying any mandatory fees to the government as the land is freehold but in Salt Lake the owners of a plot has to pay Rs 5 lakhs to the government if they want to their leasehold right. 
The political parties are already feeling the pressure of not ensuring employment opportunities in the state.  Young supporters are flocking to the ruling party as it is in power but they want their pound of flesh in return.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Civic body caught in land grab row  JIAGANJ: The construction work for a community toilet in Jiaganj-Ajimganj municipality has run into troubled waters with allegations of land grab.  The Left Front-run municipality’s chairman Shankar Mondal, who is supervising the work, has reportedly allowed a breach in the Hatibagan post office boundary wall to lay the pipeline. 
On Monday, Mondal was seen on the post office premises with labourers to supervise work on connecting the new septic tank with the toilet.  Mondal said, “We have set up six community toilets.  The postmaster has given verbal permission for this. ”
Residents protested against the unethical use of post office land without taking due permissions.  Postmaster Dibyendu Bhattachrya said, “I am helpless as the chairman is influential.  I could not protest as Mondal himself was present at the spot. 
I have told my seniors about it, and will submit a written complaint to the superintendent of posts, Behrampore division, on Tuesday. ” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Parking plight for disabled devotees  KOLKATA: Almost all leading organizers have made provisions for ramps, wheelchairs and a separate entrance, but with parking restricted around most big pujas, pandal-hopping could turn out be an ordeal for the physically challenged. 
“All big pujas have volunteers to escort the challenged people inside.  But parking restrictions could pose a problem.  They obviously can’t reach out to those who will be forced to get off their vehicles a kilometer away.  This negates the purpose of having facilities inside pandals.  But we must a find an alternative,” said Partho Ghosh, vice-president of the Forum for Durgotsav — an umbrella organization of around 200 puja committees. 
“Ever since the ‘best facilities for challenged people’ award was started, things changed for the better.  Pandals started having ramps, separate entrances and wheelchairs.  Those that couldn’t create a separate entry, threw open their VIP gates.  But there is little that can be done about parking restrictions.  Sadly, despite having adequate facilities, pujas will be out of bounds for the challenged,” said Debajyoti Roy, secretary of Non-discrimination, Integration and Participation (NIP), an NGO. 
Ekdalia Evergreen, one of the most prominent pujas in south Kolkata, is likely to be hit by parking restrictions.  Though parking is allowed at a little distance from the pandal, there isn’t enough space.  “We can’t interfere with parking arrangements since it is entirely up to police to decide.  But it shouldn’t be too difficult for the physically challenged to make it to our pandal on less crowded days,” said Gautam Mukhopadhyay of the puja committee. 
Big pujas in the north could be even worse.  Pandals at Hatibagan have been allotted parking space at Ahiritola, 1.5km away.  Visitors at the College Square pandal have to park at Subodh Mullick Square, 1 km away.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

column1: Periyakkatupalayam
column2:
Flood recedes, but their pain lingers Even though floodwater has receded, many families are yet to recover from the extensive damage to their properties by rains and flash floods in Cuddalore district.  Most of the affected persons in Periyakkatupalayam are Dalits comprising 98 families from Arunthathiyar and Adi Dravidar castes.  The villagers mainly depend on the earning from working at cashew groves. 
Periyakkatupalayam is one of the worst-hit villages in the district.  The gushing water of Periyakkattupalayam Odai uprooted the lives of Dalits who have been living here for years together.  All of them have taken shelter in a nearby village. 
Amirtham(80) whose grandsons and daughter altogether eight members of her family were washed by flood and even a couple of relatives who came on a visit lost their lives. 
“I was living in the same place and never seen such floods in my life time.  Now I am in temporary shelter now and don’t know what will happen next,” Amirtham said. 
V. Rasu (40), who is resident of the same place recalled ordeal the villagers undergone on November 9.  He said, “Had the flash flood entered into the village in the night, it would have taken all our lives.  Somehow, we managed to move from here by joining hands together. ”
Some of the villagers are now coming down to their houses and attempting to revive normal lives with whatever they gathered from the ruins. 
Anbalagi (35) said, “After staying in the temporary shelter, we came today to our homes only to find that fans, grinders and other electrical are damaged. 
Some of the clothing materials dumped in soil and retrieved them.  We cleaned the soiled utensils and tried to use them for cooking in the temporary shelter. ”
Too crowded
Some of the villagers who were sheltered in temporary camps at Nadukattupalayam have been complaining that the makeshift shelter is too crowded. 
R. Palani (53) said, “Immediately after the incident, we moved to government school and later moved to another school at Kadampuliyur.  Just five days ago, we were sheltered here at Nadukattupalayam.  The shelter is overcrowded and three or four families were given shelter in an enclosure. ”
The villagers urged the government to expedite the work to identify new site where new houses can be constructed expeditiously. 
The farmers of Kalkunam village alleged that the bund of Sengal Odai which breached only after the public sector undertaking Neyveli Lignite Corporation pumped its surplus water.  Chandrasekar (64) of Kalkunam alleged that only because of the surplus water discharged into the Sengal Odai,the breach occurred in the bund and brought water inside the agricultural fields. 
Paddy lost
“Soil deposits accumulated about a feet above the paddy field and all my seven acres of paddy lost,” he bemoaned. 
However, an official of NLC rubbished these charges.  The official said on November 9, none of the NLC pumps were working and all of them were submerged in the water.  There was no power at all.  “How could we pump the water into the canal where there was no power?” he countered.  Tamil Nadu floods: When their lives were hanging by a branch Broken branches of their cashew tree saved the lives of K.  Balakrishnan and his wife Kalyani when the flood engulfed their village in Tamil Nadu’s Cuddalore district. 
Shivers went down their spines, when water gushed into their thatched hut at Periyakattupalayam, rising menacingly by the minute. 
Periyakkatupalayam was one of the worst-hit villages in the district.  Most of the affected persons were Dalits. 
“The speed and volume of water flow was threatening and it soon began filling the hut.  When we tried to get out, we saw the entire neighbourhood was rapidly getting flooded,” said Balakrishnan, recounting the horror. 
He said the only option for them was to climb the loft. 
“The loft became very shaky.  Hence, my wife and I climbed a litter higher and clung on to the central supporting bamboo of the hut and placed our legs over another bamboo,” he told PTI. 
“Soon, the front legs (bamboos) of the hut caved and we began seriously doubting our chances of survival.  Luckily, when the hut began shaking vigorously, some bamboo poles got stuck in the fallen branches of our broken cashew tree,” he said, lending a prop to the hut and preventing it from falling and being swept away by the violent current. 
As the water level kept increasing, the terrified couple removed patches of the thatched roof and, craned their necks out and waited for help.  “In that position we kept crying for help for seven hours,” he recalled. 
The couple was rescued after Balakrishnan’s nephew and another relative spotted them.  “The broken branches of our cashew tree made all the difference between life and death. 
Without them, we would have been dead,” he said. 
D.  Samydurai, another resident of the village, said the next day people came to know that ten people had been swept away by the violent currents.  Bodies were found stuck in branches of trees and floating on turgid waters. 
A small-time sound service entrepreneur, Samydurai lost Rs.  45,000 worth of equipment including speakers and amplifiers. 
Samydurai said water from the overflowing mines of the Neyveli Lignite Corporation made things worse. 
Today, the Dalit colony of Periakattupalayam has been reduced to a ghost town with most residents moving to a relief camp nearby.  While most huts have been washed away, tiled and partly concrete tenements are badly damaged. 
Samydurai alleged bias in awarding compensation to those whose houses were destroyed. 
“A landlord gets the same compensation for the loss of a dwelling unit just like a landless labourer,” he said.

column1: Palam Vihar
column2:
Townships hit by outages, discom blames builder  GURGAON: Around 40,000 residents of townships built by Ansal API are facing daily power shortage despite having paid the builder for setting up the necessary infrastructure.  Residents of Sushant Lok, Valley View Estate, API Orchid and Palam Vihar said they have been facing long outages every day, with a 12-hour power cut on December 14 last year among the worst.  They feel they are being made scapegoats in the builder's tussle with the discom, DHBVN. 
According to RTI findings by A L Baveja, a resident of A Block in Sushant Lok, DHBVN has been writing in vain to the developer, asking it to provide land for the requisite substations. 
Letters from DHBVN to Ansal API (copies of which are with TOI) show the inadequacy in the internal infrastructure, as well as establishment of 66kV and 220kV substations, have been conveyed to API a number of times, without any serious steps taken by the builder. 
According to records provided by DHBVN to Baveja, the load capacity in these townships is only one-third to one-fourth of the total demand in most cases.  For instance, the demand at Valley View Estate in Gwalpahari is 7,000 kVA, but the capacity sanctioned by the developer is only 2,000 kVA.  At Sushant Lok, while demand is 6,000 kVA, capacity is only 1,110 kVA.  Baveja's findings, including a notice sent to the builder by the discom, last year reads, " Inadequacy in internal infrastructure, when compared to the original sanctioned load, comes out to 1,75,353 kVA.  It comes out to 1,30,838 kVA when compared to the infrastructure you have developed so far.  In addition to making up for inadequacy in internal infrastructure, your total load as per norms warrants construction of at least two 66 kV substations and one 220 kV substation to cater to the electricity needs of the areas developed. " 
The discom claimed the developer had gone ahead with the sale of plots/flats for occupation without making adequate provisions for supply of electricity for them, even though it is duty-bound under licence conditions and the sanctioned electrification plan, to build the substations and external allied power distribution network. 
Vinod Punia, DHBVN executive engineer, from whose office the notices were sent to the builder, said, " We have served them notices time and again, yet they have not complied with the norms.  This is not an isolated case as there are many such builders who have not fulfilled power infrastructure needs, all of whom have also been served notices. "  When contacted, officials at Ansal API declined to comment.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  HUDA’s main water pipeline sees 11th leak in 12 months  GURGAON: Leakages were spotted in Haryana Urban Development Authority’s (HUDA) master water supply line yet again near the Basai flyover and in Sector 10 on Wednesday.  In the last 12 months alone, the pipeline has burst 10 times at different places. 
Officials said once HUDA schedules a shutdown of water supply to carry out repairs, at least two-dozen areas of the city will get affected.  However, even before repairs begin, HUDA officials said high-tension DHBVN lines passing right above the master pipeline in the area will first have to be shifted, which will take almost a week.  According to construction rules, no construction or digging activity is allowed directly under or close to high-tension wires. 
The leakages in the line were noticed by MCG officials on Wednesday after residents of Basai village complained of water seeping out of the ground on the adjacent road, a 100 m ahead of the Basai flyover.  HUDA’s sub-divisional officer Vijender Malik said there are two leaks on the 4 km-long master supply line that originates from the Basai water treatment plant and leads up to Hero Honda Chowk. 
“These lines, laid over 25 years ago, have rusted.  It has even affected the thickness of the mild steel pipes, which have corroded from 8mm to about 6mm.  The complication in the repair work is the HT line passing right above the pipeline needs to be shifted at the earliest,” Malik said. 
He explained that apart from corrosion, the pipeline has taken a beating due to constant expansion and contraction from seasonal temperature changes over the years.  “We have conveyed to the DHBVN superintending engineer that the high tension lines need to be shifted at the earliest for a suitable pipeline repair schedule to be decided upon.  The repairs involve welding of valves and collars at both leakage points and would take between 24 and 36 hours,” said Malik. 
HUDA executive engineer V K Sheokand told TOI the pipeline can be used to release water for a couple of more days without tending to the leakage.  However, even slight pressure variations can cause the pipeline to burst.  “The pipeline leads up to the Sector 16 boosting station, from where it branches to various parts of the city,” he said. 
Areas in and around Sushant Lok 1 and 2, DLF 1-4, Cybercity, Cyber Hub, sectors 14-18, 21-23, 23A, 31, 32, 40, Sheetla Colony, Signature Tower, South City-1, Jharsa, Palam Vihar, Sirhaul, Dundahera and Golf Course Road will be affected during repairs. 
The DHBVN superintending engineer was, however, unavailable for comment on when the high tension lines would be shifted to facilitate the pipeline repairs.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Gurgaon fears huge power bills after late meter reading  GURGAON: Residents of Palam Vihar have alleged that their power meter readings were taken a week late for billing, which could result in exorbitant electricity bills for many consumers in the area as there is a flat tariff of Rs 7.25 per unit if the monthly consumption crosses 800 units. 
According to the president of Palam Vihar’s RWA, Sunil Yadav, nearly 10,000 residents in the colony usually receive their electricity bills by 16th of every two succeeding months.  However, bills for the last cycle are yet to be dispatched by power discom Dakshin Haryana Bijli Vitran Nigam (DHBVN). 
“The meter readings were taken more than a week after the usual schedule, which may result in extra units being charged than what should be and will result in higher bills.  There will be cases where even if a consumer uses even unit above 800 units, they will be charged at a flat rate of Rs 7.25 per unit and they will lose the benefit of slab rates,” he told TOI. 
Some residents have even alleged that when they took up the matter with the discom’s sub-divisional officer, Sattar Khan, he told them that “it is his right to bill them however he wants” and refused to explain the delay in the delivery of electricity bills. 
Though the SDO was unavailable for comment, DHBVN’s general manager Sanjeev Chopra said, “I am aware of the bills getting delayed this month.  We are changing the way we are carrying out meter readings and billing.  From this month, readings of all consumers connected via the same feeder will be taken in one group.  This may cause a delay of about a week in this month’s billing cycle, but will be normal from the next cycle. ”
Chopra said that “this measure is being taken to keep a check on the total power input and output at every feeder” in order to keep an account of transmission losses and check the same each month.  “For the consumers, who get charged over 800 units a month, their cases may be considered for correction,” he added.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Power infra must in colonies for completion certificates  GURGAON: Following several complaints by city residents, the department of town and country planning (DTCP) has decided not to issue completion certificates to builders unless electrical infrastructure is installed in their colonies. 
In an order, issued on Wednesday, DTCP director general Anurag Rastogi has asked all officials that no builders are to be issued completion certificates unless they comply with the clause of the license regarding installation of electrical infrastructure in their colonies. 
The order also says that if any builder fails to take electrical connection from the Haryana Vidyut Prasaran Nigam (HVPN), then the DTCP will recover the cost of the same from the builder and deposit it with HVPN so as to ensure power supply to residents. 
" However, the installation of internal electricity distribution infrastructure as per peak load requirement of the colony shall remain the responsibility of the colonizer, for which the colonizer's electrical services plan and estimates need to be approved by DHBVN before obtaining completion certificates,"  reads the order. 
Rastogi said, " The said condition is neither being complied with by any colonizer nor is the same being enforced at the time of grant of completion certificate.  It is therefore directed that before passing any such case, the compliance of the said clause in its letter and spirit may be ensured. " 
Gurgaon is home to a number of such colonies built by private developers, who despite charging residents all relevant costs are denying them the right to power connections.  Various colonies, including Mayfield Garden, Sushant Lok, Palam Vihar, are still suffering due to inadequate electrical infrastructure. 
When contacted, the director of town planning in Gurgaon, Sanjay Kumar, said, " We will definitely ensure that all completion certificates are issued only after the said clause has been satisfied by the builder" . 
He, however, refused to comment on what action would be taken against builders who have already been issued completion certificates, though they have not yet provided residents with power infrastructure.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Pipe repairs to hit water supply for two days  GURGAON: Repair work on the master pipeline from Basai water treatment plant will hit water supply in the city for two days, starting January 27, HUDA officials said on Saturday. 
According to the officials, water supply will be suspended for around 85% of the city.  " Since it is a big line, repairs will take time and the water supply will remain suspended for two days, that is on January 27 and 28,"  said HUDA administrator Anita Yadav. 
Yadav said the pipeline damage had caused leakage of lakhs of litres of water over the past few days.  She added that residents must store water and use it judiciously to ensure they do not face shortage for two days. 
This is the second time that HUDA is carrying out repair work on the master pipeline in three months.  The authority had repaired the water line in three places in November.  However, despite the repairs, the pipeline continues to give a harrowing time to residents.  In the last 12 months, the pipeline has burst 11 times. 
A senior HUDA official said that the lines are over two decades old and has rusted, which leads to cracks at some places.  Apart from the corrosion, the pipeline has taken a beating due to constant expansion and contraction from seasonal temperature changes over the years. 
Areas in and around Sushant Lok 1 and 2, DLF 1-4, Cybercity, Cyber Hub, sectors 14-18, 21-23, 23A, 31, 32, 40, Sheetla Colony, Signature Tower, South City I, Jharsa, Palam Vihar, Sirhaul, Dundahera and Golf Course Road are likely to be more affected during repairs.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  'Carterpuri' after 1 day of fame, forgotten for 36 years  GURGAON: Whenever an American president jets in (and there have been seven such visits), residents of one village not too far from Delhi might be forgiven for thinking what the fuss is all about. 
Once there was a place called Daulatpur Nasirabad.  Many years ago, a dignitary came calling, from a far-off land, a man so important that his visit was marked by the rechristening of the village.  The year was 1978, that dignitary was then US President Jimmy Carter, and Daulatpur Nasirabad became 'Carterpuri'.  Though for how long Carter remains part of Haryana's soil is up in the air, for there is talk of going back to the earlier name. 
Not that the move had any salutary effect on the village's fortunes, or improved the lives of the villagers.  Carterpuri is today as nondescript a hamlet as any in north India, one of those urban villages that are neither here nor there, its present squeezed between a humdrum past and an uncertain future.  And like many similarly-sized settlements in the plains, it has been crowded out by a city that has grown unmanageably big, hemmed in by Sector 23 on one side and Palam Vihar on the other. 
Here, small hoardings battle for space with overhead wires.  There's a faint odour of sewage in the air, and muddy tracks lead to nowhere in particular.  Nowhere is where Carterpuri has headed since that red-letter-day 36 years back.  " Nothing has changed here,"  says a group of women.  " There is still no road here, nor any sewer. " 
An old man, now 85 years old, says a lucky few might have benefited in the wake of Carter's tour (he had come, it is said, because he wanted to visit the area where his mother was stationed, as a nurse, during World War II), but apart from receiving a TV set, little else came out of the visit.  " Life hasn't changed in Carterpuri,"  said a shop-owner.  " It's pretty much the same as it was when he came. " 
So while among older folk, there might still be some residual fondness for the time when the most powerful man on earth dropped in on their lives, there's no nostalgia.  Even they resignedly - almost cynically - admit that Carter's stopover did nothing for what once was (and may be again) Daulatpur Nasirabad. 
A change of name might possibly bring about a change in luck, and that's exactly what is being mooted (though it's difficult to get the official position on this).  As is the way with such things in India, renaming seems to have ended up being a political gimmick, a symbolic gesture made to the gallery.  The change has been cosmetic.  Live goes on as usual.  Like it has, and will likely do, for the 10,000 inhabitants of Carterpuri.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Man gets life term for killing lover's husband  GURGAON: Accused of murdering the husband of his paramour, a youth was handed down a life sentence by the court of district judge Harnam Singh Thakur on Friday. 
Badri, aka Pappu of Damoh, Madhya Pradesh, was arrested last year for smashing the head of Rajender Kumar with a stone on May 7.  He intended to marry Rajender's wife, Priyanka, which motivated the murder, the court observed.  Badri and Rajender were labourers and used to stay in the same locality in Palam Vihar. 
The court convicted Badri on the basis of circumstantial evidence, such as the voter ID of the deceased that was recovered from the possession of the accused, a few days after the body was found.  On the insistence of the accused, police also recovered the murder weapon - a large stone - that was lying hidden in the bushes of Sector 22, where the crime took place. 
In a statement to the court, Priyanka said, " Badri took my husband out on the night of May 7, 2014, on the pretext of helping him find a job as a driver.  But a few hours later, he returned alone and told me my husband is lying unconscious somewhere and would have to be fetched in a rickshaw, for which he demanded Rs 100 and left. " 
Badri never returned.  The following day Rajender's body was recovered by the police from the Sector 22 green belt. 
Public prosecutor Anurag Hooda said, " Though there was no eyewitness, the onus of proving innocence lay with the accused, because circumstantial evidence clearly indicated his involvement.  The deceased's wife had also claimed he was the one who took Rajender out alone, after which the husband never returned. "  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Oldest substations to be relieved of load  GURGAON: Two of the city's oldest and most overloaded substations - at Mehrauli and Sector 23 - will soon get a breather as the Haryana Vidyut Prasaran Nigam (HPVN) is all set to bifurcate the load to other nearby substations. 
" The load on the Mehrauli substation will be shifted to the Sector 9 substation by April and we are currently working on upgrading the infrastructure.  The load on the Sector 23 substation will be bifurcated to 66KV substations in sectors 4 and 20,"  said Gulshan Nagpal, HPVN's superintendent engineer. 
" This will ensure that there are no breakdowns like in the past.  Our system will be ready to take the load of the peak summer months of May, June and July,"  he added. 
The Mehrauli road substation supplies electricity to sectors 2, 4, 6, 7, 8, 9 and Railway road, and the Sector 23 substation supplies power to sectors 23,22,23A, 21, Dundahera, Dharam Colony, Choma village and Palam Vihar. 
Last year, the Mehrauli substation had caught fire twice, once in May and later in August and the residents were left to suffer for over 10 hours without electricity as temperatures soared near 45 degrees and the discom and authorities blamed each other.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  MCG moves to tackle stray animals, monkey menace  GURGAON: The municipal commissioner has lodged complaints against 22 pig owners to curb the growing menace of stray animals on the streets, which has long been a bother for residents.  The civic agency has also tied up with Friendicoes, an animal welfare organization, to manage stray dogs and has written to the wildlife conservator of the forest department to control monkeys in residential areas.  According to the joint commissioner (HQ) of MCG, Y S Gupta, the corporation has been receiving complaints about stray animals for months from residents.  These animals, not only worsen sanitation but also bite residents.  " We had conducted a survey last month and identified about 22 pig owners in the city that were warned time and again to remove the animals from MCG areas, but they didn't.  We have written to the police departments to file FIRs against them,"  Gupta said.  The corporation has asked the Sadar Bazar police station to book four persons, 9 people at Sector 5 police station, 3 persons at city police station and one person each at Sector 29, Kherki Dhaula, New Colony, Civil Lines, Palam Vihar and Badshahpur police stations.  While the wild life conservator of the forest department has agreed to assist in catching monkeysin areas like Sector 23 and Palam Vihar, Gupta said, " We will forward the stray dog complaints to Friendicoes.  They will sterilize the dogs once a month and give them anti-rabies shots for which we will pay them Rs 545 a dog. " Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  No revenue stamps at city post offices  GURGAON: Residents are finding it difficult to get hold of revenue stamps following the Haryana government's decision to not have them sold at post offices.  The government says it discontinued sale of revenue stamps at post offices because the postal department charges a 10% commission on every revenue stamp sold.  So, while elsewhere in the country one can buy revenue stamps from any post office, in Gurgaon one has to go all the way to the mini secretariat to buy the Re 1 stamp.  Residents say that in order to buy a Re 1 stamp they have to shell out much more money just to reach the mini secretariat.  " It is mandated by law to affix a revenue stamp for every cash transaction that is over Rs 5,000.  There are about 36 post offices in Gurgaon but none of them sell revenue stamp which causes lot of inconvenience to the general public as they have to travel a long distance to get the stamp,"  said Aseem Takyar, who filed a Right To Information application on the issue.  He said the issue could be resolved if the state government wanted to.  " All it needs to do is agree to pay the commission sought by the postal department like every other state in the country that has agreed to do so,"  Takyar said.  " I filed the RTI in the postal department in Delhi and they in turn forwarded it to several postal offices in the country.  Recently, I received over 500 replies from different post offices and all of them maintained that they received 10% commission from their respective state government for every revenue stamp sold,"  he said.  Takyar said the Haryana government's response said that it stopped selling revenue stamps at post offices in the state from 2007 because the department charges 10% commission.  " This is something which these two government departments should sort out so that the common man is spared the harassment,"  he pointed out.  Other residents too demanded that this issue be resolved.  " I went to the post office in Uydog Vihar the other day to get a revenue stamp but was curtly asked to go to the court complex in the mini secretariat to get it,"  said Kavita Sharma, a Palam Vihar resident. RWA accuses 3 residents of stealing Rs 5 crore  GURGAON: Three residents of Park View Residency in Palam Vihar have been booked for allegedly cheating the society’s welfare association out of Rs 5 crore on the pretext of carrying out maintenance work. 
According to the police, the complaint was filed by S C Kumar, president of the RWA who claimed that three residents had taken Rs 8 crore 27 lakh for maintenance work in flats.  But they did not start the work for several months and evaded questions from the RWA.  At the association’s insistence, they returned Rs 2.90 crores.  The RWA president then lodged a complaint with the economic offense wing .

As it turned out, the killer wanted to bump off his wife over a domestic dispute, but ended up destroying seven families living there. 
The incident took place in Shad Nagar, Palam Vihar.  Anil Kumar (52), a truck driver, has been arrested.  His family stayed on the ground floor.  Kumar had moved out himself since the quarrel.  Firefighters said 12 people were rescued.  Three fire tenders controlled the blaze in an hour. 
Fire department officials said the fire broke out at Ahlawat Apartments around 3am.  Ironically, it was Kumar’s daughter Simran who first noticed the blaze.  She ran to the first floor and alerted two families living there.  She saved three lives, including an elderly woman’s, before helping her mother, Mamata, out of the building.  But her grandmother Kailash Rani got left behind. 
One of the residents, an Air Force officer, A N Verma, said he managed to jump onto the balcony of an adjacent house.  “My son helped me.  We then raised an alarm to alert others,” he said. 
But second floor resident Jagdeep Kumar (32) was not so lucky.  He took his one-year-old son, Aksh, and tried to go down the stairs.  Both were asphyxiated.  His wife, Indu (30), looked for him but fell unconscious.  She has been admitted to LNJP Hospital with 80% burns.  Indu, an engineer, worked in Bangalore but moved here a year ago to be near her parents. 
“A team under the supervision of ACP (Dabri) M Harsha Vardhan was formed,” DCP southwest Suman Goyal said.  CCTV footage from a neighbouring building showed Kumar starting the fire. Roadways to discontinue 10 city bus routes  GURGAON: Haryana Roadways has decided to discontinue 10 routes of its city bus service out of a total of 24 routes, in wake of poor response from commuters on those routes. 
A senior official based out of the city bus depot said those routes that were incurring losses and failed to draw commuters’ response will be phased out.  According to sources, the buses that will be relieved from these routes are likely to be deployed on remaining routes, so that they do not lie unutilized. 
The director general of Haryana Roadways, Chander Prakash, has also queried city bus depot officials on the poor response of passengers to these routes.  “There is no point running buses on loss-making routes,” said Trilok Chand, general manager of city depot of Haryana Roadways, Gurgaon. 
The routes that are being discontinued include Dronacharya Metro station to bus stand via Sector 21; HUDA City Centre to Behrampur; HUDA City Centre to Manesar; HUDA City Centre to Palam Vihar and city bus stand to railway station. 
These buses are likely to be put in use on routes such as Gurgaon to Kendriya Vihar, Gurgaon to Basai, Gurgaon to Palam Vihar and Gurgaon to Manesar. Inderjit to Venkaiah: Old city needs Metro link  GURGAON: Gurgaon MP and Union minister of state for defence Rao Inderjit Singh wrote to his senior colleague and urban development minister Venkaiah Naidu and Haryana chief minister Manohar Lal Khattar asking for a review of the proposed Metro route from IFFCO Chowk to Dwarka Sector 21. 
Singh in his letter said the planned route, which passes through Palam Vihar, leaves out large section of old Gurgaon.  “I have suggested that the extended Metro rail route should be via Subhash Chowk on Sohna Road, Hero Honda Chowk, sectors 33, 34, 37 (which is a major industrial hub), Sector 10A, ESI Hospital, Sector 4/5 (covering railway station) and Sector 23,” he said. 
Singh wrote that more than half of Gurgaon’s population resides in the old city yet most of the development projects, including the Metro network built by Delhi Metro Rail Service (DMRC) and Rapid Metro, have only been set up to cater to the residents of new city.  “Most of the modern facilities are extended only to residents of new Gurgaon areas whereas the thickly populated old Gurgaon remains deprived,” said Singh. 
The MP said various RWAs had requested him for a revision in the route.  He said the route suggested by him would not only benefit residents of the old city but also thousands of people from Badshapur, Pataudi and Farrukhnagar, who commute to Delhi everyday for work.  It covers major industrial areas, railway station and most of the government approved residential colonies of the old city. 
The 12km IFFCO Chowk-Dwarka Sector 21 Metro line, which could reduce the travel time between Gurgaon and Delhi to 30 minutes, was first proposed in 2011 as a high-speed link but has been plagued by delays ever since.  Several project reports have were prepared, but those couldn’t settle the differences between Haryana government and the DMRC. 
Last month, DMRC gave Haryana three options for extending the Metro line.  The options for the corridor are extending the existing corridors—the Airport Metro or the Blue line (Dwarka Sector-21 to Noida City Center)—or building a new corridor from Dwarka to IFFCO Chowk. Boy who shot classmate 'kills' again  GURGAON: In a case of history repeating itself, the 14-year-old boy, who had made national headlines in 2007 for shooting his classmate dead in the city's Euro International School, has been booked now at the age of 21 along with his friend for shooting another friend dead in the Sector 21 market on Wednesday night. 
According to police, around 9pm on Wednesday, the accused, Aakash alias Ashu, came in a car with his friend Manish Goga, from Dundahera village, and the two shot at their friend, 23-year-old Manish, who was eating momos at a stall in the market.  They then fled the spot in their car. 
Manish, who is himself a history-sheeter, was rushed to Columbia Asia hospital by his friend Ahmad Sher but he was declared brought dead.  Manish, who is from Muzaffarpur in Bihar, was a friend of the two accused.  Based on the statement of Ahmad Sher, the Palam Vihar police lodged an FIR against Aakash and Manish Goga under sections 302, 120b and 34 of IPC and the Arms Act.  No arrests have yet been made. 
According to police, Manish was a criminal who has been booked in cases of murder, attempt to murder and theft.  He was recently released after serving a jail term for attempt to murder a lawyer in Kapashera. 
Preliminary investigation revealed that Aakash was the same Class 8 boy who in 2007 had not only smuggled his father's friend's gun into Euro International School in Sector 45 but along with a classmate, Vikas, shot another classmate, Abhishek Tyagi.  They had shot Tyagi after a tiff with him some days before the crime. 
A year in the correction home does not seem to have had any impact on the accused.  Azad Singh, father of Aakash, was also accused of conspiracy in that case, but he told TOI that he was acquitted by the court. 
" My son runs his own factory in Basai now and he could not be involved in this murder,"  Azad Singh told TOI. 
On December 11, 2007, Aakash and Vikas, who had some dispute with Tyagi, reportedly fired five bullets at Tyagi from close range following a fight in Euro International School.  Tyagi, who was hit by four of the bullets, including one in the temple and two on his chest from close range, died on the way to hospital. 
Aakash and Vikas were sent to a juvenile home while the father of Aakash and his friend, Raj Singh Dalal, were also booked.  The revolver used in the crime belonged to Dalal.  The case in the session court is only against Aakash as all other accused have been acquitted. 
Meanwhile, Ravinder Tyagi, resident of Sector 14 and father of the 2007 victim, Abhishek Tyagi, has demanded additional security in the wake of the latest killing by the person accused of having killed his son.  Ravinder Tyagi was given security by police in 2007 on his plea that he felt threatened following the killing of his son.  " I have sought additional police security,"  he told TOI. Dwarka e-way oustees to get plots in Sector 110A  GURGAON: The Dwarka expressway project crossed a major hurdle on Wednesday after the Punjab and Haryana high court resolved the dispute over allotment of plots to New Palam Vihar families by directing Huda to allot plots in Sector 110A instead of Sector 37C. 37 ‘intruders’ ‘intercepted’ in Operation Hamla Thirty-seven ‘intruders’ were identified and nabbed on Wednesday during Operation Hamla, an anti-terrorism security drill under way across the coastal districts in Tamil Nadu, according to Additional Director General of Police, Coastal Security Group, C.  Sylendra Babu. 
The bids at ‘infiltration’ were foiled in Chennai, Nagapattinam, Mandapam and Tuticorin. 
Dummy bombs were seized at six locations.  In Tuticorin district, 10 ‘intruders,’ including five at sea, were intercepted. 
For the first time, 500 fishermen joined the CSG in ‘identification’ and ‘interception’ of ‘intruders’ in this mock exercise, Dr.  Babu told The Hindu . 
Apart from a fleet of 24 fast interceptor boats of the Tamil Nadu Coastal Security Group, 15 fishing boats were involved in Operation Hamla.  With the support of fishermen, whom he called ‘eyes and ears’ of vigil, dummy explosives were seized in Nagapattinam. 
The 48-hour exercise, which commenced at 6 a. m.  on Wednesday, involves active participation of 5,000 personnel, including officers of coordinating security agencies like Indian Navy, Indian Coast Guard, Coastal Security Group, Central Industrial Security Force, police force from 13 coastal districts, Chennai City police and Customs and Fisheries departments. 
With four-tier security blanket, surveillance was increased at sea, shore line and also at territorial level across the State, Dr.  Babu, the operation coordinator, said. 
As part of the two-day Operation Hamla, the district police began mock combing operations in the coastal areas of Kanyakumari district. 
Vigil has been mounted in the coastal areas from Arockiyapuram to Neerodi. 
Hundreds of police personnel were pressed into service with a view to creating awareness among people of the need to be vigilant over suspicious movement of any persons in their locality. 
The CSG undertook patrolling at sea from Chinnamuttom fishing harbour, apart from taking up shore patrolling on motorcycles in Colachel, Manavalakurichi and Neerodi. 
Additional personnel were posted at Colachel and Chinna Muttom check posts, police sources said.  Fishermen seek ban on fishing near coast A group of representatives from coastal hamlets in the district submitted a petition to Collector M.  Karunakaran on Tuesday seeking a ban on fishing by mechanised boats from Chinna Muttom fishing harbour in areas close to their villages. 
In the petition, the representatives said fishermen from nine coastal hamlets of the district, with their fibreglass boats and catamarans, were still following the traditional fishing practices while the mechanised boats operating from the neighbouring Chinna Muttom fishing harbour near Kanyakumari were practising trawling methods that seriously affect marine wealth. 
When the mechanised boats, in a bid to have better catch, had their operations close to the coast, it often lead to the destruction of traditional fishermen’s fibreglass boats, catamarans and their fishnets and subsequent clashes. 
Even though several rounds of talks were held with the mechanised boat fishermen, no amiable solution had been arrived at yet. 
Hence, the Collector should ban fishing operations by mechanised boats in areas close to the coast.  The mechanised boats should leave the Chinna Muttom harbour by 7 a. m.  and return to base before 10 p. m. 
To ensure this, a chain should be tied across the entry-exit point of Chinna Muttom harbour.  They should not be allowed to practise ‘stay fishing’ that would allow them to stay in the deep sea up to one week, they said. 
The damage caused by mechanised boats to the fibreglass boats, catamarans and fishnets should be adequately compensated. 
Above all, the uncontrolled and illegal use of high power engines up to 450 HP in the mechanised boats should be banned and officials attached to the Department of Fisheries should conduct frequent checks, the petitioners also said. 
Fishermen from Koottapuli, Perumanal, Thomaiyarpuram, Idinthakarai, Uvari and Koottappanai met the Collector and submitted the petition. 
Representatives from coastal hamlets in Tirunelveli district submitted a petition to Collector
M.  Karunakaran Fishermen for ban on fishing near coast A group of representatives from coastal hamlets in the district have submitted a petition to Collector M.  Karunakaran seeking a ban on fishing by mechanised boats from Chinna Muttom fishing harbour in areas close to their villages.

To ensure this, a chain should be tied across the entry-exit point of Chinna Muttom harbour.  They should not be allowed to practise ‘stay fishing’ that would allow them to stay in the deep sea up to one week, they said. 
The damage caused by mechanised boats to the fibreglass boats, catamarans and fishnets should be adequately compensated. 
Above all, the uncontrolled and illegal use of high power engines up to 450 HP in the mechanised boats should be banned and officials attached to the Department of Fisheries should conduct frequent checks, the petitioners also said. 
Fishermen from Koottapuli, Perumanal, Thomaiyarpuram, Idinthakarai, Uvari and Koottappanai met the Collector and submitted the petition. 
Representatives from coastal hamlets in Tirunelveli district submit petition to Collector Case against two fishermen Kanyakumari police have registered a case against two fishermen of Chinna Muttom on a charge of threatening Assistant Director of Fisheries Subramanian.  According to the police, I.  Silvestre (52) and another unnamed fisherman had violated the department’s order to adhere to fishing timings at Chinna Muttom Fishing Harbour on June 30.  Though the officials used winch rope to prevent fishermen from entering the sea for fishing after 9 p. m. , the two had allegedly damaged the rope and prevented Mr.  Subramanian from discharging his duty around 9.30 p. m.  Based on a complaint filed by the official, Kanyakumari police have registered a case.  Further investigations are on.  Invasion of mechanised boats rocks fishermen grievance day meet The first-ever fishermen grievance day meet was held at Radhapuram in the district on Friday, in which a good number people from coastal hamlets aired their grievances and sought effective solutions for perennial problems. 
The foremost issue that rocked the meet was the invasion of mechanised boats from Chinna Muttom fishing harbour which carry out fishing operations close to the coast, often triggering mid-sea clashes among fishermen. 
Fishermen from Koottapuli said that the district administration should take firm measures to stop indiscriminate fishing in the region close to the coast at odd hours by the mechanised boats operating from nearby Chinna Muttom harbour. 
“Since the mechanised boats damage fibreglass boats, fish nets and even kill fishermen on the high seas, they should be banned or regularised.  Besides finalising permanent fishing timings for the mechanised boats, the district administration should allocate funds from Kudankulam Neighbourhood Development Programme for constructing a groyne in their village,” Jude, a fisherman from Koottapuli, said. 
Register cases
Chairing the meet, Collector M.  Karunakaran instructed the Coastal Security Group police to register cases against the mechanised boats that carried out fishing operations near the coast and damaged the fibreglass boats. 
Former panchayat president of Uvari S. V.  Antony said that a good number of cancer patients and 85 persons suffering from renal failure and requiring periodic dialysis in Uvari were undergoing treatment. 
Since there was an alarming rise in such cases, the Department of Public Health should conduct a comprehensive study in Uvari to ascertain the problems causing these diseases. 
“Moreover, a dialysis unit under the supervision of qualified technicians should be established at the Primary Health Centre in Uvari,” Mr.  Antony said. 
Dr.  Karunakaran said that a detailed study would be conducted in coastal villages about this issue and adequate medical facilities would be made available for these serious ailments in government hospitals close to coastal villages. 
Drinking water scheme
“Moreover, the drinking water scheme planned under Kudankulam Neighbourhood Development Programme at a cost of Rs.  68 crore will be commissioned as early as possible,” he assured. 
Another group of fishermen wanted liquor shops running close to their villages to be removed.  Search boat to be stationed at KKNPP jetty Kanyakumari-based State government’s ‘search boat’, which used to be pressed into service on getting SOS from fishermen in distress at the high seas, will be stationed at Kudankulam Nuclear Power Project (KKNPP) jetty soon, Collector M.  Karunakaran said. 
Raising this issue at fishermen’s grievance day meet held at Radhapuram on Friday, some of the participants said that the search boats meant for Tuticorin and Kanayakumari districts had been anchored in harbours in the respective districts, and hence search operations could be commenced immediately on getting distress calls from fishermen. 
However, there was no ‘search boat’ for Tirunelveli district though it had 13 coastal hamlets, they said. 
Dr.  Karunakaran said the ‘search boat’ meant for the district had been anchored at Chinna Muttom fishing harbour as there was no proper jetty or harbour in Tirunelveli district.  When some of the participants pointed out the availability of a jetty at the KKNPP, the Collector ordered the fsheries officials to station the boat at the KKNPP. 
S. V.  Antony of Uvari and Liguori of Kooduthaazhai appealed to the Collector to ensure construction of a fishing harbour at an appropriate spot in the district so that the Tirunelveli fishermen, who had been practising traditional fishing methods with small fibreglass boats, could switch over to modern fishing practices with mechanised boats.  Stalin of Idinthakarai demanded a cold storage facility for the village.  A group of fishermen from Koottapuli appealed to the Collector to sanction permanent concrete houses being built under ‘KKNPP Neighbourhood Development Programme’ to their village too, which was immediately accepted. 
Dr.  Karunakaran said that a branch of Indian Overseas Bank would be inaugurated at Koottapuli, and asked the villagers to cooperate with the bank in identifying a building.  Some of the fishermen suggested that the unused community hall in the hamlet could be used for the purpose. 
“If the bank wants to convert it into a branch, we’ll bear the expenditure,” they assured.  The Collector said that the branch at Koottapuli would be ready for inauguration before September-end. 
When the fishermen raised the problems they were facing on high seas from the Coastal Security Group and the Indian Coast Guard due to the absence of identity cards issued by the Fisheries Department, Dr.  Karunakaran ordered the officials to initiate the work in this regard and complete it within a month.  Search boat to be stationed at KKNPP jetty Kanyakumari-based State government’s ‘search boat’, which used to be pressed into service on getting SOS from fishermen in distress at the high seas, will be stationed at Kudankulam Nuclear Power Project (KKNPP) jetty soon, Collector M.
