‘Boat for Tirunelveli district anchored at Chinna Muttom’ Fishermen net rocket shell Fishermen from Kanyakumari netted a rocket shell in the sea near Chinna Muttom on Monday. 
Vincent and three others had ventured into the sea from Chinna Muttom on Sunday night.  When they were fishing one and half nautical miles from the shore, they found a metal object like a rocket-shell weighing over 12 kg and measuring 2 feet in their net.  They immediately alerted the Coastal Security Zone (CSZ) personnel, who recovered the shell . 
An official attached to CSZ told The Hindu the Bomb Disposal Squad from Madurai has been summoned to defuse it.  Fishermen had netted a few rocket shells in 2007 in Kanyakumari.  Boat held by country craft fishermen released A mechanised boat from Kanyakumari with 10 fishermen aboard was detained while they were engaged in fishing close to the shore of Periyathalai in Tuticorin district on Saturday.  They were held captive by the country craft fishermen of Periyathalai for trespassing into their waters in violation of Tamil Nadu Marine Fishing Regulation Act, 1983. 
When mechanised boats fish within three nautical miles close to the shore in violation of the Act, nets cast by country craft fishermen suffer damages spoiling their livelihood.  Hence, enforcement agencies should keenly monitor such violations and prevent such incidents.  Joint Director of Fisheries, Tuticorin region, R.  Amal Xavier, told The Hindu that the fishermen, who were held captive, from Chinna Muttom, had been released after a meeting involving Fisheries Department officials from Kanyakumari and Tuticorin district was convened at Periyathalai. 
During the meeting, the local fishermen were assured that steps would be taken to prevent trespassing in future.  It was their only demand, Assistant Director of Fisheries (Marine), Tuticorin, P.  Isaac Jeyakumar said.  Mechanised boat fishermen from Chinna Muttom on strike A large number of fishermen from Chinna Muttom abstained from fishing from Tuesday midnight, demanding the government to allow them to carry out multi-day deep-sea fishing, said Fr.  Churchil, secretary, South Asian Fishermen Fraternity (SAFF), here on Thursday. 
Fr.  Churchil told The Hindu that fishermen from Thoothur, Colachel and Muttom were allowed to go for multi-day fishing.  Thoothur fishermen used to stay in mid sea for 30-50 days, whereas fishermen from Colachel and Muttom were allowed only 7-10 days of deep-sea fishing, he said.  Multi-day deep-sea fishing would fetch a good catch for the fishermen, and who could also save considerable money spent on fuel. 
The fishermen had gone for multi-day fishing for 4-5 days for the last one month, but they were allegedly told by the Additional Director of Fisheries to stop this practice last week.  “When the government permits international vessels to stay in Indian waters for any number of days, why the Indian fishermen are not permitted for deep-sea fishing for multiple days?” asked Fr.  Churchil.  “Deep-sea fishing helps the fishermen earn a decent income and generate foreign exchange for the country as well,” he noted. 
Chinna Muttom fishermen met the Collector and other officials recently to press for their demand.  But they were told to wait until Deepavali festival got over, he added. 
Now, about 4,500 fishermen from Arogyapuram, Chinna Muttom, Manakkudi, Keezha Manakkudi, Kanyakumari and Rajakkamangalam and other coastal villages, who used to venture into the sea from Chinna Muttom, participated in the strike.  When contacted, a Fisheries Department official said the problem would be sorted out once construction of Colechel and Thengaipattinam fishing harbours was completed.  Rain with heavy wind in Kanyakumari Due to the low pressure formed over the South West Bengal Sea, intermittent rain with heavy wind continued on Friday in Kanyakumari district.  The coastal villages from Arogyapuram to Neerodi experienced gale on Thursday night.  The sea was rough with high tides lashing to a height of 15 to 20 feet on Friday morning. 
As a precautionary exercise, the fishermen kept off the sea.  While mechanised boats remained anchored at sea, small boats were kept on the shore. 
As a result of this, the busy fishing harbours in Chinna Muttom and Colachel were deserted.  Intermittent rain lashed the catchment areas of the dams.  Colachel and Kannimar areas experienced moderate rainfall.  A maximum rainfall of 15.2 mm was recorded in Puthan Anai.  The inflow into Pechiparai has increased to 630 cusecs and the discharge was maintained at 600 cusecs. 
The water level of the dam stood at 45.64 feet against its full capacity of 48 feet.  The inflow into Perunchani dam was 223 cusecs and the discharge was100 cusecs, while the water level of the dam stood at 74.77 feet as against its full capacity of 77 feet. 
Officials of WRO of PWD said that they are closely monitoring the situation round-the-clock, and in case of heavy rain, the discharge from the dams will be stepped up.  The flood warning issued a month ago in the down streams areas is there to stay till further orders.  People living on river banks have been asked to move to safer places, the official said.  Rain and gale hit Tuticorin Rain returned to Tuticorin on Friday, accompanied by a gale, which uprooted over 200 trees in the port town.  Several residential areas were inundated and water entered the ground floor houses in a few colonies and the Government Medical College Hospital. 
As all the 14 motors pumping drinking water to overhead tanks went under water at the Rajaji Park pumping station in Tuticorin, water supply to the town was cut.  Operation of the pumping station at nearby Vallanadu has already been affected by the earlier wet spell. 
A 15-minute gale uprooted several trees on the Collector’s office premises and blew off tiles glass window panes in several residential areas, which have been affected by inundation in last week’s rains. 
Several areas went without power as the uprooted trees fell on overhead power lines.  Revenue officials were pressed into service to take stock of the damage caused by the gale and fire and rescue services personnel, along with Tangedco workers, were involved in removal of the uprooted trees and restoration of power supply.  Rain water entered the Sivan Temple at Tiruchendur. 
197 mm in Manjolai
In the neighbouring Tirunelveli district, Manjolai recorded the highest rainfall of 197 mm and catchment areas of all reservoirs continued to experience significant rainfall.  PWD officials released 14,000 cusecs of water from the overflowing Papanasam dam and over 18,000 cusecs from Manimuthar dam, which has already reached its maximum level of 118 feet.  As a result of heavy discharge, the Tamirabharani swelled once again and inundated the Karuppanthurai low-level causeway connecting Melapalayam and Tirunelveli Town.  Discharge from the two dams was scaled down by noon.  Water entered several low-lying areas in Tirunelveli and three houses suffered extensive damage, injuring three persons.  Police personnel were deployed with safety gear along the Tamirabharani. 
Kanyakumari district experienced widespread rainfall and discharge from Pechiparai dam was increased to 2000 cusecs. 
The maximum rainfall of 29.2 mm was recorded in Myladi.  As the Western Ghats received heavy rain, flow into dams increased.  People living on the banks of the rivers were asked to move to safer places and ban on bathing in Thirparappu falls continued on Friday. 
Due to heavy rain, ferry services to Vivekanandar Rock and Tiruvalluvar Statue in Kanyakumari were suspended for about two hours in the morning.  Five houses in Agasteeswaram taluk and four in Vilavancode taluk were damaged on Thursday night.  Majority of fishermen from Colechel and Chinna Muttom did not venture into sea due to rough sea.  Widespread rain in Kanyakumari district Many parts of Kanyakumari district experienced rain with occasional thundershowers on Thursday night, and the rain continued till 11 a. m.  on Friday. 
The maximum rainfall of 29.2 mm was recorded in Myladi.  Due to dark clouds visibility was affected, and vehicles plied with head lights on till 8.30 a. m.  Some roads were flooded with rainwater. 
As the Western Ghats received heavy rainfall, inflow into dams has increased.  The inflow into Pechiparai dam crossed 1,500 cusecs in the afternoon, and the discharge was raised to 2,000 cusecs in the evening. 
The level in the dam was 46.30 ft. 
Water level in Perunchani dam stood at 74.90 ft, with an inflow of 404 cusecs and a discharge of 351 cusecs. 
Due to the increase in discharge from Pechiparai dam, Kothaiar, Paraliar and Kuzhithurai rivers flooded.  Public Works Department asked people living on the banks to move to safety .  The ban on bathing in Tirparappu falls continued on Friday. 
Water level in major dams was (in feet): Chitrar I 16.20, Chitrar II 16.30 and Poigai 25. 
Rainfall registered at various stations was (in mm): Pechiparai 22.4, Perunchani 18.4, Chitrar I 16.4, Chitrar II 9.4, Aralvoimozhi 14.2, Mambazhathuraiaru 5, Balamore 8.4, Kottaram 10.8, Kannimar 11.7, Eraniel 3.4, Anaikkidangu 7, Colachel 4.6, Kurunthancode 5.2, Adayamadai 8.2, Mullanginavilai 7, Puthananai 19.6, Nagercoil 16.4, Boothapadi and Surulode 21.6, PWD sources said. 
Ferry services suspended
Due to heavy rain, ferry services to Vivekanandar Rock and Thiruvalluvar Statue were suspended for about two hours on Friday morning.  However, the services were resumed around 10 a. m. 
Tree uprooted
An old tree was uprooted and came down crashing in Kottar Vagaiadi North Mada Street in Nagercoil on Friday morning, snapping power lines.  Tangedco officials rushed to the spot and restored power supply, official sources said. 
Houses damaged
Five houses in Agasteeswaram taluk and four houses in Vilavancode taluk were damaged in the rain on Thursday night.  Many fishermen did not venture into sea from Colechel and Chinna Muttom fishing harbours due to the rough sea.

column1: Ramamurthy Nagar
column2:
24 kids escape after rashly-driven school bus overturns  BENGALURU: Twenty-four children aboard a rashly-driven school bus had a miraculous escape after the vehicle overturned and landed on its right in north Bengaluru, on Thursday afternoon.  Two students and an ayah sustained injuries, while 22 other children escaped with minor bruises. 
The minibus was contracted to ferry children of Vidyashilp Academy, near Jakkur Flying Club.  The accident happened around 1.45pm on Double Road, near Arkavathy Layout, off Jakkur Main Road, north Bengaluru. 
Investigations revealed the driver, Vijendra Kumar, 28, was driving rashly, and lost control over the vehicle over a sloping stretch.  He braked suddenly, in a bid to avoid hitting the road median, sending the vehicle toppling. 
The bus had travelled about 2km from the school and was headed towards Kalyan Nagar and Ramamurthy Nagar to drop children.  The injured ayah, Devi, 42, immediately alerted the school about the incident. 
Driver Vijendra jumped out of the vehicle and pulled all the students out through the door.  Passersby helped him, even as the school rushed an MUV and ambulance to the spot.  The children were taken to a private nursing home nearby, and administered first aid. 
While the rest were sent home, Niharika Muttanna K of Kalyan Nagar and Advay Santosh Nair, both class 1 students aged 7, and Devi, a resident of Doddabanasawadi, were referred to Columbia Asia Hospital, Hebbal, for further treatment. 
Niharika, with an injury on her forehead, was shifted to the general ward, while Advay underwent a minor procedure for cuts suffered on his head and right ear. 
Devi, who suffered a fractured right hand, was discharged around 4.30pm. 
Yelahanka traffic police arrested Vijendra, from Mysuru, on charges of driving in a rash and negligent manner.  He was subjected to an alcohol test and doctors confirmed the findings were negative. 
The school was working half-day in view of a farewell function.  As the photo of the school bus lying on its side went viral, the school messaged parents: “Nothing serious has happened.  All are safe and have reached home. ”
However, Kalpana Mohan, principal, Vidyashilp Academy, who visited the hospital, said: “Twenty-two students in the bus sustained minor injuries and were given first-aid.  Niharika and Advay were shifted to the casualty ward of Columbia Asia.  Doctors confirmed that both are out of danger. ” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Gang of 3 hacks man to death near CMR college  BENGALURU: A 27-year-old youth was hacked to death on III C Cross Road, near CMR College, OMBR Layout, east Bengaluru, on Thursday morning.  Eyewitnesses said Amol Krishna, a resident of Maruti Sevanagar, had come to the college aat 10.30am to write a BBM subject examination he had failed earlier. 
" He had just parked his motorcycle in front of a bakery behind the college when a group of men led by Dileep alias Deepu, 22, a BA dropout from the same college, came towards him.  Amol tried to get back onto his motorcycle and flee but the gang caught him,"  an eyewitness said. 
Amol, an employee of a private finance company, was attacked with knives and choppers by a three-member gang who came in a car.  Passersby noticed him lying in a pool of blood and shifted him to a nearby hospital in Banaswadi where he succumbed to his injuries. 
Police claimed the attack was the fallout of a love affair.  Amol's friends claimed he and Dileep had a long-standing enmity.  " Their parents intervened and warned them to keep the peace,"  said one of Amol's friends. 
A police officer said, " We know the attackers are on the run but we have obtained vital clues about three persons involved in the crime,"  a police officer said. 
Investigation, so far revealed that there were three assailants in the car.  While two of them were identified as Deepu and Ajay, the third man's identity is not known.  Deepu is a resident of OMBR Layout. 
" We found that Amol and Deepu had an affair with the latter's collegemate from Jharkhand.  Amol is the son of retired armyman Krishnappa,"  a police officer said. 
A case of murder has been registered against the assailants at Ramamurthy Nagar police station.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Chaos in hospital after farmer dies of H1N1  BENGALURU: Chaos prevailed outside Koshys Hospital, Ramamurthy Nagar, east Bengaluru on Wednesday afternoon over the death of a 45-year-old farmer, suspected to be suffering from H1N1.  Nagaraj Muniyappa was initially admitted to Koshys Hospital but was moved to Rajiv Gandhi Institute of Chest Diseases (RGICD) almost a week later where he was declared brought dead.  Later the body was moved back to Koshys, where doctors claimed they were treating Nagaraj for low BP when he was in reality dead, his kin alleged.  But Koshys Hospital authorities said they were only examining the body as per hospital norms.  Nagaraj, a farmer from Chintamani in Kolar district, was brought to Koshys Hospital last Thursday with symptoms of pneumonia.  On Wednesday morning, his family decided to shift him to Rajiv Gandhi hospital after his condition deteriorated. 
M Narayanaswamy, a family member, said Nagaraj was kept in ICU of Koshys Hospital where doctors never allowed the family to speak to him.  âWe suspected something amiss and decided to shift Nagaraj to Rajiv Gandhi hospital.  Koshys Hospital doctors put Nagaraj in an ambulance around 12.30pm,â Narayanaswamy said. 
At Rajiv Gandhi hospital, doctors declared Nagaraj brought dead. 
Dr Shashidhar Buggi, director of RGICD, confirmed that the patient was brought dead.  âAt 1.30pm, Nagaraj was brought by 108 ambulance.  As we were told it was a critical case, our anaesthetist went inside the ambulance.  The patientâs heart beat was nil and there was no pulse.  He was brought dead.  We informed the same to the patientâs relatives.  There was no admission made,â he said.  The family members rushed back to Koshys Hospital with the body where doctors took the body inside and examined it for 30 minutes before confirming the death.  âNot knowing that Rajiv Gandhi hospital doctors had declared Nagaraj dead, Koshys doctors said they are treating him for low BP.  Sometime later, doctors came out and said Nagaraj was dead,â Narayanaswamy said.  Claiming the test was a hospital norm and that Nagaraj seemed to have died en route to RGICD, KB Mukesh MD, Koshys Hospital said, âThe family just rushed back from Rajiv Gandhi hospital and accused us of treating a dead body.  We needed to cross check and thatâs why we examined the body. â
However, the family said they will not file any police complaint.  Nagarajâs death is not included in the health departmentâs list of persons who died due to H1N1 on March 4. 
HOSPITALSPEAK
Lab reports confirm that Nagaraj, who was admitted six days back, had severe pneumonia and tested positive for H1N1.  We had alerted his family that his condition may deteriorate.  Bowing to family pressure, we agreed to shift him to Rajiv Gandhi hospital.  We had tested his pulse and heart beat before shifting him to ambulance and he was alive KB Mukesh | MD, Koshys Hospital
Suo motu plaint against hospital
Dr Rajini, district health officer, told the media that the health department will take up a suo motu complaint.  She said Koshys Hospital failed to inform the authorities that the patient had been diagnosed with H1N1 and also failed to issue a discharge summary.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Virudhunagar MLA recevies death threat  MADURAI: Virudhunagar MLA, K Pandiarajan, who had been fighting political heavyweights in the district over acquisition of land for a railway overhead bridge (ROB) in the constituency, reportedly received am anonymous death threat on Saturday. 
The MLA received threats at his office and on his Facebook page, warning that he would lose his head if he interfered in the ROB issue. 
A complaint has been lodged with police. 
The construction of a ROB in Ramamurthy Nagar in the heart of Virudhunagar town, which recently received court approval, has been a bone of contention for a long time.  The railway line in Virudhunagar town intercepts the town into two halves.  The level crossing there is closed 88 times a day, causing inconvenience to the public.  Despite public demand for an ROB, several people who owned land where the bridge was supposed to come up, including former DMK minister K K S S R Ramachandran, opposed the idea. 
In January, 2012, K Pandiarajan filed a petition urging the court to pass a direction for the construction of ROB.  On March 31 this year, the court ordered the government to go ahead with the construction.  Recently, two DMK councillors from the Virudhunagar municipality have gone to court against the ROB and obtained an interim injunction on the same. 
Speaking to TOI, Pandiarajan said he saw the threat as a desperate attempt to stop the ROB works.  Instead of the 28 people who had gone to court earlier opposing the bridge, only two had now sought an interim injunction, clearly showing that their numbers were dwindling, he said. 
" An empowerment committee, comprising experts from the government and the railways, came out with a report that said the railway under bridge was not feasible, as it would involve bursting of the rocky surface in the region.  After this, the court passed orders and tenders were called.  Tenders will be opened on May 13 or 14,"  he said. 
Pandiarajan met the Superintendent of police, S Maheswaran, who assured him of action against the unknown people who issued the threat.  Since the threat was also made on his Facebook page, the cyber wing too will investigate the matter, sources said.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  CM's convoy inconveniences Bengalureans  BENGALURU: Chief minister Siddaramaiah went on an inauguration spree on Friday, declaring open police stations at Kothanur, Ramamurthy Nagar and Bagalur, a flyover at Nagavara, grade separator near Kanteerava Studio junction and a few other civic projects that have already been thrown open to the public. 
Inaugurating a police station in Kothanur, Siddaramaiah urged the police department to connect with the peo8ple and work with a citi8zen-friendly approach as it will help them prevent crimes more efficiently.  " Preventing all crimes is not possible, but if every station has a good connect with people, police will be able to get tipoffs, which will help prevent crimes,"  he said. 
The CM was accompanied by home minister KJ George and Bengaluru city in-charge minister Ramalinga Reddy.  Besides, the CM's convoy had at least 40 cars belonging to local Congress leaders and workers, and tens of people welcomed Siddaramaiah at every spot.  The movement and stopping of these vehicles inconvenienced Bengalurea8ns wherever he went.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Rationalist files complaint against practitioner of 'dynamic science'  MANGAURU: A Mangaluru-based rationalist has filed a complaint against a person who claims to cure cancer with 99% success rate to the health minister, drugs controller of Karnataka and the director of Ayush. 
Narendra Nayak, president, Federation of Indian Rationalist Associations, who filed the complaint under the Drugs and Magic Remedies (Objectionable Advertisements) Act.  Nayak accused him being a quack, saying he opened his shop in Bengaluru and posted details on Facebook.  Nayak said claims of 99% cure cannot be made even by the most advanced facilities in the world. 
" If this were to be true, it would be a revolution indeed and a life-saving therapy for millions of cancer patients.  If it were false, it should invite criminal prosecution for the claimant identified as Dr Shaji V Kudiyat,"  said Nayak. 
When contacted, Dr Shaji said he has a BHMS degree from the Homeopathic Government Medical College, Thiruvananthapuram, MD in Homeopathic Philosophy from Vinayaka Missions Homeopathy College, Salem, PG Diploma in yoga from Annamalai University, Tamil Nadu and also PG certificate in counselling from St Theresa's College, Ernakulam.  " I combined all these three on the basis of a new scientific hypothesis called 'Dynamic science'.  In some cases, surgery is recommended but done outside and not by us,"  he said. 
He said DNA and the vital force are interconnected.  " The problem with cancer is with material philosophy which is the base of science.  They destroy the tumour and fail to identify the root cause which produces the tumour.  We try to identify the cause,'' he added. Dr Shaji, who has been practising for the past four years in Ramamurthy Nagar, Bengaluru, said he recently came to Mangaluru to attend a cancer conference at Fr Muller College.  Nayak said: " The person claims to be practising something called dynamic science which is not listed under any system of evidence-based medicine or under Ayush.  He claims to be a homeopath and if he practises anything else, it would mean cross practice which amounts to malpractice. "  Dr Shaji said, " I'm a licensed practitioner and a qualified person. "  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Helmetless Sudanese dies in accident in Bengaluru  BENGALURU: A Sudanese national was killed after his bike hit a median near ASR Choultry in Ramamurthy Nagar early on Sunday. 
Police said Mohammad Abdel Majid Osman was riding a Pulsar 220cc bike, while his friend Mosub was riding pillion. 
KR Puram traffic police said Majid, a second-year BCA student at Aditi College, was speeding and not wearing a helmet. 
" There is a sharp turn on Ramamurthy Nagar Ring Road.  Because Osman was riding too fast, he crashed into the divider.  Both Osman and Mosab were thrown into the air,"  police said. 
Osman sustained severe head injuries and died on the spot.  Mosab was admitted to Hosmat Hospital's ICU with fractured legs. 
Both Osman and Mosab were in India on a student visa.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Shop owner robbed Two men robbed a garment shop owner and made away with valuables worth Rs.  50,000 in Ramamurthy Nagar on Wednesday night. 
Sunil, the owner of Suman textiles, was about to close the shop when two men entered as customers.  They soon overpowered him and tied him up before robbing his wrist watch, gold ring and cash.  Sunil managed to untie himself and called his family for help. 
Sunil told the police that while two robbed him inside the shop, four others were waiting outside to guard. 
The Ramamurthy Nagar police have taken up a case.  Woman murdered: husband, friend arrested Two persons were arrested late on Friday night for allegedly abducting and murdering a woman near Bagalur on December 29 night.  Police are on the lookout for four others. 
Police said that the prime accused is Arun (28), a resident of Bommanahalli, who works as a clerk in an advertising company.  He had married Ramya (23) in 2013.  However, differences cropped up between them within a year.  He had called Ramya to celebrate his birthday at a café in Ramamurthy Nagar. 
When Ramya did not return home, her mother filed an abduction case on December 30, said Inspector V. L.  Ramesh of Ramamurthy Nagar Police Station. 
On December 30 morning, the disfigured body of a woman was found by a pond in Bagalur.  She had been stabbed repeatedly on the torso and face.  A case was registered by the Bagalur police.  They referred the case to the Ramamurthy Nagar police after the identity of the deceased was established. 
On Friday night, police arrested Arun and his friend Srinivas.  They have been remanded to 10 days in judicial custody. 
Youth arrested for rape
A 20-year-old youth was handed over to the police by passers-by for allegedly sexually assaulting a 40-year-old ragpicker on Friday night.  The man, Kishore, supplies water cans.  He allegedly assaulted the woman near his house, off Old Airport Road, dragged her to a desolated spot and attempted to sexually assault her. 
On hearing her screams, three passers-by rushed to the spot.  They handed Kishore over to the J. B.  Nagar police.  A rape case has been registered against Kishore.  Both Kishore and the woman were subjected to a medical examination. 
Doctor commits suicide
A 26-year-old doctor was found hanging from the ceiling around 8 a. m.  in her house at Doddabanaswadi on Saturday.  According to the Banaswadi police, the girl, Deepti, is from Andhra Pradesh.  She stayed alone and was working in a nursing home nearby. 
Police said that she had called up a colleague early on Saturday threatening suicide.  The alleged cause of her distress was the fixing of her marriage by her parents in her hometown, which she vehemently disapproved of.  The colleague rushed to the house, only to find the door locked, said the police.  Two homemakers commit suicide Two homemakers committed suicide in their homes in RPC Layout and Hampi Nagar in Vijayanagar. 
In the first incident, Swetha (34) allegedly immolated herself in her kitchen at her residence in RPC layout on Saturday morning.  Her husband was outside their home when the incident took place.  He rushed her to Victoria Hospital where she was declared brought dead. 
Shwetha’s parents, who live in Belagavi, are on their way to the city.  Swetha’s husband has taken a six-month sabbatical to prepare for a competitive exam. 
In another incident, Vedavathi (22) was found hanging in her bedroom by her mother-in-law at around 11 p. m.  She alerted her son, Praveen, who immediately shifted her to hospital where she was declared brought dead. 
Lorry rams auto
An autorickshaw passenger was killed and two others injured when a lorry rammed an autorickshaw at Kasturi Nagar on Saturday.  Police identified the deceased as Venky, a resident of Ramamurthy Nagar.  The injured are Sunny, Venky’s friend, and auto driver Manju.  Masked man ransacks house Taking advantage of an open window next to the main door, an unidentified man with his face covered, barged into the house and ransacked a house of jewellery and other valuables in Rammurthy Nagar in the wee hours of Sunday. 
The robber latched the bedroom doors before ransacking the house and packing three bag-packs containing laptops, valuables, clothes, a necklace and even chocolates and dry fruits. 
Hearing the commotion, Jagadishwari (58) woke up and raised an alarm prompting the other members to wake up. 
As the masked man tried to escape, Jagadishwari’s son, Satish managed to open the latch and chase the robber.  Sensing trouble, the accused abandoned two bags and ran away with one bag. 
He ran for a few yards where his associate was waiting in a scooter and sped away.  Satish tried to catch them but since it was dark, he could not even see the registration number of the vehicle. 
The Ramamurthy Nagar police have taken up a case and are investigating.  Power supply hit in parts of city It was a dark evening for many as power supply to several areas in the northern and eastern parts of the city were affected for at least three hours on Saturday evening due to a flashover in the transformer at the 220 kv Hebbal station. 
It resulted in supply failure in the L R Bande, C-station and Banaswadi sub-stations as well, resulting in intermittent supply from 6 p. m.  to nearly 9.30 p. m. 
Hebbal, Sanjaynagar, Ganganagar, Banaswadi, Bhartinagar, Benson Town, Fraser Town, Venkateshpura, Seshadripuram, Malleswaram, Kavalbyrasandra, Kadugondanahalli, Vasanthnagar, Ramamurthy Nagar and Yeswanthpura were the worst hit by the problem.  27 A 27-year-old youth was hacked to death in broad day-light near CMR College in OMBR Layout in Ramamurthy Nagar on Thursday morning. 
The deceased has been identified as Amul Krishna.  He was a resident of Seva Nagar and working in a private finance company. 
On Thursday, around 10.30 a. m. , Amul Krishna had came to the area near CMR College to meet his friends.  While he was waiting near a bakery, three persons in a car attacked him with lethal weapons in full public-view and sped away. 
The public, who were in a state of shock, rushed the profusely bleeding Amul Krishna to a private hospital, where he succumbed to his injuries. 
The Ramamurthy Nagar police rushed to the spot and after preliminary enquiries revealed that his alleged love affair could be the reason behind the murder. 
“The attackers are on the run but we have obtained vital clues about them,” said the police adding that the accused will soon be nabbed.  Bengaluru Today: February 21 Religion

Inquiry against private hospital The Bruhat Bangalore Mahanagara Palike has taken up a suo motu inquiry against a private hospital in Ramamurthy Nagar for alleged medical negligence and cheating. 
Nagaraj (45), a resident of Chintamani, was admitted to Koshys Hospital in Ramamurthy Nagar a week ago for H1N1.  Unable to cope with mounting bills, the family got him discharged on Wednesday and shifted him to Rajiv Gandhi Institute of Chest Diseases where he was declared brought dead. 
The family has now alleged that the private hospital had treated a dead Nagaraj for almost a week and fleeced the family. 
BBMP officials visited the private hospital.  They found that the hospital had not maintained proper records.  Relatives of patients want doctors to be more sympathetic With the doctors’ protests gaining momentum, families of patients who suffer owing to alleged medical negligence state that there is a need for doctors to be more “sympathetic” towards patients and their families. 
Justice seems far
Rashmi R. , aunt of Mariam Kouser, the four-year-old who suffered brain damage owing to alleged medical negligence in December 2013, said her niece continues to be in a vegetative state and shuttles in and out of hospitals. 
Although a case has been filed with the Medical Council of India, justice seems far for the family. 
“Her life will never be the same.  There is a need for doctors to be more responsible.  Doctors see several patients a day and sometimes tend to delegate work to their juniors.  For them, it might be just another case… but for patients and their families, the doctor’s role is crucial.  There is a need for doctors to be more sensitive to their needs.  The damage caused is irreversible,” she said. 
Narayanswamy, whose brother died earlier this month owing to alleged medical negligence at a private hospital in Ramamurthy Nagar, said, “Doctors in private hospitals refuse treatment if we do not pay money.  It is a testing time for us and tempers may run high.  Doctors should be considerate and must provide treatment first, as sometimes it is a matter of life and death. ”
There is a need for doctors to be more responsible.  Doctors see several patients a day and sometimes tend to delegate work to their juniors.  For them, it might be just another case. 
Rashmi R. Aunt of Mariam Kouser CCB busts scam in PDS stock It’s been a month since Central Crime Branch officers busted a major scam involving transportation and selling of rice meant for the Public Distribution System (PDS) to rice mills in and around Bengaluru, but little progress has been made in the case. 
On March 24, the CCB nabbed three persons red-handed while transporting 50 tonnes of rice to mills in Kolar for processing and selling in the open market for higher prices.  The suspects were handed over to the jurisdictional Ramamurthy Nagar police for further investigation. 
The prime suspect, Satyamurthy, is a resident of Jayanagar.  He claimed to have been carrying out this business for the many months in nexus with some officials of the Food and Civil Supplies Department and the owners of fair price shops in Bengaluru, indicating that the seizure was just the tip of the iceberg. 
The police had remanded the trio in judicial custody and sent notices to the officials concerned seeking an explanation.  They are yet to get a response. 
Joint Commissioner of Police M.  Chandrashekhar, who heads the CCB, said that they would take over the investigation considering its sensitivity and potential scale of the scam. 
“We suspect it has wide-scale ramification with officials of the Food and Civil Supplies Department and touts not only duping the State government but also beneficiaries of the PDS. ”
Trio were transporting 50 tonnes of rice to mills in Kolar for processing and selling in the open market Groom dies in accident A bridegroom who was on his way to invite relatives for the wedding died in an accident in Madiwala on Monday morning. 
Koti Reddy (28), a resident of Kodichikkanahalli, was working in a private firm in Kundalahalli.  His bike was hit by a water tanker from behind.  Madiwala Traffic police registered a case and arrested the tanker driver. 
Jewellery shop looted during power cut
A man looted a jewellery store in Ramamurthy Nagar during a power cut amidst heavy rain on Sunday evening. 
He entered the shop in Dasappa Layout around 8.45 p. m.  and asked to see a ring.  The shopkeeper took out a tray containing around 40 rings for him to select. 
The man threw chilli powder into the face of the shopkeeper and fled with the tray.  The store owner has lodged a complaint with Ramamurthy Nagar police. 
Chain snatching
Two unidentified persons snatched a gold chain of around 20 grams from Sudha (65) while she was on a morning walk near her house in Tilak Nagar on Monday morning.  Traffic jams, loud crackers greet citizens as CM inaugurates civil works in city Bengalureans faced another day of bumper-to-bumper traffic and noisy celebrations as Chief Minister Siddaramaiah inaugurated major civil works in the city. 
Beginning from his residence at 11 a. m. , Mr.  Siddaramaiah first inaugurated the flyover at Kanteerava Studio junction, built at an estimated cost of Rs.  46.98 crore. 
Two skywalks – at Babusapalya junction and Kammanahalli Junction on Outer Ring Road – were inaugurated, as well as a flyover at Nagawara junction on ORR. 
Police station inaugurated
The Chief Minister also inaugurated the police station at Ramamurthy Nagar.  Despite regulations, massive flexboards were visible at the inaugural venue.  (Photo: Chitra V.  Ramani)
Traffic jam
Commuters were irate as vehicles were stopped at Outer Ring Road and other places to make way for the CM's convoy, leading to a huge jam at Outer RIng Road.  The convoy was followed by the private vehicles of local leaders.  With crackers being burst on the road, several vehicles were forced to stop and the traffic police struggled to regulate traffic. 
A reader questions the Chief Minister's prescience in conducting the inauguration on a weekday:
>@BloreConnect just a week back, Hon'ble CM told that he will do city rounds only on Sundays to avoid traffic jams!!!— VENU GOPAL (@u_venugopal) >June 19, 2015
Mr.  Siddaramaiah later inaugurated the skywalk at Kammanahalli on Outer Ring Road, as well as Kothnur and Bagalur police stations.  The CM chose not to speak at any venue, and instead cut the ribbon and waved at party workers before setting out to the next point on his agenda. 
Business was slow at the market near Bagalur police station due to the passing convoy.  Photo: Sampath Kumar G. P.

It was attended by around 75 students and staff members of Government Intermediate College.  labour and Industrial laws, Child labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Act, Right to Information Act, Right to Education, Dowry Prohibition Act, Domestic Violence Act, Environment Protection Act and How to lodge FIR under CrPC were the core issues discussed by the students of School of law. This was followed by a question and answer round in which the students raised their law- related queries, which were appropriately answered by the students of School of law.

Crawford market parking attendant caught on tape charging Rs 300, held  MUMBAI: Overcharging for parking even at BMC lots in south Mumbai is not a secret, yet little action is taken.  Prompted by numerous complaints, a non-profit ran a sting operation on the extent of the extortion recently to goad the police and the civic body into action. 
Still, only a lowly parking attendant has been arrested with the cops saying they are checking if they can widen the scope of the probe.  Interestingly, the parking lot that was targeted is located next to Crawford market and opposite the police commissioner’s office.  The BMC headquarters is also a stone’s throw away.  Afzal Khan, who runs Adarsh, the NGO that conducted the sting, said they had received several complaints that the private contractor running three parking lots in the area was overcharging.  “There were several complaints that despite paying five times the official rate, people were not getting parking slots.  As a result, there were huge jams at Crawford market, the mouth of JJ flyover and the Eastern Freeway.  Hence we decided to do a sting operation,” said Khan. 
In the first week of December, as crowds were peaking for Christmas at Crawford market, Khan’s friends Toushaf Shaikh and Asif Sayyed went to the parking lot with a car with a Tamil Nadu registration.  “We kept our secret camera on as we entered the parking lot.  It was afternoon peak time when the attendant told us at the entrance it will cost Rs 300 per hour.  When we asked why they were charging so much, he said it was the rate.  We agreed and paid.  The conversation was taped,” said Shaikh. 
The accused were found parking even outside the marked areas, prompting traffic chaos.  The attendant had bragged to the team that they had greased the palms of cops, traffic policemen and BMC officials. 
Based on Adarsh’s complaints, the Azad Maidan police on Monday arrested Anees Ansari, 43, an employee of the BMC contractor for Crawford market area, and booked him for extortion and cheating.  Sources claimed the contractor has appointed sub-contractors to run the parking lot. 
“We have gone through the CCTV footage and it appears that the accused were demanding more than the official charge.  They have even done forgery.  We are probing if the scope of investigations can be further widened,” said Narendra Singh, senior inspector Azad Maidan. 
“I am not aware of the incident.  I can comment only after getting information about the issue,” said a senior BMC official. 
At the moment, the BMC charges uniform parking rates across the city (see box).  A proposal to revise the rates three fold and levy varying charges according to location has been cleared by the BMC improvements committee but pending with the general body for over a year. Towing service man cons navyman, held  MUMBAI: If your car breaks down and you need to tow it to a garage, don’t call a service from a number on the Internet, as you may get conned. 
The city crime branch’s property cell on Friday arrested a 27-year-old man, who under the pretext of towing away a car belonging to a naval officer, fled with it and also duped him of Rs30,000.  The police arrested Zubair Khan from Dharavi and recovered the Santro belonging to the officer from Navy Nagar in Colaba.  “The accused admitted to have similarly conned a Pajero owner recently.  We are checking if he is involved in anymore cases,’’ said inspector Nandkumar Gopale. 
Last July, the officer was driving along the Eastern Freeway when his car met with an accident.  “He contacted a call centre, whose number he found on the net, and it gave him two or three towing service numbers.  When he called one number, a man came immediately and towed away the vehicle.  He offered to repair the car cheaply,’’ said investigating officer Deep Bane. 
The accused, along with the complainant, towed it to a garage in Bandra.  The accused, claiming it was his garage, said the repairs would cost Rs30,000.  The officer immediately paid him Rs10,000, and promised the rest when work began.  Within two days, the accused said he urgently needed the remaining amount to complete the work.  The officer handed him the amount near Regal theatre at Colaba, not realizing that he was being duped.  Two days later, when the officer tried calling, the phone was switched off.  When he went to the garage, its actual owner said he did not know him.  The Sewri police have registered a case of cheating, said deputy commissioner of police (crime) Dhananjay Kulkarni. 
The police tracked the call centre’s number and traced the accused to Dharavi based on the IP address from where he had uploaded the advertisement. At Freewayâs start, a boom in vertical slums alters Chembur  Kala Suresh and Parveen Nisa live in neighboring apartment complexes at the northern end of Mumbaiâs newest marvel, the Eastern Freeway.  But their lives couldn't be more different. 
Suresh lives in a gated high-rise next to the middle-class colony of Indian Oil Nagar on the Ghatkopar-Mankhurd Link Road.  Across the road, Nisa lives with her family in a 200 sqft tenement in the Natwarlal Parekh slum rehabilitation complex, where she copes with erratic water supply and risky living conditions.  âAfter bringing us here, the authorities left us to deal with overflowing gutters and thieves roaming freely,â she says. 
Once considered far-flung and polluted, the eastern suburbs are set to boom in the next few years thanks to the new connectivity provided by the Monorail and Freeway.  Land prices in Chembur have been rising sharply and old buildings are making way for new.  But in adjacent Govandi and Mankhurd, an equally dramatic housing development has taken place quietly: a stack of low-income complexes have risen on old factory lands in one of the worldâs largest slum resettlement efforts. 
More than 100,000 people have been transplanted here over the past ten years, cleared off pavements, railway tracks and plots of land in the rest of the city to make way for road and rail projects.  At least half of them were moved here before 2011, contributing a chunk of the 2.6 lakh people added to this municipal ward between 2001-2011. 
Mass rehabilitation has enabled infrastructure development in Mumbai.  But the effect on the lives of the slumdwellers and on their new neighborhood has been less positive.  The Mumbai Metropolitan Region Development Authority, which resettled the slum-dwellers, didnât upgrade the public infrastructure in the Govandi-Mankhurd area to cope with the influx.  The result: a strain on basic facilities in one of Mumbaiâs most underdeveloped areas, an uptick in unemployment and crime, and rising tension between old and new residents. 
Choked infrastructure
The strain is evident at Nisaâs Natwarlal complex.  Resettlement has given slum-dwellers a new, legal home but little else.  âWe have a pucca toilet and my children can bring their friends home now without feeling ashamed,â says Nisa, who moved here from a pavement in Sewri.  âBut what do I do if I canât find a job here or send my children to good schools nearby?â
The local municipal school is overcrowded so Nisaâs two sons go to private schools in Chembur.  M East Ward, in which Govandi and parts of Chembur fall, needs 191 schools but only has 56, according to a report by non-governmental groups. 
Public health services are also overwhelmed.  Another resident, Kantha Nadar, continues to take her ailing husband to KEM Hospital near her old Byculla shanty.  On average, a health facility in Mumbai serves 9,696 people.  But in M East Ward, one health facility serves 27,438 people. 
âThey could meet their basic needs even if they were staying on a footpath in Byculla, as they had good hospitals and schools nearby,â admits Kiran Dighavkar, the assistant municipal commissioner of the ward.  âThat is not the case here, they could have planned it better. â
Some of the displaced slum-dwellers have found work in Chembur shops or the Vashi markets.  Others like Nadar travel to their old jobs and some have even sold their homes and moved back.  A Tata Institute of Social Sciences study showed that in one resettlement complex, 446 of 3,634 tenements had been rented out and 29 sold. 
Many here are also unemployed, however.  In the complexes, thereâs talk of a drug problem, sex work, and a fake documents racket.  âWe tell rickshawallahs that we want to go to Govandi municipal colony.  Otherwise they refuse because our area is notorious,â says Sachin Lubana, a resident of the Lallubhai resettlement complex.  Sangramsinh Nishamdar, deputy commissioner of police, Zone 6, admits that petty crime has risen but denies the presence of organised gangs. 
Reluctant neighbours
When people are displaced suddenly, they lose the community structure that ensures social control, says Leena Joshi, director of TISSâs M-Ward Initiative.  Agrees civic activist and Chembur resident Rajkumar Sharma, âIf you uproot pavement and slum people and put them in a far off placeâ¦ their livelihood is finished, some of them will get into wrong ways of making money. â He blames the government for focusing only on the western suburbs. 
The problem is aggravated by the increasingly segregated living conditions in the city, Joshi adds.  âEarlier, neighbourhoods used to have mixed environments,â Joshi says.  That allowed middle-class colonies and slum areas to develop a symbiotic relationship.  âNow towers are coming up in the old middle-class areas and everyone shops at malls. â
In Govandi, insecurity has stoked the distrust between sudden neighbours.  The women in the slum rehabilitation complexes canât find domestic work in the Indian Oil Colony - middle-class families like Sureshâs prefer to hire help from Shivaji Nagar, an old slum settlement further down the road.  Suresh, whose building has added CCTVs to every floor, blames the new complexes for incidents of chain-snatching and pickpocketing - and for lowering Govandiâs real estate value.  âPrices in other parts of Chembur have gone up four times but here it has only doubled,â she says. 
In turn, Nisa and her neighbours at Natwarlal claim their complexes are targets for miscreants from Shivaji Nagar.  At a recent womenâs group meeting in their building, a young man snatches a phone kept near the door and escapes - despite the presence of a police chowkie in the compound.  âEven after seven years, I still donât feel at home here,â says Nisa. New AC buses connect south Mumbai to Thane via freeway  MUMBAI: BEST will not only increase bus fares from Sunday, but also modify several routes to cater to commutersâ needs.  On public demand, BEST will resume AC bus services connecting SoBo to Thane via the Eastern Freeway.  The buses will cater to office-goers during morning and evening peak hours and could cut the commute to Fort/Colaba/Nariman Point to just an hour. 
The undertaking also plans to float tenders to procure 299 new red buses for Mumbai, besides installing more LCD screens, adding new seats with better leg space and installing âweather resistantâ electronic route indicators in 800 buses.

Minor abducted, raped and dropped back home  MUMBAI: A four-year-old girl was kidnapped from outside her fifth-floor flat at a Mhada building near the Wadala Truck Terminus, sexually assaulted and then dropped back on Saturday. 
The incident occurred around 10.30pm while the girl was playing outside her house.  The accused abducted her and took her to the Eastern Freeway.  After sexually assaulting her, he dropped her back at the building’s ground floor, said the police.  The girl’s mother who had been looking for her found her lying injured at the ground floor.  She lodged a complaint on Sunday morning. 
“Based on accounts of eye-witnesses, a sketch has been prepared,” said additional commissioner (central region) RD Shinde.  “A shopowner in the neighbourhood had seen the accused as the latter had visited his store to buy an ice-cream, minutes before the abduction.  The accused may have lured the girl with the ice-cream,” said the police.

Property rates rose by 7% in 2014, 0.3% in 2013  MUMBAI: Residential property prices in Mumbai increased by only 7% last year and a negligible 0.3% in 2013, said a report released on Monday. 
The eastern suburbs from Kurla to Mulund saw an increase of 6% in 2014 and 5% in 2013 as land was still available to launch new projects.  South Mumbai and the western suburbs between Malad and Borivli recorded similar increases.  Bandra, Khar, Santacruz and Juhu also saw average price growths, as these areas lack a good supply of high-rises.  Rates in areas like Thane and Navi Mumbai did not rise much either; the uncertainty surrounding the proposed Navi Mumbai airport did not work in favour of the satellite city, said the report by Jones Lang Lasalle (JLL) India. 
Chembur and Wadala stood apart from the lacklustre trend in residential price growth.  “The two suburbs saw a tremendous price increase of 58% and 50% in 2014 over 2013, thanks to completion of infrastructure projects like the Eastern Freeway, which connects Chembur to south Mumbai, and the monorail, which was in the news recently for all the wrong reasons,” it said. 
The report said even the average hike of 7% was primarily due to the development control (DC) rules that came into effect from 2013.  Developers had to start paying for additional (fungible) FSI towards construction of lifts, lobbies, flower beds, balconies, etc, which had been FSI-free areas earlier.  Other reasons for the increase in per-square-ft prices include the rise in ready reckoner rates and escalations in the cost of labour and raw materials. 
“Home prices in the financial capital are evidently not submitting to inflation, which is affecting cost of living in most other respects.  Of course, given the sluggish demand for homes owing to already crippling prices, there is not much scope for appreciation,” said Ramesh Nair, COO, business & international director, JLL India. 
The meagre increase in average property prices in the city stands in stark contrast to the general inflation rate of 6% in 2014 and 9% in 2013 (as per CPI data).  “These figures definitely put paid to the popular perception that Mumbai’s developers keep increasing prices despite the fact that inventory has been building up and housing demand slowing down over the last couple of years,” said Nair. Eastern Freeway to be extended till Mint Rd, Harbour line to shift  MUMBAI: The 17-km Eastern Freeway will be extended up to the Mint Road junction in South Mumbai.  The Freeway currently ends at Orange Gate on P D’Mello Road.  The Mumbai Metropolitan Region Development Authority plans to build a 1.5-km extension by way of a new flyover right up to Mint Road. 
The Freeway has helped decongest Dr Ambedkar Marg, Rafi Ahmed Kidwai Marg, Port Trust Road and Eastern Express Highway as it offers faster connectivity between Ghatkopar and CST, with exits at the Panjrapole Junction, Bhakti Park and Mysore Colony. 
A senior MMRDA official said, “It will help reduce congestion on chock-a-block P D’Mello Road, which narrows down near Orange Gate due to the north-bound ramps of the Freeway. ”
The plan to extend the Freeway was mooted by the Mumbai Port Trust, which agreed to relocate encroachments, if any. 
He said, “We have told the Freeway consultants to examine the proposal, including cost and number of lanes possible. ”
The extension may be two- or four-lane depending on space availability.  A two-lane flyover may cost Rs 40 crore, while the four-lane one may be double that. 
The Freeway was originally planned from Prince of Wales Museum but the plan was aborted to due to lack of space.  The first stretch from Orange Gate to Anik (9.29 km) was built as an elevated corridor, and then till Shivaji Chowk in Chembur (4.3 km) at ground level.  The third and final Panjrapol-Ghatkopar leg is at a height of 22 metres, making it the tallest bridge point in Mumbai. 
Meanwhile, Central Railway has proposed to shift the Harbour line from the west of CST to the east, along P D’Mello Road. 
The elevated line will originate from CST’s platform No 18 and connect Dockyard Road.  The freed up Harbour line can be used as the fifth and sixth lines for main line traffic. 
A Central Railway official said, “We are working out an arrangement where pillars for the Freeway extension can be use for laying of elevated tracks. ”
Commuters using the corridor will be provided a link to the main line stations and Sandhurst Road at Masjid and Sandhurst Road with skywalks.  Meanwhile, the Empowered Committee on Mumbai Transformation has suggested connecting the Freeway to Girgaum Chowpathy via S V Patel Road and Cowasji Road. 
The elevated road will have to be built above the railway tracks and JJ flyover, and will be a crucial east-west connection.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  CST-Panvel corridor plan may have to be reworked  MUMBAI: The CST-Panvel high-speed corridor plans will have to be revised as the Eastern Freeway may be extended and the Harbour line corridor may be shifted along P D’Mello Road to accommodate extension of the fifth and sixth lines for the Main line corridor on Central Railway (CR). 
CR plans to divert the Harbour line from Dockyard to the east of CST, adjacent to P’DMello Road, as land acquisition will be a problem between CST and Currey Road.  The Harbour line corridor at CST and Masjid will be merged with the fifth and sixth lines proposed between CST and Kurla.  The fifth and sixth lines exist between Kurla-Thane. 
The Mumbai Metropolitan Region Development Authority (MMRDA) plans to extend the Freeway by 1.5km to decongest P D’Mello Road.  A senior Mumbai Railway Vikas Corporation (MRVC) official said, “The high-speed corridor was planned along P D’Mello Road.  If MMRDA extends the Freeway and the Harbour line is shifted, we will have to rework the alignment of the corridor in South Mumbai. ”
MRVC said they could bring the corridor through Mumbai Port Trust (MbPT) land.  The official said, “MbPT has to be on board to get the corridor right up to CST.  We could also build the corridor along Mansion Road, parallel to P D’Mello Road. ”
Unlike the Western Railway (WR) elevated corridor, where land acquisition could have been a problem, private land does not have to be acquired on the entire 49km CST-Panvel stretch.  Unlike WR, where a portion of the corridor has to go underground, the Harbour line project will be elevated up to Kurla, and will be at the ground level from Mankhurd. 
The government land mostly belongs to MbPT.  Some slums, mainly in Mankhurd and Govandi, are illegal and rehabilitation will be a major problem. Now, shipping ministry wants Rs 448 crore to part with land for Sewri-Nhava link  MUMBAI: The cost of the Mumbai Trans-Harbour Link (MTHL) may go up, because the shipping ministry has sought Rs 448 crore as compensation for use of port land for the project.  While the Mumbai Port Trust (MbPT) will have to part with 24 hectares, the Jawaharlal Nehru Port Trust (JNPT) will have to hand over 2 hectares of land for the construction.  Of these, only 13 hectares will be used on a permanent basis for the project. 
An official of the Mumbai Metropolitan Region Development Authority (MMRDA) said the shipping ministry had levied a rate in accordance with its land policy, which stipulates that the amount is to be fixed on the basis of the ready reckoner rates in areas closest to the port land to be used for a project. 
The official said shipping ministry has also decided to charge money wherever construction will be carried out mid-sea within the boundary of the JNPT and MbPT. 
“We have asked the state to request the shipping ministry to give the land at a concessional rate,” the official said. 
A senior MMRDA official said the rates decided by the shipping ministry were too high despite the public purpose behind the project. 
“The shipping ministry has communicated that we will have to shell out Rs 448 crore for this land as per the land use policy,” the official said.  “This figure does not include another Rs 400 crore that the shipping ministry has sought as lease charges for a period of 90 years to be paid in parts annually. ”
The official said the project cost will increase now as the new amount was not factored in when finalizing the estimates. 
The MBPT had leased out land to the MMRDA at a token rate of Re 1 for the construction of the 17-km Eastern Freeway (EFW). 
“We don’t expect the shipping ministry to charge as low as it did for the EFW,” a state official said.  “Still, concessional rates should be considered in the interests of the city. ”
The MMRDA official said the project would not face hurdles because of the cost decided by the shipping ministry.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News. Ghatkopar and Andheri Metro stations provide interconnectivity with Central Railway and Western Railway suburban networks respectively.  âAs a norm, the originating station has the highest footfall. Sakinaka and Marol stations were third and fourth on the list with monthly footfalls of 14 lakh and 10 lakh respectively.  Both these locations are home to many business houses. 
In the pre-Mumbai Metro days, BEST bus number 340, which plies between Ghatkopar station (W) and Andheri station (E) was the most profitable route. Drunk woman lawyer rams Audi into cab on Eastern Freeway, kills 2  MUMBAI: An Audi driven at speed on the wrong side by a drunk woman hit a taxi headlong on the Eastern Freeway in the early hours of Tuesday.  So severe was the impact that the fire brigade had to be called to cut through mangled steel to pull out the taxiâs driver.  He and his front seat passenger didnât survive.  His three back seat passengers are in hospital with fractures and other injuries. 
The woman, Janhavi Ajit Gadkar (35), works in the legal cell of a top corporation at Nariman Point.  The deceased are taxi driver Hussain Sayyed (57) and soap trader Haji Salim Sabuwala (50).  The injured are Sabuwalaâs wife Hafeeza (45), daughter Sabiya (22) and son Noman (18). 
An RTO officer who examined the accident site and the vehicles involved said that looking at the impact, it seemed that both vehicles were at high speed, with the Audi clocking at least 120kmph.  He said Janhavi escaped injuries or death because of her carâs airbags. 
Around 7pm on Monday, Janhavi left her office with two colleagues for Hotel Marine Plaza, where she drank whisky.  They parted three hours later, but Janhavi spent time in her Audi Q3 on Marine Drive till around 12.30am. 
Then she started driving towards her Chembur flat, which is in an upmarket building near RK Studios.  She took P DâMello Road and then the Freeway, driving on the wrong side.  Half a kilometre before Panjarpol tunnel, near Shivaji Nagar Masjid, she grazed two cars before colliding with the taxi.  The accident occurred between 1.10 and 1.20am. 
The Sabuwalas, who live in Null Bazar, Nagpada, were returning from an eatery in Bhiwandi, where they had gone to celebrate son Nauman's success in the SSC exams. 
An eyewitness of the accident, who gave his name as Hassan, said, âI was returning with my family when the incident occurred.  I immediately got hold of the woman and called the RCF police.  Passers-by removed the injured taxi passengers and took them to Sion hospital.  We also called the fire brigade to free the driver.  Janhavi tried to hush up the matter by offering payment to the victims on the spot and telling us not to call the police. â
Dilip Raut of the RCF police said Janhavi was so drunk that she could barely stand.  âWe immediately sent her for medical tests.  The reports are awaited. â
Janhavi has been arrested under several sections of the IPC and the Motor Vehicle Act, including culpable homicide not amounting to murder and rash driving.  If convicted, she may get a maximum of ten years of rigorous imprisonment.  She has been remanded in police custody till Wednesday. 
Assistant commissioner of police Jeevaji Jadhav said, âThe road was almost empty.  Janhavi, driving under the influence of alcohol, did not realize her direction was wrong.  She entered the Freeway on the wrong side at its mouth at Masjid Bunder. â
Joint commissioner (law and order) Deven Bharti said the police have strong evidence and witnesses to prove the case against Janhavi.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News. Thane police crackdown on illicit brew  THANE: Seven persons including four women have been arrested who were allegedly found in possession of illicit liquor across Thane police commissionerate. 
In the wake of Malvani hooch tragedy, the Thane police raided — Bhiwandi, Kasarwadavali and Kapurbavdi area late on Saturday and Sunday. 
In Thane city, at four different locations, the Kapurbawdi police arrested three women and two men for allegedly possessing illicit brew worth Rs 690 and arrested Manjula Shinde, Gokula Dhamode and Anubai Meghe from Koknipada area.  Pramod Gharat was arrested from Chitalsar area late on Sunday night. 
Kamlakar Raut 37, who was operating a country liquor shop without any license beside a civic school in Kasarwadavali was arrested and liquor worth Rs 5000 was seized from his possession by Kasarwadavali police. 
The Kongaon police raided a secluded location behind an automobile store and found 100 litres of illicit raw materials.  The accused managed to flee the scene and none was arrested.  Simultaneously, Bhiwandi crime branch raided a house of Ankush Bhavare 35, in Kongaon area and seized liquor bottles worth Rs 625.  Bhiwandi city police arrested Parvati Gangurde from Padmanagar and found brew worth Rs 220. 
The police said that all of them have been booked under different sections of Bombay Prohibition Act.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.
