Malkanagiri receives 317.2 mm rainfall in 48 hours Heavy downpour triggered by depression over Bay of Bengal battered Odisha’s Malkanagiri district paralysing normal life and disrupting road communication badly. 
Malkanagiri recorded 317.2 mm of rainfall during past 48 hours which is enough to flood large parts of seven blocks in the district. 
According to office of Special Relief Commissioner, due to very heavy rainfall, communication to most part of the district was disrupted and flood water overtopped the roads and bridges at many places.  “Some villages especially in Kalimela and Korukonda blocks were marooned.  The telephone and mobile phone service was also partially affected,” the SRC office said. 
Korukonda block town of Malkanagiri, which had received 254 mm on Saturday, recorded 187 mm rainfall on Sunday.  Malkanagiri district headquarter town also recorded precipitation of 206 mm on Sunday. 
Reports from the district said situation improved as the rain stopped since Sunday morning.  “Connectivity on Jeypore and Malkangiri road has been restored as flood water has receded from Pangam Bridge and Saptadhara Bridge.  Similarly, connectivity from Malkangiri to Motu and Balimela has been made motorable.  It will take some more time for restoration of Kalimela-Padia road,” it said. 
Two units of Odisha Disaster Rapid Action Force (ODRAF) from third battalion of Odisha State Armed Police with 16 personnel and required equipment reached Malkangiri to assist the District Administration in search, rescue, road clearance and other relief operation. 
Besides, 99 fire services personnel also moved to Malkangiri with 13 power boats, 19 mechanical saws and 13 inflatable tower lights.  Dry food had been provided to people taking shelters at different places. 
Apart from Malkanagiri, other southern Odisha districts have received heavy rainfall during past 24 hours under influence of the depression.  Rainfall measuring 142.3 mm was recorded at Nabarangpur, Koraput (84mm), Gajapati (75.8mm), Rayagada (74.6mm) and Ganjam (70.9 mm).  Due to heavy rain, a diversion road near an under-construction bridge in Mohana block of Ganjapati district was swept away.

column1: Badarpur Junction
column2:
BG passenger trains likely to run from April Correspondent BADARPUR, March 4  Looking at the progress of the broad gauge works in the Lumding-Badarpur hill section and the line up to Silchar, it is expected that the passenger trains on the broad gauge line will run from April, said Ajit Pandit, NF Railway chief administrative officer. 
Talking to media persons here, Pandit said that in the new BG railway track a diesel engine will be run first from New Halflong to Badarpur and then up to Silchar on a trial basis from March 15 to 20.  After that a goods train will run on the track.  As per plan, if everything is found satisfactory then the passenger trains will run from April next which will be a Bihu gift to the people of Barak Valley. All pending works will be completed within the mega block period.  Further, the works at Badarpur Junction is going on in war footing, said Pandit, who came here to inspect the progress of work along with Rabindra Ram, NF Railway Chief Engineer, PK Das, Deputy Engineer of NF Railway (Construction), Silchar and several other high officials.  The officials inspected each and every department of the newly constructed railway station buildings and the three platforms which have been constructed with all modern amenities.  Talking about dismantling of the meter gauge track, earth works, track-linking, ballasting and packing of track, etc. , the official said that the progress of work has been quite satisfactory. 	Meanwhile, construction of major and minor bridges, road overbridges and underbridges, station buildings, platforms, etc. , have been completed and the final touch has to be given.  The works on the railway yards in Silchar and Badarpur have also been completed, the railway official said, adding that a large number of BG signal points have already been set up by the engineers of the signal department.  The railway official informed that all the 102 locations of broad gauge connection have already been completed.  Construction works at all the 17 tunnels in the Lumding-Badarpur hill section have also been completed and there is no problem at the tunnels, he said.  From Lumding to Silchar, the total length of the BG project is 210 km, and there are 17 tunnels.  This national project has 79 major bridges, 340 minor bridges, 28 railway stations and four halt stations.  Among the 28 railway stations, Lumding, New Haflong, Silchar and Badarpur railway stations have been identified as the most important railway stations.

column1: Kalan Masjid
column2:
Fifth road rage accused arrested  NEW DELHI: The fifth accused in the Turkman Gate road rage incident, who was evading arrest from the past three days, was finally arrested from the Trans-Yamuna area on Wednesday.  Police said the accused has been identified as Aminuddin alias Amin Pahalwan.  The car involved in the case has been impounded. 
On the day of the incident, Pahalwan (50) was returning with his son Shahdab in their Hyundai i20 from Seelampur after attending a wedding.  When Shehnawaz’s bike brushed against their car, it led to a heated argument.  The five accused then thrashed, kicked and beat up Shehnawaz brutally leading to his death. 
“Twelve teams were formed to arrest the accused.  He was finally caught by a team including inspectors Satinder Mohan (special staff), Yash Veer Singh, Anil Sharma and VN Jha.  We received a tip-off about Amin’s movement and nabbed him from Anand Vihar ISBT.  Amin has more than seven cases lodged against him, including one of rioting,” said Parmaditya, DCP (central). 
During interrogation, it was revealed that Pahalwan had actively provoked his son Shahdab to beat up Shehnawaz.  The other accused, Saleemuddin, started beating the victim after he saw them get into an argument.  Amin confessed that he got angry when the bike touched his car. 
Pahalwan is well-known in the Walled City, but as his name suggests he has never been a wrestler.  He has 22 siblings and all are involved in construction and property dealing businesses since 2010, police said.  Originally from Meerut, Pahalwan stays with his wife, three sons and two daughters.  The family is known as “Kali Duniya Ke Loag” in the Walled City.  A police officer said the family lives near Kalan Masjid.  As in local dialect Kalan becomes Kali, the family is known by this name. 
Pahalwan, a murder accused, was politically active and friends with Shoaib Iqbal, former MLA from Matia Mahal, until they got into an argument and he allegedly shot at him in 2011.  Later, he alienated himself from Iqbal and started supporting AAP, sources said.  Prior to 2011, another case was lodged against him in 2001.  Police said he was first arrested in 1995 in an attempt to murder case.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

column1: Morivali
column2:
Sena neta ambushed and hacked to death  AMBERNATH: A Shiv Sena corporator, Ramesh Gunjal (40), was hacked to death on a road in Ambernath on Friday .  Police sources said, before dying, Gunjal named 13 people, and police are now searching for them. 
The accused have been identified as Sachin Chavan, Pintya Gaikar, Ramdas Gaikar, Vishal Zaveri, Mayur Thackaray , Jagdiah Shetey , Deepak Kalimbe, Guddu Vargade, Omkar Gaikar, Keval Gaikar, Ajay Thackaray , Shankar Chalvadi and Ashish Shravane. 
All the accused have been charged with murder and under Arms Act. 
This was the 13th political killing in last 20 years in Ambernath city , popular for political rivalry . Most victims are from Shiv Sena, which has rival groups within the party itself. 
The police said Gunjal was a resident of Morivali village in Ambernath (west) and was a corpora tor from ward number 41in Ambernath (east). 
The police said on Friday around 10.15 am, Gunjal had gone to a nearby barber shop and was returning on his motorcycle when attackers dashed their car into his bike and attacked him with sharp weapons. 
Police sources said after the incident, Gunjal was lying injured on the ro ad for 10 minutes but no one came to his aid. 
Later, he somehow called up his supporters who then rushed him to a nearby private hospital.  Doctors shifted him to Shreedevi hospital in Kalyan where, around 2.30 pm, he died during treatment. 
“We have got some names revealed by Gunjal before he died and hunt for them is on,“ said Vasant Jadhav, deputy commissioner of police, Zone 4, Thane police. 
The police have also learnt the number of the vehicle used by the accused. Police sources said Gunjal was a labour contractor and had monoploy in the Ambernath MIDC area; he used to supply labourers to many construction sites. 
He also had political and personal rivalries with villagers in Morivali due to which they had bycotted him. 
Two years ago, Gunjal was attacked but he survived.  He also has many criminal cases registered against him in Ambernath police station including assault and robbery. 
The incident has led to tension in the area and shops remained closed in the locality.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

column1: Rabindra Sarovar
column2:
Minors gang-raped in New Alipore flat  KOLKATA: The Bansdroni police on Saturday arrested four youths from New Alipore, Behala and Thakurpukur for allegedly gang-raping two minor girls at a New Alipore flat on Thursday night. 
The accused had promised the girls â students of Class IX â an outing, but took them to the flat in New Alipore instead and raped them all through the night, says the complaint.  The two girls are close friends and study in a well known school. 
According to police, the girls came in contact with the prime accused, 20-year-old Anik Bhattacharya, on a social networking site.  He had allegedly used the âHokkolorobâ platform to befriend them.  Over time, the accused introduced some of his other friends to the girls. 
On Wednesday, Anik asked the girls to meet him and a few of his friends at Rabindra Sarovar on Thursday, say police.  The teenage girls agreed as they knew Anik and his group. 
When the girls didnât return home in time, their family started looking for them but drew a blank.  The families then lodged separate missing personâs complaints with Bansdroni police. 
Police said that after the girls met the accused at Sarovar, the youths executed the âsecond part of the planâ.  Anik allegedly lured the girls to visit his house in the upscale P-block of New Alipore.  Once there, the accused allegedly confined the two minors in a room and took turns to rape them throughout the night. 
According to the FIR, a copy of which is with TOI, the youths allegedly forced the schoolgirls to visit other places with them and clicked objectionable photographs of them.  They threatened to make these photographs public if the girls went to police, says the complaint. 
On Friday morning, the two girls returned home, battered and traumatized.  They stayed silent for most of the day but broke down in the evening and told their parents. 
After a case was registered at Bansdroni police station, the officers worked jointly with their counterparts at New Alipore.  Anik and his friend Avishek Tarafdar, a resident of Behalaâs Banamali Naskar Road, were arrested from Anikâs house on Saturday.  Their questioning led to the arrest of Sanket Ghosh (19) from Narkeldanga.  The cops rounded up a fourth accused, Soumajit Das alias Raj (18), from Thakurpukur. 
âWe have produced them in court.  The accused have been sent to police custody till March 26.  We have charged them with gang rape, criminal conspiracy, being procurator of a minor girl, wrongful confinement, watching a woman in a private act, criminal intimidation and sections 3 and 4 of the stringent POCSO Act that deals with sexual offences committed against minors,â said Santosh Pandey, DC, south suburban. 
Police sources said they have received complaints that the accused may have operated a racket in the garb of a friendship club.  âWe will look into this allegation too,â said an officer.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Calcutta Medical Research Institute launches ICU on-the-go  KOLKATA: The C K Birla Hospitals on Friday rolled out a fleet of ambulances with in-built ICU and facilities for transmission of patient’s vitals on the go, live monitoring via webcam and life-saving equipments and drugs.  Mayor Sovon Chatterjee and police commissioner Surajit Kar Purakayastha flagged off the ambulances at CMRI. 
The ambulances will be stationed at seven locations — Victoria Memorial, Park Circus, Sarat Bose Road, Hazra, Rabindra Sarovar, Howrah and Joka.  On this new fleet, medical care will be administered on the spot by trained paramedics, who will be guided by doctors via live video-streaming.  The live audio-video screening facility will connect the ambulance to the team of emergency care doctors at the hospital, which will also enable the team at the hospital to be prepared for the arriving patient, thereby mitigating any delays in the medical care, said hospital authorities.  The ambulances are also equipped to transmit ECG results and other vital parameters to the medical staff, so treatment for conditions like myocardial infarction and stroke can start on the ambulance itself, they pointed out. 
Chatterjee said: “It’s a big boost to medical facilities in Kolkata.  I’m more excited as five years ago, when I became mayor for the first time, I had an amnesty scheme where we raised some funds.  Now, with the Mamata Banerjee government in power, there are 21 trauma ambulances at various points of the city.  With these seven ambulances, it’s a step forward as they are state-of-the-art and we don’t have the infrastructure to have such advanced facilities in our ambulances. ”
Purakayastha recounted an overseas experience to explain the crucial role of an ambulance in the case of an accident.  “Several years ago, I was in an exchange program in the UK.  While having an interaction with a British cop at Leeds, we witnessed an accident.  When it happens here, we wait for the police to take the victim to hospital.  But there the cops did nothing.  I was surprised.  In less than 90 seconds, the siren of an ambulance was heard.  As soon as the victim was picked up, the police cordoned off the area and started investigating,” said the police commissioner. 
“In the UK, work areas are clearly defined and people are assigned to specific jobs.  That is a sign on developed nation.  Policemen are not trained to handle patients with serious injuries.  Mishandling can put the victim’s life at risk.  Lives lost in accidents are very high in Kolkata.  Even a single life saved is invaluable,” he added. 
Purakayastha then requested CMRI to plan an ambulance scheme for the Kolkata Police initiative ‘Pronam’ for senior citizens.  The hospital’s vice-president (operations) Jashodhara Ghosh responded: “We are happy to confirm our participation. ” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Tree hacked, rare birds lose their habitat  It was a condolence meeting for an untimely death of a tree that proved shelter for rare migratory birds at Rabindra Sarovar which blossomed into a spontaneous movement on Sunday morning.  The rare birds, they rued, would not come back again.  After setting a precedence in creating awareness, the organisers, a motely group of bird-watchers, morning walkers and nature lovers, now want to take the movement forward to ensure that whoever, an individual or government agency think twice before hacking a tree in a park or on the road side. 
The organisers put a wreath on the remainder of the hacked full-grown Segun tree (teak) at Safari Park, at Rabindra Sarovar, but the wide array of emotions it evoked on Sunday morning was quite extra-ordinary.  It was an opportunity for nature lovers to drive home the point that the loss was irreversible and it is high time to zero in on the perpetrators and punish them. 
“The hacking of the tree is shocking as we kept informing Safari Park officials how the small patch of land in the Safari Park has become a sanctuary of rare migratory birds.  We spotted on September 9 Indian Paradise Flycatcher, on 10 Brown Breasted Flycatcher, on 12, Asian Brown Flycatcher on 27 Forest Wagtail and on the same day a pair of Bluethroats,” said Sudip Ghosh, an avid bird-watcher, who was pleasantly surprised by the arrival of the rare guests.  “Where else in Kolkata could you find them?” he asked. 
“But to our shock, on September 29, we found the dense habitat completely destroyed.  Shegun trees and fruit bearing trees, thickets, undergrowth all cleared.  They could never gauge the irreversible damage they caused.  The birds would just fly away once they look down,” rued D J Ckakraborty, another passionate bird-watcher.  Their environment needs undergrowth, dead trees, thickets, bushes and not just lawns.  Safari park is a unique place where morning walkers and birds can live peacefully just that they need that small space, he added. 
S K Dubey, a keeper of the Lions Safari Park, owns up the responsibility of hacking the tree.  “I did not understand it, my mistake. ” But nature lovers are ready to accept his apology.  “He hacked it because it is Segun, knowing the value of timber.  It cannot be one-of-case.  They must have smuggled out many such trees,” said Chakraborty.  Environmentalists, who examined the natural damage, filed a complaint with the Lake Police Station on Friday 2 October 2015. 
“When inspected by nature-lovers on Friday morning, the tree stump was still oozing sap, indicating that the murder was recent.  The Safari Park showed ample evidence of the tree stem and branches being piled for onward disposal.  The evident reason for the hacking of the trees was the need for ‘forest’ clearance masterminded by the Lions Club of North Kolkata and the consequent ‘development’ of Safari Park,” said Mudar Patherya, another environmentalist. 
The increasing attempts of converting a naturally grown urban forest into a manicured park are evident all over the Safari Park.  A concrete base of a fountain has come up at a place where full grown tree once existed.  “The problem begins when we start thinking that even the nature belongs to us only.  All other creatures exist because of us.  So, we tend to bulldoze when nature does not conform our utilities,” said nature activist Arjan Basu Roy. 
Susmita Banerjee, a court appointed authority for Rabindra Sarovar’s greenery, tried to down play significance of the condolence meeting.  “I admit that a tree was hacked.  It is indeed a mistake.  But these people are trying make a mountain out of a mole. ” But her comment only drew the wrath of the nature lovers at the Park.  Please first read the laws and the legal provisions against their violations,” said Sanchita Dey.  Another campaigner.  The Safari Park, which enjoys a 300m frontage on Southern Avenue, has been leased for maintenance purposes by Kolkata Improvement Trust, a government body that owns the 192 acre Rabindra Sarobar. 
In the last couple of years, the Lions Club of North Kolkata has ‘developed’ Safari Park through concrete investments in a musical fountain, congregation platforms, deities of goddesses (transforming the park into an open air place of worship for members of a specific community) and home for the gardener.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Kolkata Metro Puja gift: Wi-Fi & app to track trains  KOLKATA: Metro rolled out free Wi-Fi at Park Street and Maidan stations on Tuesday and promised to extend it along the length of the network very soon. 
Along with Puja gift came the announcement that Metro will run a record 738 services during the festive days, starting at 1.40pm on October 20, 21 and 22 and continuing till 4 am on October 22.  On October 23, services end at 11pm.  Metro has also launched an app through which passengers can track trains and stay updated about special services. 
“We’ll run 200 services each on Saptami, Ashtami and Navami, and 138 on Dashami.  Special security arrangements have been made,” said Metro Railway general manager A K Kapoor, adding that an additional lift is being installed at Dum Dum and centralized AC plants have come up at Kalighat and Rabindra Sarovar. 
Kapoor said that more counters will be manned during the Pujas to sell paper tickets to pandal hoppers.  No tokens will be issued during the Pujas to prevent confusion among first time users.  Metro has received proposals from two cellular firms to introduce seamless service along the route.  They will use the Metro’s co-axial leaky cable in the tunnels.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Commandos, ladies squads to be deployed by Kolkata Metro during Pujas  KOLKATA: Metro Railway will deploy a commando unit and three women squads for security during the four days of the Pujas this year.  A ‘striking reserve’ will also be stationed at Metro Bhavan to rush to any spot in case of an emergency.  The security personnel will be deployed in two shifts from 1.30pm to 4.30am, an official said. 
“This year, we will deploy 415 security personnel every day between October 20 and October 24.  In 2014, we deployed 350 security personnel.  They will be deployed in two shifts, from 1.30pm to 9.30pm and 9.30pm to 4.30am.  We shall also have three ladies squads comprising 11 personnel each.  These will be stationed at Dumdum, Sovabazar and Kalighat.  We have selected these stations as there is a lot of rush there during the Pujas.  Each squad will comprise a lady officer and five lady constables.  Every squad will also have five more constables.  They may be male or female, depending upon availability.  Last year, there was only one such squad for the entire stretch,” said Indrani Banerjee, Sr PRO, Metro Railway. 
The commando unit that will be deployed at Kalighat will comprise a dozen personnel.  According to Banerjee, the unit will have 11 trained commandos led by an officer.  They will also work both shifts and move to any station if there is trouble.  The ladies squads will be deployed on platforms, particularly after evening and throughout the night to check molestation and other crime against women. 
“We are also taking steps to prevent all sorts of crime including attempts by subversive elements to disrupt services.  The ‘striking reserve’ at our headquarters will remain alert to react to any situation.  The personnel will rush to any station at a moment’s notice.  In 2014, we had concentrated our security staff at Dumdum, Mahatma Gandhi Road, Chandni Chowk, Esplanade and Rabindra Sadan.  Apart from these stations, there will be deployments at Sovabazar, Jatin Das Park and Rabindra Sarovar this year.  We have added these three stations as well as there were huge crowds there last year.  Apart from all this, there will be special monitoring by the Kolkata Police.  Metro authorities will co-ordinate with all agencies to ensure a safe Puja for passengers,” Banerjee added.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  88-feet Durga idol at Kolkata's Deshapriya Park finds place in Limca Book of Records KOLKATA: After going down in the history of Durga Puja as the pandal that closed down midway into the festival, the much touted 88 feet Durga idol at Deshapriya Park is adding another first to its lists.  The tallest ever Durga idol in the world has now found a place for itself in the Limca Book of Records, Asian Book of Records and Indian Book of Records.  It may also lead its way to the Guinness World Records. 
The idol, like its counterparts in the city, will not vanish into oblivion.  This fibreglass idol will be dismantled and re-assem bled at its new address.  It could be Eco Park or Rabindra Sarovar or any other place in the city.  Keeping in mind the huge traffic that brought the city to a standstill, the key criteria to find the goddess a new home would be traffic control capacities in the area.  The Durga Puja committee would be meeting on Tuesday evening to take a call on the same alongside deciding who walks away with the idol. 
Apart from the sole sponsors of the puja -Star Cement, others in the race to take up the preservation are city industrialists like Harshavardhan Neotia, the Birlas and several others whose names could not be ascertained.  Relocation of the idol would also call for a bit of remodeling in terms of the basic structure support. 
“A temporary bamboo structure was made because the idol was to be around only for the pujas.  A steel structure will have to be made to support the gigantic idol and ensure that it stays safe against natural calamities,“ said Sanjay Agarwal, director, Star Cement. 
Star Cement, the cement manufacturing company promoted by the Kolkata based Century Plyboards group, had invested Rs 6 crore in running the three-month close to long campaign promoting not just the Deshapriya Park puja but also the company.  The move was part of Star Cement's brand building exercise to increase its foothold in eastern India.  The campaign that ran across West Bengal, Assam, Meghalaya, Agartala, Jharkhand and Bihar was designed by JWT who are pulling up their socks to design a fresh campaign revolving around the same idol.  However, this time the budget would be tighter.  The new campaign would be unveiled by the end of the week. 
Despite the controversy surrounding the puja, the sponsors (Star Cement) seems to have achieved targets in terms of grabbing eyeballs.  Thanks to the frenzy the campaign created, Star Cement is now a household name, at least in Bengal, added Agarwal.

column1: Lakhan Ke Padde
column2:
Badals bent upon framing Congress leaders in false cases: Bajwa CHANDIGARH: Accusing SAD of indulging in " political vendetta" , Congress today alleged that the top leadership of the ruling party was " conspiring"  to implicate its leaders in false cases to gag the opposition voice. 
Punjab Congress president Partap Singh Bajwa slammed Chief Minister Parkash Singh Badal and his son and Deputy Chief Minister Sukhbir Singh Badal alleging that they were " intimidating, threatening and gaging voice of opposition" . 
The " Badal government is conspiring to frame"  Congress spokesperson Sukhpal Singh Khaira in a drug case, Bajwa said at a press meet here, also attended by former MLA Khaira, AICC secretary Kuljeet Singh Nagra and two other sitting MLAs. 
Khaira had been vocal against the Badal family for their alleged " corrupt, tyrannical and unconstitutional rule. " 
Unable to bear the brunt of the frontal attack launched by Congress, the Badal duo and their " police militia"  have once again embarked on their favorite political vendetta drive, by singling out important party functionaries to gag the voice of the opposition, Bajwa alleged. 
Khaira said the Badal regime has registered six " false FIRs"  against him during the past few years.  " Not content with this political victimisation of Khaira and unable to coerce him into silence, the Badals are now conspiring to register more criminal cases against him,"  Bajwa said. 
Khaira said police had recently arrested former sarpanch of Lakhan Ke Padde village in Fazilka Gurdev Singh.  " Police under political pressure recorded a false statement of Gurdev Singh after torturing him to implicate Khaira in the drug case,"  Bajwa said. 
The Badals have also " falsely implicated"  two Independent MLAs from Ludhiana, who are brothers, recently, he claimed. 
Bajwa said Congress would soon meet the Governor to apprise him of this " political vendetta"  against party functionaries and demanded that Special Investigation Teams be formed to look into the links of the Badals and Revenue Minister Bikram Singh Majithia with drug smugglers. 
Khaira said " soon the government is going to book me in false cases, they have withdrawn by security cover and I am pretty sure that they are going to physically eliminate me by way of road accident as so many accidents take place. " 
Meanwhile, Khaira ruled our joining Aam Aadmi Party.  He, however, admitted that at one point of time he wanted to join AAP as his NRI supporters asked him to do so.  " But seeing AAP functioning as they expelled their founder members and dictatorial attitude, I decided to not to go ahead and decided to remain in Congress,"  Khaira said.

column1: Manakudi Road
column2:
Collector inspects rain affected areas Collector Sajjansingh R.  Chavan inspected the rain affected areas in Kanyakumari district on Saturday, along with revenue officials, as the wet spell provided a respite.  He inspected the Pechiparai dam, Paraliar old bridge, Tiruvattar, Mangadu, Alavilai and Thengaipattinam
As PWD released excess water from major Pechiparai and Perunchani dams, heavy flow was noticed in the Kuzhithuraiyar, Kothaiyar, Valliyar and Paraliyar.  Bathing in Thirparappu falls was banned due to flooding. 
Safety concerns
The Chief Engineer (Madurai Region) of PWD, P. L.  Valliyappan, Superintending Engineer (Tamirabharani Circle) K. A.  Abdul Hameed and Executive Engineer (WRO) S. K.  Subramani inspected the safety of Pechiparai, Perunchani, Chittar I and II dams. 
Water level
Water level of Pechiparai dam was at 45.90 feet, with an inflow of 683 cusecs and discharge of 1013 cusecs.  Level in Perunchani dam was 74.88 feet and the reservoir had an inflow of 713 cusecs.  The outflow was maintained at 300 cusecs. 
Houses damaged
As many as 58 houses have been partially damaged in rain-related incidents across the district since the onset of monsoon. 
The slow-paced under ground drainage (UGD) work has added to the woes of the public in Nagercoil, as trenches have been filled up with rain water.  WCC Road, MS Road, Meenakshipuram, Beach Road and Manakudi Road have become unmotorable. 
Pot holes have also developed in the newly laid National Highway from Kavalkinaru to Kalyakavilai at many places. 
PWD officials inspect the safety of Pechiparai, Perunchani, Chittar I and II dams

column1: Sohansadar
column2: Tortured for dowry, newlywed woman ends life  FEROZEPUR: Harassed by her husband and his family for bringing less dowry, a newlywed woman allegedly committed suicide by consuming poison at her in-laws' house in Nihalewala village in Ferozepur on Sunday night.  In his complaint to the police, victim's father Gurjant Singh, a resident of Sohansadar village of Fazilka district, said his daughter Vandana got married to Mangat Singh in December last year and sufficient dowry was given at the time of wedding.  He claimed that Mangat, a drug addict, and his parents allegedly drove his daughter to take the extreme step.  Police have registered a case of abetment to suicide under Section 306 of the IPC against Mangat, his two family members.  No arrest had been made so far.  The autopsy has been conducted at Ferozepur civil hospital. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

Stating this at the inaugural session of an awareness programme on Shodhganga, a digital repository of theses and dissertations of higher education set up by the Ahmedabad-based Information Library Network (INFLIBNET), under the University Grants Commission, at the university on Thursday, Vice-Chancellor K.  Byrappa said that trials have been conducted by providing the service in certain places within the campus.  It would fully become operational by the month-end. 
Mr.  Byrappa said that the e-portal of the university would be operational within a month.  It would take the university closer to e-Governance.  He said that the e-portal would be interactive and more vibrant than the website now. 
Best lectures given by experts in various sectors in the university would be made available in the e-portal in phases.  Once it becomes operational, the university would switch over to e-governance in phases. 
In the first phase, it would enable filing of applications to avail of various services of the university on-line.  It would help in speeding up the administration.  Engagements Mangaluru

Four A garden of 190 plants of the Western Ghats tree species grown from irradiated seeds (exposed to Gamma rays) has come up on the Mangalagangotri campus of Mangalore University.  It boasts of plants of six species endemic to the Western Ghats, planted three months ago. 
It was the result of a four-year research project on ‘radiation effect on forest tree species’ by the Department of Applied Botany at the university under a Rs.  65-lakh project granted from the Board of Research in Nuclear Sciences (BRNS) under the Department of Atomic Energy.  It is said to be the first such study on forest species in the country. 
K. R.  Chandrashekar, professor, Department of Applied Botany and Principal Investigator of the project, said that seeds of 14 tree species of the Western Ghats belonging to 10 families were irradiated. 
The purpose was to evaluate the impact on the germination physiology and biochemical constituents of the seeds.  Irradiation has led to faster germination and faster growth with vigour in case of three species. 
Of the 14 species, six species were endemic to the Western Ghats, two belonged to the endangered category, two were threatened and four were wild medicinal plants. 
The samples were collected from their wild habitat and subjected to Gamma irradiation using the doses ranging from 25-300 Grays (a unit for measuring absorbed radiation). 
He said the forest plants have been classified for the first time on the basis of their response to Gamma radiation as tolerant, moderately sensitive and sensitive species. 
Tolerant plants can withstand certain doses of radiation and also show faster germination and faster growth.  For example, dormant wild species such as  Canarium strictum (dhoopa),  Terminalia chebula (alale) and  Terminalia arjuna (arjuna). 
The university will, in future, study whether irradiation has changed the medicinal properties of the plants. 
The BRNS has given “in-principle approval” to sanction Rs.  35 lakh for the study.  Additionally, more wild species endemic to Western Ghats will be taken up for seed irradiation.  Bio Mangalore University will introduce bio-metric with face interface attendance registering system for its students on its Mangalagangotri campus and its two constituent colleges from the academic year 2015-16. 
It would be introduced for teachers and non-teaching staff within two months from now, said Vice-Chancellor K.  Byrappa. 
Now 75 per cent attendance in each subject in an academic year is mandatory for a student to appear for any examination. 
The Academic Council in its meeting agreed to conduct special classes for foreign students of the university to meet the requirement of attendance as they usual join late after fulfilling certain requirements of the Ministry of External Affairs.  If they missed the semester examinations they could sit for them the next time, the council said.  Discussion on ‘Contribution of Mangalore University in regional development’ Media Alumni Association of Mangalagangotri, Mangalore University will hold a panel discussion on ‘Contribution of Mangalore University in Regional Development’ in the city on April 26, a release said. 
P. S.  Yadapadithaya, Registrar (administration), K.  Chinnappa Gowda, professor in Kannada at the University, Sripathi Tantri, a former member of the Syndicate of the university and Norbert Lobo, president, Association of Mangalore University College Teachers will take part in the discussion. The association was formed recently on the occasion of Department of Mass Communication and Journalism at the university completing 25 years, the release added. Mangalore University to adopt villages for study Mangalore University is planning to adopt some villages for carrying out sector-specific studies and providing guidance for development, its Vice-Chancellor K.  Byrappa said here on Sunday. 
Replying to questions at a discussion on ‘Contributions of Mangalore University in Regional Development’, organised by Media Alumni Association of Mangalagangotri, the Vice-Chancellor said that the villages would be selected in Dakshina Kannada, Udupi and Kodagu districts, the jurisdiction of the University.  “It is my dream,” the Vice-Chancellor said. 
He said that final semester students doing project works would be directed to visit such villages and submit study-based project works after identifying the issues. 
Mr.  Byrappa said that the University would ensure that more than 100 foreign students studied in its campus from the academic year 2015-16. 
He said that the University would release its vision 2030 document on its foundation day on September 10 this year.  The document would be prepared in consultation with experts in different sectors across the country. 
B. M.  Hegde, the former Vice-Chancellor, of the erstwhile Manipal Academy of Higher Education (now Manipal University), said that government control over universities should go and there should be autonomy to impart quality education.  “Now universities have become agents of the government,” he said, adding that the government should stop nominating its members (political appointments) to academic councils and syndicates of the university and instead should allow the university to select the members from among experts. 
Sripati Tantri, a former member of the Syndicate of the University, said that the University should introspect on whether it was imparting quality education. 
K.  Chinnappa Gowda, a professor of Kannada and the former Registrar (administration) of the University, said that the University in all these years has been able to identify traditional knowledge system of the region and foster it.  P. S.  Yadapadithaya, Registrar (administration), said that the university would shortly organise an open house to showcase its strength. 
Earlier, Manohar Prasad was felicitated on the occasion for his three decades of service as a journalist.  After felicitating him, the Vice-Chancellor announced that the University would appoint him as an adjunct professor at the university. 
Mangalore University will have a single entry point to its campus after 7 p. m.  after some months, said Vice-Chancellor K Byrappa. 
At a function here on Sunday he said that it would be done for security purposes.  The university is now taking steps for making a single entry point as researchers and students would be studying late in the night.  Mangalore University to conduct ‘open house’ on June 12, 13 Mangalore University, accredited with an A grade from the National Assessment and Accreditation Council (NAAC), will host for the first time next week, an open house to showcase its strength for the graduates who intend to join post-graduation courses in any of its institutions. 
The open house, a popular concept in foreign countries, would be conducted on June 12 and 13 at its Mangalagangotri campus, said K.  Chinnappa Gowda, professor and senior dean, and K. R.  Chandrashekar, professor and co-ordinator for the open house. 
According to Mr.  Chandrashekar, the university is the first among conventional universities in the State to conduct such a programme. 
Mr.  Gowda said the university offered 35 post-graduation courses through 27 departments on its campus, two colleges owned by it and at its post-graduation centre at Chikka Aluvara in Kodagu district. 
Degree holders and their parents could visit each department on the open house days and interact with faculty members on the scope of the courses, employment opportunities, specialisation available, past placements of students, etc. 
He said the university offered hostel, gym, sports, laboratory and library facilities.  It had about 18 study chairs that organised series of lectures by eminent persons.  It had many teachers with Ph. D.  degrees.  Such facilities would expose students to a better academic atmosphere. 
He said students in many colleges were not aware of the facilities available at the university.  If they got familiarised with the facilities it would help them take a decision on whether to join a post-graduation course of their choice in a degree college nearest to them or at the university. 
Visiting the departments and interacting with faculty members would help them shed inhibitions. 
Mr.  Chandrashekar said that each department would have their profiles to showcase their strength.  There would be help-desks to guide students and parents.  Highlights of each department would be exhibited through boards. 
Mr.  Gowda said the government wanted to increase the gross enrolment ratio of students to higher education.  Conducting an open house could prompt students to enrol for post-graduation courses.  Organising it was the brainchild of K.  Byrappa, Vice-Chancellor. 
The open house would be conducted between 10 a. m.  and 5 p. m.  If required, it would be extended to June 14.  Briefly Teacher training workshop
The International Geoscience Education Organisation would be organising a teacher training workshop at the Geological Survey of India, Mangaladevi Temple Road, between July 7 and 10, for teachers who teach earth science topics to students of high school.  The workshop would be conducted by renowned earth science educators — Nir Orion from Israel and Chris King from the UK.  There is no registration fee.  Interested teachers may send in their application by email through their heads of institutions torshankar_1@yahoo. comor send by regular mail to R.  Shankar, Professor of Marine Geology, Mangalore University, Mangalagangotri, 574199 before June 20.  For details, call Prof.  Shankar on 9916823885. 
Fee concession
Brilliant PU College, Mangaluru, administered by Shrividya Education Foundation, has been offering attractive concessions to meritorious students.  Institute Chairman Ram Mohan Rai has said students scoring 98 per cent and above in SSLC would get full concession in fees of college, coaching and hostel; those scoring above 95 per cent would get full concession in college fee; those scoring above 85 per cent would get 50 per cent concession in college fee and those scoring above 75 per cent would get 25 per cent concession in college fee.  Besides these, scholarships too would be provided to students based on their SSCL scoring.  Admissions are now underway for the PU courses.  For details, contact the college at PVS Centenary Building, Kudmul Ranga Rao Road, Kodialbail, Mangaluru (Phone: 08242495995/ 9945238106). 
RTA meeting postponed
The meeting of Dakshina Kannada Regional Transport Authority, scheduled for Thursday, has been postponed to June 25.  The postponement was necessitated due to the ongoing process of fixing reservation for gram panchayat heads, said an official release. 
Power shutdown
in Udupi
Power supply would be affected in Adi Udupi and surrounding areas on Friday between 9.30 a. m.  and 5.30 p. m . following urgent repair works on Bannanje and Ambalapadi feeders.  Areas affected are — Adi Udupi, Pandubettu, Kalmadi, Malpe town and port, Madhwanagar, Nayarkere, Kadabettu, Ambalapadi, Kinnimulki, Kannarpadi, Ajjarkad and surrounding areas.  Mangalore University to declare degree results tomorrow Mangalore University will announce the results of its undergraduate examinations conducted in April-May on June 12, at the inaugural day of its ‘open house’ at the campus.  But students will be able to view them by logging on to the university’s website only in the university campus at Mangalagangotri through WiFi-enabled network. 
The results will be available on the internet on the university’s websitewww. mangaloreuniversity. ac. in on June 14, according to K.  Byrappa, Vice-Chancellor. 
Announcing this to media here on Wednesday, Mr.  Byrappa said that students and parents visiting the campus on June 12 and June 13 during the ‘open house’ can see the results using free WiFi facility to be provided on those two days. 
The ‘open house’ would be organised to showcase the strength and facilities at the university to those graduates who would like to join the postgraduate courses offered by the university at the institutions owned by it. 
He said that the results of 77,608 students who appeared for the examinations of undergraduate courses in April-May would be out on May 12.  It would include results of 37,994 B. Com.  students, 6,019 B,Sc.  students, 3,674 BCA students and 816 BSW students and students who appeared for examinations of other courses. 
He said that the decision to not post the results on the internet on June 12 has been taken consciously to attract undergraduate students to the university campus to the ‘open house’. 
This way, the students could visit the departments of their choice to know more about the postgraduate courses. 
Foreign students
The Vice-Chancellor said that the university has planned to admit 150 foreign students to postgraduate courses and research during the academic year 2015-16.  This would be in addition to about 20 students admitted during 2014-15. 
He said that the university has received 540 applications from foreign students seeking admission.  The applicants were from 32 countries.  Of them, 150 would be admitted.  The university would shortly begin constructing international house, a hostel, for foreign students in its campus. 
The Vice-Chancellor said that 1,543 post-graduate seats in 24 departments having 37 post-graduate courses were available in the university and at institutes owned by it for 2015-16.  Engagements Mangaluru

Mangalore varsity yet to upload exam results Students of undergraduate courses of Mangalore University, who were expecting the results of their examinations conducted in April-May, were disappointed as the varsity did not upload the results on the internet on Sunday as promised earlier. 
Vice-Chancellor K.  Byrappa and the Registrar (Evaluation) B.  Narayana had told media here on Wednesday that the results would be made available on the internet after the two-day open house on the campus, which ended on Saturday. 
The varsity had made available the results through free Wi-Fi network on the Mangalagangotri campus on June 12 and June 13.  Results of B. Com. , BBM, BSW, BCA and B. Sc.  courses were made available. 
The Registrar (Evaluation) told The Hindu on Sunday that results of all courses including B. A.  would be uploaded on the internet either on June 18 or June 19.  He said that the B. A.  course had 144 combinations.  Hence, uploading the results would require some time.  Results of all courses would be uploaded at a time, he said. 
Mr.  Narayana said that results of other undergraduate courses were available on the university campus now through Intranet.  Students could log on to the university websitewww. mangalore university. ac. inin any of the computers in the campus to know the results. 
Convocation
Meanwhile, the university is expected to announce the names of persons who would receive its honorary doctorates at the 33rd annual convocation scheduled on January 17, on the previous day (Tuesday) of the convocation. 
The authorities had promised to upload them on Sunday
‘Results available through Intranet on varsity campus’ University planning PG centre at Hiriyadkka After laying the foundation stone for an advanced science research centre at Belapu village in Udupi district recently, Mangalore University is now planning to open a postgraduate centre in the district. 
Addressing presspersons on Tuesday, K.  Byrappa, Vice-Chancellor, said that the university was examining the possibility of opening the centre at the Government First Grade College at Hiriyadkka, Udupi district. 
Discussion held
The college had 11 acres of land.  Adjoining the college, the university had identified about 39 acres suitable for the centre.  The Syndicate of the university had held a discussion on the issue. 
He said the centre would not be opened in the current academic year.  If all goes as per plans, it could be opened from the next academic year. 
Mr.  Byrappa said the university would offer postgraduate courses in Hindi and Sanskrit on the Mangalagangotri campus from the current academic year. 
A degree college, which would be a constituent college of the university, would be started at Konaje from the current academic year.  It would have B. A.  and B. Com.  courses. 
The evening college to be opened at the University College, Hampankatta, from the 2015-16 academic year, would also offer B. A.  and B. Com.  courses. 
Integrated course
He said that the university had introduced a five-year integrated course in tourism at its Field Marshal K. M.  Cariappa College. 
A student joining the course after II PU and completing first year would get a diploma in tourism; after second year an advanced diploma; and a BBM degree after three years; a honours degree after four years and an MBA in integrated tourism after five years. 
In addition, a two-year postgraduate course in MBA (tourism administration) too has been started at FMKMC College. 
A second batch for the evening M. Com.  course would be started at University College if there was demand, he added.  University to offer courses in yogic sciences Mangalore University will offer certificate and diploma courses in yogic sciences at its University College in the city from this August, according to K.  Byrappa, Vice-Chancellor. 
Speaking to presspersons on the sidelines of the International Yoga Day celebrations at the University on Sunday, he said that the certificate course would be of six months and diploma course would be of one year. 
Minimum qualification
The classes would be conducted from 6.30 a. m.  to 8.30 a. m.  There would be no upper age limit to join the courses.  The minimum qualification to join the courses would be pass in the SSLC. 
The University has been offering a regular postgraduation course (M. Sc. ) in Human Consciousness and Yogic Sciences at the University campus in Mangalagangotri for over a decade. 
It was the pioneer university in the State to offer a M. Sc.  course in yoga with yoga therapy. 
Earlier, addressing a gathering during the celebrations, the Vice-Chancellor said that the need of the hour was to study the biochemical reactions in the body after doing yoga and document them.  There was a need to conduct research on this aspect and publish the findings, he said. 
Yoga lab
The Vice-Chancellor said that Govardhan Mehta, former director, Indian Institute of Science (IISc), Bengaluru, who visited the university campus last week, showed keen interest in the M. Sc.  course in yoga offered by the university and suggested to set up a full-fledged laboratory to study the biological changes in body after yoga scientifically. 
The faculty of the Department of Human Consciousness and Yogic Sciences taught simple yoga to teachers, non-teaching staff and students at the university campus on the occasion.  No entrance test for certain courses Mangalore University, henceforth, will not conduct entrance tests for such postgraduation courses, which have received applications below the sanctioned intake seats. 
The academic council of the university, in a special meeting on Saturday, endorsed a decision taken to this effect at a meeting of chairpersons of different departments on July 17. 
K.  Byrappa, Vice-Chancellor, told the academic council meeting that the university conducted entrance tests for admission to some postgraduate courses.  There was no point in conducting entrance tests for such courses, if the number of applicants was below the number of sanctioned seats. 
The tests would have to be conducted only if the applications exceeded the sanctioned number of seats.  The academic council decided not to introduce revised syllabi for undergraduate and postgraduate courses offered under correspondence mode from the current academic year.  It was because the study material of those courses, as per the revised syllabi, was not ready. 
Hence, the courses would be offered as per the old (existing) syllabi.  The meeting was told that the council had, in its earlier meetings, approved the revised syllabi of various courses offered by the Directorate of Correspondence Courses.  Though the syllabi were ready, some expert teachers have not yet submitted the study material. 
Hence, the revised syllabi would be implemented from the academic year 2016-17. 
The council approved the draft statute governing the establishment of University Evening College at the University College premises, Hampankatta, and creation of 27 posts, including that of principal and 13 assistant professors. 
It approved the draft statute for establishing University First Grade College at university campus, Mangalagangotri, and creation of 27 posts. 
It decided to sanction an additional M. Com.  batch for G.  Shankar Government Women’s First Grade College, Udupi, for 2015-16, with certain conditions. 
To a question by a member, B.  Narayana, Registrar (Evaluation) said that the results of re-evaluation of answer scripts of undergraduate courses would be announced within August 2.  When Amrut Shenoy, a member, asked about the revised examination manual not being uploaded on the website and teachers not having access to it, Mr.  Narayana said that it would be uploaded shortly. 
‘No point in conducing test
if number of applicants is less than number of sanctioned seats’ ABVP stages protest demanding payment category fee reduction Activists of the Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP) staged a dharna on the Mangalagangotri campus of Mangalore University on Monday urging the university to reduce payment category fees of various postgraduate courses for 2015-16. 
They squatted in front of the Mangala auditorium, where a six-day centralised counselling for admission to postgraduate courses began from Monday. 
In a memorandum submitted to the university, Jayesh P. K. , city unit secretary, ABVP, said that the university had reduced the fees hiked only for merit category seats but not for payment category seats.  According to the university now, the hike in fees for merit category seats was 10 to 12 per cent from what it was during 2014-15.  He said that all courses had limited number of merit category seats. 
Hence all applicants could not get seats under merit category.  There were many students from economically poor sections of the society who would be deprived from getting admission as the payment category fees still stood high. 
The memorandum said that fees for Applied Botany and Applied Zoology courses now stood at Rs.
795 from Rs.  39

column1: Likewise the fee for Mathematics had been hiked from Rs.  43
column2: 280 to Rs.  53

column1: It said that if the university reduced the fees for payment category also it would help many poor students to pursue higher education.  Otherwise only some would have access to it.
P. S.  Yadapadithaya

CPI(M) Kasaragod district conference from January 9 : The three-day district conference of the Communist Party of India (Marxist), beginning January 9 at Koliyadukkam, near here, will strive to streamline the functioning of the party in its traditional stronghold, which has sizeable population of minority communities. 
The delegates meeting, to be attended by senior party leaders, will be inaugurated by Polit Bureau member Kodiyeri Balakrishnan at 10 a. m.  The meeting will be attended by 282 delegates, who comprise 31 district committee members and 251 representatives elected from 12 party area committees and 113 local committees, district committee secretary K. P.  Satheesh Chandran told a press conference here on Tuesday. 
The valedictory session of the meeting will be held on January 11 at Chattanchal.  As many as 50,000 party workers are expected to take part. 
The delegates meeting will be inaugurated by Kodiyeri Balakrishnan.  Chandy facilitating graft: Kodiyeri The State is witnessing a phase of bad governance with scams and corruption rocking the Oommen Chandy Cabinet every day, Communist Party of India (Marxist) [CPI-M] Polit Bureau member Kodiyeri Balakrishnan has said. 
The Chief Minister should resign as he was facilitating corruption and pursuing anti-people policies, he said inaugurating the three-day district conference of the party at Koliyadukkam, near Chattanchal, on Friday. 
The district meet was a precursor to the party State meet in February. 
The High Court had stated that the State government cannot seek to withdraw the palmolein import case.  This clearly pointed a finger at Mr.  Chandy. 
The government was unable to implement any welfare projects for the common man, he said. 
The BJP government was pursuing neo-liberal policies more vigorously than the previous Congress government.  It promoted religious conversions.  Mr.  Chandy was extending support to the Sangh Parivar’s agenda by maintaining that the State had not witnessed any forcible conversions, he said. 
The policies of the Centre had been creating unrest in among the working class and the deprived sections. 
The Left Democratic Front (LDF) assumed significance at this point and the political climate in the State was conducive to it coming to power in the upcoming local body elections. 
The party was trying to streamline the political and organisational setup ahead of the party congress in Visakhapatnam in April. 
A. K.  Narayanan, party district committee member, presided over the function.  CM to flag off torch With days left for the commencement of the 35th National Games in Kerala, Chief Minister Oommen Chandy would flag off the Statewide relay for the games torch here on January 23.  The relay that would conclude in Thiruvananthapuram would be flagged off by Mr.  Chandy at a function scheduled at the Government college premises here at 9.30 a. m.  A meeting chaired by Collector P. S.  Muhammed Sagir in his chamber on Wednesday evolved strategies for the successful hosting of the programme.   The function will also honour sports persons from the State who took part in the previous National Games.  The authorities here have decided to accord a rousing reception to the torch relay in eight centres – Cherkala, Chattanchal, Periye, Kanhangad, Neeleshwaram, Cheruvathur and Kalikadavu, official sources here said.  The meeting was also attended by ADM H.  Dineshan besides other senior district officials and senior office-bearers of the district sports council and other sports bodies.  Palakkad takes narrow lead Palakkad took a narrow lead in the race for the gold cup at the 55th State School Arts Festival here on Saturday. 
Palakkad was on 344 points while the host and defending champion, Kozhikode, was just one point behind, with 343 points. 
Thrissur was on 339 points, followed by Kannur (327), Kasaragod (325), Kottayam (323), Alappuzha (321), Ernakulam (318), Malappuram (317), and Thiruvananthapuram (313).

Palakkad had 692 points, while Kozhikode was on 685.  In the third place was Kannur (677), Thrissur (670), Malappuram (653), Kottayam (650), Kasaragod (648), Ernakulam (644), Alappuzha (642) and Kollam (627).

A piece of land for all his music Only music could be more sweet for vocalist Ustad Hassan Bhai.  On Tuesday, the 71-year-old ace musician got the title deed for five cents of land at a revenue adalat here. 
Ustad, as he is fondly called, is well-versed in Carnatic, Hindustani, and Western vocal.  This former disciple of Shehnai maestro Ustad Bismillah Khan had been staying in a rented house at Koliyadukkam in Chemnad grama panchayat. 
He had to dispose of his 20 cents of land to marry off his three daughters.  He and his ailing wife then shifted to the rented house, he said. 
He had been surviving on the meagre salary paid by the Saraswathi Sangeetha Kala Kshethra at Paravanadukkam.  He also taught children at Palakkunu, Vellarikundu, Bovikkanam, Kanhangad, and Kannur, sources said. 
Ustad Hassan Bhai, who can reportedly play 30 varieties of musical instruments, opted not to take hefty remunerations for his recitals in the true traditions of music.  His plot was at Chattanchal, sources said.  Ustad Hassan Bhai was all thanks to the district for having included his name for the title deed.  The music does not stop as Hassan Bhai intends to build a house on the plot.  Assembly furore: LDF pickets key offices The dramatic incidents and unprecedented chaotic scenes witnessed during the budget presentation in the State Assembly on Friday had its repercussion here with the LDF activists picketing taluk, village, and sub-registrar offices in the district. 
Raising slogan against the UDF government accusing K. M.  Mani as tainted Finance Minister, the LDF activists laid siege of the key seats of power in the five Assembly segments in the district partially disrupting the functioning of the offices. 
The protesters picketed taluk offices in Manjeshwaram, Kasaragod, and Hosdurg (Kanhangad), village office at Chattanchal, and Sub-Registrar office in Trikaripur. 
The protesters resented the moves to deploy heavy posse of watch-and-ward personnel and police inside and outside the Assembly, during the budget presentation. 
Large numbers of police personnel were deployed at the picketing venues as the LDF activists took out a march in Kanhangad.  UDF observes ‘black day’ The United Democratic Front (UDF) observed ‘black day’ on Sunday in protest against the conduct of the Left Democratic Front (LDF) MLAs in the Assembly during the Budget presentation on Friday. 
Inaugurating a public meeting, DCC president C. K.  Sreedharan said the display of violence in the Assembly to prevent Finance Minister K. M.  Mani from presenting the budget, terming him a tainted Minister, was a pointer to the fact that the CPI(M)-led LDF was deviating from taking up issues of public concern and appeared to be isolating itself by launching ‘anti-people’ agitations. 
The Left parties in recent times were bent upon adopting any means to ensure that the elected government failed to discharge its responsibilities, he alleged. 
Leaders of various UDF constituent parties took part in a public meeting, organised by the UDF district committee, at Chattanchal, some 12 km from here. 
A similar meeting organised by the UDF Kanhangad mandalam committee was inaugurated by KPCC executive member M. C.  Jose at Kottachery.  Burglars decamp with postal parcels Thieves decamped with parcel bags from the Kudlu RD Nagar branch post office, near here.  The incident came to notice when the postal employees opened the office on Thursday after two consecutive holidays. 
A complaint lodged at the Town police station here said that 15 parcel bags were stolen by the burglars who broke open the front door of the building. 
The burglary is the third in recent times.  Burglars had earlier targeted post offices at Shiribagilu and Chattanchal earlier.  The incidents have brought to light the need for enhancing vigil at building housing post offices.  Temple burglary: 2 held with idols The police here have arrested two persons, including the prime accused, in connection with the burglary at Kammadam Bhagavathi temple near Chittarikkal.  The police team led by Vellarikundu Circle Inspector T. P.  Sumesh arrested Ahamed Kabir, 25, the prime accused, and K. V.  Sadanandan, 39.  The police are on the lookout for the absconding Tajuddin, a resident of Mangad near Uduma.  Superintendent of Police K.  Srinivas at a press conference on Monday said the accused stole the panchaloha and brass idols.  The duo were remanded to 14 days custody by the Judicial First Class Magistrate Court II in Kanhangad.  The idols, which are valued over Rs.16 lakh, were found kept in a sack in the house of Ahammed Kabir at Chattanchal.  Girls bag top ranks in Samastha exams Girls bagged most ranks in the public examinations conducted by the Samastha Kerala Islam Matha Vidyabhyasa Board (SKIMVB) in May this year, the results of which were announced on Monday. 
Nearly 95 per cent of the students who took the Class V, VII, X, and XII examinations were qualified for higher studies.  More than 2.15-lakh students had taken the examinations conducted simultaneously in Kerala, Tamil Nadu, Pondichery, Karnataka, Maharashtra, Lakshadweep, Andaman, Oman, Bahrain, Malaysia, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, and the UAE.  When 20,321 students secured distinction, 51,355 got first class and 32,920 second class.  M. K.  Fatima Shadila from Thazhekode, Malappuram, won the first rank and T. T.  Haleemathu Fidya from Chattanchal, Kasaragod, won the second rank in Class V examinations. 
As many as 4,958 students passed with distinction in Class V examinations, which registered 90.76 per cent pass.  In Class VII, C.  Mohammed Jasil from Parappur, Malappuram, and M. P.  Shahana Sharin from Thachanattukara, Palakkad, won the first and second ranks respectively.  They were 12,375 distinctions in Class VII examinations. 
E. K.  Ahamed Kabeer from Vallapuzha, Palakkad, won the first rank and C. K.  Juwairiya from Pallippuram won the second rank in Class X examinations. 
In Class XII, P. C.  Shabana Jasmin from Pookkottur, Malappuram, and Fatima from Alampadi, Kasaragod, won the first and second ranks respectively.  Board office-bearers said that cash awards would be given to rank winners and their teachers. 
SAY exam
They said save-a-year (SAY) examinations would be conducted for those who failed in only one subject. 
The SAY examination will be held at 128 centres on August 2.  The last date to apply for SAY examination will be July 20.  20 injured in bus At least 20 persons were injured, one of them critically, in a head-on collision involving a bus and a truck at Bevinja on the Cherkkala guard section, around 8 km from here, on Wednesday. 
The accident occurred around 1.30 p. m.  when the private bus plying on the Kanhangad-Kasaragod route collided with the fish-laden truck while negotiating a sharp curve, the police said. 
Jamila, 44, a resident of Kunnupara near Chattanchal, was taken to a hospital in Mangalore with critical injuries while 10 others, including the bus driver, were admitted to E. K.  Nayanar Cooperative hospital at Chengala. 
Traffic was disrupted for over an hour on the busy and narrow NH stretch because of the accident.  Rs.9.74 lakh lost during bike ride Cash worth Rs.9.74 lakh is said to have been lost while carrying it in a motorcycle after withdrawing it from a treasury here on Friday. 
The cash, said to be salary and Onam allowance for the staff members of Government High School, Pakkam, near Bekal, was reportedly lost while carrying it in a motorcycle after withdrawing the amount from the Sub-treasury at Chattanchal. 
Rajesh, a teacher of the school carrying the cash bag hooked to his motorcycle, realised the loss as he reached Kuniya locality by riding through the badly damaged National Highway, according to a complaint filed with the Bekal police, said.  Chandy to address campaign tomorrow : The UDF campaign for the November 2 local body election is expected to peak when Chief Minister Oommen Chandy will make a whirlwind tour of the district on October 19. 
Mr.  Chandy will address poll meetings in six places, including the hilly pocket of Chittarikkal where the alliance is facing threat from an Independent candidate, Sherly Sebastian, who recently formed part of a locally cobbled front after quitting the Congress. 
Mr.  Chandy is scheduled to address public meeting at Uppala, Kasaragod, Chattanchal, Kanhangad, Chullikkara and Chittarikkal before entering Kannur district where he will address a meeting at Payyannur, DCC president C.  K.  Sreedharan said.

column1: Rampura Basti
column2:
Mother sets boy on fire for stealing Rs 5 in Bikaner  BIKANER: A six-year-old boy was set afire by her mother when he stole Rs 5 to eat snacks in Bikaner town on Tuesday.  Police said the boy has sustained nearly 40% burn injuries, mostly on his hand, abdomen, chest, thighs and genital and is undergoing treatment in critical condition at PBM Hospital. 
The boy has given his statement to the police, narrating how her mother set him afire.  The police have rounded up the mother and interrogation with her is going on. 
According to the police, the boy, Sahil Kumar, is a resident of Rampura Basti in Bikaner.  In his statement given to police said that on Monday morning, he took Rs 5 from his house and went to a nearby shop for purchasing snacks. 
During that time, his mother saw him and snatched the money from him.  Later, she took him inside the house, poured kerosene and threw a burning match stick on him.  Sahil said he started shouting due to burning, and then his aunty and grandmother came forward and saved him by throwing water. 
Jagdish Prasad, ASI of Naya Shahar police station, who recorded the statement of Sahil, said that he has burning effects on his hand, abdomen, chest, thighs and genital.  He said a case has been registered under Section 307 of IPC against his mother.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

C Road, Thakkakuttai, Mulakulam, Mairie Oulgaret, JJ Nagar, Oulgaret, Kamban Nagar, Jaya Nagar, Sellapappu Nagar, Mariyal Nagar, Pitchaiveeranpet, Radhakrishnan Nagar, Ajees Nagar, Mugambikai Nagar, Pavazhakaranchavady, Pavanar Nagar, Boomianpet, Ragavendra Nagar, Pon Nagar, Satyasai Nagar, GN Palayam, Ezhil Nagar, Natarajan Nagar, Thirukuralar Nagar, Roja Nagar, Vasantam Nagar, Vennisamy Nagar, Arumparthapuram, Ganapathy Nagar, Radha Nagar, Muthupillai palayam, Balaji Nagar, Gopalankadai, Amma Nagar, Kannagachettykulam, Periya Kalapet, Chinna Kalapet, Pillaichavady, Pondicherry University Quarters, Pondicherry Engineering College, Alankuppam, Sanjeevi Nagar, Tsunami Quarters, Central Prison, Navodaya Vidyalaya School, Law College, Kalyanasundaramoorthy Nagar and adjoining areas.

column1: Besant Nagar
column2:
Party begins early as Chennai rings in new year  CHENNAI: The bubbly was uncorked early as the city got ready to usher in the New Year.  Some attended midnight mass at church before partying, while a few others tucked in early to make sure they would wake up soon for a visit to a temple. 
A vibrant energy infused the air in the city on New Year's eve.  From normally surly autorickshaw drivers wishing their passengers a good year to strangers embracing each other in shops, restaurants and even among speeding vehicles, almost everyone wanted to greet everyone else. 
Ravi Raghavan and his wife were among the energetic all-nighters.  " We usually start New Year's Eve with a round of golf, relax at a club, get drinks and dinner delivered at home and head out for dessert at 1am and filter coffee at 4am,"  Raghavan said.  " This time there will be a trip to the temple as January 1 is vaikunta ekadasi. " 
More than 15,000 police personnel were on the roads to maintain law and order and ensure the celebrations were safe and stress-free.  Following the bomb blast in Bengaluru, all places where parties were planned were told to compulsorily install CCTV cameras at entry and exit points.  Restaurants were warned against serving liquor after 1am. 
Several companies let their employees go home early to spend time with friends and family.  " We were let off by 2pm after which our company organised games and distributed prizes,"  said Shiva Ranjan, a banking app designer.  But getting home was not easy.  Places like General Patters Road and Nungambakkam High Road were choked with vehicles as people headed out to party or worship. 
The city's beaches were swamped with revellers.  The famous Elliot's Beach in Besant Nagar was completely packed as was the nearby Velankanni church.  Vehicles were stopped much ahead of the beach promenade. 
In the kuppam (fishing hamlet) at Kottivakkam, the 'line' was clearly drawn - the men celebrated on one side with Tamil 'gaana' numbers, while their women huddled on the other, quietly talking. 
The trend of house parties was also in evidence.  " Clubs are way too crowded and expensive.  At house parties there is a closed circle and we have the kind of fun we want,"  said Sinduri Shyam Sundar of Adyar.  " We are also safer inside and we can stay back and not drive in the middle of the night,"  added Reema Mukherjee, who threw a party at her Alwarpet residence, complete with a dress code. 
These parties are also an alternative for those who miss booking tables at hotels.  " Many hotels offer packages where you can have dinner, party and stay in a room to avoid drunk driving,"  said Pradeep Kumar. 
For Suganthi K, attending midnight mass on New Year eve has been a ritual since her school days.  Now, her husband accompanies her.  " We attend a midnight mass and then go to a temple nearby,"  she said.  The mother of two said she felt at peace while attending a mass.  " I feel positive that the year ahead will be good,"  she said.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  New Year parties peaceful in Chennai barring minor accidents  CHENNAI: The celebrations in the city to usher in the New Year were relatively peaceful but there were some accidents despite police’s careful preparations.  At least 300 people were injured in minor accidents, mostly on interior roads, in Chennai and its suburbs, while three people were killed. 
More than 18,000 police personnel, including senior officers, were out on the roads, some until 3am, to ensure there were no untoward incidents.  They were largely successful.  No cases of drunk driving were registered but those found driving while drunk were told to stop at the place and proceed only after they got sober. 
As on previous occasions, the city’s beaches bore the brunt of the revelry.  While the famous Marina, where at least 7 lakh people partied into the wee hours, generated 4.5 tonnes of garbage, while the Elliot’s beach in Besant Nagar generated 2.5 tonnes of waste.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Action taken on plaints, fibs Chennai corporation  CHENNAI: Since it was launched to allow residents to complain about grievances, the city corporation’s toll-free number 1913 has been inundated with calls.  The staff manning the line call complainants to enquire about the ‘service’ and the corporation sends ‘action taken’ messages.  However, residents say, problems remain.  Last month, V S Lingaperumal of Velachery complained about hawkers completely taking over the pavements on CSIR Road in Taramani.  “Four days later, I got an “action taken” message and then a “complaint closed” message but the encroachers are still there,” he said.  “I rang up all officers in the zone but everyone was vague,” he said.  Curious, he chatted with the encroachers.  “They told me they pay the ward councillor 10,000 a year. ” Others have had experiences ranging from the bizarre to funny.  A day after T D Babu of Shastri Nagar complained of a tea stall encroaching upon a pavement, a corporation dog-catching van landed up at his house.  “The staff took a dog menace complaint,” he said, laughing.  “ What is the point in having this system or complaining online which doesn’t free us from hassles when we still have to personally chase officials?” Babu says he’s made at least one complaint a day but has never been satisfied.  Bharath,* of Besant Nagar, says he has been making the same complaint for three years, in vain.  “A company is using a residential building for commercial purposes without corporation approval.  But no action was taken.  We are worried this will be unofficially regularised and our residential locality will turn commercial,” he said.  The corporation admits to such “errors” and says it is sensitising employees to respond better.  “Prompt action is taken in complaints about garbage, street lights, mosquitoes, dog menace.  But complaints such as encroachments and unauthorised constructions take more time to be redressed.  Some may be tangled in legal disputes,” said an official.  “Some employees close cases to show statistics and to ensure they are not hauled up but we are addressing this issue. ” The system works like this: A resident calls 1913 and makes a complaint.  The operator registers it online with the complainant’s name, address and mobile number.  This is forwarded to the assistant engineer and only he/she can close the complaint after informing the complainant.  “We call and check if the complaint has been taken care of as we get many calls saying the complaint has been closed without action being taken,” said a member of ‘1913’.  “If it has been falsely closed, we inform the AE but our role stops there,” he said. (*Name changed)Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  16,000 duplicate voter entries removed from rolls in Chennai  CHENNAI: The public elections department has found a way to delete multiple entries of voters from the electoral rolls.  It used photograph identification software to weed out as many as 15,736 duplicate entries of voters in Chennai. 
" The elections department developed software for a pilot de-duplication drive.  Officials used the software to scan photographs of voters and found 15,736 multiple entries,"  chief electoral officer Sandeep Saxena said.  " We deleted the names of these voters after issuing notices to them. " 
The software initially identified a list of 58,000 possible duplicate entries by photographic comparison.  It scans facial dimensions and features to identify individuals but has a margin of error and may identify different individuals as the same person. 
But armed with the list of possible duplicate entries, election officials conducted a field verification and found that in 15,736 instances the software correctly identified replica entries. Saxena said officials will use the software to identify multiple voter entries in the rolls in other districts in the coming months.  Officials deleted a total of 2.87 lakh entries in the summary revision. 
Chennai district election officer Vikram Kapur released the final electoral roll at Ripon Buildings.  Statistics from the Chennai district election office show Velachery, which includes Gandhi Nagar, Besant Nagar, Kasturba Nagar and Taramani, has 2.85 lakh voters, more than any other constituency.  It is followed by Perambur (2.77 lakh), Virugambakkam (2.76 lakh), Anna Nagar (2.75 lakh) and Saidapet (2.69 lakh). 
Women voters have outnumbered men in the electoral rolls in Chennai district.  Of the total 38.34 lakh voters enrolled, 19.11 lakh were men, 19.21 lakh were women and 769 were transgenders. 
Kapur said 57,922 new voters were included on the electoral rolls since October 15, 2014, of which 25,407 reached the age of 18 after the last election. 
Officials will distribute voter ID cards at polling stations on January 25, National Voters Day.  Voters can check to see if their names are included on the rolls in the corporation's zonal offices.
