No more rain likely in Chennai, says Met office but predicts more misty mornings  CHENNAI: The northeast monsoon has ended and there will be no more rain this season, the regional meteorological office has declared.  City residents can, however, expect misty mornings as long as winter lasts, officials said. 
While the city was enveloped in mist early on Saturday and Sunday, even throwing flights off schedule at the Chennai airport, by Monday the visibility had improved considerably.  " Mist is usually a seasonal occurrence, but it may even appear in March or April.  The city can expect misty mornings on any day through the winter,"  said area cyclone warning centre director S R Ramanan. 
Over the weekend, northerly winds caused the humid city air to condense, resulting in mist.  " Mist occurs when cool winds blowing from the northern part of the country interact with humid air in the city causing condensation,"  said Mahesh Palawat, chief meteorologist of private weather forecasting agency Skymet. 
Mist may also occur after a cold night just after sunrise if the skies are clear and air still, he said.  " After a warm day, the surface of the earth heats up.  As night falls and temperature drops, the earth surface begins to cool, turning coldest just before sunrise.  At sunrise when the temperature rises, air turns warm and humid.  The cool earth surface turns the warm, humid air into mist which eventually evaporates.  This may not occur if the sky is cloudy as it traps humid air from escaping,"  added Palawat. 
While Chennai airport officials had a torrid time rescheduling and rerouting flights during the weekend, morning walkers said they look forward to winters to experience the mist.  Jogger V Karthikeyan said, " I visit the Marina every year during the winters just to enjoy the mist.  Today, a soothing coolness and reduced visibility cloaked the city.  It was a relaxing break from the humid mornings. " 
However motorists were not so thrilled.  " It is safer to drive slowly when you are enveloped in mist.  I ended up reaching office late on Saturday,"  IT employee R Jagannathan said.  Most areas, including Triplicane, East Coast Road and Besant Nagar, were covered in mist over the weekend. 
This week the sky over the city will be partly cloudy with the maximum temperature at 31 degrees Celsius and minimum temperature 24 degrees Celsius, as per the met website.  However, all it takes is for the sky to be clear for a few hours in the morning for mist to form, officials said. 
The city received 129cm of rain in 2014, including the rain from the southwest monsoon, against the 109cm of rain in 2013.  The northeast monsoon that set in on October 21, 2014 brought 75cm of rain against the 44cm of rain brought by the previous northeast monsoon. Veteran actor V S Raghavan dead  CHENNAI: Tamil film actor V S Raghavan passed away in his sleep at a hospital in T Nagar on Saturday evening after a battle with pancreatic cancer.  He was 89 and is survived by his sons K R Srinivasan and K R Krishna, daughters-in-law and a grandson. 
A seasoned veteran of more than 1,000 films, Raghavan was seen recently in âOru Kanniyum Moonu Kalavaanikalumâ (2014) and TV serials Valli, En Iniya Thozhi and Uyirmei.  He began his career as a sub-editor at Maalathi magazine and went on to act in stage plays.  After acting in a play âVairamaalaiâ, Raghavan went on to make his film debut in the screen adaptation of the play under the same title in 1954. 
Former chief minister J Jayalalithaa paid tributes to the veteran artist in a press release: âHe treated everybody with love and affection.  His death is a great loss to the film industry.  I convey my heartfelt condolences to his family and his friends in the film fraternitym,â she said. 
One of the few actors to have played âfatherâ to legends M G Ramachandran and Sivaji Ganesan in several films, Raghavanâs most memorable movies include âNenjil Ore Aalayamâ (1962), âKarnanâ (1964), âKaadhalikka Neramillaiâ (1964), âBommaiâ (1964), âIru Kodugalâ (1969) and âUrimaikkuralâ (1974). 
He shared a special friendship with late director K Balachander who directed him in several films.  Raghavan was noted for his role in Balachander-directed tele-serial Anni in the early 2000s and headed the Tamil Nadu Iyal Isai Naadaga Manram in the early 1990s. 
The cremation will be held at 5pm on Sunday in Besant Nagar, his family said.  âMany of his close friends from the film and television industry have been calling to convey condolences.  We expect a large gathering of film personalities tomorrow,â said Janaki Srinivasan, his daughter-in-law.

Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  251 Olive Ridleys found dead in 5 months  CHENNAI: In what is certain to set alarm bells ringing, 251 Olive Ridley turtles have been found dead along the 14km stretch between Neelankarai and Napiers Bridge by volunteers of the Student Sea Turtle Conservation Network (SSTCN) in the five weeks since the nesting season. 
While 171 dead turtles were washed ashore in 2012, the number rose to 185 in 2014.  In 2015, with more than half the season to go, the death toll has already touched 100 between Napiers Bridge and Srinivasapuram and 151 between Neelankarai and Besant Nagar.  The number of death turtles in just the first week of February is 66, said SSTCN reports. 
To put this number in perspective, activists cite the situation in 1982, when 20 dead turtles washed ashore. 
“Since the nesting along the Madras Beach can be categorised as only ‘ thin’ or moderate, mortality due to incidental catch in fishing operations of nesting females could have an adverse effect on the breeding population visiting the coast and consequently on recruitment. 
A careful study of this is needed in order to advice any preventive and precautionary regulatory measures to be adopted in specific type of fishing operations during the nesting season,” reads the report ‘Recovery programme for Olive Ridleys (Lepidochelys Olivacea) along the Madras coast by E G Silas and M Rajagopalan, published by Central Marine Fisheries Research Institute in 1982. 
More than 30 years later, the threat of ‘unregulated fishing operations’ is as persistent as ever.  In a petition filed in the Madras high court, the amicus argued that Chennai’s coast was on the migratory route for these turtles to reach the coasts of Odisha and other nesting grounds along the east coast.  “The culling of turtles along our coast therefore does not affect only the turtles that approach our shores to nest but results in a massacre of the migrating turtles as well,” read the petition.  The biggest danger to the turtles are the nets used by trawlers and gill nets used by smaller fisherman.  Conservationists advocate the use of turtle-excluding devices to save Olive Ridleys.  “They can cost as little as 5,000 to install but can save thousands of turtles,” said Akila Balu of SSTCN. 
Turtles come to Chennai and other parts of the eastern coast between late December and early April.  Each turtle lays eggs at least two times with each nest having around 100 eggs. 
While nests are sometime poached, hatchlings are often eaten by dogs or die of dehydration when they get distracted by street lights and head towards the road instead of the sea.  With such low survival rates, conservationists estimate that only one in 1,000 eggs reaches adulthood.  Adult turtles, on the other hand, get entangled in nets.  They either drown or have their flippers cut off fishermen who want to get rid of the turtle without damaging their nets.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Ambulance on Marina sands to rescue visitors from drowning  CHENNAI: Drowning off the Marina has become too frequent an incident, and rescuers are finding it difficult to take the victims to hospitals in time.  They have to be first carried across the beach to the ambulance on the service lane, sometimes a few hundred metres away, and precious time is lost.  Now, a four-wheel drive ambulance from the ‘108’ service promises to pick up the victims from the shoreline, cutting time and saving lives. 
The service begins on Thursday.  The all-terrain vehicle can move on the sand and provide first-aid to people being rescued from the water and move them quickly to a hospital.  Every week more than four people drown off the city beaches, but the government hasn’t found it necessary to post life guards.  When authorities argue that guards cannot be posted as swimming here is per se illegal, the four-wheel drive ambulance on the beach is an improvement to the grave situation. 
“These ambulances are equipped to attend to emergencies in non-motorable areas,” said B Prabhudoss, regional manager of GVK EMRI that operates 108 in Tamil Nadu.  “To begin with, we will employ them in and around Marina beach.  “Except for the size of the vehicle, which is smaller than the regular ambulance on road to facilitate quicker reach, the facilities in the ambulance will be the same. ” They will attend to emergencies of visitors as well as residents of the neighbouring fishing hamlets. ” 108 will soon launch more ambulances at beaches in Besant Nagar, Mahabalipuram and Pazhaverkadu. 
The city police have been taking efforts to keep a tab on swimmers at the beach by deploying personnel on beach buggies.  Coastal Security Group also keep vigil along the coast on all-terrain vehicles.  Despite all this, many venture into the sea. 
The National Crime Records Bureau statistics show that in 2013, Chennai reported 265 drowning cases, which was the highest among 53 major cities in the country.  At least four cases were reported last week.  The ‘108’ ambulance vehicles attend to about 50 cases a month on the city beaches.  The government-run service, which has a fleet of 684 ambulances, has 30 all-terrain vehicles for hilly regions of the state.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Demand for organic products up in Chennai  CHENNAI: When Supriya Arokyaraj developed a skin condition, she realised that the soaps and detergents she used to wash her clothes were aggravating it. Nadeera Harris of Desi Basics on Greams Road sources and sells organic kitchenware as well as cosmetics and cleaning products.  âFor the past three years, we have been selling organic soaps, shampoos, and shower gels as well as indigo hair dye made of indigo and henna powder. At Desi Basics, customers can pick from neem, tulsi, vettiver, or lavender soaps as well as organic mosquito repellents made of lemon grass and eucalyptus.

Their detergent is made of certified organic soap berries, processed in a particular way so as to make it suitable for a washing machine.  âThe dish washing product has soap berry, neem leaf, and lemongrass,â says Srinivas.

Besant Nagar man, 93, missing after walk  CHENNAI: A 93-year-old resident of Besant Nagar who left home for a walk three days ago, has not returned.  R Sampath Kumar, an ex-serviceman, woke up and had a cup of tea on Thursday before stepping out. 
His son S Parthasarathy, 68, said he tried to dissuade him, but could not.  " He normally did not go for morning walks, but on Thursday he insisted on stepping out after his tea.  And since then he's been missing. "  The family has searched hospitals in the city and got in touch with relatives in his native Srirangam to carry out inquiries, but to no avail. 
" I have searched all the hospitals and old age homes.  My relatives in Srirangam have also not been able to locate him,"  said Parthasarathy.  Police have registered a complaint and circulated his photograph among patrol vehicles. 
Sampath Kumar, who spent most of his life in Assam, retired as a food analyst at an army facility.  The family described him as keeping fairly good health although getting a bit forgetful of late.  " He was an army man so he would never use his walking stick and always walked upright.  He had hearing problems and at times ask us who he was,"  said P.  Rukmani, the missing man's daughter-in-law. 
Parthasarathy said a few years ago his father took off on a moped to visit the army canteen and had a fall near the Monroe statue.  A few people rushed him to the general hospital but took away the Rs 3,000 he had on him, he said.  " I would keep advising him not to go out alone but he would say he was bored and needed a walk. "  The son said most of the time he would allow his father to go out for a walk alone, but would follow him at a distance to keep an eye on him till he returned home.  " He was a regular at the temple and we searched there but could not find him. " 
Parthasarathy said, " there are times when he has gone missing and I have managed to trace him as I know the route he takes for a walk.  He will not go outside Besant Nagar.  My appeal to the general public is to please call us on 9840112225 if you spot him anywhere. " 
Sampath Kumar was dressed in an olive green shirt and a dhoti.  Rukmani said she hoped he was unharmed since he always carried cash on him.  " Once he went to the bank and by just telling his name got the withdrawal form filled up and brought Rs.10,000 in cash home. " 
" There is absolute silence in the house without him and I hope to find him and bring him home soon,"  added Parthasarathy.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Missing 93-year-old found 20km from home  CHENNAI: Six days after a 93-year-old resident of Besant Nagar, ex-serviceman with dementia and a hearing impairment, went missing while out on a morning walk, a scrap merchant who found him unconscious near a mosque in Kundrathur, more than 20km away, reunited him with his family on Tuesday. 
Sampath Kumar’s son S Parthasarathy, 68, who in a frantic search for his father since he vanished last Thursday had distributed photographs of the elderly man among autorickshaw drivers in an attempt to track him down, says he was in Guindy on Tuesday morning when he received a call. 
“The caller identified himself as Sadiq Ali,” Parthasarathy said.  “He told me he had seen an advertisement I had taken out for my missing father in a Tamil daily on Tuesday and said he believed he had found my father.  I rushed to Chengalpet Government Hospital where Ali had admitted my father.  ”
Sampath Kumar’s daughter-in-law P Rukmani said it was nothing short of providential that someone had traced the elderly man in a city as large as Chennai, given that dementia has reduced him to a childlike stage with almost complete loss of memory. 
Visibly relieved to be back home, Sampath Kumar said, “I don’t know where I went, but that family really treated me well. ” He was referring to the family of another patient in the hospital who shared their food with him.  “I don’t mean to be a trouble to anyone and have even kept money ready for my funeral expenses,” he said.  “They helped me.  People should help others in need. ”
Ali, 42, a scrap merchant, said he found the man in an unconscious state outside a mosque in Kundrathur at 11am on Monday. 
“I realised that he had probably collapsed due to weakness.  His clothes were soiled,” he said.  “I called some friends and we cleaned him up and changed his clothes.  We knew he was hungry so we bought him idlis.  I decided to take him to hospital and then inform police. ”
“By Tuesday morning he could tell me his name.  I recalled seeing an advertisement for a missing senior citizen in a newspaper that day.  When I checked the ad again I realised that I had found Parthasarathy’s father,” Ali said.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Corporation removes bio-toilet from Besant Nagar beach  CHENNAI: More than nine months after it was installed, the bio-toilet meant to keep the famous Elliot’s beach in Besant Nagar clean has been removed. The members voiced their concern over civic issues and lack of safety.  “Vendors have taken over all the pavements, and there is no space for pedestrians,” said former Anna University professor V Chandrasekhar, who is the president of the group.

column1: The student volunteer network that has been patrolling the city’s beaches from the late 1980s found 65 dead turtles since the New Year’s day.

Tree Foundation volunteers are involved in conservation of the critically endangered turtles from Neelankarai to Marakkanam.  “Almost 123 dead turtles were washed ashore between December 20 and January 13
column2: ” says Supraja Dharini of the foundation.

column1: On Saturday alone
column2: more than 60 turtles were ashore dead from Neelankarai to Alambarai.  Conservationists say that the main reason for such high sea turtle mortality is due to commercial trawl fishing nets

column1: The turtles need to come to the surface of the sea every 40-45 minutes to breathe.  Trapped in the fishing net
column2: they can’t come up.  Once the net is raised

column1: “Many of the dead turtles are washed deep into the sea as well
column2: ” says Mr.  Arun.  Local fishermen have also been reporting that they have observed many dead turtles floating in the sea this season.

column1: The conservationists have been waging a relentless war with the State government for years now for a law to ban the killer nets like in many western countries.  A week ago
column2: the Fisheries Department held a meeting with the fishermen.

column1: The fishermen were told to fish beyond five km from the shore and boat owners were asked to instruct the workers not to fish in regions off shore to estuaries.  They were also asked to pull up their nets every one hour.
As a major step towards conservation of the city’s flagship species
column2: the Fisheries Department in association with the Tree Foundation will be organising a demonstration of the Turtle Excluder Device (TED) next week for all the trawl boat owners.

column1: Scientists from Central Institute of Fisheries Technology will display indigenously designed TED to the boat owners.  “TEDs are low-cost devices and the loss will only be marginal
column2: ” says Mr.  Arun.  Chennai today Religion

column20: Thirunindravur; 7 p. m.  AAP marks Delhi victory with rally Taking Sunday evening visitors to the Elliots Beach in Besant Nagar by surprise
column21: the Aam Aadmi Party staged a rally here to celebrate the party’s phenomenal victory in the Delhi Assembly polls.

column1: Many in the rally of around 500 people sported Gandhi caps and held broom-sticks.
Many of the participants were first-timers to AAP events.
“We never thought a non-corrupt party could win any election in this country.  Arvind Kejriwal has given us new hope.  We want this movement to prosper in Tamil Nadu
column2: ” said M.  Gnanasekaran

column1: Some were of the view that if not for the India-Pakistan World Cup encounter
column2: the rally may have drawn a bigger crowd.  Members of the party also flagged various corruption scandals facing other political parties in Tamil Nadu and spoke out against ‘dynastic politics’.  Residents stunned as ship nears shore Residents of Srinivasapuram

column3: 5.30 p. m.  40 bus routes to get priority makeover Following persistent delays in shifting of utilities by line agencies
column4: the Chennai Corporation has decided to prioritise the makeover of 40 bus routes
column5: likely to be frequented by delegates of the Global Investors’ Meet in May.

column1: ‘Legal challenges’
“The work order was delayed because of various legal challenges.  The line agencies are yet to complete digging work.  We will complete work on 40 important roads by May 15
column2: ” said an official.

column1: The roads include stretches leading up to heritage sites
column2: the Secretariat
column3: the airport and port.  The civic body has issued work order for 194 roads
column4: and they will have better pedestrian facilities

column1: The Corporation has planned to reduce the number of roads covered under the project following a study of pavement conditions done using advanced technology.
Non-invasive technology
After screening 197 roads using non-invasive technology
column2: a private agency has recommended shelving of work on some roads that are in good condition.

column1: “This is the first time roads are getting a makeover based on analysis of data collected using non-invasive technology
column2: ” said an official.

column1: Kamarajar Salai in Virugambakkam
column2: 3{+r}{+d}Main Road in Besant Nagar and Water Tank Road in Arumbakkam are among the roads found to be in good condition.

column1: No relaying work will be taken up on such roads
column2: officials added.

column1: “A few of the roads relaid two years ago were included in the list generated for relaying
column2: ” said an official.

column1: In addition to shelving some road work
column2: the civic body is also likely to postpone work on 50 roads because of digging of roads for fault rectification by Tangedco.  Metrowater will also dig 10 of the roads.  Relaying will begin only after completion of the work.

column1: By July
column2: the civic body will relay all 194 bus route roads.  The new roads will be ready before the monsoon

column33: 7 p. m.  City youth shine in football The sands of the Elliots Beach
column34: Besant Nagar witnessed some intense football action at the finals of the Gamessa Soccer League tournament on Sunday.

column1: In one of the final matches of the Under-17 category
column2: the boy’s team from Udumalpet hammered Santhome 5-2 to win the trophy.  The four-day tournament held for different age categories is the precursor for selection to the Homeless World Cup to be held in Amsterdam in Netherlands in September.  30 teams participated from all over the State.

column1: Though the team from Chennai was beaten in the Under-17 final
column2: the city can take pride from the selection of S.  Vignesh and P.  Parthiban for the Indian team to the Homeless World Cup tournament.  The two lads hailing from slums in Santhome and Mylapore were groomed through Summer Soccer

column1: While Vignesh is studying in an Industrial Training Institute in Tiruvottiyur
column2: Parthiban is working in a pharmacy company.

column17: 7 p. m.  Nemmeli plant to remain shut on June 10 Residents of the southern parts of the city may not get water from Nemmeli desalination plant on June 10 as the facility will be shut down between 6 a. m.  and 6 p. m.  for maintenance.

column1: The desalination plant
column2: which has a capacity to treat 100 million litres of water a day (mld)

column1: However
column2: as the facility will undergo maintenance works and electricity shutdown on Wednesday

column1: These areas are fed a minimum of 90 mld of water from the desalination plant in Nemmeli.  Water will be provided through tankers to areas that do not receive piped water supply on Wednesday.  There is no charge for this water
column2: which will be provided free by Metrowater.

column1: The desalination plants in Nemmeli and Minjur play a crucial role in ensuring continuous water supply to southern and northern Chennai and manage water crisis despite dwindling storage in reservoirs.

column14: 7 p. m.  Robot’s day out on the beach ver since the launch of the Swachh Bharat campaign by Prime Minister Narendra Modi
column15: nearly everybody is out there cleaning the city.  And now
column17: but even robots have taken to the cause.  ‘Swachh Bot’
column18: created by 40 students from around the city

column1: Trained at the K. K.  Nagar-based institution Kidobotikz
column2: these children have worked for weeks to create the fully-functional robot that has participated in various beach clean-up events.  The makers plan to modify it to clean the roads too.  The children were handpicked by the trainers at Kidobotikz

column1: “We train over 200 students.  We asked them to deploy their skills to build a robot to clean their houses.  They were enthusiastic and even made videos of their robots at work.  The best 40 were selected to work on Swachh Bot. ”

column3: you would not have missed the difference from say
column5: which was like any other in the city – badly maintained with garbage strewn everywhere — seems to have been transformed.

column1: The difference is especially noticeable considering the fact that the two iconic beaches of the city
column2: the Marina and Elliots Beach in Besant Nagar are prime examples of poor maintenance.

column1: Cleaning drives

Walkers associations and social activists in Thiruvanmiyur had been trying for long improve the civic condition of the beach by installing seating facilities for the public and organising cleaning drives.
However
column2: their efforts got a major boost when a private company Rialto adopted the beach under its Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) programme.

column1: E.  Senthil Murugan
column2: who works in the company and is involved in the CSR initiative

column1: He says that by involving the Chennai Corporation and private conservancy operator Ramky
column2: garbage collection has been fully streamlined.

column1: Oher benefits
The other benefits from the adoption have been the greening of the beach by watering the avenue trees
column2: installing tree guards and re-arranging and repairing the concrete benches

column1: Chanderswamy
column2: who initiated the CSR activity

column1: He adds that by bringing all the stakeholders including the civic body and the private conservancy operator into the picture
column2: the beach has become a paradise for walkers.  No single technique will do t is no longer about rainwater harvesting.  It is about applying the right harvesting technique in a given situation.  According to a study conducted by Rain Centre

column1: The study has divided the city into four recharge zones
column2: based on soil formation and recharge potential.

column1: According to the study
column2: areas along the coast and river banks such as Besant Nagar
column4: Spurtank Road and Gandhi Nagar have the potential to recharge every drop of rainwater that falls on their soil.  Besides sandy soil
column5: these areas also have a low water table before the onset of the monsoon

column1: The study has urged residents to ensure utmost harnessing of rainwater at their houses
column2: including driveway runoffs.  It has asked the government to dig recharge wells along road margins to replenish groundwater.  Recharge wells dug on the roadside at Kalakshetra Colony
column4: Kilpauk and Ayanavaram fall under recharge zone II
column5: which is characterised by sandy soil
column6: but has a high water table.

column1: However
column2: areas that have clayey soil and rocky terrain need a different rainwater harnessing technique to sustain groundwater source.

column1: Mr.  Raghavan said these areas
column2: with their clayey soil are categorised as recharge zone III

column1: There are certain other areas in the city where harnessing rainwater may prove difficult owing to rocky terrain
column2: says the study.  In areas such as Little Mount
column4: residents may have to put up a combination of a recharge well and a borewell pit.

column1: The Rain Centre also plans to survey rainwater harvesting structures and provide suggestions to residents.  People may either contact the Centre on ph: 24918415 or 9677043869
column2: or the Chennai Metrowater at ph: 28454080 and 45674567 to clarify doubts on the maintenance of such structures.  The bits and bytes of social service They are immersed in gadgets. column1: Only five incidents under the Arms Act have been recorded in Chennai during 2014

column1: Dhauli Hills
column2:
Light vehicles to take visitors atop Dhauli in Bhubaneswar  BHUBANESWAR: Tourists, visiting the famous peace pagoda at Dhauli Hills on the outskirts of the city, would soon have a pleasant time as the state government has decided to introduce light vehicles to carry them from foothills to hilltop.  The decision was taken in the wake of frequent accidents of tourist buses at the hills.  “The tourism department has decided to introduce eight 32-seater vehicles.  The government would sanction funds for the vehicles in the next annual budget,” culture and tourism minister Ashok Panda told TOI. 
Nearly 1,000 tourists, including foreigners, visit Dhauli every day, tourism department sources said. 
On February 7, 2012, four persons were killed and 30 injured as the tourist bus, carrying them, skidded off the road while descending.  Overshooting the concrete fence, bordering the hilly roads, the bus crashed down nearly 40 feet and got stuck in trees. 
In another incident on October 9 last year, a tourist from Nadia district in West Bengal was killed as the bus, he along with others was travelling in, fell into a gorge. 
To draw more visitors to Dhauli, the tourism department has also decided to introduce ropeway.  “We had a preliminary discussion on the issue at a meeting.  Ropeway has already been introduced at Nandankanan here and Taratarini Temple in Ganjam district.  We would invite the operators to finalize the proposal,” Panda said. 
The tourism minister said the government has also decided expedite the process to install light and sound show at Dhauli.  In October, the state government signed an MoU with Indian Tourism Development Corporation in this regard.  The project is hanging fire since 2010. 
Construction of a market complex to rehabilitate local traders, development of tourist police and earmarking places for picnickers were also discussed. Archaeologists dig deep to uncover evidence of ancient civilization  BHUBANESWAR: The Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) has started extensive excavation at Suabarai village in Pipili block about 15 km from here after indications emerged in June last year of the presence of a civilization that flourished nearly 3,500 years ago during the Chalcolithic Age. 
“We can’t say anything until we find some concrete evidence about the existence of an ancient civilization here,” said deputy director of ASI Jeevan Patnaik. 
The excavation began on a mound amidst paddy fields located on the banks of the Daya river and at the southern end of the historic Dhauli Hills.  This is the same place where the famous Kalinga War was fought in 261 BC.  Some 1,50,000 fought in the war and about 1,00,000 were slain, according to a rock edict from the period found on the hills. 
During excavation in June 2014, the ASI team had found some remnants of earthen pots, fragments of pots made of red soil, and ancient stones that pointed to the existence of a human civilization.  Also the excavators found deer horns, two animal teeth measuring two inches each and skeletal remains of birds and animals at the site. 
“ASI decided to start excavation on the site after villagers unearthed two four-feet tall ancient stone sculptures from the mound while digging a pit in April 2013,” an official source said. 
The excavation has been undertaken by a technical team consisting of archaeologists Sanjay Panda and Suvendu Kumar Khuntia.  The digging will continue till the onset of the rainy season, sources said. 
“It is possible that human skeletons may be found at the site.  So, digging work is being done very carefully,” said an officer. 
Anthropologists from Utkal University in Bhubaneswar had unearthed two human skeletons at Banga in Harirajpur area under Delanga block in Puri district, about 25 km from the city in 2013. The remnants were said to be around 3,500 to 4,000 years old and from the Chalcolithic Age. 
The excavation also has significance as it may throw light on the development and growth of the ancient civilization at Sishupalgarh on the outskirts of the city.  Sishupalgarh was an urban centre with a population of more than 20,000 that flourished between 500 BC and 600 AD.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

column1: Diphu Polytechnic
column2:
Diphu Polytechnic running sans AICTE approval Correspondent DIPHU, July 5  The students of Diphu Polytechnic are in a bind as the institute has not received the approval of the All India Council for Technical Education (AICTE). 
According to reports, the Diphu Polytechnic has been running without approval from the AICTE for past few years.  As a result, the students who are studying or have completed their courses are in a state of utter confusion over the fact that their engineering diplomas might be derecognised any moment. It may be noted that the reason that the Diphu Polytechnic has not received the required approval are the various allegations against the then principal Ram Chandra Das.  Sources said that due to his negligence of duty, the institution failed to obtain AICTE approval.  He, even concealed the status of the official progress works, students alleged. As per information received under the RTI Act, there are altogether 10 polytechnics in the State including the Diphu Polytechnic.  AICTE approval has been obtained for all polytechnics for the years 2015-16, 2014-15, and 2013-14 except that of Diphu Polytechnic. The Directorate of Technical Education, Guwahati, in its RTI reply stated that Ram Chandra Das, the principal of the Diphu Polytechnic was instructed to apply online for the consideration of AICTE approval for the year 2015-16, but he did not submit the online application.  It further mentioned that for the year 2013-14, Ram Chandra Das failed to attend the concerned meeting convened by the AICTE for consideration of approval.  It was further said that like the other nine polytechnics and four engineering colleges in the State, it was the responsibility of the principal, of the Diphu Polytechnic to submit the online application to the AICTE for approval. It needs to be mentioned here that the principal was specially reminded to submit the online application and resolve the matter with AICTE several times vide letter Nos TE(P) Scheme-4/86/1406 dated 31/03/2015, TEC.  148/2004/65 dated 22-04-2015, TE(P) Scheme-20/2013/3096 dated 10/07/2013 and TE(P) Scheme-4/86/1499 dated 11/04/2013 respectively. It is amazing that at the end, though the Deputy Secretary to the Government of Assam, Higher Education (Technical) Department directed the principal to submit the online application to AICTE for getting its approval for the year 2015-16 through letter No TE (P) Scheme-4/86/1406 dated 31 March, 2015, but no efforts were made by him. It is interesting to know that despite knowing well about his failure and negligence, he was then posted as the Controller of Examination at the State Council for Technical Education, by the concerned authority on April 27, 2015. Meanwhile, the local people have demanded of the Government to solve the long-pending problems of the institution immediately.

column1: Sathyamurthy Bhavan
column2:
Congress appointments upset Tamil Nadu party men  CHENNAI: The Congress high command has appointed AICC treasurer Motilal Vora and Indiaâs last Governor General C Rajagopalachariâs great grandson C R Kesavan to the TNCC Trust, which is the custodian of three properties in the heart of Chennai valued at several crores of rupees.  They fill the vacancies caused by the resignations of former Union ministers G K Vasan and Jayanthi Natarajan from the party. 
The appointments have upset Congress cadres in Tamil Nadu as neither Vora nor Kesavan have contributed to the growth of the state Congress and they expected senior state workers to be picked as trustees, informed sources told TOI.  It is understood that partymen are particularly unhappy over the choice of Kesavan as he is the great grandson of Rajaji, who was chief minister of Madras presidency and had split the party in the 1960âs to form the Swatantra Party, which helped DMK to come to power in 1967 defeating Congress.  Vora, a former Madhya Pradesh chief minister, is considered an outsider. 
In a statement, TNCC chief E V K S Elangovan said Congress president Sonia Gandhi has appointed Vora and Kesavan to the trust which is the custodian of the party headquarters (Sathyamurthy Bhavan) at Royapettah, the Congress grounds and the buildings at Teynampet including the Kamarajar Arangam, a popular venue for theatre and performing arts. 
The trust was reduced to three members -- Elangovan as executive member, former MLA D Yasodha and Rajya Sabha MP Sudarsana Natchiappan -- following the exit of Vasan, who formed a new party, and Jayanthi Natarajan. 
Following his return from the United States, Kesavan joined Congress in 2001 on the advice of veteran party member K Natwar Singh and was later appointed as director of the Rajiv Gandhi National Institute for Youth Development at Sriperumbudur.  âIt is an honour to be nominated member of this prestigious trust and I will strive to work for its improvement in cooperation with the existing members,â Kesavan told TOI. It is understood that partymen are particularly unhappy over the choice of Kesavan as he is the great grandson of Rajaji, who was chief minister of Madras presidency and had split the party in the 1960’s to form the Swatantra Party, which helped DMK to come to power in 1967 defeating Congress.  Vora, a former Madhya Pradesh chief minister, is considered an outsider. 
In a statement, TNCC chief E V K S Elangovan said Congress president Sonia Gandhi has appointed Vora and Kesavan to the trust which is the custodian of the party headquarters (Sathyamurthy Bhavan) at Royapettah, the Congress grounds and the buildings at Teynampet including the Kamarajar Arangam, a popular venue for theatre and performing arts.

Following his return from the United States, Kesavan joined Congress in 2001 on the advice of veteran party member K Natwar Singh and was later appointed as director of the Rajiv Gandhi National Institute for Youth Development at Sriperumbudur.  “It is an honour to be nominated member of this prestigious trust and I will strive to work for its improvement in cooperation with the existing members,” Kesavan told TOI. HC: Protest not at the cost of public order  CHENNAI: The right to protest cannot include right to cause nuisance or harassment to public at large, the Madras high court has said. 
Disapproving of police permission for a caste outfit to hold demonstration in front of Tamil Nadu Congress Committee (TNCC) headquarters on December 12, 2014, the first bench said: “The concept of holding demonstrations propounding or rejecting a political and social philosophy would be questionable, especially when it is outside the residence of some people or in busy traffic areas.  ”
A P Suryaprakasam filed a PIL seeking action against police personnel who permitted the agitation outside TNCC’s Sathyamurthy Bhavan in Royapettah, and people who had participated in it.  The protest was staged against certain comments made by Karti Chidambaram on former TN chief minister K Kamaraj. 
In the petition, Suryaprakasam alleged that there were designated spots in Chennai for holding protests, it is illegal on the part of police to permit demonstration in front of the TNCC headquarters on December 12, 2014 .  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Cong MLA files police complaint against state chief  CHENNAI: Unseemly factionalism racked the Tamil Nadu unit of the Congress once again, with the party’s Mahila Congress leader S Vijayadharani accusing TNCC chief EVKS Elangovan of using abusive language.  An Elangovan supporter in turn accused Vijayadharani of hurling at her abuses with a caste tone. 
Following complaints from both factions, Anna Salai police invoked IPC sections 506 (I) (criminal intimidation), 323 (assault), 284 (B) (abuse) and 354 (outraging the modesty of woman), section 4 of Tamil Nadu Women Harassment (Prevention) Act against Elangovan and three of his colleagues, including the newly appointed traders’ wing secretary M S Dhiraviyam.  A case has also been registered under sections 506 (I) (criminal intimidation) and Prevention of SC/ST (Prevention of Atrocities) Act against four persons, including Vijayadharani and Mahila Congress vice-president M Manasa. 
On Friday, Vijayadharani wrote a letter to AICC president Sonia Gandhi and vice-president Rahul Gandhi, demanding action against the PCC chief.  On Saturday noon, state Mahila Congress vice-presidents R Santha Sreni and Manasa lodged a complaint with police, charging Elangovan and three functionaries with verbally abusing them, including Vijayadharani.  The two complainants said they were also roughed up by some of the partymen. 
There was more drama later in the evening, with Alis alias Manohari, another vice-president of TN Mahila Congress and Elangovan supporter lodging a complaint against Vijayadharani and Manasa, under the SC/ST (Prevention of Atrocities) Act.  Manohari, accompanied by some senior party functionaries and some women wing members, all from the Elangovan camp, accused four partymen and women, including Vijayadharani and Manasa, of hurling abuse at her with caste overtones. 
Only recently, a group of senior leaders from the state, led by former Union minister P Chidambaram, had met Sonia Gandhi and Rahul Gandhi to demand Elangovan’s ouster and his replacement with a new PCC chief capable of taking leaders and cadres along with him.  The move brought former PCC chief K V Thangkabalu in direct confrontation with Elangovan, with both leaders aiming barbs at each other in public forums.  On Thursday, TNCC vice president and businessman H Vasanthakumar raised the banner of revolt, questioning Elangovan’s authority in removing him from the post of traders’ wing secretary.  He had been among those who demanded Elangovan’s removal. 
In her letter to party high-command, Vijayadharani said the PCC chief had been harassing women, which was bound to erode the party's women support base in the state ahead of the May 2016 assembly election.  In August, Elangovan invited the wrath of AIADMK cadres for his distasteful remarks about PM Narendra Modi’s visit to CM J Jayalalithaa’s residence. 
Party sources said there was high drama at the headquarters, Sathyamurthy Bhavan on Friday after some cadres ripped off banners put up in the premises to mark former PM Indira Gandhi's birth anniversary.  Vijayadharani met Elangovan and demanded action against the offenders.  “Instead of taking action, Elangovan used filthy language and told me to quit the party,” Vijayadharani said, adding she staged a sit-in protest for two hours, despite Elangovan walking out of his chamber soon after.  The vice-presidents, who accompanied Vijayadharani alleged that some Elangovan supporters roughed them up. 
Vijayadharani, who was made state Mahila Congress president in August, said because of Elangovan's attitude, efforts taken to win over the confidence of women proved futile.  “Elangovan cannot ask me to quit the party, whose ideology I love most.  Things are becoming unpleasant with him in the state,” she said. 
When contacted, Elangovan denied the allegations.  “It is a democratic party and any one can air their views.  I only told Vijayadharani not to shout and make a big noise and to lower her voice.  There are eyewitnesses to the incident,” he told TOI.  Insiders say that Elangovan’s remarks made in the ‘heat of the moment’ had vitiated the party atmosphere further.  Actor Nagma, who is also in-charge of the state Mahila unit, said, “Things have to be sorted out between the two presidents.  Any action can be taken only by our party high-command. ” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Elangovan, Karti Chidambaram resume war of words After a brief lull, the war of words between Tamil Nadu Congress Committee (TNCC) leader E. V. K. S.  Elangovan and AICC member Karti P.  Chidambaram resumed and this time it is over the latter’s tweet congratulating Aam Aadmi Party leader and Delhi Chief Minister-elect Arvind Kejriwal. 
In his tweet, Mr.  Karti said: “Lessons from #AAPSweep, no one is invincible, state politics needs a credible leader n an agenda.  People want leadership at their doorstep. ”
Congratulating the AAP and Mr.  Kejriwal for the big win, he said, “Many lessons to learn for the Congress particularly for us in the#TNCC.  Need a face n an agenda.  Will we?”
Reacting strongly to the message, Mr.  Elangovan said If Mr.  Karti was looking for a leader like Mr.  Kejriwal why should he search elsewhere.  “He is free to join the AAP.  He has said many things against the Congress party and it is for the high command to look into this issue and initiate action,” he said. 
Talking to reporters at Sathyamurthy Bhavan, he said Mr.  Karti was asking for trouble and he was not ready to play into his hands.  “The high command will deal with him. ”
Asked about Mr.  Elangovan’s remarks, Mr.  Karti said he was not ready to join issue with the TNCC leader.  “I stand by my tweet,” he asserted. 
Show-cause notice
A fortnight ago, Mr.  Elangovan slapped a show-cause notice on Mr.  Karti after he took a new initiative called 'G67' involving party workers. 
Mr.  Karti had explained that the idea behind the initiative was to bring together the generation born after 1967, the year the Congress lost power in the State, to modernise the party’s outlook. 
Karti’s tweet praising Arvind Kejriwal
irks Elangovan Jnanapith winner Jayakanthan dead Firebrand writer Jayakanthan, considered a colossus in Tamil literature, died here on Wednesday night after a prolonged illness. 
He was 81 and is survived by wife, two daughters and a son.  He won both the Jnanpith and Sahitya Akademi Awards. 
Jayakanthan never hesitated to swim against the current
Tamil novelist, short-story writer and essayist Jayakanthan significantly enriched modern Tamil literature by portraying the lives of those on the fringes society.  And he shocked the same society with his nonconformist views, often questioning long-held views on women and chastity. 
Sri Lankan Tamil literary critic K.  Sivathamby used to say that one of the greatest contributions of Jayakanthan was the change he brought about in the “process of thinking” in the Tamil literary world. 
“He wrote about the subjects not explored by others.  He identified the agon, a literary device in Greek tragedy indicating conflict, in the lives of the subaltern and popularised it,” he said. 
Born in 1934 in Cuddalore, Jayakanthan ran away from home to Madras and became a member of the Communist party at a very young age. 
His first short story appeared in a little known magazine Sowbakiyavathi.  He went on to become a prolific writer, authoring over 35 novels and novellas, innumerable short stories and two autobiographies—Oru Ilakkiyavathiyin Arasiyal Anubavangal and Oru Arasiyalvathiyin Ilakkiya Anubavangal—besides writing articles and composing poems. 
His novels Sila Nerangalil Sila Manithargal, Oru Nadigai Nadagam Paarkiral, Yaarukkaga Azhudhaan and Cinemavukku Pona Chithalu were adapted as films.  Jayakanthan himself experimented with film-making and directed Yarukkaka Azhudhaan, Unnai Pol Oruvan and Paathai Theiryuthu Paar. 
His novels and short stories published in literary magazines and popular journals made him a household name in Tamil society.  And in a state where Brahmins are at a receiving end, Jayakanthan viewed the community sympathetically and his works bear testimony to his views. 
In the Communist party, he was close to K.  Baladhandayutham.  JK, as he was known, said in his autobiography that it was Baladhandayutham, just released after serving a life term, who drew him to politics with his thunderous speeches. 
He took enormous pride in his skills as a writer and fiery orator.  He spoke his mind candidly, undaunted by anyone or anything.  At a meeting organised at Sathyamurthy Bhavan to condole the death of Chief Minister C. N.  Annadurai, he made the leaders squirm by lambasting Anna and the DMK. 
But he mellowed down with the passage of time and DMK leader M.  Karunanidhi, despite Jayakanathan’s contempt for the Dravidian movement, respected him and finally won him over.  “I have always been against the Dravidian movement.  But the leaders have always been kind to me,” he said at a meeting later. 
He shared the passion of many CPI leaders for Nehruvian socialism and had great respect for Indira Gandhi.  He later joined the Tamil Desiya Katchi launched by E. V. K.  Sampath and both of them, along with poet Kannadasan, went over to the Congress subsequently. 
He also edited a pro-Congress daily Navasakthi for a while. 
Once his popularity as a writer declined, and as the Congress’s political fortunes too nosedived, he withdrew into a shell.  Yet, his courage of conviction was something very rare, and he never hesitated to swim against the current.  Long before Rajiv Gandhi’s assassination, he denounced the LTTE as a fascist organisation at every opportunity, much to the chagrin of Tamil nationalists. 
He wrote very little in the last phase of his life, but used to be the centre of a regular adda at his room or in his residence in Chennai. He wrote very little in the last phase of his life.  AP govt. misused power: M.K. Stalin DMK treasurer M. K.  Stalin on Wednesday said though he was against felling of trees and smuggling of forest timbers, the Andhra Pradesh government had misused its power by killing 20 persons in the name of preventing red sanders smuggling.  In a statement here, he said the action of the Andhra Pradesh police not only violated human rights, but also inhuman.  He also wanted an inquiry into the incident by a sitting judge.  Pointing to reports that the killing of 20 persons in police firing was a pre-planned murder, he said the failure of the Tamil Nadu government to act despite the tense situation on the State’s border was highly condemnable. 
‘A pre-meditated encounter’
TNCC president E. V. K. S.  Elanogovan said the bullet injuries received by the victims had proved that they were shot from a close range.  “It seems it was a pre-meditated encounter,” he told reporters at Sathyamurthy Bhavan.  He also demanded a CBI inquiry into the suicide of senior engineer of the agriculture department Muthukumarasamy.  Jayakanthan’s views closer to Dravidian ideology, says Kanimozhi Forty-six years after writer Jayakanthan lambasted the Dravidian Movement and DMK founder C. N.  Annadurai at Sathyamurthy Bhavan, DMK MP Kanimozhi on Wednesday declared at the same venue that the late writer’s views were close to the Dravidian ideology. 
“He was never in favour of a nation in which Tamils or other nationalities would lose their identity and rights.  He also wondered whose interest the Indian Constitution was representing and argued that a Constitution denying self-determination to States was nothing but a slave manual,” she said at a condolence meeting for Jayakanthan organised at the Congress headquarters by the Desiya Murasu reader’s circle. 
Ms.  Kanimozhi said there was no difference between the State autonomy propagated by the DMK and Jayakanthan’s views on the subject.  She said even though Jayakanthan was highly critical of Dravidar Kazhagam founder Periyar, the grand old man appreciated every word Jayakanthan spoke at the Tamil writers’ conference. 
Writer S.  Ramakrishnan said though the Communist Movement taught and shaped Jayakanthan, Jawaharlal Nehru remained an inspiration for him.  “Nehruvian idealism found expression in his characters,” he said, rejecting the allegation that Jayakanthan’s works smacked of propaganda.  “He himself said one of the functions of literature is propaganda,” said Mr Ramakrishnan. 
CPI leader K.  Subbarayan said Jayakanthan was a continuation of the long tradition and greatness of Tamil land and its great men delved deep in wisdom.  CPI (M) MP T. K.  Rangarajan, Jayakanthan’s friend P. S.  Kuppusamy and senior Congress leader and editor of Desiya Murasu A.  Gopanna spoke.  Chennai today RELIGION

Congress men block road, seek action against AIADMK cadres Condemning the continuing incidents of burning of effigy of Tamil Nadu Congress Committee president E. V. K. S.  Elangovan and Monday’s attack on TNCC headquarters ‘Sathyamurthy Bhavan’ in Chennai by the All India Anna Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam cadres, Congress cadres blocked the road in front of their party office at Kokkirakulam here on Tuesday. 
Raising slogans against Chief Minister Jayalalithaa, the Congress cadres, led by former Union Minister R.  Dhanushkodi Athithan, blocked the road, disrupting vehicular traffic on the busy thoroughfare for a while.  They also tried to rip off the poster of Ms.  Jayalalithaa, but the attempt was thwarted by police. 
When the police warned them of stern action, the Congress cadres wound up their agitation immediately and went inside their party office.  The protesting Congress functionaries said that if the police decided to register a case against the Congress cadres for the agitation, they should first register a case against those who had been burning the effigies of Mr.  Elangovan since Monday.  Maintain law and order: Vasan Tamil Maanila Congress president G. K.  Vasan hoped that the ruling party will realise its prime responsibility for upkeep of law and order in the context of protests by AIADMK partymen against Tamil Nadu Congress Committee president E. V. K. S.  Elangovan. 
Mr.  Vasan, who was here to take part in the conference of TMC’s agricultural wing, told reporters on Wednesday that agitations must not cause public inconvenience and that people were keenly watching utterances by leaders of political parties. 
Leaders can no longer assume that they can expand vote bank by exceeding their brief while criticising political rivals, Mr.  Vasan said, in an apparent reference to Mr.  Elangovan’s portrayal of the recent meeting between Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Chief Minister Jayalalithaa.  “Those in responsible positions must not insult duly elected representatives,” Mr.  Vasan said, but added the TMC did not endorse the protests by AIADMK in front of Sathyamurthy Bhavan, the Congress headquarters. 
Total prohibition
On total prohibition, Mr.  Vasan said it could be practically implemented in stages.  AIADMK stages protests against TNCC chief E V K S Elangovan CHENNAI: AIADMK workers today staged protests here and in several other parts of the State against Tamil Nadu Congress Committee chief E V K S Elangovan for criticising the recent meeting between Prime Minister Narendra Modi and their party supremo and Chief Minister Jayalalithaa. 
After Modi called on Jayalalithaa here on August 7, Elangovan had slammed both AIADMK and BJP and in reference to the meeting he had used some words which were allegedly derogatory. 
Condemning him, ruling party workers staged protests and burnt his effigies in locations including T Nagar, Anna Salai and Manapakkam where Elangovan's residence was located. 
AIADMK workers, who tried to march towards Elangovan's residence and Congress headquarters Sathyamurthy Bhavan, were blocked by police. 
Tamil Nadu BJP president Tamilisai Soundararajan said her party would stage protests across the state tomorrow against Elangovan for his " uncivilised criticism. " 
While ally of the ruling party, AISMK chief Sarathkumar condemned Elangovan for his remarks, opposition parties have expressed support for the TNCC chief. 
" AIADMK regime can as usual file defamatory cases or could express their views democratically.  However, burning his effigies or violence is unacceptable,"  Karunanidhi said here in a statement condemning the protests by the ruling party. 
MDMK chief Vaiko too condemned the protests. 
Effigies of Elangovan were burnt in Salem and Coimbatore and other parts. 
AIADMK workers, led by MLAs, staged demonstrations at various places in Coimbatore. 
Elangovan had made the controversial remarks here on August 14 while participating in a protest organised by his party seeking liquor ban in Tamil Nadu. 
Meanwhile, Congress workers staged a protest inside the party headquarters here against AIADMK.  Congress men tried to burn an effigy of Jayalalithaa.  However, it was thwarted by police. 
Following the protests and counter protests, a strong posse of police has been deployed in Congress and AIADMK offices. 
Protests by AIADMK workers were held yesterday as well i

Training in rearing milch animals The Indian Overseas Bank’s Rural Self Employment Training Institute has planned to conduct a six-day free training programme on rearing milch animals. 
The programme is meant for educated rural unemployed youth. 
Candidates, both men and women, in the age group of 18 to 35, are eligible to apply. 
Interested candidates can apply along with their educational certificates, ration card and three passport size photographs to the institute at 1506/2, Fourth West Street (opposite to Thillagar Thidal auto stand), Pudukottai, on or before April 18.

column1: Bhitoripaam
column2:
Ruins discovered Correspondent NORTH LAKHIMPUR, May 6  Thousands of people, old and young, men and women have been pouring in from various parts of the district and outside to a remote village on the foothills of Assam-Arunachal Pradesh border in Lakhimpur district.  The purpose is to have a glimpse of statutes and other artefacts found on the backyard of Dileep Upadhyay, a peasant of Bhitoripaam village, Phoolbari under Nowboicha Revenue Circle of Lakhimpur district. 
Upadhyay, while digging the ground on his backyard for a well found statues, decorated pillars and other artefacts in ruins in layers.  As the news of these discovery spread into the nearby villages, people in large numbers began arriving in large numbers to have a look on them and to offer prayers.  All the antique artefacts, a broken beam with three statues, some pillars and other parts of architectural patterns have been placed for public display under a shed by Dileep Upadhyay where people are offering flowers and money as a mark of reverence and devotion. Meanwhile, the Deputy Commissioner and Superintendent of Police, Lakhimpur district, has visited the place and the district administration has taken adequate measures to preserve the antiquities for archaeological research and verification.  A team of Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) from Delhi is scheduled to visit the place for verification and research on the antiquities.  To prevent any private digging or excavation, the Lakhimpur district administration has imposed prohibitory orders under Section 144 CrPC.  A four member ASI team comprising research assistant Abhijeet Deka and State archaeological technical officer Nabajeet Deori visited the site on Tuesday.  According to them, based on preliminary investigation, the ruins are dated back to be during the period of 10th to 12th century AD.  However, the ASI experts said that final dating of the ruins could only be confirmed after thorough investigation and research.

column1: Wanowrie Bazaar
column2:
Defence Minister:  PCB members urge defence authorities to reopen roads  PUNE: The elected members of the Pune Cantonment Board (PCB) on Wednesday demanded the defence authorities reopen the Elite Lines Road on Ghorpadi village and Right Flank Road in Wanowrie Bazaar for public use.  According to the members, the defence authorities closed the roads without following a legal procedure.  The members pointed out that defence minister Manohar Parrikar, during his visit to the city on January 7, had directed the defence authorities to reopen the roads, but the latter have not followed the directives yet.  During the general body meeting, the members threatened to launch an agitation if their demands are not considered.  PCB vice-president Kiran Mantri alleged that the defence authorities are closing city roads citing security reasons without issuing a public notice to invite suggestions and objections from them.  “Local residents who take the Elite Lines Road linking Kalyaninagar and Koregaon Park are now forced to use longer routes to reach the same destinations.  The road should be reopened as there is no security threat to the army units,” Mantri said.  Senior PCB member Vinod Mathurawala said the wall constructed on the Right Flank Road linking Wanowrie Bazaar to the surrounding areas should be demolished and the road should be reopened for the smooth flow of traffic as it is maintained by the PCB.  The road was closed without issuing public intimation.  Mathurawala pointed out that the PCB has erected street light poles on the stretch and it has been maintaining the roads for several years now.  Another PCB member Vivek Yadav said the defence authorities should discuss the issue with the PCB officials, elected members and public representatives like MPs and MLAs.  “The defence authorities did not consult the principal director of defence estates, Southern Command Headquarters before closing the roads.  This caused a lot of inconvenience to the public,” Yadav said.  Other members Dilip Giramkar and Atul Gaikwad said the army should improve its security arrangements and construct a wall outside its units instead of closing the roads to avoid direct confrontation with people.  The members appealed to the PCB president Brigadier A K Tyagi to issue an order to reopen the roads.  Tyagi told the members that he is not the final authority to take any decision on the issue.  But, he assured the members that he will convey their demands to his superiors.  The decision to close the roads was taken as per law, he added.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Cantonment roads closure: Members call on Parrikar  PUNE: Elected members of the Pune Cantonment Board (PCB) have once again sought the intervention of defence minister Manohar Parrikar to re-issue directions to the defence authorities in Pune to reopen the Elliot Lines Road in Ghorpadi and Right Flank Road in Wanowrie Bazaar. 
PCB vice president Kiran Tushar Mantri, in the presence of MP Anil Shirole, has handed over a memorandum demanding the immediate opening of both the roads, among other demands, to Parrikar at the New Circuit House on Saturday. 
The other demands include relaxing the stringent floor space index norms, revoking the decision of the General Officer Commanding-in-Chief of Southern Command, Pune of curtailing over Rs 7.86 crore from the annual budget of the PCB for 2015-16, action against defence authorities not paying service charges of nearly Rs 276 crore to the PCB and the state government collecting local body tax from traders on behalf of the PCB. 
The government has abolished the LBT collected by the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) with effect from August 1, 2015. 
PCB members Priyanka Shrigiri, Atul Gaikwad, Dilip Giramkar and Vivek Yadav representing the BJP were present on the occasion. 
Mantri, in her memorandum, said Parrikar, during his visit to Pune on January 7, had issued directions to local military authorities to re-open the closed roads, but they had opened only two of the four roads.  She appealed to Parrikar to re-issue directions to re-open the Elliot Line Road linking Kalyaninagar and Koregaon Park and Right Flank Lines Road linking Wanowrie Bazaar to the surrounding areas as it was causing severe inconvenience to local residents, forcing them to use longer routes to reach destinations. 
The road closure issue had rocked the general body meeting of PCB on March 18.  The members had appealed to PCB president Brigadier A K Tyagi to issue an order to reopen the roads.  Tyagi had told the members that he was not the decision-making authority, but had assured the members that he will convey their demands to his superiors.  The decision to close the roads was taken as per law, he had said. 
Mantri also demanded the relaxation of FSI norms, which is one in the civil area and 0.5 in the bungalow area, as residents were unable to obtain permissions for conducting repairs and reconstructing old and dilapidated buildings.  The FSI restrictions came into force in 1988.  The Southern Command had rejected the PCB’s proposal to increase the FSI because of environmental concerns.  Mantri also demanded that the proposal of the new building bye laws be approved in public interest. 
On budget curtailment, she said the PCB had made a provision of over Rs 19 crores in the annual body for 2015-16, but the principal director of defence estates had curtailed the budget of over Rs 5.36 crore, which was further reduced to over Rs 7.86 crore by the GOC-in-C when it was sent for his sanction.  There is no need to reduce the budget as maximum income is generated from local sources, she added. 
The vice president said defence authorities had not paid service charges of nearly Rs 276 crore to the PCB.  The authorities had released funds of Rs 1 crore for 2014-15.  Parrikar’s intervention was also sought to release the service charges as soon as possible as it was affecting developmental work in the cantonment area. 
The board was getting its octroi share of Rs 18 crore from the PMC after deducting water charges.  After octroi was abolished in 2013, the PMC had stopped paying this sum to the board.  The civic body had started the LBT on April 1, 2013 which will be abolished from August 1, 2015. 
Mantri urged the government to pay the pending octroi dues to the board as compensation as the board is not authorized to collect LBT from traders. 
Parrikar held discussions with J Sharma, principal director of defence estates, Southern Command and others.  He assured the members that he would look into their demands.  An email sent by TOI to the defence spokesperson was unanswered.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Wanowrie area celebrates a more meaningful Eid  PUNE: At a time when festival celebrations are getting louder, this gesture by residents of Wanowrie, Ram Tekdi and surrounding areas comes as a trendsetter. 
There was a time when a wall of close to 20 to 25 loud speakers would blare music and 150 to 200 flex boards and banners would be unfurled at various junctions in the area for Eid-ul-Fitr. 
However, Eid on Saturday, was different.  Not only did the residents stay away from the loudspeakers and flex banners routine, they also donated food items and new clothes to 100 poor Muslim families in Ramtekdi so that they could celebrate the festival. 
They collected close to Rs 90,000 after deciding to do away with the sound and visual pollution.  The initiative, an effort from the Wanowrie police station and Maharashtra Muslim Front, started with regular interactions with the residents of these areas in the month of Ramzan.  Senior inspector Bapu Kale, in-charge of Wanowrie police station, said, " For a month we conducted meetings with youths, various mandals, senior citizens, NGOs and maulanas of the areas falling under our police station.  During these meetings, we appealed to the groups to celebrate Eid peacefully.  We requested them not to display banners and restrict loud speakers.  We convinced them that with the same money, some charity could be done. " 
To their credit, citizens responded positively and it was evident on Saturday when not a single loud speaker or banner was seen in these areas.  There are 11 mosques in Ghorpadi, Wanowrie, Wanowrie Bazaar, Wanowrie gaon, Ramtekdi and Salunke Vihar Road.  All these places did not have loud music nor the banners.  Nadeem Shafi Mujawar of the Maharashtra Muslim Front said, " Many families in Ramtekdi cannot afford daily meals.  Besides, the ingredients to cook the Eid feast are expensive.  We were happy that we could help these 100 families and at the same time celebrate the festival peacefully. " 
Mujawar along with other members of the organization including Shahaji Sawant, Sharif Khan, Hasan Quereshi and others bought new clothes including sarees for ladies, dry fruits, milk and rice and this was distributed to poor families. 
Police took utmost precaution in Ramtekdi area due to the recent clashes between citizens, but the festival was celebrated peacefully.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Duo attack three with sickles in Wanowrie  PUNE: Two men, brandishing sickles, went on an attacking spree injuring four men over a petty dispute in Wanowrie village around 11pm on Saturday.  The condition of one of the injured is serious while three others sustained minor injuries.  Police arrested one of the assailants on Sunday while a hunt has been launched to trace his aide.  " The assailants, Dadya alias Swapnil Waghmare (27) and Mazhar Shaikh (28), both from Wanowrie Bazaar, beat Abid alias Amit Ramesh Sasane (29) and attacked him on his head with a sickle.  Waghmare and Sasane had had a dispute some time back and the attack was in response to the quarrel,"  said senior inspector Bapu Kale, in-charge of the Wanowrie police station.  Kale said, " The assailants also attacked Tejas Nivrutti Chopade (24) and Abhijeet Deepak Gaikwad (21), who live nearby, when they tried to intervene.  The assailants ran away after villagers rushed to the spot. "  Sikander Khaivalya (38), who lives in the area, chased the attackers and tried to overpower one of them after some distance.  But they turned back and beat Khaivalya before escaping.  The villagers admitted Sasane in a private hospital.  A police team arrested Waghmare from his hideout on Sunday morning.  " Waghmare has confessed to attacking Sasane and others.  Shaikh, who is still missing, has been booked for abetment.  Sasane and Waghmare did small-time jobs together,"  Kale said.  Police could not record Sasane's statement because he is not in a position to speak.  The Pune cantonment court has sent Waghmare in police custody remand till July 22 for recovering the weapon and for ascertaining the motive behind the attack.  Pervez Inamdar, managing director of Inamdar Hospital in Fatimanagar where Sasane is being treated, said, " Sasane has suffered several injuries before.  He underwent a CT scan, but we did not find any major abnormalities.  His family members have sought his discharge from the hospital against medical advice. "  The victim's cousin, Atul Ganesh Wanawadikar (29), has lodged a complaint against the assailants which has been registered under section 307 (attempt to commit murder) of the Indian Penal Code.  Police have beefed up bandobast in the area although no untoward incident was reported from Wanowrie village after the attack.  Kale said, " No law and order problem has been reported in the area. " Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

column1: Mattuthavani
column2:
Seven shops sealed for not paying rent  MADURAI: Cracking the whip on erring shopkeepers in Mattuthavani Integrated Bus Terminal, city corporation commissioner, who conducted an inspection, ordered the closure of about seven shops, which had been eluding from paying the rent for the last three months.  Officials said the major crackdown on Wednesday against the shopkeepers was conducted after receiving a large number of complaints.  The shopkeepers were encroaching public space creating hardship for the passengers.  There are roughly 180 shops constructed by the corporation.  Many violations were identified during the inspection.  About seven shops have been closed down and the rest of the shops have been severely warned.  Many shops do not even have the shutters to close and seal.  Commissioner C Kathiravan ordered his officials to fine each shop without shutters with Rs 30, 000 and force them to install it immediately.  Cleanliness was not properly maintained and shops were found modified without the consent of the civic authorities.  Even as the shops were not permitted to use stoves to prepare food many were found doing it.  Items kept outside, encroaching the public space including eatables were seized.  He ordered the officials to raze down the modifications made by the shopkeepers. 
Kathiravan said, “Almost all the shops here violated the rules ultimately creating hardship for the passengers.  More than 20% of the shops here have not paid the rent for the past three months.  It is clearly evident that the monitoring officials have failed to look into the issues.  Although action has not been initiated this time, they will be taken to task if they continue with the same attitude,” he said. 
Expecting that the officials and shopkeepers would not follow his instructions, the commissioner came back in a few minutes by leaving his vehicle outside and true to his expectations he found the officials having left the place without carrying out the works assigned to them and the shopkeepers continuing with their business leaving his instructions to the wind.  He then instructed the officials to seal the erring shops, make the changes he had instructed about and asked them to send the photos of completed tasks. 
Having seized a large amount of edible items like biscuits, fruits and sweets in the sudden eviction drive the civic body donated them to old age and children’s homes in the city.  The officials seized materials like school bags which were sold encroaching the public area.  The school bags were asked to be donated to corporation school students who needed one.  Office space likely Corporation authorities who inspected the Mattuthavani Integrated Bus Terminal after receiving complaints from the public are planning to construct spaces which can be occupied for office use on rental.  C Kathiravan, corporation commissioner, along with officials including A Devadoss, assistant commissioner inspected the buildings which house the shops had a short discussion with engineering section officials too.  The commissioner mooted the plan of constructing a first floor which can be rented to private parties as office building.  There is space to the tune of thousands of square feet.  Buildings with the participation of private sector can be constructed there without much investment from corporation side and can be given on rent.  While the corporation is need of fund, the rental amount from the space could add the revenue.  The commissioner instructed the officials to plan something for office buildings instead of small shops as they would further create problems in the bus terminal, he said.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Bus operators claim toll fee on ring road is unauthorised  MADURAI: Aggrieved over the order by a single judge of the Madras high court Madurai bench in collection of user fee on Madurai's Inner Ring Road, an appeal has been filed at the high court bench.  Virudhunagar District Bus Owners Association (VDBOA) represented by its secretary has preferred the appeal against the single judge's order passed on October 31, 2014 partly allowing the VDBOA's earlier petition.  The members of VDBOA are the stage carriage operators operating either within Virudhunagar district or on inter-district routes between Madurai and Virudhunagar.  To ease traffic congestion, the government had established an integrated bus stand at Mattuthavani and an Inner Ring Road on the northern side of Madurai.  It was opened for public and vehicular operation from November 1, 2000, by virtue of government order of the municipal administration and water supply (MC. II) department, dated October 23, 2000 and toll fee was fixed for using the said road.  By the same order, the municipal administration and water supply department had notified permitting the Madurai Corporation to collect toll fee for the first five years with an annual rate of 8 per cent.  However, the toll collection continued even after the cut-off period without further notification.  Challenging it the VDBOW filed a case seeking to direct the corporation to refund the amount collected from its members from December 1, 2005 till date and further forbear it from collecting any toll fee for using Inner Ring Road in Madurai city.  The corporation told that it is entitled to collect toll fee for 15 years and as per the government order passed in January 2014, it has been granted permission for collection of toll fee up to October 31, 2014 with increase of 8 per cent.  After hearing it, the judge quashed the January 2014 order but rejected the petitioner's refund claim.  Aggrieved over it, it has now filed an appeal stating that the order is suffering from improprieties, perversities and illegalities, and hence it needs interference of the court.  The appellant obtained information under the RTI Act about the collection of user fee on the ring road from November 1, 2000 to April 30, 2014.  As per the information, the collection came to around Rs 120 crore.  Actually, the corporation had to pay only Rs 64 crore inclusive of interest towards the borrowed amount from TNUDF.  When it achieved the target, it still collects fee at the rate of 8% every year, the appellant said.  When the matter came up for hearing, the division bench comprising justices S Tamilvanan and V S Ravi ordered notice to be issued to the municipal administration and water supply secretary and Madurai corporation commissioner. Many violations were identified during the inspection.  About seven shops have been closed down and the rest of the shops have been severely warned. Commissioner C Kathiravan ordered his officials to fine each shop without shutters with Rs 30, 000 and force them to install it immediately.  Cleanliness was not properly maintained and shops were found modified without the consent of the civic authorities.  Even as the shops were not permitted to use stoves to prepare food many were found doing it.  Items kept outside, encroaching the public space including eatables were seized.  He ordered the officials to raze down the modifications made by the shopkeepers.  Kathiravan said, " Almost all the shops here violated the rules ultimately creating hardship for the passengers.  More than 20% of the shops here have not paid the rent for the past three months.  It is clearly evident that the monitoring officials have failed to look into the issues.  Although action has not been initiated this time, they will be taken to task if they continue with the same attitude,"  he said.  Expecting that the officials and shopkeepers would not follow his instructions, the commissioner came back in a few minutes by leaving his vehicle outside and true to his expectations he found the officials having left the place without carrying out the works assigned to them and the shopkeepers continuing with their business leaving his instructions to the wind.  He then instructed the officials to seal the erring shops, make the changes he had instructed about and asked them to send the photos of completed tasks.  Having seized a large amount of edible items like biscuits, fruits and sweets in the sudden eviction drive the civic body donated them to old age and children's homes in the city.  The officials seized materials like school bags which were sold encroaching the public area.  The school bags were asked to be donated to corporation school students who needed one. Office space likely Corporation authorities who inspected the Mattuthavani Integrated Bus Terminal after receiving complaints from the public are planning to construct spaces which can be occupied for office use on rental.  C Kathiravan, corporation commissioner, along with officials including A Devadoss, assistant commissioner inspected the buildings which house the shops had a short discussion with engineering section officials too.  The commissioner mooted the plan of constructing a first floor which can be rented to private parties as office building.  There is space to the tune of thousands of square feet.  Buildings with the participation of private sector can be constructed there without much investment from corporation side and can be given on rent.  While the corporation is need of fund, the rental amount from the space could add the revenue.  The commissioner instructed the officials to plan something for office buildings instead of small shops as they would further create problems in the bus terminal, he said.
