City corpn to fix 4,000 street lights in extended areas  MADURAI: The city corporation is planning to increase the density of street lights from 311 lights per square kilo metre to 344 in coming days. 
Mayor V V Rajan Chellappa announced the plan during his Republic Day speech on Monday. 
The corporation maintains 47,123 street lights in city limits, including 64 high mast lights, 11,200 sodium vapour lights, 33,495 tube lights, 42 mercury lights, 1,822 CFL lights and 246 sodium lights, from Madurai bench of the Madras High court to Mattuthavani Bus stand. 
The corporation will be adding 4,000 more street lights in extended areas of the city in coming days, the mayor said. 
Lack of street lights, especially in extension areas, have been the constant complaint from councillors during the council meetings. 
In the last three years, the civic body had spent Rs 6.05 crore for laying new roads at a stretch of 72 km, the mayor said.  The city corporation also effectively tackled drinking water crisis last year, he added. 
Fifteen employees of the corporation wee conferred with ‘Amma’ awards at the function.  The awardees were given Rs 5,000 in cash and a certificate. 
The awardees included 10 teachers from corporation schools who achieved 100 % results in last board examinations.  Four bill collectors – one each from four zones – also were part of the awardees for achieving tax collection above their targets, according to corporation officials. 
The mayor gave away the awards.  Last February, the corporation council passed a resolution of creating AMMA awards to honour best performing employees of the civic body.

Madurai rowdy on run held from Chennai hideout  CHENNAI: The city police arrested Mayakannan, a rowdy involved in more than 50 cases in Madurai and Chennai, from a hideout in Kosapet.  He was involved in several murder, extortion and robbery cases reported across the state.

Based on complaints from businessmen, police were on the lookout for the man.  They got information that he was hiding in Chinnathambi Street in Kosapet, and a police team nabbed him.

Worn-out city buses offer a rough ride  MADURAI: A journey in city buses here is no joy ride, as jerky vehicles and worn-out seats are putting passengers to physical hardship.  Just 10 minutes' observation of buses at the Mattuthavani Integrated Bus Terminal is enough to give a clear picture of the state of buses operating under the Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation (TNSTC) here.  Many buses are found without window shields.  The sheets covering the body of the buses are flaky.  Passengers also complain that shock absorbers in buses have little effect, leaving them with back pains.  The seats are also in a miserable condition.  Commuters are now increasingly dumping TNSTC buses, which are usually the preferred mode of transportation, for share autos.  P Santhalakshmi has not enjoyed a ride in a city bus for at least five years now.  " We last felt pleasure of travelling in a city bus when new buses (under the Jawaharlal Nehru National Urban Renewable Mission) were introduced some five years ago.  The buses nowadays have a worn-out look and travelling in one is no longer a pleasure,"  she said.  " In several buses, the window shields are stuck, broken or not found.  They cannot be used when needed.  During rains and heavy wind, we cannot sit beside the windows as there is no protection and we are directly exposed to it,"  said V Manikandan from Melur.  According to officials, there are 2,596 buses under TNSTC Madurai region, which also includes Virudhunagar, Dindigul and Theni districts.  There are 1,180 buses in Madurai alone.  Of these, 300 buses were received under JnNURM.  Besides places in the city, buses connecting other towns like Tirumangalam, Tiruparankundram, Usilampatti and Melur are also operated from here.  R Vasudevan, general secretary, CITU (TNSTC), Madurai, said the condition of buses used to be much worse.  At least now officials had intervened to sort out the shock absorber problem, he said.  When contacted, a senior official from TNSTC, Madurai region, said they are now looking into the issue.  " I have been concentrating on problems connected with shock absorbers in the buses provided under JnNURM.  The work is over and we have set right the problem in around 225 buses out of the total 300.  Now, it's time for us to concentrate on the body of the bus.  The issue will be sorted soon,"  he said. No major announcements, focus on revenue generation  MADURAI: For the second time in a row, the city corporation has presented a deficit budget, with the civic budget announced for the financial year 2015-16 estimating a deficit of close to Rs 6.24 crore.  V V Rajan Chellappa, mayor, on Tuesday presented the budget in the presence of corporation commissioner, C Kathiravan.  The budget estimates revenue of Rs 601.99 crore for the year against an expenditure of Rs 608.23 crore.  Confirming earlier TOI reports, no major schemes were announced.  The councillors fund, which was introduced last year, has been increased from Rs 10 lakh to Rs 15 lakh this year.  The fund will be used by the corporation upon special request from the concerned councillor for a particular work.  While councillors welcomed the increased the amount, some complained that the corporation still had not used the amount provided for last year.  M Chellam, councillor of ward 63, said the corporation had not used the fund allocated to her ward.  The mayor replied that when councillors requested for a particular development work in their ward, they should particularly mention that the councillor's fund is to be used.  A new Omni bus terminal near Mattuthavani has been proposed, expected to be carried out at an estimated cost of Rs 15.78 crore.  In addition, Rs 11 crore has been allocated for the construction of two lorry parking yards at Mattuthavani and Kochadai areas.  An additional 17 urban health centres and four community health centres under National Urban Health Mission (NUHM) have been announced.  Authorities said that instead of announcing big projects, they were concentrating on generating revenue.  The cash-strapped corporation is in no mood to declare projects they might not be able to fulfill.  Due to lack of funds, many projects announced last year, like construction of skating ground and another swimming pool, free transportation for corporation school students and establishment of 100 Amma children's parks, have not been executed. Expert who helped Sagayam in granite inquiry dies in accident  MADURAI: A 54-year-old man who helped U Sagayam in his investigation into the multi-crore illegal granite quarrying scam was killed in a road accident near his house in the outskirts of the city on Friday morning. 
S Parthasarathy, an aero-modelling expert, recently helped the committee during its surveying activities by videographing the areas affected by the rampant quarrying, using a drone fitted with camera.  While police registered a case under IPC 304-A (causing death by negligence), family members did not rule out the possibility of foul play. 
A businessman by profession, Parthasarathy had a separate aeromodelling laboratory at home and often engaged in classes with the students of top schools and engineering colleges to explain aeromodelling.  He held several demonstrations in the district and other parts of the state.  He owned several unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) out of passion and also spent time with researchers in this field. 
Police said Parthasarathy met with the accident when he was driving home on his hatchback early in the morning.  He left the house to drop a student, who had visited for academic purposes, at Mattuthavani bus terminal.  He rammed his car against a road side tree.  The bonnet of the vehicle was heavily damaged and he suffered serious injuries.  Passersby informed the police, and both the police and family members reached the accident spot at Veerapanchan in Madurai-Sivagangai Road.  He was taken to a private hospital, where he died at 7am, one and half hours after the incident, police said. 
Forensic teams were called in to collect evidence from the spot, besides a motor vehicle inspector and top police officers from the rural police department.  However, after elaborate investigation, police maintained there was no ground for suspicion. 
Talking to reporters, his relatives said all angles should be investigated.  The way the accident took place creates suspicion, they said.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Not even 5% of drivers adhere to system  MADURAI: Last Thursday marked the end of six months since the fixed auto rickshaw fare was introduced in Chennai.  Unfortunately, not even a 5% of auto rickshaw drivers have adhered to the fixed fare system in the city till now. 
Despite various efforts taken by the officials to ensure autos in the city ply by meter, they were able to achieve a feat of making 90% of regular autos and 80% of diesel autos to install meters alone.  RTOs failed to convince the auto drivers to use the meters.  Apparently, one can see many autos have not even removed cover of the meters since they have been fixed some three to four months ago. 
On October 16, the mandatory fixed auto rickshaw fare came into effect in the city.  Considering the difficulties faced by the auto drivers in installing the meters immediately, the district administration gave a grace period of 45-days to fix it.  Following it, severe checking was conducted to ensure all the autos were fixed with meters. 
However, the efforts following it to ensure that the drivers used meters only failed. 
Although RTOs conducted checks and even seized around 30 autos every month, it could not create any impact.  RTOs too showed slackness in conducting the checks on regular basis citing shortage of manpower. 
“I travel by autos often.  Not even a single time I have come across an auto rickshaw driver using the meter.  Even if you ask them, they say that it is not feasible for them as they have to return empty.  I can pay only for my drop not for the return,” said K Mythili from New Bangajam Colony. 
While a section of auto rickshaw drivers say that the fare set by the government would not help to earn a decent income, another section of drivers say that they want the officials to break the shackles of stand system and area problem. 
“If I go to Mattuthavani from Periyar bus terminal I have return empty as the auto drivers there would not let me to take passengers.  Since auto stands have flourished at every part of the city and they possess a command over certain areas, often we end up in picking up quarrel with them when we get passengers,” said S Muthumari, a driver from Periyar. 
“To end the problem, the government should increase the minimum fare at Rs 30 and Rs 15 for each additional kilometre instead of Rs 25 and Rs 12 at present,” urged N Kanagavel, district president of Madurai Auto Rickshaw Drivers Association of CITU. Madurai residents hope rain would help water flow into parched tank  MADURAI: Residents in Anna Nagar and KK Nagar are anxiously looking at the Vandiyur tank with a hope that the incessant summer rain would bring an inflow into the parched tank, which is their main water source in the northern part of the city. 
" It is this tank, which led to many residents choose KK Nagar, Melamadai and Gomathypuram, because it was always known to hold water throughout the year.  But, now this tank has remained bone dry for three consecutive years,"  said A Asokan, a resident. 
About 10 years ago, water flowed into the tank whenever there were heavy rains across the district.  But, now encroachments of major channels that bring water has led to the inflow stopping.  P Pandi, president of the Gomathypuram Residents Welfare Association and secretary of the Federation of Vandiyur Tank Water Development (FVTWD), said they are keeping their fingers crossed hoping that water would reach the tank, when water is released for irrigation in June this year from the Periyar dam. 
" We just have to hope that the water level in Sathaiyaru dam the main source for Vandiyur tank touches the magic number of 29 feet,"  he said.  However, the water level in the Sathaiyaru dam is only 13 feet, without an inflow or discharge on Saturday.  He said that they had obtained all information with regard to the tank through RTIs and all paper work was in place to ensure that the water reached the tank during irrigation this year.  " Usually, we receive water when water flows through the Kallanthiri channel.  However, this year, the channel from Moondrumavadi in K Pudur has been cleared and kept ready to bring water through the channel that crosses the flower market near Mattuthavani and the water coming through this channel would be much more and we could almost fill it up, with it,"  he said. 
Madurai North MLA, AK Bose, said that he had raised the issue of deepening the Vandiyur tank and also submitted letters to this effect to the PWD minister and chief minister.  " When everything was going well, Amma (Jayalalithaa) went through a difficult phase and everything was stalled.  Now, we can hope that everything will be set right,"  he said. 
The MLA said that he had also asked the authorities to clear the encroachments on the channel in Ilandhaikulam.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  TNSTC bus driver attempts to set self, branch manager on fire  MADURAI: A 38-year-old driver attached with the Tamil Nadu state transport corporation (TNSTC), K Pudur depot attempted to commit suicide on Sunday night alleging that his branch manager had forced him to work overtime against his wishes.  Senthil Kumar, who poured petrol on himself, also poured petrol on the branch manager Dhayalakrishnan. 
The incident took place at Mattuthavani bus terminal at midnight.  Both men were hospitalised after petrol got into their eyes. 
Senthil Kumar, son of Solaimalai from Narasingam Road in Kadachanendaal was reportedly supposed to have ended his shift by 9.30pm as his duty time started at 1pm.  Senthil and conductor Saravanan were operating the bus on the C3 route, which connects Mattuthavani, Theppakulam and Mattuthavani. 
When Senthil Kumar reached Mattuthavani at 9.30pm on Sunday, he was asked to go for a trip to Trichy as there was huge crowd to clear.  Senthil Kumar refused, citing health problems.  However, he was asked to make a trip to Arapalayam.  Though he wanted to take rest, he obliged and went on the trip.  However, when he came back, he was asked to go to Arapalayam again.  An argument broke out between him and the branch manager.  An angry Senthil Kumar reportedly bought petrol from a nearby bunk, poured some on himself and some on Dhayalakrishnan and attempted to set both on fire.  Police said Senthil Kumar could also be charged with attempted murder if they received a complaint from the branch manager.  The transport department and police carried out an investigation. 
R Vasudevan, secretary of Centre of Indian Trade Unions, TNSTC said when contacted that in the last three months, there has been pressure on the employees to work extra time. During a recent meeting with corporation officials, mayor V V Rajan Chellappa pointed out that most of the roads were covered with fine dust. 
Until the city corporation procured a suction truck for cleaning roads a few months ago, 25 workers per zone used to carry out the cleaning work. column1: Boodhan Pochampally
column2:
Thieves eyeing small temples It appears that burglars were targeting small temples. 
Since August 1, the thieves have looted at least 10 temples in various places.  They broke into a Lord Rama’s temple at Yarragaddagudem and another Lord Rama’s temple at Indlur of Thipparthy mandal on August 1 and took away gold and silver ornaments. 
On the same night, unidentified miscreants gained entry into Gangadevamma temple in Kattangur and took away valuables and ornaments of the presiding deity. 
The miscreants also made a futile attempt to loot another temple located at Muthyalamma Gudem village of Kattangur mandal the same night. 
Four days later, the burglars took away the ornaments and cash from the hundi of Saibaba temple at Aitipamula village in Kattangur mandal and also gained entry into a house located close to the temple and took away some cash.  Ten days later during on Saturday night, the burglars struck again in Anumula mandal. 
They took away ornaments and cash from hundi of Sri Pabbathi Anjaneya Swamy temple, Naidupalem, Sri Swyambu Sambulingeshwara Swamy temple, Peruru and another Anjaneya Swamy temple located at Anjaneya Tanda.  On Sunday night, the burglars struck again in Boodhan Pochampally mandal from where they took away some cash from hundi and Rs.  8,000 worth gold and silver ornaments from goddess Durga Devi temple at Peddarallapally village. 
Speaking to The Hindu , CCS DSP Sunitha Mohan said that they have asked the patrolling police to visit all the temples in their purview in the wake of series of incidents. 
Stating that the burglars were easily gaining entry into these temples since the small temples lack security, Ms.  Sunitha Mohan said that they were closely monitoring the movement of all the old criminals and assured that they would nab the culprits soon. 
However, the DSP said that they were not sure that all these incidents were interlinked.  The CCS Police have nabbed a couple of burglars a month ago who were involved in a series of thefts in temples.  Mauritius team visits Nalgonda The Minister for Social Integration and Economic Empowerment, Mauritius, Prithiviraj Sing Roopun, said that they would adopt various welfare schemes being implemented by the Government of India for development of various sections of people in rural parts of the country. 
The Mauritius Minister along with Permanent Secretary Bojrazsingh Boyramboli and other senior officials visited Koyyalagudem village of Choutuppal mandal in Naglonda district of Telangana State on Thursday to study the life of weavers, SHG women and functioning of Panchayat system. 
The team visited textile park at Boodhan Pochampally . 
Officials from the Government of India and State government accompanied the visiting team to both the places. 
The Minister interacted with the weavers, SHG women, members of panchayat and enquired about the impact of various welfare schemes introduced by Indian government on their their life. 
Speaking to news reporters after the interaction programme, the Mauritius Minister said that the SHG women told them that the life had changed a lot after the formation of self-help groups in the rural parts. 
“We understood that India took to growth path by eliminating poverty, improving literacy rate, effectively utilisation human resources and natural resources by implementing various schemes which we would also introduce in Mauritius, Mr.  Sing said.

column1: Sankaranpalayam
column2:
Drinking water supply commences in 3 wards of Vellore Corporation Treated water supply from the Combined Water Supply Scheme (CWSS) with river Cauvery as source reached Vellore Corporation on Tuesday, with supply to parts of three wards commencing in the evening. 
Officials said the clear water was pumped into the over head tank at Sankaranpalayam and was supplied to parts of ward numbers 33, 37 and 38 that included areas in and around Velapadi.  The Corporation has a total of 60 wards. 
The CWSS with river Cauvery as source is being implemented at a cost of Rs.  1,295 crore.  It is being carried out to cover Vellore Corporation, 11 municipalities, five town panchayats and 944 rural habitations across the district. 
Currently, the Corporation was providing 40 litres of water per capita per day (LPCD) to residents.  Drinking water was supplied once in 15 days to most of the areas, and commencing of CWSS is likely to improve the water supply.  CWSS envisages supply of 135 LPCD to Vellore Corporation, officials said. 
The trial run of the scheme commenced on March 26.  During a review meeting held last week, officials told School Education Minister K. C.  Veeramani that treated drinking water could be supplied to some areas in the Corporation within a few days.  Minor works that included laying of pipelines on the Chennai-Bangalore National Highway would be completed within a few weeks.  1,938 applicants to appear for UPSC examination A total of 1,938 candidates will appear for the Civil Services (Preliminary) Examination – 2015 of the Union Public Service Commission (UPSC) in Vellore district on August 23.  This is the first time that the exam is being conducted in Vellore. 
It will be held at six centres in two sessions – E. V. R.  Nagammai Government Girls Higher Secondary School, Kosapet, Muthurangam Government Arts College, Bagayam, Thanthai Periyar Government Institute of Technology, Thorapadi, D. K. M College for Women, Sankaranpalayam, N.  Krishnasamy Mudaliar Higher Secondary School, Sainathapuram and Voorhees College, Anna Salai, a press release said. 
A total of 1,938 applicants will appear for the exam.  Four visually challenged candidates will appear for the exam at Voorhees College. 
Training for exam hall supervisors, assistant supervisors, assistant coordinating supervisors and officers of various departments was held on Tuesday. 
Applicants should not bring electronic gadgets such as cell phones and calculators to the exam hall. 
To ensure that the applicants do not carry these gadgets inside the hall, two women police personnel and three men police personnel will be posted at each exam centre.  They would check the applicants for the gadgets and also see to the security of the hall, the release added. 
Special bus services are also being arranged for the applicants, the release said. 
Four visually challenged candidates will appear for the exam at Voorhees College Civil Services examination held in Vellore for the first time For the first time, the Union Public Service Commission’s (UPSC) Civil Services (preliminary) Examination was conducted in Vellore on Sunday. 
Six centres
The examination was held across six centres in the district.  A total of 1,936 candidates were eligible to take the examination.  However, there were large numbers of absentees for the examination that was held in two sessions. 
An official said 837 candidates appeared for paper I examination in the morning (1,099 absentees), while 806 candidates were present for the paper II examination conducted in the evening (1,130 absentees). 
Among the candidates were two visually challenged persons, who appeared for the exam at Voorhees College.  A third visually challenged person, who was eligible for the exam, did not appear, he added. 
The examination was conducted at E. V. R.  Nagammai Government Girls Higher Secondary School, Kosapet, Muthurangam Government Arts College, Bagayam, Thanthai Periyar Government Institute of Technology, Thorapadi, D. K. M College for Women, Sankaranpalayam, N.  Krishnasamy Mudaliar Higher Secondary School, Sainathapuram and Voorhees College, Anna Salai,
Convenient
Conducting the exam in Vellore made it convenient for candidates from the district.  Officials said earlier, the candidates had to travel to centres in other districts including Madurai, Coimbatore and Chennai to attend the examination. 
Thirty-one-year-old K. V.  Samikannu, a visually challenged candidate from Tirupattur, said this was third time he was appearing for the exam, and writing it in Vellore was convenient.  “Last time, I had to go to Chennai to write the exam,” he said. 
This teacher of a government school has been aspiring for the civil services from a young age. 
Officials said they had made all necessary arrangements including bus services for the candidates.  Lack of coordination switches off more than 1000 landlines in Vellore The partial disruption of telecommunication service in Vellore on account of the damage caused to the BSNL cables by the contract workers, engaged in the digging of a trench for laying main pipelines for the Combined Water Supply Scheme (CWSS) on Anna Salai in Krishna Nagar, has exposed the lack of coordination among the various government bodies which have to dig roads for providing services. 
The contract workers dug the trench for the CWSS envisaging bringing water from the Cauvery River near Mettur on behalf of the Tamil Nadu Water Supply and Drainage (TWAD) Board.  The trench was dug for laying a pipeline to connect the existing overhead tank of the Vellore Corporation in Sankaranpalayam so that Cauvery water could be pumped to the tank which supplies water to several wards. 
According to a BSNL official, about 1,200 telephone lines have gone out of order in the Thorappadi and Krishna Nagar areas for the last nearly 15 days on account of the damage caused to the cables.  “We were not informed about the digging of the trench,” said a BSNL official. 
A telephone subscriber said that this problem would not have arisen if the TWAD Board had informed the BSNL about the plan of digging the trench and ensured that the BSNL field staff and officials were present to identify the location of the BSNL cables. 
Another BSNL official said that coordination meetings of government bodies and departments such as the BSNL, the State Highways Department, National Highways and the TWAD Board which are involved in the digging of roads are held periodically.  But the coordination did not percolate to the field level, he said. 
A BSNL official said that the work of restoring the cables has been hampered by the flooding of the trench with drainage water. 
“Several telephone lines have been restored and we are working on a war footing to restore the remaining lines,” he said. 
K. A.  Sankarasivam, president and Gowtham Singhee, Treasurer of the Vellore Citizens Welfare Forum, said that the district administration should take serious note of the issue and ensure that there was better coordination among the various departments in order to avoid damage to public infrastructure and disruption of vital services such as telecommunication and water supply in future.  A coordination meeting should have been held between the TWAD Board and the BSNL officials before undertaking the work, said Mr.  Sankarasivam.  Middle level officials of the concerned departments should have been present while digging the trench, said Mr.  Singhee. 
The executive engineer of the TWAD Board was not available for his comment when this Correspondent tried to contact him.

column1: Jumerati
column2:
Cash worth 50K stolen from trader’s scooter  BHOPAL: A sum of Rs 50,000 kept in a scooter in old city area was stolen on Monday.  A case was later registered at Kotwali police station.  It was the second incident of theft from a vehicle within a few hours in city.  Earlier, one lakh rupees was stolen from a car in MP Nagar. 
Police said a grain merchant in Jumerati area, Shailendra Rathore, 38, resident of BDA colony in Koh-e-Fiza area in his complaint said he closed his shop and went to Lalwani press road to buy something.  A bag that contained Rs 50,000 in cash was kept in the dickey of his scooter which he parked in-front of a complex. 
On return, he found dickey of scooter was open.  When he checked it, cash kept in the bag was missing.  Subsequently, the matter was reported to police. 
Cops said the incident took place at busy market area where a number of CCTVs are fitted in shops.  Footages are being examined to get a lead on the accused. 
Earlier at MP Nagar, accused confused car driver who was waiting by saying some currency notes of Rs 10 denomination were lying on car’s roof.  By the time he got down to check it, accused disappeared with the bag containing cash kept in the car.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  BMC officials inspect development works Commissioner of Bhopal and officer in-charge of Bhopal Municipal Corporation (BMC) SB Singh along with BMC Commissioner Tejaswi S Naik inspected various development works being carried out in the city. 
To facilitate the citizens with better cleanliness, water supply and other amenities various developments works are being carried out in the city.  On Friday SB Singh inspected and reviewed the ongoing developments.  On finding inappropriate cleanliness services and absenteeism of employees at work in various areas of the city, Singh showed his discontentment. 
He instructed the employees to remain present on their duties and be punctual towards their work.  He asked the employees to finish the work within two days’ time.  He said that the cleanliness drive should be carried out in city with efficiency and employees should be persistent towards their duties or else stern steps will be taken against the concerned employee.   He further said that he will regularly keep a check on the ongoing works and also instructed the sanitary in-charges to inspect the cleanliness drive daily in their respective areas and prepare a report over it. 
The officer in-charge BMC, SB Singh along with Naik inspected the development works at Jinsi, Jehangirabad, Sultania Hospital, Central library, Hamidia Road, Bhopal Talkies, Sindhi Colony, Kazi Camp, DIG Bungalow, Chhola Road, Bus Stands, Jumerati, Chowk Bazar, Unani Shafakhana, Jehangiria School, Moti Masjid, Kamla Park, Polytechnic Square, TT Nagar and nearby areas.  During the visit Singh also received major information about the ongoing development works. 
On the visit, Singh instructed the sanitary in-charges to maintain cleanliness in their respective areas and keep a check on daily basis.  Further Singh will also inspect the areas daily and will provide better facilities to the citizens.  BMC removes more illegal encroachers The anti-encroachment squad of Bhopal Municipal Corporation (BMC) is continuing its action to remove encroachments from various areas of the city.  The squad removed more encroachments, here on Tuesday. 
The squad removed encroachments from 80 feet road, ISBT, lal Ghati, Gandhi Nagar, Ashoka Garden, Dusshera Maidan, Raisen Road, Kalpana Nagar, Polytechnic Square, link Road 1, Kamla Park, and nearby areas. 
Under the action against encroachments, the BMC squad removed five stand boards, two cycles, five boxes of mangoes, pan parlours and more from the shops and cautioned the shopkeepers to keep the stuff within their boundary or else stern action would be taken against them.  The squad removed encroachments and illegal constructions from markets, roads and other public places. 
Another team of anti encroachment squad also removed encroachments from Subhash Nagar, Anand Nagar, District Court Road, Government Press, Prabhat Chouraha, Raisen Road, ITI Road and nearby areas. 
While taking an action at the respective areas, the squad removed hand-carts, pan parlours, tin-shades, water tanks and other encroachments.  Besides, the squad also seized three truckloads of materials. 
Earlier the squad took action at Chowk Market, Jumerati, Azaad Market, Ghoda Nakkas, Old Vegetable Market, Hamidia Road, Sindhi Colony and nearby areas.  The squad asked the shopkeepers not to encroach at the public places and create obstacles in smooth movement of the traffic. 
While taking the action the anti encroachment squad gave a mass announcement asking the locals of the areas not to encroach again and maintain cleanliness in the city.  Inter-state Sansi gang's 7 members nabbed Seven members of inter-state Sansi gang of Haryana were nabbed by GRP Bhopal and recovered valuables worth Rs 10 lakh from his possession.  A city-based man has been arrested for harbouring the gang. 
SP GRP Avdhesh Goswani said that the gang was active in the area for the past one year and during the period, they have committed more than a dozen crimes and in the initial investigations they have confessed 12 thefts which have been confirmed so far by the victims.  Goods worth around Rs 10 lakh have been recovered so far and further investigation is on. 
Sayeed Ahmed Shah Arfin alias Bobby (38) of Jumerati Saray Central lodge near laxmi talkies area has sheltered 7 miscreants who belong to Sansi gang of Harayana and have arrived to commit crimes in trains.  He was nabbed earlier for thefts in trains but was granted bail on the basis of health problems, he added. 
The seven members of the gang belonging to Sansi caste have been identified as Satybhan Singh (33), Ved Prakash (36), Satyapal (20), Dalbeer Singh (35), Praveen Singh (19), Sandeep Singh (20) and Umed Singh (38). 
Police said that nabbed accused have confessed 12 thefts in past one year and it is possible that they have committed several other thefts in other parts of the country in the same period which would be investigated. 
Bobby who has sheltered the gang has played an important role in providing all facilities to the Sansi gang from shelter to food and providing vehicles for travelling in the nearby areas like Habibganj, Obedullahganj, Vidisha and other areas. 
During the investigation, it was found that Bobby’s wife Kausar Jahan and Sayeed Abu alias Babu used to arrange food and other essentials.  It was also revealed that Kausar used to travel with the gang to evade suspicion due to woman passenger. 
The gang has its presence across the country.  There are around 7-8 inter-state gangs and in which 40-45 Sansi gang members are active.  Bobby was wanted in seven crimes by GRP Bhopal and having a reward of Rs 25,000.  Bag carrying  cash, important documents stolen from Old Sindhi mkt A bag carrying Rs 19,000 cash and important documents were stolen from Old Sindhi market under Tilajamalpura police station area late on Tuesday evening. 
According to the police, the victim Jairaj Rajdev’s bag was stolen from his scooter parked in front of his house.  A complaint was lodged with the Tilajamalpura police and in his complaint the victim stated that when he returned home on Tuesday evening a youth fell on the road, facing seizure.  After spotting the youth suffering he rushed to his help by leaving the bag in the scooter. 
After the youth regained conscious and the victim returned, found the bag which he had left in the scooter was missing.  Victim raised suspicion that the youth and his accomplices have stolen the bag in a planned manner. 
Based on the complaint after the preliminary investigation the police have registered a case under Section 379 of the IPC and have started further investigation.  Bag was carrying Rs 19,000 and documents related to accounts claimed the victim. 
In the initial investigation police have found that the youth suffered from epilepsy and it is possible that someone from the group of people gathered at the spot to help the youth have stolen the bag as the locals are aware of the business of the victim and his routine which might have helped the miscreants. 
The victim owns a shop in Jumerati and deals in oil.  The incident took place on Tuesday when he returned in the evening after closing the shop.

column1: Krishanraja Sagar
column2:
Krishnaraja Wadiyar’s birth anniversary fete a low The 131st birth anniversary of Nalwadi Krishnaraja Wadiyar was celebrated in the city on Thursday but was a low-key affair. 
Reckoned to be the architect of modern Mysuru, the region witnessed a slew of developments under him including expansion of agriculture, Railways, establishment of major industries, completion of the Krishanraja Sagar dam, University of Mysore, Sahitya Parishat, State Bank of Mysore, urban and town planning through City Improvement Trust Board, reservation for the backward classes in public services (Miller Committee recommendations) to name a few. 
While the district administration garlanded the statue of the erstwhile king at K. R.  Circle, members of the Ursu community took out a procession with his portrait accompanied by a band.  Similarly, the Mysore Urban Development Authority (erstwhile CITB) paid tributes to its founder. 
The anniversary celebrations were more of a commemoration by garlanding the statue and were devoid of any programme or seminar to assess his contributions to the region.  The former Mayor, Purushottam, took exception to such low-key celebrations which, the officials, attributed to the prevalence of code of conduct due to the gram panchayat elections. 
But it is pertinent to note that there are no official celebrations on a grand scale by the district administration or the government to mark the birth anniversary of Krishnaraja Wadidyar IV though a demand for it is gaining traction in recent years.

column1: Yerrangali
column2:
Farmers block national highway, seek increase in price of land Farmers from various villages, including Veni Veerapur, Kolagallu, Yerrangali in Ballari taluk, on Monday blocked the Ballari-Kuditini stretch of NH-63 demanding the enhancement of the price of their land already acquired by the Karnataka Industrial Area Development Board and allotted to Brahmani Steels, owned by G.  Janardhan Reddy, former Minister and mining baron. 
Due to the blockade, movement of vehicular traffic was disrupted on the road for nearly two hours. 
Around 4,700 acres of land were acquired for Brahmani Steels as per the price, ranging between Rs.  5 and 8 lakh per acre, recommended by the Price Fixation Committee, headed by the Deputy Commissioner. 
The steel plant has not come up following the arrest of Mr.  Reddy by the Central Bureau of Investigation on the charge of illegal mining in the Ballari reserve forests. 
The committee had recommended the price for land acquired by the board for Arcelor-Mittal Steel Plant, in the same vicinity, between Rs.  8 and 16 lakh per acre. 
Recently, the price of the land acquired for setting up a steel plant by the National Mineral Development Corporation, a central government undertaking, ranged between Rs.  12 and 25 lakh per acre. 
Meanwhile, the farmers, under the Bhoo Horata Samiti, had staged a series of agitations demanding the increase of the price of the land acquired for Brahmani Steels. 
Now they are demanding that the price be fixed at Rs.  25 lakh per acre and also urged the authorities arrange for a meeting with the Chief Minister in this regard. 
K.  Mukudappa, president of the state unit of AHINDA and former member of Karnataka Public Service Commission, along with other farmer leaders, led the agitation.

column1: Kondathu Kaliamman Temple
column2:
Court moved to perform puja Madras High Court has asked authorities concerned to consider a petition moved by N. K.  Andavar seeking permission to perform puja at Kondathu Kaliamman Temple at Pariyur in Erode district. 
Justice M.  Sathyanarayanan asked the Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Department to consider the plea within six weeks. 
Mr.  Andavar said that puja was not performed in a traditional manner at the temple after the department took over the temple.  The local resident, who have been performing the puja, are not informed about puja conducted by the department, he said. 
Even the representations to the department in December 2012, and April last year, have not been considered.

column1: Elephanta Island
column2:
Coast Guard rescues boat with 78 near Elephanta  MUMBAI: Seventy-eight people, including 33 women and 18 children, were rescued after a fishing boat in which they were returning ran aground minutes after it started sailing from Elephanta Island on Tuesday. 
The incident occurred when they were heading home to Nhava village after performing the Maha Shivratri pilgrimage. 
They were taken safely to the Belapur hover port and disembarked after a 30-minutes rescue operation by a Coast Guard vessel.  The incident occurred at 4.45pm, around 7.4km off the Mumbai coast, after Navrang hit some rocks.  A defence official said it was not a registered ferry boat service. 
An SOS was sent from the boat and the state government alerted the Coast Guard.  âA team led by commandant Sandeep Safaya reached the spot, carried out a speedy operation, and saved the lives,â said inspector general S P S Basra. 
The Coast Guard received the SOS around 5.10pm.  A defence ministry spokesperson said the boat was stranded off Gharapuri Island, also known as Elephanta Island.  âThe rescued passengers disembarked at Belapur hover port at 6.15pm,â said the spokesperson. 
âPeople panicked when the rescue team reached the spot within 10 minutes.  They were standing on the boat after it hit rock bottom.  The boat has started tilting when the rescue team reached the spot,â said a Coast Guard official who was part of the rescue operation.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  ‘Temporary spaying centres to check canine population’  NAVI MUMBAI: The civic body will now set up temporary sterilization centres in every node to curb population of stray dogs.  The solution was proposed by deputy municipal commissioner J Sinnarkar on Wednesday, as NMMC has been facing the corporators’ ire for not being able to curb the stray population growth.  Sinnarkar added that they will identify the vacant plots for setting up these temporary centres in around three months. 
“In spite of having a sterilization centre, the number of stray dogs hasn’t reduced.  It has now become essential to undertake mass sterilization activities, for which more centres, equipped with all the necessary medical infrastructure, need to be set up on temporary basis in each ward,” said Sinnarkar. 
Officials from the veterinary department said that annually around 14,000 dog bite cases get reported in the city.  Currently, the civic body conducts sterilization programme from the centre set up in Turbhe. 
Dr Deepak Paropkari, chief civic health officer, said that the average monthly sterilization figure of around 450 stray dogs is grossly inadequate in comparison to their reproduction ratio.  “On an average, 1,500 stray dogs need to be sterilized every month, to be able to address their ever-increasing population.  But this cannot happen at the existing centre,” he said. 
The corporators sought an explanation for the increasing population of stray dogs in the city after the administration proposed to procure anti-rabies vaccination.  27 strays neutered by NGO in Elephanta: Activists of NGO In Defense of Animals (IDA) successfully conducted their first sterilization camp at Elephanta Island near Uran, earlier this week by sterilizing 27 stray dogs.  The Gram Panchayat reportedly could not fund this program but they offered IDA two large rooms to conduct the camp.  The NGO is now also planning to conduct several more such camps in far-off places to curb the stray population.  “The municipalities in bigger cities must also conduct multiple sterilizations of stray animals.  This is the best way to keep animal population in check,” said a Vashi-based animal welfare worker.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Finally, a speed boat service from city to Elephanta island  NAVI MUMBAI: After almost two decades, Navi Mumbaikars can use water transport again to visit a sought-after tourist destination in less than half an hour.  An air-conditioned speed boat service has taken off from Retibundar, Belapur to Elephanta Island on Friday.  The service is aimed at Navi Mumbaikars who want to visit the island without taking a detour from Gateway of India.  A first-of-its-kind service from Navi Mumbai, the boat will ferry around 40 passengers at a time and will take around 20 minutes to reach Elephanta.  The service has been launched by Hindjal Pravasi Vahatuk Sahakari Sanstha (HPVSS), a flagship of project affected persons and will cost Rs 200 per head.  Taking four trips a day (see box), the speed boat has an open sitting space under the roof and an indoor air-conditioned cabin.  The 17-km journey will cut down on time, compared to the routes from Gateway and Uran coast, which take over an hour.  “The service was delayed as we had to seek several permissions from various agencies.  Now, citizens can save time and money too,” said Ravindra Patil, president of HPVSS.  “We took the speed boat today and it turned out to be quite a pleasant journey.  Earlier, we used to take train from Nerul to CST then to Gateway of India by taxi, which was very expensive and time consuming,” said Ajit Koli, a Nerul resident.  Cidco had earlier facilitated landing jetty to a private agency to run hovercraft services from Sagar Vihar, Vashi, and Sarovar Vihar, Belapur, to Gateway of India in 1996.  But the service was discontinued a year later.  “Next, we will seek permission to run the service between Belapur and Gateway.  But it will take time, as Gateway does not have a jetty facility for such a high speed boat,” added Patil. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  AC speedboat service from Navi Mum to Elephanta  NAVI MUMBAI: An air-conditioned speedboat service started on Friday from Retibundar in Belapur to Elephanta Island.  The boat will ferry around 40 passengers at a time and will take around 20 minutes to reach Elephanta.  The Hindjal Pravasi Vahatuk Sahakari Sanstha (HPVSS), a flagship of project affected persons, has launched this service which will cost Rs 200 per person per trip. 
The speedboat will run four trips a day.  The 17km journey will cut down on time, compared to the routes from Gateway and Uran coast that take over an hour.  “The service was delayed as we had to seek several permissions from various agencies.  Now, Navi Mumbaikars can save ample time and money, too,” said Ravindra Patil, president of HPVSS. 
“We took the speedboat ride and it was pleasant.  Earlier, we used to take train from Nerul to CST, then to Gateway of India by taxi which was expensive and time consuming,” said Ajit Koli, a Nerul resident.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Ten-year-old swimmer eyes 8 sea routes along Arabian coast  NAVI MUMBAI: Ten-year-old Uran Boy, Raj Patil, will attempt to swim eight long distance sea routes between November 1 and 30 along the Arabian coast, to become the country’s youngest open water swimmer.  “He is aiming to enter the Limca Book of Records.  From December onwards, he will take on international sea routes to complete five more feats till June 2016,” said his father, Santosh Patil, an international swimmer and coach.  Raj will open the marathon with a 24km swim from Kegaon Beach to Kanoji Angre Island, followed by Mora Port to Gateway of India and return on November 4.  The third attempt will be include the swim from Elephanta Island to Mandwa Jetty (21km) on November 6 followed by Revas Jetty to Bhaucha Dhakka (22km) on November 15.  Besides, he will swim from Mandwa Jetty to Gateway of India (15km) on November 18, followed by Raj Bhavan to Gateway (15km) on November 21.  The Rewas Jetty to More Fort swim (22km) will be held on November 25 and the final Belapur Jetty to Gateway swim (25km) on November 30.  The funding for the expedition has, however, been a handicap.  “His school has allowed him six hours off every day for practice and I hope a few philanthropists will come forth to partially aid the adventure,” his father added. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Yet another milestone for city swimmer  NAVI MUMBAI: City swimmer, Raj Patil (10), has bagged yet another milestone by swimming across the 24-km stretch from Mora Port to Gateway of India on Thursday.  Patil touched the gateway and swam back to Mora Port in 8 hours and 54 minutes.  With this swimming expedition, Raj aims to set the record as the country’s youngest swimmer.  “The attempt was quite tough, although it was my practice route,” said Raj.  Impressed by his talent, senior naval officer from Karanja, P K Singh, rewarded Patil with a token of Rs 5,000.  This was followed by Uran MLA Manohar Bhoir presenting Raj with Rs 15,000 to square up a small portion of expenditure for the expedition.  “Raj has become the first swimmer in the country to cross this channel twice in a go in a single day.  Many did the one way swim but Raj made the return trip as well,” said Raj’s proud father, Santosh Patil.  The remaining swimming routes he will cover include Elephanta Island to Mandwa Jetty (21km), Revas Jetty to Bhaucha Dhakka (22 km), Mandwa Jetty to Gateway of India (15 km), Raj Bhavan to Gateway (15 km), Rewas Jetty to More Fort (22 km) and Belapur Jetty to Gateway (25km). Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Coast Guard rescues 78 pilgrims off Mumbai coast Seventy-eight pilgrims, who were stranded in a ferry off the Mumbai coast, were rescued by the Indian Coast Guard on Tuesday. 
The pilgrims had gone to visit the Someshwer Shiva temple near the Elephanta Island for Shivaratri on a local passenger craft, ‘Navrang. ’ Around 3.30 p. m. , while returning to the Nhava Sheva port, the vessel’s engine got stuck in a mud patch. 
“In view of the occasion of Shivaratri celebrations, a local passenger craft ferried 78 persons from Nhava Sheva to Gharapuri.  After visiting the Someshwer Shiva temple, when the vessel was making a return journey, it hit a submerged mud patch thereby rendering the engines dead.  The boat subsequently started to become unstable in view of the overcrowding,” stated a Coast Guard press release. 
“The vessel intimated the local police for help and two civil boats were sent immediately, which proved ineffective due to the treacherous navigation conditions.  The Coast Guard was intimated around 4.30 p. m. ,” it said. 
The Coast Guard hovercraft H-197 was pressed into action.  It carried out the rescue and relief operations.  Of the 78 pilgrims, 20 were women and 18 children. 
The Coast Guard claims that the vessel was carrying more people than what was permitted, and was sailing without life-saving equipment on board.  It plans to bring up the issue with the Maharashtra Maritime Board.  Coast Guard rescues 78 people after ferry runs aground near Elephanta Islands Using a hovercraft, the Indian Coast Guard (ICG) personnel on Tuesday rescued 78 people –including 20 women and 18 children, after a ferry in which they were travelling hit a muddy patch and ran aground near Elephanta Islands off Mumbai coast on Monday evening. 
The ferry “Navrang”, carrying 40 men, 20 women and 18 children, was on its return journey from Elephanta Islands to Nhava Sheva, when the mishap took place.    “The vessel was an over-crowded boat without any life saving equipment on board and was stranded in low tide,” a senior ICG official said. 
On the occasion of “Mahashivaratri”, the ferry had carried the passengers from Nhava Sheva to Elephanta Island, where Someshwar Shiva Temple is located. 
“After visiting  the temple, all passengers boarded the vessel at about 3:30 pm for their return journey to Nhava Sheva.  The vessel while manoeuvring to leave the jetty, hit a submerged mud patch which rendered the engines dysfunctional,” the official said. 
Before long, the over-crowded boat became unstable.  “The passengers were in no position to reach safety owing to rise in tidal water and surrounding depths.  The vessel operators alerted the police and sought their help,”
One police boat and two civil hired boats were immediately sent to the area which proved ineffective due to the treacherous navigation situation.  The police subsequently got in touch with Coast Guard Regional Headquarters at 4.30 pm. 
As a hovercraft is not restricted by shallow water, Indian Coast Guard hovercraft ACV H-194 commanded by Commandant Sandeep Safaya, was launched with medical and relief material from Belapur Hover Port at 5.05 pm. 
The hovercraft reached the stranded vessel at 5.24 pm and rescued all 78 passengers from the stranded boat by 5:36 pm.  The timely rescue of the passengers by Indian Coast Guard averted any untoward incident.  All the rescued people were provided with relief and were thereafter taken to Belapur Hover Port where they alighted and left safely for their homes.

column1: Amherst Street
column2:
Rats make life hell for Kolkatans  KOLKATA: Kolkata Municipal Corporation roads and civil engineering department is battling an unlikely foe.  The department has been struggling to repair roads damaged by rodents.  Large parts of central and north Kolkata have been affected by rodents, but residents living in the Amherst street and Baithakkhana market area are the worst sufferers. 
A visit to Guruprasad Chowdhury lane off Amherst Street and Sankar Ghosh Lane adjacent to Vidyasagar College (for women) on Wednesday revealed that these areas are infested with large rats, which dig holes into the lanes and damage the foundation of the houses. 
A poor garbage disposal system has much to do with the rat menace, complained Saswata Pal, a resident of Sankar Ghosh Lane.  Some residents have put up notices requesting neighbours not to dump garbage there, which the rodents feed on. 
A century-old building on Guruprasad Chowdhury Lane, Amulya Niketan, is under threat from the rats, which have also damaged a specially designed three-storeyed building beside Amulya Niketan.  Sanjukta Sen, one of the residents, said that the rat menace was growing by the day. 
“We have been suffering due to the practice of throwing left-overs on the roads.  We have asked our neighbours to stop throwing garbage on the road, but all appeals have fallen on deaf ears,” Sen alleged.  Atin Ghosh, member, mayor-in-council overseeing the KMC civil engineering department said the civic body was trying to take up a befitting method to eliminate the menace. 
“We need to undertake a survey to find out the damage and the routes of the rats.  The solution will follow,” Ghosh said.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Educational institutes blamed for student deaths  KOLKATA: The mysterious deaths of two students in north Kolkata and Salt Lake have turned murkier with their respective families registering FIRs against the educational institutes in which they were studying. 
In one incident, Utpal Raut, uncle of Rammohan College student Payel Naik, filed a case of negligence against the college hostel.  Payel, 18, was talking to fellow boarders when she collapsed.  Doctors at Medical College Hospital declared her dead, saying she had suffered a massive cardiac arrest.  Her mother Minati Naik said Payel was neither ill nor had a medical history.  “We have registered a case at Amherst Street police station,” said Bastav Baidya, DC (north). 
In the other incident, Bidhannagar South police have registered a case under Sec 306 IPC (abetment to suicide) after getting a complaint from Kishalay Das, father of Kamalika Das, 17, a Class-XI student of a central board school who allegedly committed suicide on Friday.  According to Das, Kamalika killed herself because her principal, class teacher and Hindi teacher had suspended her for a week for copying homework.  “We’ll proceed according to evidence,” said a Bidhannagar police officer.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Traffic trauma after Bowbazar blaze  KOLKATA: A fire in Bowbazar threw traffic haywire in evening peak hours on Monday.  Lakhs of commuters had to get off buses and taxis and trudge the chaotic streets. 
It took more than an hour for vehicles to travel the 6km from Manicktala to Esplanade.  The ripple effect was felt for hours afterwards. 
The blaze spared lives but gutted at least four shops, reducing property and belongings to ashes.  Till late evening, flames were still leaping from charred shops and plumes of smoke cast a blinding haze on the congested business area where shops jostle for space with century-old homes. 
The fire seemed to have started around 4.30pm at a carpenter’s ground-floor workshop that doubled as his home.  Initially, locals tried to douse the flames, but stacks of wood, plywood and adhesive fed the flames that soon spread to other shops. 
Carpenter Hari Sharma had been living in the rented accommodation at 150 Amherst Street for 50 years along with his wife Sona Devi, three sons, their wives and children.  “My son Nagendra’s wife had just stepped out to fetch her child from school when the fire broke out.  We lost everything,” said a distraught Sona. 
Till about 9pm, 35 fire tenders worked tirelessly to put out the blaze.  Police diverted traffic to MG Road to allow easy access for fire engines. 
DC-central D P Singh confirmed that there was no casualty.  Amid the usual murmurs of fire engines reaching late, neighbours and store owners close to the gutted shops were grateful to the fire fighters. 
“Thanks to the firemen, the flames were contained in time.  I shudder to think what could have happened had the blaze spread in such a congested area,” said Jyotsna Banerjee, who lives next to the gutted building where the fire started. 
The third floor of her house did catch fire though.  “A baby was born in our family after years a few days ago.  I heard the baby wailing as the maids ran down the stairs screaming for help.  That’s when we realized that our house was on fire,” said Banerjee.  “I’m grateful that we are all alive. ”
Owners of neighbouring stores sat on the pavements praying for the crisis to blow over.  With electric supply snapped, entire Bowbazar had plunged into darkness. 
Sona Devi, yet to come to terms with the loss, alleged her landlord’s sons had set her home on fire.  “They had given us an ultimatum to evict the room.  They filed a case against us, but lost in court,” said Nagendra. 
Those close to landlord Ashok Shaw, however, trashed the allegations.  Partha Mukherjee, OC of Muchipara police station, said: “We don’t suspect any foul play. ” Mayor Sovan Chatterjee, too, visited the spot.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Ominous signs in Kolkata’s erratic rainfall  KOLKATA: A steady but unpredictable change in weather has rendered Kolkata vulnerable to natural calamities that could affect nearly half of its population, says a study by a green NGO. 
More than 60% people residing along the Ganga would face terrible time in case a powerful storm strikes, it warns.  Essential services like power, water supply and sewage will be cut off in at least 50 municipal wards, the survey says. 
Based on an analysis of Kolkata’s weather over 110 years, Centre for Environment and Development (CED) points out a major change in the city’s rainfall pattern. 
Between 1905 and shows, the earliest onset of monsoon was on May 26, 1937, and the latest on June 25, 1976.  Monsoon was delayed 29 times between 1939 and 1980, but it’s a trend now. 
Till the Nineties, monsoon and rainfall were more or less predictable, it says.  But over the last two decades, onset of monsoon has often been delayed, punctuated by long dry periods.  They have been followed by phases of heavy rainfall towards the end of monsoon leading to severe waterlogging and disruptions. 
“The weather change is perceptible and has made vast stretches of Kolkata vulnerable.  We saw it when Cyclone Aila struck six years ago.  The city’s lack of preparedness was exposed.  If there is a repeat, the consequences could be equally bad,” said A K Ghosh, director of CED, who led the study. 
If heavy rainfall and a storm surge combine with high tide — quite possible in Kolkata’s conditions — it would spell disaster for river-side dwellers.  There is nothing to stop a wall of water from sweeping in. 
Some 50 wards have been identified as most vulnerable.  “This is where the damage could be extensive.  Kolkata’s power installations, water supply facilities, industries, warehouses and slums are concentrated in these wards.  A storm surge can leave the city paralyzed,” explained Ghosh. 
What’s quite worrying.  there is no system in place to tackle a disaster, he says.  “Neither is there a dedicated and trained volunteer corps to deal with climate change-related events.  Evacuation shelters for the population in slum areas are still inadequate,” said Ghosh. 
Garden Reach, Kidderpore and Tollygunge are listed among the most vulnerable.  So are some areas Maidan, Amherst Street, Theatre Road, College Street, MG Road, Ultadanga, Kankurgachi and Phoolbagan.  Even parts of New Alipore, Southern Avenue, Rashbehari Avenue, Deshapriya Park, Shovabazar and Shyambazar may be hit, the study says . 
It is time for Kolkata to have a dedicated disaster management plan and a team to implement it, agrees green activist Subhas Datta.  “The city is expanding towards Sunderbans which acts as the buffer during disasters like Cyclone Aila.  This is all the more reason why we should have a fool-proof plan to deal with such calamities.  Not having one is dangerous,” said Datta.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  IIT-Kgp draws up College St makeover plans  KOLKATA: If the ambitious Barnaparichay project has remained stuck in the doldrums, donât lose heart yet.  A couple of architecture students of IIT-Kharagpur have come up with a ârejuvenation planâ for a 300-metre stretch of one of the cityâs most loved icons: Boipara, aka College Street. 
As things stand now, the future of Boipara as envisaged by the IIT students â green tram tracks on both sides of College Street, a no-traffic zone, adda zones equipped with book and food kiosks â might be more in the realm of high fantasy, but could well become non-fiction. 
The plan by the IIT students, mentored by their teachers, has attracted the urban development ministry, that has agreed to fund the project, even though no one was willing to even indicate what costs are involved.  A source said it was âlikely to run into several croresâ. 
But the ministry, through the Institute of Urban Affairs and the School of Planning and Architecture, Delhi (SPA), has already started a dialogue with the state government, said sources. 
The planners hope to execute their design on a 300-metre stretch starting from Surya Sen Street crossing and ending at Mahatma Gandhi Road.  The plan also includes Bankim Chatterjee Street and Bhabani Dutta Lane. 
âThat stretch has been made completely out of bounds for traffic and converted into a pedestrian zone,â said Joy Sen, head of the architecture department, under whose guidance the students, Souradeep Paul and Sweeya Tangudu, worked. 
âOnly the tram tracks have been allowed.  The pavements have been broadened and the book stalls converted into shaded bamboo kiosks,â Sen added. 
The design also caught the eye of Bina Balakrishnan, one of the countryâs best-known traffic flow designers, based in Bengaluru. 
Noticing the potential in the project, Balakrishnan herself studied the traffic flow on College Street and come up with a suggestion: divert traffic to Surya Sen Street and make it emerge from MG Road at the Amherst Street crossing.  âItâs possible.  We have to work it out with the traffic and urban development departments,â she told TOI. 
The adda zones have been specially designed for intellectual discussions, like it used to be on College Street, said the students. 
The project will shape up in partnership with the KMC, since it involves heritage.  âWe are thankful to IIT-Kharagpur for the design.  We are looking forward to thrashing out the details with the Centre, so that the project can be implemented.  It involves a lot of money and we hope to be funded by the ministry,â said mayor Sovan Chatterjee.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Kolkataâs own rescue team is on the job 24X7  KOLKATA: Rescuing is their mission and passion.  Because of their commitment to come to the aid of people in distress even Kolkata Police counts on them as friends in need.  Nitaidas Mukherjee and his team have been working silently in Kolkata on rescue missions for a while now. 
âBe it rescuing an abandoned child or an ailing person found on the street or helping rescue and hospitalization of the injured during disasters like fire, we can always bank on Nitaidas Mukherjee and his team for support.  They are there whenever we require them,â said an officer of Muchipara police station. 
The Muchipara police station called the Dasâs rescue ambulance and the team during the Amherst Street fire on February 2.  The emergency rescue team reached within minutes and assisted the fire fighters and police.  Though firefighters doused the flames efficiently and no casualty was reported, the rescue team stationed themselves there to tend to the minor wounds sustained by the firefighters. 
âThis rescue team is present whenever there is a fire in the city.  Their ambulance is equipped with emergency medicine and first aid equipment.  They are doing a commendable job,â said an official from the fire brigade. 
Nitaidas started his social work as a 10-year-old when he and a friend tended to an ailing boy found near Dhakuria lake.  Nitaidas decided to completely devote himself to social work by founding HIVE India, a non-profitable organization, about two decades ago to rescue the abandoned and the lost, counsel them and help them reunite with their families.  The organization also helped educate street children.  The latest addition to its profile is the 24X7 emergency response unit. 
The unit boasts of 15 regular volunteers trained in rescue operation, apart from those who come and go.  The unit has three fully equipped rescue ambulances as well. 
âEarlier I used to work on my own to help people in distress whenever possible.  When I came across this team I joined it as working as a united force would give a better chance of success,â said Debabrata Chakraborty from Dhakuria, a volunteer. 
The team works in association with the Kolkata Police, organizations like Childline, government agencies like the disaster management group, child welfare committee and others.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.   Fake notes cloned too close to true  KOLKATA: Counterfeiters in Kolkata have managed to clone six security features â including micro-printing and the security thread â triggering concern among security agencies and the Reserve Bank of India. 
Whatâs unique this time is that the racketeers seem to have painstakingly extracted the security thread from condemned notes that are auctioned by RBI.  These are inserted into fake notes by expert goldsmiths who are hired from parts of Howrah, say sources. 
The Special Task Force (STF) of Kolkata Police is questioning two close aides of an arrested suspect, Chandrasekhar Jaiswal, to find out how they sourced the printing machine.  STF fears that the counterfeit notes came from outside the city because the unit busted at Kankurgachi doesnât have the precision to make such fake notes.  Investigators suspect the criminals downloaded the printing procedure from the internet to produce counterfeit notes at Domjur, Howrah.  Police expect âsome good newsâ by late Friday night. 
âWe want to ascertain how Chandrashekar managed to get hold of the money dice template and thread for rupee notes and foreign currency too.  We have asked RBI if it recently auctioned any scrap items and a list of those who participated in it.  We are in touch with Customs and NIA, too,â said a source, adding that they also want to know if a dice was stolen in 2012. 
So far, STF has found that the gang methodically procured shredded notes auctioned by RBI to extract the security threads.  âYou need master goldsmiths, found in the hundreds in Howrah, to carry out this work.  We have 12 suspects under our scanner,â said an officer.  âIn some fake notes, the security threads were intact.  They look just like the original.  We had to take the opinion of experts to confirm they were fakes. â
What also worries security agencies is the fake foreign currency seized from the gang.  âThe idea was to push them in the Kolkata currency transfer market.  We have asked our informers to get in touch with dealers,â said a source.  The cyber crime wing is trying to retrieve Chandrashekarâs emails that were sent on 20 4G dongles.  The original designs of Turkish, Zimbabwean and Euro notes reached him through email, say investigators. 
Banking and security establishments have confirmed uncanny similarities between the fake notes found on Farakka Express last week and those seized from Amherst Street in Kolkata.  Police went on the overdrive after a private bank recovered fake notes of lakhs in face value during a transaction with a businessman in North Dinajpur.  The seized notes have six basic security features â micro-printing, the Gandhi watermark, green security thread, use of 100% cotton paper, embossing by insertion of intaglio images and the electro watermark â that RBI uses to prevent counterfeiting.  Whatâs most shocking, micro-printing â one of the most important security features â has been compromised. 
Three other key features, including the optically variable colour feature, are still secure.  The fake notes were so perfect that RBI experts took hours to identify each note.  This has led RBI to consider adding other security features that can be detected only under UV rays.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest India News.  Downpour catches Kolkata unawares  KOLKATA: Heavy rain drenched the city and the suburbs on Monday evening.  The short, sharp shower caused waterlogging in some areas of the city and two persons were killed by lightning in Burdwan.  The wind speed being less than 79kmph, the city did not get a Nor’wester.  However, the districts received higher wind speeds.  The Met office said that the possibility of rain on Tuesday, however, is very low. 
A cyclonic circulation building over Gangetic West Bengal, Odisha and Chhattisgarh for a few days triggered the rain.  Hours before the thundershower, Met office had predicted rain for districts in South Bengal. 
“The cyclonic circulation is waning and we expect it to weaken further.  The chances of rain on Tuesday are very low,” said director of Kolkata reg-ional meteorological centre G C Debnath. 
Stretches on EM Bypass were the worst affected on Monday evening, with areas in Mukundapur, Patuli, Kalikapur and Madurdah getting waterlogged and affecting vehicular movement. 
The civic body was also caught unawares as areas like Amherst Street, CR Avenue and College Street localities were also waterlogged. 
Flight operations were hit for over an hour at Kolkata airport as the thunderstorm and lightning lashed Dum Dum.  All departures were halted and five incoming flights were diverted. 
Many Kolkatans welcomed the respite from the heat and humidity.  “I have been waiting for the rain since last Friday.  I hope it rains more often to keep the mercury in check,” said Sushmita Laha of Lake Town. 
But the story was different in the districts.  Suresh (40) and his son Jogu (25) were were at their paddy field in Burdwan’s Searsole when the thunder squall hit the district. 
They rushed to take shelter under a tree but were struck by lightning and died.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  TMC scores brownie points with Kolkata's sewer network upgrade  KOLKATA: Every May, residents of Sukeas Street, Amherst Street and Kesab Sen Street would dread the arrival of monsoon.  Rains always brought with it nightmares for them, flooding streets and even invading homes.  Since last year though, the situation has undergone a sea change.  Overhaul of the main sewer line along APC Road and AJC Bose Road cleared the clogging.  At Hrishikesh Park on Amherst Street, capacity of the drainage pumping station was increased and new pumps were installed.  This has raised the water carrying capacity of the drainage pipelines significantly and monsoon is not synonymous to inundation anymore. 
“The situation has changed dramatically.  Sukeas Street used to get flooded at the slightest downpour.  Water would inundate all homes.  Photographers would rush to take pictures of boats plying on the street.  But now, water recedes quickly,” said 73-year-old Tapan Kumar Lahiri, who grew up in the locality. 
Shilpa Gupta, a research scholar and a resident of Amherst Street, recollected how the locality would stink after a heavy downpour as water would get stagnant for a couple of days.  “While people enjoy monsoon after a spell of scorching heat, monsoon was like a nightmare for residents of Amherst Street.  We would get marooned after spells of heavy shower.  Now with a marked improvement in the drainage network, we are ready to welcome the rainy season,” she said. 
Some though are unhappy because they have lost the opportunity to make a killing.  Lalji Mahato, who has been pulling rickshaws for decades, rued the loss of big bucks during monsoon when he would make in a day as much as he otherwise did in 10 days. 
According to a KMC drainage department official the overhaul of the century-old brick sewerlines along APC Road had made the difference.  “The underground sewerage system along APC Road, which drains water of areas like Bidhan Sarani, Kesab Sen Street, Amherst Street and Sukeas Street, was on the verge of a collapse.  An overhaul of the network increased its capacity.  So the picture has changed,” the KMC official said. 
Being aware of the impact of the drainage development scheme, the Trinamool Congress has made it an elections issue.  The civic cell of the ruling party has put up hoardings and banners across the city claiming that a change in the drainage system has been an achievement of the present civic board. 
Mayor Sovan Chatterjee, who had planned a poll campaign two months ago, had stressed on the issue of waterlogging and its solution during the present civic board’s regime.  “We planned and took measures to free certain areas of the city of waterlogging.  We have become successful as residents in areas such as Amherst Street, Sukeas Street and Camac Street — known as waterlogging-prone areas — have been freed of that sinking feelings,” Chatterjee said. 
The Left Front however, refuses to admit the task as an achievement of the Trinamool Congress board.  On the contrary, Rupa Bagchi, the opposition leader in the KMC, claimed that the Left Front board had conceived a Rs 500 crore sewerage and drainage upgrade plan under JNnURM scheme in 2008 and accordingly work started next year.  “We had planned the project and executed the same in large areas of the city,” Bagchi said. SFI activists hurt in lathicharge  KOLKATA: The city centre turned into a battlefield following a police crackdown on Left student activists at Rani Rashmani Avenue on Thursday afternoon.  A total 37 students were injured in the police lathicharge, of which four had to undergo CT scan at Medical College and Hospital.  Nine policemen including four lady police officers sustained injuries. 
Sensing the the reactions, police commissioner Surajit Kar Purakayastha held a press meet in the evening to explain under what circumstances the police had to take steps.  The Left student organisations had taken out the rally on the second death anniversary of SFI leader Sudipto Gupta demanding a judicial inquiry.  Sen died in custody two years ago, while being taken to prison in a bus, after a similar law violation programme. 
The student rally was peaceful in the entire stretch from College Square to Rani Rashmani Avenue with senior policemen — the joint CP and several DCs — were seen walking the streets in front.  A huge barricade was put up at Rani Rashmani Avenue to stop the rallyists at this point.  Unarmed policemen stood behind the barricade. 
Seeing the elaborate police arrangements ahead a section of SFI students began breaking law by removing the barricades placed on the sides of the thoroughfare.  While some pushed ahead, the policemen standing behind tried to push them back leading to a scuffle.  Little did the agitators know that a team of lathi wielding policemen would charge them from behind.  These policemen came from along the Dorina Crossing end and lathicharged the students.  Taken aback by the sudden attack, some retraced their steps while others joined in a counter attack taking out the poles tied to the SFI flags.  A policeman was found daring the crowd.  Later he gave them a chase and was caught in the mob. 
Many students who broke their head in the clash cursed the police that lathicharged the unarmed students.  “Police unleashed a reign of terror today.  They were in a combative mood from the very beginning.  Police hit SFI state committee member Soumen Mitra on his head while he stood beside me.  Today’s incident is a sad commentary on the state’s law and order,” said SFI all India general secretary and CPM MP Ritabrata Banerjee.  Later, CPM state secretary Surjya Kanta Mishra and Left Front chairman Biman Bose paid a visit to the hospital. 
The police commissioner didn’t mention about the lathicharge.  He only said that the police had to take steps against a group of SFI students who were trying to push through the barricades and heading towards Raj Bhavan.  “When SFI representatives had come to us asking permission for the rally, we told them to defer the date because the President of India was in town and he was staying at Raj Bhavan.  They kept insisting on holding the rally to mark the death anniversary of their leader Sudipto Gupta.  We had to guard the area around Raj Bhavan for obvious reasons.  There was a magistrate on the spot and buses to take the agitators in custody after law violation,” the commissioner said. 
Claiming that the police were transparent, the police commissioner dished out the “unedited CCTV footage of the incident. ” The footage captured at around 3.12 pm showed SFI activists were being pushed back.  The main aluminium barricade had unarmed policemen behind it.  It was not clear though what prompted these students to retrace their steps.  It revealed that SFI activists were taking out poles from the flags and throwing them at the police.  “They also pelted stones at the police.  Since the President is in town, we had to take steps to control the mob,” the police commissioner said.  Additional officer in charge Amherst Street Manoj Jha sustained serious injuries.  Police have recorded a case in the New Market Police Station. 
While SFI all India secretary held that Sudipto was “killed in custody” two years ago, the police commissioner read out excerpts of the inquiry report that indicated that the student leader might have hit a light post on the way to prison while he was leaning out of the bus taking student activists to jail.
