Apart from India, the racket was active in the US and Canada, where the gang lured clients with offers to service computers at nominal rates.  Two of the fraudsters â Sanjay Mandal and Sanky Jaiswal â were arrested on Saturday. 
The gang, which duped hundreds over the last six months, used a method commonly used by professionals to serve overseas clients.  Initially they built a large database sourced from companies based in Sector V in Salt Lake.  Based on this database, Mandal called up people in India, the US and Canada. 
Using the alias Daniel, Mandal told them that their computers have junk files and cookies that can harm it and enable data theft.  He offered to clear the files and make the machine run at an optimum speed for a nominal charge.  According to police, the gang charged around $100 for each cleaning. 
Mandal, a resident of Murshidabad, and Jaiswal, a resident of Kolkataâs Amherst Street, rented two flats at Rabindrapally in Kestopur, which served as their office.  After the âclientsâ agreed to pay the amount, Mandal asked them to click open a software called TeamViewer.  TeamViewer is used by professionals to provide remote servicing and hence there was nothing to suspect.  Through TeamViewer, Mandal got remote access to the clientâs computer and hacked it.  Then he stole important data, including bank account details and passwords. 
Mandal apparently admitted to police that he stored the password and used it to steal data after the computer was serviced.  While the system was hacked, no junk files were deleted.  The amount due with the client was then transferred to a receiver based in the US.  The receiver later transferred the amount to a money transfer agency.  Police believe international money transfer agencies are also involved in the racket. 
But the fraud did not end there.  Mandal called up the client once again, posing as a government employee.  He claimed that the client had been cheated and that the fraud had been detected by the âanti-scam branchâ.  The organization would give the money back if the person agreed to pay the charges required for transferring funds back to him.  Some of the âclientsâ agreed and wired the money. 
âBased on definite leads, we set a trap to arrest them from Kestopur.  We think a bigger gang is involved and are trying to crack the rest,â said Arka Banerjee, ACP, Airport Zone II.  The duo had also roped in a few NGOs in the racket.  The US-based agents and money transfer agencies were given a part of the amount as âcommissionâ.  Police recovered eight credit and debit cards, a swiping machine, a laptop, a few dongles and three handsets.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Films make stamps post perfect  KOLKATA: What’s the connection between a cell phone, a stamp and an actress? Difficult, unless one is aware of Austrian-American actress Hedy Lamarr.  During World War II, she along with composer George Antheil developed spread spectrum and frequency hopping.  The principles of her work have been incorporated into modern Wi-Fi, CDMA and Bluetooth technology.  She was inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame.  A stamp released on her from Austria happens to be among the thousands of others in the collection of Kolkata-based philatelist Dipok De.  The grand old man of Indian philately and one of the founder members of Cine Central is now working on an as-yet untitled English book on cinema and stamps. 
Seated in his office on the ground floor of a residential apartment on Amherst Street, 78-year-old Dipok De knows about the history of world cinema like the back of his palm.  Clad in a batik punjabi and a lungi, De runs his fingers through his greying beard as he points at the stamp folders and says, “India was the first country to design a stamp on Charlie Chaplin!”
Born in Chittagong, De had shifted to Burma during his childhood.  That’s where he got smitten by the film bug before coming to Kolkata where he enrolled into the Indian College of Arts and Draftsmanship.  Thereafter, he opened his own advertising firm and used to work on ads that were published in newspapers abroad.  “In 1990, I wanted to host a national exhibition called Cinepex.  But few stamps on world cinema were available then.  So, I had to include other personalities.  The scenario changed in 1995.  The world celebrated the centenary of Lumiere Brothers,” he informs. 
The advent of emails, however, was a blessing in disguise.  “To survive, post offices worldwide tapped on the interest in cinema to issue stamps that would appeal to collectors.  The maximum number of stamps was released on Marilyn Monroe! I personally have 200 stamps on her,” De says. 
Some countries issued real gold, silver and platinum stamps too.  “I’ve a gold-plated stamp on ‘Gone With The Wind’,” De proudly shows while ruing the fact that India still hasn’t cashed in on this trend because of bureaucratic issues.  “African countries have stamps on Amitabh Bachchan, Mithun Chakraborty and Kajol.  Republique De Guinee has a stamp on Aishwarya! But we don’t.  In India, the maximum number of stamps released on a film personality is just two.  That was for Satyajit Ray,” he says.  De had designed Ray’s commemorative stamp by using a still from ‘Pather Panchali’, a profile of Ray and the Oscar.  “I’m the only Indian to have designed a stamp for the United Nations.  It was issued on November 22, 1985,” he says. 
Showing his collection of 1500 pages of film stamps comes with an impromptu cinema quiz.  Who is the only person to have got a Nobel and an

column1: Mujmahuda
column2:
VMC cracks down on mango, sugarcane juice vendors  VADODARA: Food safety officers of Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) cracked down on outlets selling mango and sugarcane juice in the city.  The step was taken in wake of the summer setting in and such outlets opening up across the city. 
VMC officials checked such outlets across the city in a concerted drive.  The drive was conducted in Tarsali, Makarpura, Manjalpur, Mujmahuda, Gotri Road, Makrand Desai Road, Vasna Road, Dandia Bazaar, Fatehgunj, Chhani, Karelibaug, Ajwa Road and other areas. 
Designated officer under the Food Safety and Standards Act, additional health officer Dr Mukesh Vaidya said that 23 outlets selling mango juice as well as 27 selling sugarcane juice were checked by the officers.  He added that the drive would be continued in coming days. 
The officers found colour being used widely in mango juice.  They destroyed 230 kg of mango juice, 120 kg of sugar syrup laced with colour and 70 kg of mangoes that were not fit for consumption.  The officials also disposed off 590 kg of ice and around three kilograms of colour. 
The vendors were issued a warning and asked to maintain hygiene at their outlets.  Sixteen members who were not registered were issued notices by the civic body asking them to get themselves registered.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  20-year-old girl ends life  VADODARA: A 20-year-old girl allegedly committed suicide by consuming poison in Mujhamahuda on Thursday night. 
The deceased was identified as Rekha Monidevi.  According to police, the girl was found in an unconscious condition on Sama-Savli Road.  She was rushed to the SSG Hospital, where she died during treatment. 
Rekha was a native of Assam and had come to the city with her family.  Her father is with the Indian Army and is currently posted in Jammu & Kashmir.  The girl stayed with her mother at Mujmahuda. 
The girl did not leave any suicide note.  The police are conducting investigation to ascertain the exact reason behind the extreme step. 
Her mother has also not been able to understand the reason behind the suicide. 
This is the second incident of suicide in the city within two days.  On Wednesday, 17-year-old Saraswati Pohle had hung herself at her house in the Bhundwada area in the Walled City.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

column1: Zainabia Imambara
column2:
PIL questions Bhendi Bazar shrine ‘sale’ in Mumbai  MUMBAI: The protest against the alleged sale of Zainabia Imambara, a two-storey shrine at Bhendi Bazar, has reached the Bombay high court with the filing of a public interest litigation questioning it. 
The PIL filed by Kishwar Mirza, an advocate, has relied on an “owner’s letter of consent” given on April 21, 2010, by the Zainabia Trust’s managing trustee and builder, Akhtar Rizvi to the Saifee Burhani Upliftment Trust (SBUT) authorising it to seek redevelopment permission.  SBUT is redeveloping buildings in the area.  Mirza alleged that Rizvi had done this “with oblique motives’’ to cause monetary benefits for himself and wrongful loss to the Shia community. 
Mirza’s petition said she learnt about the sale during Moharrum last November after pamphlets were distributed condemning it.  The charity commissioner office thereafter issued documents confirming that Zainabia was a public trust for the community’s benefit.  Mirza moved the HC, saying a trust which was a public religious endowment can neither be sold nor third party rights can be created as it belonged to the community at large, and also without following due process of law.  Mirza’s petition said she learnt about the sale during Moharrum last November after pamphlets were distributed condemning it. 
Mirza said the plot, known as Babar Ali Imambara, was in existence for over 100 years.  It is visited by Shias throughout the year for attending religious lectures and worship.  She said SBUT “in the guise of redevelopment and so-called cluster development” has been purchasing buildings in the vicinity of Zainabia Trust to “house community members and oust non-Bohra community members’’. 
The PIL said religious feelings and sentiments of Shias had been hurt and a Zainabia Bachao Committee was formed “condemning and protesting’’ against the sale of the Imambara.  Mirza urged the HC to direct the respondents not to sell or create third party rights in favour of SBUT or any trust, and also Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation not to grant demolition/redevelopment permission.  Advocate Shehzad Naqvi on Wednesday cited urgency to a division bench of Justices V M Kanade and Revati Mohite-Dere, which posted the hearing on January 29.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

column1: Bellada Bagewadi
column2:
Take advantage of government schemes, seers tell farmers Heads of religious institutions in Hukkeri taluk launched a campaign to instil confidence among small and marginal growers in distress to prevent them from attempting suicide. 
On Friday, heads of Lingayat mutts and other religious institutions formed a forum titled ‘Mathadeeshara Nadige Raitharedege’ and travelled across 51 villages of the taluk from 10 a. m.  to 8 p. m. 
During their visits to villages, the seers interacted with growers and village elders and advised them to manage their resources properly and take best advantages of government schemes to improve their financial condition. 
The campaign was led by Sri Chandrashekhar Shivacharya Swami of Hiremutt, Hukkeri.  Sri Kashinath Swami of Ghodageri Virakta Mutt, Sri Mallaiah Swami of Shivanand Mutt, Shivanand Swami of Bellada Bagewadi and Shri Siddeshwar Shivacharya Swami of Khanapur Ullagaddi were present. 
The farmers were also advised on crop rotation, drip irrigation, watershed development, dairy development and organic farming practices to save the cost on fertilizer and pesticides.  They said the farmers should avoid taking loans at high interest rates from moneylenders and get interest-free loans provided by the government.  The forum also decided to join a people’s delegation to the Deputy Commissioner’s office to pressure the government for obtaining an early verdict on the Kalasa-Banduri Nala project from the Mahadayi Waters Dispute Tribunal, in Belagavi on August 13. 
Heads of religious institutions visit
51 villages in Hukkeri taluk

column1: Aakulam
column2:
Bio innovation centre to aid disease research, diagnostics With the inauguration of a bio innovation centre here on Sunday, the Rajiv Gandhi Centre for Biotechnology (RGCB) is set to acquire a new platform for high-end disease research and diagnostics. 
Scheduled to be dedicated to the nation by Union Minister for Science and Technology Harsh Vardhan at the KINFRA Film and Video Park near here, the facility constitutes the first phase of a Rs.100-crore project aimed at creating an ecosystem for fundamental research in disease biology and molecular medicine.  Spread over 50,000 sq ft, the building has platforms for next generation genetic sequencing, high-end bio-imaging and molecular diagnostics. 
“The burden of viral diseases is seen to be increasing at the global level.  While Ebola, Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome have been reported from several countries, Kerala’s encounter with bird flu and influenza virus and the possibility of new strains pose threats, highlighting the need for development of vaccines,” says M.  Radhakrishna Pillai, Director, RGCB. 
Four focus areas
The bio innovation centre will focus on four broad areas, namely laboratory medicine and molecular diagnostics, microbiome biology, chemical biology, and viral disease biology.  The first thrust area involves the application of molecular sciences for disease management.  Researchers at the centre will collaborate with clinicians to understand the impact of microbial genetic material on diseases such as cancers, diabetes, and schizophrenia. 
Another major focus of the research programme is the development of synthetic anti-microbial peptides to overcome antibiotic resistance and the application of biodegradable polymers as nanoparticles for controlled release of anticancer drugs and targeted delivery of drugs.  The viral disease biology programme is expected to result in the development of potent viral vectors for varying applications. 
The second phase of the project slated to come up at Aakulam includes an advanced centre for molecular and cellular therapeutics and a 75-bed hospital to be operated in collaboration with the Regional Cancer Centre for clinical trials on cancer vaccines and methods such as stem cell therapy and gene therapy. 
It will also provide business incubation facilities for biotechnology start-ups.  Tender processes for the campus are in the final stages, Dr. Pillai said.  Energy conservation awards The Kerala State Energy Conservation Awards 2015 have been announced. 
Travancore Cochin Chemicals, Kochi, has bagged the award in the category of large-scale energy consumers while HLL Life Care, Aakulam, won the award in the medium-scale energy consumer category.  In the institutions/organisations category, the Kerala State Electricity Board, Thiruvananthapuram, and Kerala Prisons and Correctional Services Department were selected for the award, while K. C.  Baiju of Cherthala was chosen for the award in the individual’s category.  Vasundhara Sarovar Premiere, Vayalar, is the award winner in the buildings category. 
The Kochi refinery of Bharath Petroleum Corporation and Cochin Shipyard got commendation certificate in the large-scale energy consumer category while Mathrubhumi Printing and Publishing Company, Thiruvananthapuram, won the commendation certificate for small-scale energy consumers. 
Cochin International Airport Limited was selected for a commendation certificate in the buildings category and K. P.  Mohanan, Thrissur, and B. G.  Sreedevi, Thiruvananthapuram, in the individual category.  Electricity Minister Aryadan Mohammed will give away the awards on December 14. 
56 applicants save 77 mu of power, 9610 tonnes of oil, 209 tonnes of LPG Centre will consider Rs 100 crore bio lab for Kerala: Harsh Vardhan THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The Centre will seriously take into consideration Kerala government's plea for setting up a bio-safety lab in the state at an estimated cost of Rs 100 crore for virus testing, Union Minister for Science and Technology Dr Harsh Vardhan today said. 
The Minister's assurance came in response to a request from Chief Minister Oommen Chandy while dedicating the first phase of Rajiv Gandhi Centre for Biotechnology (RGCB) Bio-Innovation Centre (BIC) at the KINFRA Film and Video Park at nearby Kazhakootam. 
" It is the responsibility of the government to ensure public health and safeguard public interest,"  Vardhan said adding he would look into the feasibility of setting up the bio-safety lab on his return to Delhi. 
He pointed out that the bio-technology (BT) sector had grown 70 per cent in the country, and in 10 years it was expected to reach USD 100 crore, with production pushing it to the third biggest industry, ahead of the pharmaceutical industry. 
By 2025, the country was set to be the third biggest global player in the field of BT, which works in disease prevention and producing vaccines, he said. 
" The RGCB creates and trains the best manpower and brings scientific research into the public domain,"  Dr Vardhan said. 
" Time bound R&D should be done here,"  Chandy, who delivered the presidential address, said pointing out that virus testing for Kerala was now done in labs in Pune and Bhopal. 
" A bio-safety lab will be beneficial not just for Kerala, but for all of south India,"  the Chief Minister.  " Diagnostics and testing for disease is mandatory for Kerala, which plays host to migratory birds and visitors from different places.  When Kerala was hit by epidemic, the RGCB played a valuable role in diagnostics,"  he noted. 
RGCB director, Dr M Radhakrishna Pillai, unveiled plans to set up a 75-bed facility with the help of Thiruvananthapuram Medical College's Regional Cancer Centre at Phase II of the BIC Aakulam centre. 
The sprawling facility at phase one, spread over 50,000 sq ft, has advanced platforms for next generation genetic sequencing, high-end bio-imaging as well as a state-of-the-art molecular diagnostics facility that serves Kerala and neighbouring states. 
The facility has also signed an MoU with the Kerala State Council for Science, Technology and Environment that will enable the Kottayam-based Srinivasa Ramanujam Institute for Basic Sciences to do research here.

column1: Cornfield Road
column2:
HC raps KMC over city’s dirty streets  KOLKATA: Calcutta high court on Friday came down heavily on Kolkata Municipal Corporation (KMC) over the heaps of plastic and garbage piled up along city stretches.  Chief Justice Manjula Chellur held that the plastic packs are a major reason behind Kolkata’s waterlogging problem. 
“I have seen heaps of plastic scattered in and around my bungalow, something I have never encountered in any other metro.  What is the corporation doing? Are they sleeping? They should step up vigilance over plastic dumping and mechanize the garbage clean up process,” the Chief Justice said.  She directed KMC to submit a plan, within a fortnight, about what steps it is taking to prevent waterlogging in the Monsoon. 
The court warning comes at a time when Narendra Modi is urging state governments and urban local bodies to take steps to clean up public places under the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan. 
State counsel Tapan Mukherjee drew flak from the bench of Chief Justice Chellur and Justice Joymalya Bagchi when he pointed to the chronic waterlogging in Mumbai.  “This is a negative attitude of looking at things.  You should address the problem with a positive mindset and take steps,” Justice Bagchi said. 
KMC lawyer Alok Ghosh informed the court that the civic body has already taken up a host of measures for the overall development of the city.  Ghosh pointed to stretches such as Lord Sinha Road, Southern Avenue, Panchanantala, South End Park in Garia, and Cornfield Road where the water logging problem has been solved.  Having said that, the lawyer informed the court that the city’s population had increased manifold since the British set up the infrastructure.  However, the KMC lawyer did not use this as plea to evade the problem. 
“We have done quite a few things.  We have the status report ready.  I will submit a report on the steps taken,” Ghosh said. 
The Howrah Ganatantrik Samity had moved the court in 2007 seeking direction from the high court to restrict use of plastic and a ban on the plastic manufacturing units in the city to counter the water logging problem.  It had also asked for desiltation of canals and open drains, as well as removal of encroachments on canals to free up the sewage flow channels. column1: Nalban Food Park
column2:
Nalban facelift gets underway  KOLKATA: The Nalban Food Park will look within a few months.  The state fisheries development corporation (SFDC) is working on a project worth Rs 1.67crore to give the park a facelift with extention of the area, new lighting and seating arrangements and beautification of the waterbody in an eco-friendly way. 
SFDC managing director Soumyajit Das said that Rs 35 lakh has been utilized to set up a new boundary wall in the extended area.  “A development plan has been chalked out and a boundary wall has been set up, lighting and seating arrangements are being improved and eco-friendly toilets are being installed,” he said.  The project is being carried out towards the Sector V end of the Nalban bheri. 
No structural construction is being done since it falls under a wetland. 
Earlier, the forest department, fisheries department and Kolkata Metropolitan Development Authority conducted a survey, following which the beautification plan was cleared. 
The overall plan is to develop the park as a tourist spot where visitors can spend time and have recreational activities.  Keeping this in mind, the authorities even plan to develop it as a water park.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Fish fest to mark 50 yrs of govt unit  The State Fisheries Development Corporation (SFDC), in association with the National Fisheries Development Board (NFDB), Indian Chamber of Commerce (ICC) and state fisheries department, will celebrate its golden jubilee by organising a three-day `Fish Fest' from December 18 to 20 at Nalban Food Park in Salt Lake.  The aim is to showcase and promote the fisheries industry with an aim to increase fish productivity in the state and to attract more investments in the sector. 
SFDC managing director Soumyajit Das said SFDC have been taking up a number of activities in the recent past to develop the state's fisheries sector.  “The event will be organised to promote fisheries in the government and corporate sectors.  There will be a food court that will serve various fish dishes, like Vietnam sheatfish, basa, apart from more familiar dishes,“ he said.  Representatives of several other state fisheries development boards will also be present during the threeday event. 
Das said that fish medicine was also something they wanted to highlight at the event. 
Sources said that the government was very keen on developing the industry to lessen the dependency on states like Andhra Pradesh.  The plan is to offer incentives, subsidies and grants to entrepreneurs investing in this sector.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

Hosted by the Lingua Mystica Society of Language Experts, the workshop is aimed at French students as well as teachers. 
According to the organisers, the pronunciation sessions sought to help French speakers master the nuances of pronunciation.  The take-way for teachers was to keep themselves abreast of the modern methods of teaching French pronunciation. 
A fair share of participants is expected to come from schools and colleges in the region.  The afternoon session would be devoted to pronunciation-related competitions.  The workshop, scheduled from 10 a. m.  to 5 p. m. , is being held at the Pondicherry Social Service Society, No.  81, Laporte Street, Puducherry 605001. Public, NGOs pitch in with relief materials The public, institutions and non-governmental organisations swung into action, chipping in with relief work from Wednesday, following incessant rains which have lashed Puducherry and surrounding regions in the last few days. 
Relief materials
NGOs Trust for Youth and Leadership (TYCL) and Mughil collected relief material to be given to the Narikuravar community in and around Puducherry, and others affected by the rains. 
A group of 80 Narikuravars were first shifted to a government school in Kottakarai near Auroville where they were provided food and shelter, said Siva Mathiyazhagan, co-founder, TYCL. 
They were later moved to a community hall in Achirampattu village near Koot Road on Wednesday, he said.  Narikuravars living in and around Lawspet were provided milk, bread and cooked food, as they were running out of supplies. 
Food packets distributed
The NGOs also distributed 1000 food packets and fire wood to residents of Palli Thennal in Villupuram, after the village was water-logged, on Thursday.  Essential items were provided in the water-logged Maduvupet, near Krishna Nagar. 
The NGOs are also beginning work in Cuddalore district, and a group of 25 doctors will travel with them on Friday. 
“Our requirements include Floor mats, bed sheets, rice, milk, bread, biscuits, emergency lights, water purifier packets, sanitary napkins, candles and matchboxes. 
People can drop things off at our office at Number 17, Pookara Street, Muthialpet, by 1 p. m.  on Friday (0413-2224243/ 08056463930),” said Mr.  Mathiyazhagan.  Those in the town area can drop off materials at No.6, Aurobindo Street, between 11 a. m.  to 2.30 p. m. 
Materials for flood affected
Another NGO, Deshna Foundation, is collecting material for those affected by the rain in areas including Rediarpalayam, said Amaladevi Vaithianathan who runs the organisation, which operates out of Number 8, first floor, 2nd cross, Surya Gandhi Nagar, Muthialpet (88708 26001 / 99523 43625)
Residents pitch in
Some individuals tried to help out in as many ways as they could. 
Swaminathan, a resident of Saradambal Nagar, and his family realised that patients and caretakers of the Rajiv Gandhi Government Women and Children Hospital, Ellaipillaichavady, would need lunch on Wednesday, given the heavy rains. 
So they cooked sambar rice, and carried water bottles and biscuits and distributed them to around 60 people, mostly poor patients and their caretakers, said his daughter-in-law Ruckmani Narayanan. 
Hotel Aksharadha in Villianur has announced that it can accommodate 1000 persons in its Annai Thirumana Mandapam, Villianur, where they will be providing food from Thursday. 
The organisers can be reached at 9445445608, and have also asked for support from sponsors and volunteers. 
Free medical services
The Mahatma Gandhi Medical College and Research Institute will be offering free medical services for those affected by flooding at its Pillayarkuppam hospital where they have set up a shelter and its City Centre near Balaji theatre (95855 09995, 98421 11361, 95666 64685 and Toll free 1800 425 1008). 
Caritas India and Catholic Relief Services (CRS) has begun distribution of relief materials in Puducherry, and will be extending its work to Cuddalore, Villupuram, Thiruvalluvar, Chengalpet and Kancheepuram districts, said Father Albert Thambidurai.  Materials such as dry ration and bed sheets can be dropped off at the Pondicherry Multipurpose Social Service Society office located at 81, Laporte Street, and SAMSS, Vikravandi, Villupuram District (9994372059). 
NGOs distributed food packets and fire wood to residents of Palli Thennal, Villupuram

column1: Sarakkalvilai
column2:
Man held for sexually abusing girl Suchindram police arrested a 55-year-old man on the charge of sexually abusing a 13-year-old girl on Wednesday.  According to police, the accused was employed as a driver by the victim’s family.  It is alleged that the accused indulged in sexual abuse of the girl while transporting her from a school in Nagercoil to Parakkai village on Wednesday evening. 
Based on a complaint lodged by the victim’s father, Suchindram police arrested C.  Chandra Mony (55) of Keezha Sarakkalvilai of Edalakkudi village.  He was remanded in judicial custody. 
A case has been registered under Sections 294 (b) (obscene acts and reciting songs), and 506 (i) (criminal intimidation) of the Indian Penal Code and Section 10 of the Protection of Child from Sexual Offences Act, 2012.  100 kg of ganja seized; 1 arrested The district police seized 100 kg of ganja neatly packed as 2 kg each and stocked in a locked house and arrested one person, said T.  Eswaran, Deputy Superintendent of Police, here on Wednesday. 
Four others were absconding, he told reporters and added that a special team rounded up the drug peddler M.  Bhuvaneshmani alias Buneshmani (31) of Seethapal while he was selling ganja near Santhaivilai Bridge on the Aralvoimozhi-Seethapal Hill Road. 
Interrogation of Bhuvaneshmani revealed that the gang was selling ganja from a godown from Aladi Sivan Temple Street in Sarakkalvilai near here. 
The gang brought the contraband from Andhra Pradesh through four persons from Theni district.  As many as 11 cases were pending against Bhuvaneshmani, the DSP said. 
He was produced before the judicial magistrate at Boothapandi who remanded him in judicial custody.  A hunt is on to nab M.  Jagannathan, M.  Subbiah Thevan, M.  Jayakumar of Usilampatti and P.  Murugan alias Keeripatti Murugan of Andipatti in Theni district. 
Aralvoimozhi police have registered a case. 
The special team of police included sub-inspectors attached to the SP office D.  Samson Jebadoss, S.  Gunasekaran and Shankar.  The team was led by Mr.  Eswaran and Kottar Inspector T.  Gajendran.  100 kg of ganja seized; 1 arrested in Madurai The district police seized 100 kg of ganja neatly packed as 2 kg each and stocked in a locked house and arrested one person, said T. column1: Maranthalai
column2:
Closure orders issued to six unauthorised schools Closure orders were issued to six nursery and primary schools in the district that functioned without any authorisation from Directorate of Elementary Education. 
Collector M.  Ravikumar served the orders, according to a statement here on Tuesday.  The schools lacked basic infrastructure and deemed unfit to run.  There was no safety to students of the schools located alongside of the by-pass road here. 
Despite giving time to the school administrators to get approval from the directorate through the Education Department here, no interest had been shown from the administrators.  Hence, the closure order was issued to Little Angel School, Maranthalai, Tiruchendur Taluk, James School, Tooveypuram, Tuticorin, Fathima School, Kayalpattinam, Somu Vidhyalaya School, Annai Nagar, Tuticorin, P. R. R.  School, Palai Main Road, Pudukottai, and Mahatma School in Kovilpatti, the statement added.

column1: Thirumuruganpoondi
column2:
Vintage apparel machinery museum at Knit The ‘vintage apparel machinery museum’ set up at the 13th edition of knitting technology fair organised by Hi-Tech International Trade Fair Private limited at Thirumuruganpoondi near here draws hundreds of apparel entrepreneurs and youth. 
The museum, conceptualised by the organisers along with NIFT-TEA Knitwear Institute and Boomanz— a fashion consultancy firm, has a huge collection of miniature models and sketches that depict the transformation the apparel machinery underwent over the past four centuries. 
The visitors could see the exhibits till February 9. 
Rajish K.  Ravindran, creative director of Boomanz, told The Hindu that the scaled-down models of sewing machines and other machinery, as well as the sketches of knitting machines, were made after an extensive research.  “We have used the clay imported from Thailand to make the miniature models of the sewing and knitting machines,” added G.  Boopathi of Boomanz. 
Meanwhile, the sketches were drawn by professional artists using charcoal, colours and high quality pencils. 
Some of the attractions at the museum include the models/sketches of the 18th century Swiss Box Iron, which used a heated metal piece placed inside the hollow of the iron to press the fabrics without scorching the cloth, and a multi-system hosiery circular knitting machine used more than a century ago, paving way for the production of high-quality socks. 
Model of a power embroidery machine used during the Industrial Revolution era from 1760 to 1820 was also a huge attraction. 
“Young entrepreneurs should get inspired and go for modernising the inventory in their units to keep up with the changes and demands of the apparel production,” Raja Shanmugam, an apparel exporter and chairman of Confederation of Indian Industry (Tirupur district council), opined.  13th edition of Knit The 13th edition of the Knit-Tech, a knitting technology trade fair organised by Hi-tech International Trade Fair, would come to a close on February 9. 
More than 200 companies from India and abroad were exhibiting state-of-the-art machinery related to the knitwear production which include circular knitting machines, dyeing and finishing machines, knit printing appliances, computerised flat knitting machines, yarn conditioning machines, sewing machines and fabric dyeing machines, among others. 
Apart from these, textile printing inks, air treatment solutions, spares of embroidery machines, knitting accessories, stripped fabrics, air compressors and needles used for production of hosiery items were displayed. 
A vintage apparel machinery museum set up on the fair arena at Thirumuruganpoondi had given an added flavour to the event.  The expo had taken the visitors through a journey of transformation which the apparel machinery under went in the last three centuries. 
The organisers had also organised fashion shows and seminars to give value-addition to the exhibition. 
Since the exhibition was approved by the India Trade Promotion Organisation, exhibitors from foreign countries were able to bring the instruments without the payment of import duty for its display.  coimbatore today RELIGION

Maharaja Institute of Technology: Recruitment drive, 10 a. m.  Kumbabhishekam held Thousands of devotees witnessed the kumbabhishekam of the 13th century-built Thirumuganathaswamy temple at Thirumuruganpoondi near here on Friday.  The temple was renovated recently at an outlay of Rs.  28 lakh. 
C.  Saravanabhavan, Executive Officer of the temple, told The Hindu that the Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowment Department had arranged 25 rooms for mentally challenged persons. 
“Only condition for allotting the rooms free-of-cost is that the mentally challenged persons should be accompanied by a relative and they could stay for a maximum stretch of 48 days,” Mr.  Saravanabhavan said.

column2:
Disruption in power supply tomorrow There will be no power supply between 9 a. m.  and 4 p. m.  on Saturday in the areas coming under 220 KV receiving station, Somanahalli, for maintenance works. 
According to a release, areas coming under the following sub stations will be affected. 
Arehalli: Naidu Layout, Chikkalasandra, Sarvaboumanagar, Uttarahalli Main Road and surrounding areas.  Puttenahalli, J. P.  Nagar 6th Phase, Jaraganahaali and M. S.  Layout.

column1: Phulewadi Road
column2:
Cops finalise 8 immersion procession routes  KOLHAPUR: The district police administration on Friday announced eight procession routes for 550-odd Ganesh mandals towards Panchganga Ghat for immersing idols. 
The routes have been planned according to the distance of the mandal from the immersion site and avoid congestion caused by the spectators following the processions.  The traffic department has marked diversion points at many places as well as the routes that will be totally closed for vehicles during the procession for easy passage of the pedestrians through the congested areas. 
Officials of the city traffic department said a week-long survey was conducted to finalise the routes.  Since many mandals emphasised on decongestion of roads during immersion processions in the internal parts of the city, especially in Mangalwar Peth and Rajarampuri, the traffic department has made changes by installing barricades at alternative places which may also help decrease the procession time. 
R R Patil, police inspector of the city traffic department, said, “We will deploy 97 policemen to control traffic along the procession routes.  Moreover, 40-odd traffic police personnel will also monitor the traffic flow along regular routes that get clogged because of heavy rush towards the procession routes.  We have directed the policemen to strictly monitor the routes to avoid any untoward incident. ”
Meanwhile, squares along major roads have been considered entry points for the processions.  For instance, Gokhale College chowk will be the entry point for the mandals from areas such as Udyamnagar, Rajarampuri, Daulatnagar and Takala.  The administration has planned alternative procession routes to facilitate the mandals catch up with other mandals along the main procession route. 
“The decongestion efforts along Phulewadi Road will be undertaken by placing barricades at a couple of points to avoid pedestrians’ direct entry in the processions.  We have planned the procession routes for around 24 hours during which most of the mandals will immerse their idols,” Patil said. 
Meanwhile, the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) has made alternative arrangements for idol immersion at Irani Khan, Kotitirth lake and Rajaram Bandara.  A pandal has been set up at the river ghat for accepting the idols to avoid their release into the river, which leads to pollution. 
“The major concern pertaining to repair of the roads damaged along the procession routes has been addressed.  Besides, hawkers or any other vendors too have been completely prohibited on the routes,” stated a press release issued by the KMC. 
Moreover, the administration has prohibited parking along 100m from all procession routes and the ones approaching the main routes.  Parking facilities will available at Bindu Chowk, Siddharthnagar and Dasara Chowk.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

column1: Palanipet
column2:
Elderly woman murdered, valuables stolen Seventy-eight-year-old Gomathiammal, widow of Parameswaran, a retired loco pilot, who was staying alone in Palanipet in Arakkonam was found murdered in her house on Thursday morning. 
According to the police, a neighbour called up Gomathiammal’s son Nandakumar in Chennai that articles were strewn all over in the house.  When he cross-checked with another neighbour, he was told that Gomathiammal was found murdered. 
The neighbour also told him that a bureau in his house had been forced open and articles from it were strewn all around. 
Nandakumar rushed to Arakkonam and lodged a complaint with the Arakkonam town police. 
An ear-stud worn by Gomathiammal and her cell phone were missing. 
The police have registered a case under section 302 (murder) and section 380 (theft in dwelling house) of the Indian Penal Code.  Youth held for murder A.  Appu alias Sankararam (18) of Marathahalli, Bangalore was arrested by a special team on Friday in connection with the murder of a 78-year-old woman and theft of gold jewels in her house in Palanipet in Arakkonam on March 25. 
According to police sources, Appu used to visit his sister who was a tenant in the house of the deceased Gomathiammal, widow of retired loco pilot Parameswaran a couple of years ago.  Appu had entered the house of Gomathiammal when she was asleep and removed an ear-stud.  When she woke up due to the disturbance, he strangled her to death and took away Rs.8000 and jewels from the bureau.  On the instructions of P. K.  Senthilkumari, Superintendent of Police, Vellore district and Kannappan, Deputy Superintendent of Police, Arakkonam, a special police team comprising Dillibabu, Inspector and Palaniswamy, Sub-Inspector of Arakkonam Town Police Station was formed to nab the culprit.  Investigation by the special team revealed that Appu was a habitual criminal who was currently on bail in a robbery case in Bangalore.  Two rings and an ear-stud stolen from the house and a tablet which was purchased with the stolen money were seized from the accused.  The SP appreciated the efforts of Dillibabu and his team in arresting the accused within 10 days of the offence.

column1: Veeramarasanpettai
column2:
1,900 tonnes of Thanjavur paddy despatched to Erode The Tamil Nadu Civil Supplies Corporation despatched 1,900 tonnes paddy from here to Erode for milling and distribution in that region. 
The paddy procured from farmers at the direct purchase centres throughout the district during the kuruvai and samba seasons used to be stored in massive godowns at Pillayarpatti, Punalkulam, Veeramarasanpettai, Paruthiappar Koil, and Ammanpettai from where they were transported in trucks to the Thanjavur Junction.  The paddy weighing 1,900 tonnes, packed in gunny bags and transported from those warehouses, were then loaded on to 42 rail wagons were later flagged off to Erode.

column1: Ekadthangal
column2:
Claims pouring in for car, property loss  CHENNAI: Insurance claims have started to trickle in after record rains drenched Tamil Nadu this week.  State owned United India Insurance has already got 130 claims for 110 crore. 
" Majority of claims have come in from Chennai.  We have also got claims from Puduchery and Cuddalore too.  A lot of claims pertain to property losses due to rains,"  said the CMD of United India Insurance, Milind Kharat.  City gota record rain of 23.5 cms of rainfall in 24 hours between 8 am on Sunday and 8 am Monday, causing extensive damage to property and life. 
Another PSU insurer, New India Assurance too has received 70 claims so far totalling 30 crore in Chennai.  " It's early days.  We are still awaiting the full claims data.  While the sudden flooding in Chennai has resulted in claims coming from the city, claims have not yet come in from other parts of the state,"  CMD of New India Assurance, G Srinivasan said. 
Insurers also said the losses mirrored the areas which got inundated.  " We have got claims from small and medium business units and those based in industrial zones like Ambattur and Guindy,"  Srinivasan said.  Similarly, Tata AIG which has so far got 35 claims pertaining to property, motor and damages caused to small business units.  " The claims have come in from Ambattur, Avadi and Ekadthangal, areas which saw heavy flooding,"  M Ravichandran, president, insurance at Tata AIG General Insurance said. 
Private insurer Bajaj Allianz General Insurance has got more than 200 claims and the company is expecting substantial losses from the motor and property line segments.  " The city has a higher concentration of high end vehicles hence we are expecting considerable losses from this segment.  Of the claims that have been reported for motor, many of them are pertaining to high end cars.  In case of property insurance, we have received claims for damage to stocks and other assets from business and commercial set ups due to inundation,"  chief technical officer of the company, Sasikumar Adidamu said.  The average claim size for property received by the company stands at Rs 12 lakh.  Apart from Chennai, Bajaj has received claims from Vellore, Kancheepuram, Tiruvallur, Arakkonam, Cuddalore, Panruti and Neyveli.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

column1: Gulati Chowk
column2:
80mm rainfall opens the floodgates  LUDHIANA: Eighty-mm rainfall on Thursday was too much for city roads, with most of the stretches getting water-logged, leaving commuters a harried lot.  With Ludhiana municipal corporation allegedly forgetting to clean up the drains, 3 hours of rain caused a lot of chaos on roads.  Traffic flow was hit hard.  Residents complained that there were many areas in which MC did not take up the task of cleaning the drains ahead of monsoon season.  Somnath Grover, a resident of Model Town, said, " Every year MC somehow cleans the drains before monsoon, but this year they didn't do so.  Our area was flooded within few hours of rains.  Till afternoon there was no help from MC to help residents. "  The water-logged areas included New Lajpat Nagar, Model Town, Model Town Extension, Dugri, Civil Lines, Sarabha Nagar, Gurdev Nagar, Old City, Gill Road.  Several areas housing offices of city top officials --- police commissioner, DC office, MC office --- were also left battling water woes.  Sudeshna Singh, a resident of Dugri, said, " It took me an hour to reach old city from my home due to slow movement of traffic due to water-logging.  MC has left no stone unturned to make Ludhiana roads flooding. "  Officials in the control room, set up to take complaints of water-logging, said they did not receive any complaints regarding water-logging on Thursday.  But residents across the city said nobody in MC responded to their complaints.  " I tried to complain about water-logging in my area on every possible number of municipal corporation.  They said when the rain will stop, MC staff will be there to solve the problems.  MC Ludhiana is never going to learn any lesson to deal with monsoon.  It seems, we are destined to bear the brunt throughout our lives,"  said Manjit Kalia, a resident of New Shimlapuri.  Additional commissioner Kamlesh Bansal said, " We held an immediate meeting.  We have designated officials to insure residents don't face any problem in the future.  Motors will be installed especially in low-lying areas to flush out rainwater.  Apt manpower will be deployed to solve problems of water-logging as soon as these are reported. "  Along with waterlogging and traffic jams, poor condition of roads added to the worries of residents.  " These roads have become more dangerous and slippery.  Potholes will get wider and may become death holes,"  said Pankaj Arora, a commuter from industrial area. Under water: Bharat Nagar Dugri Civil Lines Tagore Nagar New Lajpat Nagar Model Town Model Gram Model Town Extension Ghumar Mandi Mall road Sarabha Nagar Gill road areas Old city areas Government offices Bus standTraffic takes a ride Pakhowal road Bharat Nagar chowk Kocchar market Bhai Wala chowk Jagraon bridge Old city areas Samrala chowk Chandigarh road Road cave-in: Gill chowk Model town, near Gulati Chowk Dashmesh NagarDownload The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Immediate need to repair roads in Model Town area  LUDHIANA: With everybody going gaga about Ludhiana getting the Smart City tag, there are several areas where administration needs to ensure basic facilities are in place, if not more. 
In the posh Model Town area, condition of roads is pathetic and the civic body seems to be indifferent about it.  The areas where the road is not in good shape include Gulati Chowk and road between Dugri Road and GNIMT College Road. 
Potholes are everywhere and due to the monsoon it has become dangerous for commuters, especially on two-wheelers.  There is also no arrangement for streetlights in the evening. 
" Due to the potholes and waterlogging, I met with an accident.  I was stuck there for five minutes and that led to traffic jam.  People kept honking, but nobody came forward to help me.  It was only after a passerby saw my struggle and came forward to help,"  said Rashmi, a student of GNIMT, Model Town. 
" The town had already lost its charm.  The roads really need to be repaired as soon as it is possible plus they should be a little broader,"  said Suneeta, a homemaker of Model Town.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  CCTV footage helps find stolen pet  LUDHIANA: Three days after a pet dog was stolen from outside a gurdwara in Model Town, police found the animal from a man belonging to Sangrur district on the intervening night of Friday and Saturday.  The dog was stolen by a couple from near a park when her owner had gone for a walk on Tuesday.  Komal Ahluwalia, owner of pit bull and a businesswoman of Model Town area, said, " We got CCTV footage from the gurdwara and many other business establishments in the area which helped us a lot in identifying the woman, who had stolen the dog.  When we shared the footage on WhatsApp and Facebook, some people identified the woman, who worked as a sales girl at a business store at Gulati Chowk. "  " From the girl, we got the address of the accused and then police rounded them up at around 7.30 pm on Friday.  After the police questioned the accused, he revealed the whereabouts of our pet,"  she added.  The pet was recovered at midnight.  " The dog had injuries in the limbs, which was possibly dragged by the culprits" , said the owner of pet.  Even as Model Town police identified the accused as Gurbhag Singh of Sangrur, but they didn't reveal the identity of the woman.  They also didn't register a case against the duo.  " As the person had not stolen the dog from the house, so no case is made against him,"  said Avtar Singh of Model Town police. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

column1: Khapri Lake
column2:
Multimodal International Hub For Birders  NAGPUR: Several years on, the Multimodal International Hub Airport at Nagpur (MIHAN), a special economic zone for industries, may be looked upon as a symbol of development – or perhaps the lack of it — by now, but for young naturalists it continues to be an intrinsic birding destination. 
Many known names from city fondly recollect having started bird watching from the historic Telhara and Dahegaon lakes, built by the Bhonsla rulers.  Part of Mihan now, these lakes and its periphery continue to enthusiastically draw birdwatchers. 
Veteran bird expert Gopal Thosar, and a Nagpur Heroes awardee, recalls, “In 1975, when I started bird watching, thousands of resident and migratory birds use to flock these lakes, which then typically was a woodland.  Poachers from the city too were active and used to lure village boys by offering them Rs 5 per bird.  I sensitized these boys and managed to stop poaching. ”
Today, the beauty of both the lakes and adjoining areas have faded with development.  Too much construction activity has cut off incoming water sources of the lakes from Shivangaon.  “A compound wall has also been constructed around Telhara lake which is proving detrimental to birds.  The water of these lakes will be in great demand for industries and that will be the last straw,” says Thosar. 
Pushkar Kulkarni, an engineering student, echoes the same feeling.  “I started birdwatching as a child with my father Sanjay, who was a regular visitor to the area.  He took me to Telhara and Dahegaon lakes,” he said. 
Kulkarni recalls Dahegaon was popular for water birds, especially migratory Red-Crested Pochards and Comb Ducks, which were seen in over 600. 
“This year only 80-100 are seen.  Yet, as number of bird watchers have gone up frequency of visiting this place has increased resulting in discovery of more diversity and species,” informs Kulkarni. 
If you ask well-known bird expert Dr Anil Pimlapure, a dentist by profession, why birds preferred Mihan, he says Mihan is connected with three ecosystems.  There are lakes, grasslands and scrubland.  “Hence you can sight variety of birds in Mihan.  Even though development is taking place, number of transport vehicles and residential area is not so alarming to keep birds away,” says Dr Pimlapure. 
“I started birding from Telhara and Dahegaon lakes in 1984 and used to visit the place in morning and evening.  The bird count has definitely gone down but still there is bird life,” he adds. 
Dr Pimlapure informs birds too have a line of control (LOC).  In Mihan, loss of bird species in scrub, forest and agriculture areas due to industries and human settlements will be taken over by urban biodiversity species like mainas, babblers, bulbuls, doves, robins, pied starlings.  “Even today, while birding in Mihan one can sight at least 100 bird species,” says Dr Pimlapure. 
Kulkarni admits that Telhara lake is surrounded by scrubland and it was famous for larks and pipits.  Early morning or late evening is the best time to watch them but nowadays their number is decreasing.  Last year this place hosted Mongolian bar-headed geese but this year they have moved elsewhere. 
“Now a wall surrounds the lake and a big building construction is going on here.  In spite of all this we can still enjoy birding in Mihan which we birders popularly call as LRK (Lesser Rann of Kutch) of Nagpur.  It is full of surprises,” informs Kulkarni. 
Dr Pimlapure feels if the two water bodies are kept intact, hopes for bird life are still alive.  “At one time Ambazari was the most visited spot by birds and birders.  Today, due to rampant fishing, there is 80% drop in number of birds that used to visit the lake.  Dahegaon and Telhara should not meet the same fate in the name of development,” he warns. 
Avid bird watcher Indraneel Dani too has a similar story to tell.  “In the advent of Mihan, the count of birds has gone down if not number of species.  You are still lucky to sight multiple species like bristled grass bird and imperial eagle.  Last year, rare European bee eater was sighted.  It was perhaps first record in Central India,” Dani informs. 
However, now both Telhara and Dahegaon lakes are shrinking due to encroachments.  Weeds have come up and there is a need for lake management.  It is high time authorities think of sustainable development because birds are symbols of healthy ecosystems. 
RARE SIGHTINGS IN MIHAN
* European Bee-eater
* Bristled Grass bird
* Eastern Imperial Eagle
* Desert Wheatear
* Isabelline Wheatear
* Red necked Falcon
* Brahminy Kite
* Grey necked bunting
BIRDERS’ ATTRACTION
* Pallid Harrier
* Montagu's Harrier
* Bluethroat
* Blue rock thrush
* Indian courser
* Larks & pipits
* Red Munia & Tricoloured Munia
* Bonelli's Eagle

Howls of excitement over Mihan wolf sighting  Nagpur: The scrubland around Mihanon the city outskirts, which is a hot spot for birds, has sprung another surprise with the sighting of a full-grown wolf by city two bird watchers — Surendra Agnihotri and Nitin Marathe.  In April, city birdwatcher Sanjay Nafdey had sighted lesser florican, the smaller bird among the endangered bustard species.  Both, wolves and florican are listed under Schedule I of Wildlife (Protection) Act 1972 and have highest level of protection, yet continue to be ignored.  “Nagpur has got a unique distinction of being close to number of sanctuaries and national parks.  We boast of being in the vicinity of tigers and leopards, but sighting of interesting species like ‘Indian wolf’ is not reported much even though these animals are no less majestic, important and interesting.  This may be perhaps for the first time a wolf has been sighted in Mihan area,” said Agnihotri, a well-known birdwatcher from city.  He was accompanied by another birdwatcher Nitin Marathe on a routine bird watching trip to Mihan.  Agnihotri & Marathe, who work as superintendents with Central Excise, sighted the wolf on Sunday (September 6) morning in the scrubland near twin water tanks at the end of northern side of Mihan.  “We noticed sudden commotion of red-wattled lapwings in the field near them.  The birds were abnormally noisy and were actually mobbing a lone wolf that was treading cautiously in the scrubland in its typical and unmistakable style.  It was sort of a shock to see wolf’s presence in Mihan,” said Agnihotri Marathe said, “The wolf perhaps noticed our presence and was watchful.  We curiously watched this majestic animal from a distance till it moved about 400 metres towards eastern side of Mihan and then vanished into bushes but not before giving enough time to click photographs. ” A delighted Agnihotri says sighting of a healthy individual wolf at Mihan, close to the city, is certainly a good sign.  “There may be more individuals including females.  It only indicates that Mihan, which is fast going to industries, still has good flora and fauna,” he added. Interestingly, Agnihotri had earlier reported similar sighting of a pair of Indian wolf on the shores of Khapri Lake near Champa village on Nagpur-Umrer Road in May 2014.  “There are established and well-known packs of wolves near scrubby areas of Paradgaon on Umred Road, and Bor and Degma near Hingna albeit their numbers are dwindling. Agnihotri says there is presence of other wildlife species in Mihan.  These include wild boars, hare, nilgais, black bucks, and wildcats.  Other species include snakes, lizards, flapshell turtles, monitor lizards besides a variety of birds including residents and migratory. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Migratory birds herald winter  Nagpur: With the onset of winter, the first flocks of transient and migratory birds have started arriving in different parts of the region.  More species of water and forest migratory birds are expected to come along by the month end.  At Telhara Lake in Mihan, a Greylag Goose was sighted by Rohit Charpe.  Believed to be quite a rare sighting by local bird experts, the bird is usually found in Iceland, Finland, Baltic Coasts, Western Russia and others during its breeding season. Water bodies in Amravati which are regular hosts to migratory birds have started witnessing arrival of many species like Pacific Golden Plover, Black-Bellied Tern, Northern Pintail, Lesser Whistling Duck, Black Redstart, Black-Tailed Godvit, Verditer Flycatcher and Northern Shoveler.  Avid birdwatcher and founder of Disha Foundation Yadav Tarte said, “Both water as well as forest birds are being sighted here in good numbers.  Some birds have come for migration while some are just taking a halt.  It has been more than 15 days since a Pacific Golden Plover is being sighted every day at a water body here,” he said.  Tarte added that other migratory birds like Bar-Headed Goose, Common Crane and Black Stork are expected to come at Daryapur and other 24 water bodies in and around Amravati.  “Sightings of these birds have been recorded in Northern India and they are expected to reach Central India within a week,” he said.  This winter, Pandharkawada in Yavatmal district has witnessed some variations in the arrival of migratory birds, said wildlife researcher and avid birdwatcher Ramzan Virani.  “Ruddy Shelducks are usually the ones to arrive here first and in good numbers but this time they landed late and only a few are being sighted.  Surprisingly, Comb Ducks have arrived early along with Northern Pintail and Northern Shoveler.  We are expecting Common and Red-Crested Pochards,” said Virani. Northern Pintails, Lesser Whistling Ducks and Pallid Harrierswere sighted by avid birdwatchers Nitin Marathe and Avinash Londhe at Khapri Lake on Umred Road.  “This must be the first flock of the migratory birds, indicating that the winter migration has begun,” said Londhe.  Honorary wildlife warden of Akola, Devendra Telkar, said that the region has fewer migratory birds this time.  “Some River Terns and Open-Billed Storks have been sighted but till now, not many birds have come when compared to the previous years.  De-silting of lakes can be a reason,” he said.  BIRDS OF DIFFERENT FEATHERS Birds landed: Pacific Golden Plover, Black-Bellied Tern, Northern Pintail, Lesser Whistling Duck, Common Pochard, Black Redstart, Black-tailed Godwit, Verditer Flycatcher, Northern Shoveler, Ruddy Shelducks and Comb Ducks.  These are both water and forest birds which come to India for the purpose of breeding or in search of food.  Birds expected: Bar-Headed Goose, Common crane, Black stork, Common Pochard, Red-Crested Pochards are expected to arrive in a month’s time.  Usual spots of bird watching, where and distance from Nagpur Chatri and Wadali Lakes, Amravati (155km); Kekatpur and Dastapur Lake, Amravati (130km); Pohra Malkhed forest, Amravati (150km); Kumbhari, Kapsi and other water bodies in Akola 250km; Khapri, Paradgaon and Haladgaon lakes, Umred Road (35km); Navegaon Lake, Gondia (130km); Mihan water bodies (just outside city)Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Little egret with grey morph, bar-headed geese sighted  Nagpur: In a unique finding, a little egret with grey morph was sighted in the region.  Bird experts said that the morph is very rarely reported in Asia Pacific and might be a result of mutation, cross breeding or pigmentation.  The egret was recently sighted by Jayant Wadatkar, honorary wildlife warden, Amravati district and birdwatcher Neenad Abhang at upper Wardha dam near Morshi.  Though the bird was earlier confused with other species of egrets like western reef, it was finally identified as grey morph little egret.  The genesis of the morph remains indeterminate as not much research has been done it.  But bird experts were of the view that multiple factors can cause the change in colour.  “It can either be due to mutation or crossbreeding.  Another probable reason can be pigmentation, albinism which is seen in some birds,” said senior bird expert Dr Anil Pimplapure.  He added that rest of the bird’s features like black legs, yellow feet and black beak resemble with little egrets.  Pimplapure stressed that further study and continuous monitoring of the bird is required.  Wadatkar, who is keeping a regular watch on the bird’s behaviour said that it always stays with the flock of little egrets and displays same behavioural patterns.  Meanwhile, ending the keen wait of local birdwatchers, the first flock of 150-200 bar-headed geese has arrived in the region at Wadgaon lake in Umred.  According to bird watchers and experts, this is the first time that bar-headed geese have chosen this lake, probably due to changes in habitat.  The flock was sighted at Wadgaon lake by avid bird watcher Avinash Londhe who pointed out there have been no sightings of these Mongolian birds at their usual local hotspots, Paradgaon and Sayaki lakes.  “Last year, the birds had first arrived at Khapri Lake.  Crop rotation and habitat threat can be the reasons behind change in choice of water bodies,” he said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

column1: Chunar Fort
column2:
Times Passion Trail: Lessons in history, along the Ganga  Times Passion Trail takes you back to the origins of the holy river that flows through the heart of India.  Ganga aaye kahaan se, Ganga jaye kahaan re?"  Hemant Kumar asks in an evocative song from the film Kabuliwala, voicing what millions of Indians have mused silently for generations.  There are other rivers, longer and mightier elsewhere in the world; some like Amazon, Nile, Euphrates, Tigris and Indus have spawned impressive civilizations, but none can match the magic spell cast by the Ganga.  The third Times Passion Trail of season 2, Along the Ganges, is set to take you on a spiritual journey that traces the course of this mighty river from Devprayag to Rishikesh, Haridwar, Allahabad and Varanasi.  Ganga is born at Devprayag, where Bhagirathi originating in Gomukh beyond Gangotri meets Alaknanda that starts as a trickle at Vasudhara, a slender waterfall near Badrinath.  On day one in Devprayag, participants will visit the ghat for a holy bath and take part in Ganga Arti.  Devout Hindus believe that all sins accumulated in a lifetime are washed away by taking a dip in the sacred river.  This will be followed by a visit to the Raghunath temple, which will host a session on Ganga strotam, and a narration of the Ganga story by Prof K K Muhammed.  Pushpesh Pant, noted historian and food critic who will lead the trail, says a rock-cut sculpture in Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu, dating back to the Pallava period (circa 4-5 century CE) purportedly describes the scene when this life-sustaining stream descended on Earth.  Not very far away lie the ruins of Gangaikondacholapuram, the capital city founded by a legendary Chola emperor.  The caravan then heads to Rishikesh, where the famous Laxman Jhulla and lively markets await.  An early morning yoga & meditation session by Acharya Manish on the banks of the Ganga is sure to uplift spirits.  Participants also get to see some famous sites like Bharat Temple & Veer Bhadra Temple, and attend the Aarti ceremony at Parmarth Niketan before heading to Rishikesh, where spirituality meets architectural marvel on sites such as Daksh Prajapati Temple, Bilwakeshwar Mahadev Temple and Mayadevi Temple.  An informative session on Ayurveda and an organic lunch with Swami Balakrishna is on the menu here.  The most picturesque part of the trip lies in Allahabad, where a boat ride at the Triveni Sangam and a regal lunch at the Chunar Fort will serve as a treat for the senses.  Next stop is Varanasi, where a visit to the majestic Kashi Vishwanath Temple and witnessing the famous Ganga Aarti at Dashashwamedh Ghat from a boat promise to be a memorable end to a unique tour.  The trail also has fun sessions on Sanskrit and vedic maths and a visit to Banaras Hindu University.  Ganga has become a part of our culture and is encountered everywhere - in classical literature, folksongs, and sculptures.  Kalidasa has painted fascinating word pictures of the river, personifying it in Raghuvamsha and Kumarsambhava.  Adi Shankaracharya walked to take samadhi in the snow-clad Himalayas but not before he had composed the moving Gangalahari stotra.  The river, likened to the mother who nurtures, was invoked in anguish by Bhupen Hazarika as he composed the lyrics, " Vistaar hai apaar, charon oar hahakar, Ganga tu behati hai kyun?"  To embark on the Ganga trail is the beginning of an eternal journey - exhilarating and rejuvenating.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest India News.  Sucharita Gupta:  Ganga trail gets a musical touch in Varanasi  A delightful musical evening was a befitting culmination of Ganga Trail, organised as part of Times Passion Trails, an initiative by The Times of India.  The trail, that started from Devprayag and moved to Rishikesh, Haridwar and Allahabad, concluded at Varanasi and was a soul-stirring experience for the participants, who hailed from different cities. 
In Banaras, the travellers visited the Kashi Vishwanath temple, participated in the Ganga Arti and attended a lecture on Vedic Philosophy at Banaras Hindu University.  Treated to some soulful Kabir songs at Kabir Math, the participants also enjoyed a picnic in the midst of River Ganga at the Chunar Fort. 
The presence of eminent scholar Prof Pushpesh Pant, who gave some valuable inputs to the participants, added to their experience.  âTravelling along River Ganga is always a novel experience.  One tends to discover something new not only about the river but also about oneself,â he said . 
Gushing about her experience, Smita Visheshwar from Chennai said, âBanaras turned out to be as I had imagined â picturesque and beautiful. â
Dinesh Pai, a banker from Dubai, who participated in the trail, said âWe have travelled 900 kms along River Ganga witnessing different cultures which was quite a memorable experience.  What makes Banaras special is the vibrancy of the cityâ.  At the evening depicting the musical traditions of Banaras, which was held for the participants, eminent vocalist Sucharita Gupta regaled the audience with mellifluous thumri, chaiti and Holi compositions.  She also rendered some popular numbers like Nazar Lagi Raja Tore Bangle Par, Hamri Atariya Pe.  Dama Dam Mast Kalandar led to impromptu dancing by Asha Senani, Romy Agarwal and Jenice Somji. 
On popular demand Dhanush Acharya, a participant from Dubai, crooned some numbers like Phoolon Ke Rang Se, and Pal Pal Dil Ke Pas.  Others also joined in when he sang Kal Ho Na Ho.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Chunar Fort to be restored, opened for public  LUCKNOW: The historic Chunar fort in Mirzapur district of Uttar Pradesh will soon open its gates for tourists.  On Tuesday, UP chief minister Akhilesh Yadav directed that the PAC recruitment training centre running inside the fort will be vacated and said it will be revived as a heritage structure in UP. 
“The Chunar fort will remain alive.  The chief secretary will ensure funds for the heritage building,” said Akhilesh.  He was addressing international and Indian travel writers and bloggers at the Uttar Pradesh Tourism's Travel Writers' Conclave 2015. 
The fort whose history dates back to 56 BC, is currently occupied by one of the PAC recruitment training centres and is situated on the rocky banks of Ganga. 
“Those who talk about trillion dollar businesses, should talk about tourism.  They should at least retain their tradition and culture like the way we have held onto Lucknow's etiquette.  Tourism is connected to all aspects of society and people and is all inclusive,” he said. 
“We don't term UP as the state that has given the country seven PMs.  For us, those who aim to be the PM, can come to UP, be it Varanasi or other places,” said the CM. 
“A lot of people have prospered in this state that has had a rich heritage of communal harmony.  There is no discord or difference between people here, as is being claimed by some,” he added further. 
Talking over the tourism prospects of UP, Akhilesh said that the Golden Triangle (tourist circuit linking Delhi, Agra and Jaipur) will soon be trailing UP's Heritage Arc (linking Agra, Lucknow and Varanasi). 
Yadav also appreciated the talent of guides who entwine history into fiction smoothly “The guides tell you about stories such as when Tansen used to sing, lamps would be lit up.  Those who are away from science will not believe this, but science has proved that at a certain frequency of music, light can be produced,” he said. 
Chief secretary Alok Ranjan pointing out to the attempt of unleashing UP's potential to the world said, “The extent of misinformation is such that many foreign tourists believe that Taj Mahal is in Rajasthan.  We need to properly inform people around the world about our tourism assets. ” In this regard, he said that the UP government is expanding Agra to build a Mughal museum along with other projects. column1: Humayun Road
column2:
Sardar Patel Marg closed for two days  NEW DELHI: Delhi Traffic Police has advised commuters to avoid central Delhi on January 25 and 26.  As an added measure this year, police have decided to shut down Sardar Patel Marg and a part of C-Hexagon as well.  Traffic officials that parts of south Delhi might also be affected as the US president is scheduled to visit Siri Fort auditorium after the Republic Day celebrations. 
The US president is scheduled to arrive in the capital on Sunday morning and head to ITC Maurya Hotel.  Traffic officials said that all of Sardar Patel Marg which passes near the hotel will be shut down during his stay.  Traffic will instead be diverted through Ring Road from Dhaula Kuan towards Moti Bagh or Karol Bagh, police said.  TNN
" No traffic will be allowed on Tilak Marg, Bahadurshah Zafar Marg and Netaji Subhash Marg up to Red Fort after 5am on Republic Day,"  said Anil Shukla, joint commissioner, traffic. 
Police officers said that auto-rickshaws and taxi will be allowed to enter or ply in the restricted from entering Lutyen's Delhi after 7am on January 26. 
While the parade will begin around 9.50am from Vijay Chowk, there will be a related function at India Gate at 9am, said traffic police.  The parade will go via Rajpath, India Gate, Tilak Marg, Bahadurshah Zafar Marg and Netaji Subhash Marg to Red Fort. 
Areas bounded by Kautilya Marg, Kamal Ataturk Marg, Aurangzeb Road, Q-point, Humayun Road, Subramaniam Bharti Marg, Mathura Road, Bhagwan Dass road, Feroze Road roundabout, Windsor Place, Ashoka Road, Baba Kharak Singh Marg, Mother Teresa Crescent and Sardar Patel Marg up to Kautilya Marg will remain a restricted area, added officers
" Only labelled vehicles of the invitees and vehicles of bonafide residents of these areas will be permitted to enter this area from 6am on Saturday till the end of the parade about 12.30pm.  Invitees are requested to follow the routes and instructions printed on the back of label to reach the parking lots,"  said Shukla. 
During the parade, cross-traffic at ITO crossings, Delhi Gate and beyond will be allowed, depending upon the progress of the parade, said officials. 
Traffic cops have suggested several alternatives for commuters.  While those travelling between north and south Delhi are advised to use Ring Road, Mathura Road or Mother Teresa Crescent, those travelling between east and west Delhi can use Ring Road or Ridge Road. 
Those travelling to New Delhi railway station can use Connaught Place to reach the Ajmeri Gate side if travelling from south Delhi.  North Delhi commuters can use Jhandewalan while west Delhi commuters should use the ISBT bridge and approach the station from the Paharganj side.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  FIR on fake EWS admission racket in top Delhi schools  NEW DELHI: Delhi Policeâs crime branch has detected fake nursery admissions under the economically weaker section (EWS) category in leading city schools, according to sources.  An FIR (number 41) has been registered in the case, the sources said. 
An organized syndicate is believed to be involved in the racket.  The kingpin is at large. 
The police has already detected more than 30 such admissions in the last two years and suspect the number may go up substantially, the sources added. 
âThe schools where fake admissions have been detected are Raghubir Singh Junior Modern School (Humayun Road), DPS Vasant Kunj, DPS Rohini, DPS RK Puram, G D Goenka, Lancer Convent Rohini, Venkateshwara school, Dwarka, Ryan international school, Rohini and several others,â a source told TOI. 
When contacted, joint commissioner Ravindra Yadav confirmed that fake admission had been detected in these schools.  The crooks charged anything between Rs 1 lakh and 5 lakh per admission depending on the school and the income of the parents. 
Notices have been served to more than a dozen schools wherein police has sought the list of students admitted under the EWS quota and the documents furnished by them, police said. 
âWe have registered an FIR under appropriate IPC sections and served notices to more than a dozen schools, the details of which can not be shared at this stage.  Our probe is at a preliminary stage,â Yadav added.  Two of the crooks have been identified but the cops did not confirm if they had been arrested. 
The police swung into action after receiving a tip-off about a syndicate facilitating nursery admissions.  The cops served a notice to the schools about which they were tipped off and got admission documents.  Verification of the documents led the cops to identify the students and parents.  Interrogation of the parents revealed the names of people who were a part of the gang. 
A circular by the Directorate of Education confirms that Delhi Police has detected fake admissions in Delhi schools. 
âOne of the district magistrates of revenue department, has brought to the notice of this directorate that a few admissions under EWS category in various schools of Delhi have been got done on the basis of forged and fake income certificates submitted by the respective parents.  It has also been informed that due diligence is not being exercised and verification of income certificates and caste certificates is not being done by the principals/managements of the schools at the time of admission.  As a result, ineligible people are getting undue benefits and eligible/deserving students are deprived of admission under the above said categories,â the circular reads. 
âThe directorate has taken the said irregularities seriously.  Therefore, all the principals/managements of Private Unaided Recognized Schools of Delhi are hereby directed to be cautious in this regard and exercise due diligence as well as carry out necessary verification before admissions so as to ensure that benefits of admission under EWS/DG Category students reach the eligible and deserving students,â the circular further reads. 
However, Bindu Sehgal, principal of DPS Vasant Kunj, said, âWe have not received any notice from either the Crime Branch or the Directorate of Education.  Ours is a most transparent system and the draw of lots for EWS seats is done in the present of members of the parent-teacher association (PTA) and the DoE's nominee.  Sometimes we have done home-visits too to check if the candidate genuinely belongs to this category but have not detected any fakes so far. â
Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education Act, 2009 makes it mandatory for all private unaided recognized schools to admit at least 25% children belonging to economically weaker sections and the disadvantaged group category to entry level classes and provide free and compulsory education to them till completion of elementary education. 
Further, private unaided recognized schools (non-minority) running on land allotted by government agencies are also under obligation to admit 20% children belonging to EWS Category in upper classes.  The income and caste certificates issued by the competent authority of revenue department, GNCT of Delhi are fundamental and decisive documents to claim the benefits under EWS/DG Category.
