Phones off, Delhi couple who ran racket dodge police again  NEW DELHI: More than 30 policemen in six teams are raiding places in Delhi, Haryana and Rajasthan to catch two people suspected to have operated the nursery admission racket in top Delhi schools. 
Sources said the gang ran separate operations in north and south Delhi.  The one in Rohini and other north Delhi areas was headed by a man named Prince.  His wife, Punita, was also involved and three of their associates have been identified. 
A source in one of the raiding teams said the couple's phones were traceable in Haryana till Friday night but had been switched off since Saturday morning.  Police are trying to track down the people they were in touch with before going underground. 
Prince and Punita were educational consultants in the Rohini area and are suspected to be involved in admission rackets at the college level also.  They have managed to throw police off their trail at least thrice in the past one month and change phone numbers frequently. 
Police are scanning call details of the couple to ascertain whether they were in touch with school officials and are likely to seek lists of school officials' phone numbers. 
" Fake admissions have been detected at Raghubir Singh Junior Modern School (Humayun Road), DPS Vasant Kunj, DPS Rohini, DPS RK Puram, GD Goenka, Lancer Convent Rohini, Venkateshwara School, Dwarka, Ryan International School, Rohini and several others,"  a senior officer told TOI. 
TOI had reported on Saturday that an FIR had been registered in this connection.  The number of cases is expected to increase beyond the 30 detected so far.  Notices have been served on more than 12 schools to provide lists of students admitted under EWS quota and the documents furnished by their parents. 
The FIR in the case states that EWS seats are sold on the basis of fake income and residence proofs.  In some cases, children are admitted under a false name which is changed later.  " This illegal practice defeats the very purpose of the scheme launched for economically weaker section of society,"  it states.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Cops smell rat in move from EWS to general seat  NEW DELHI: The crime branch, which is probing fake nursery admissions, has asked schools to submit the list of students who were admitted under the EWS quota but later applied for a change to general category.  Police have information that a large number of students had changed their quota to get out of the ambit of probe, if one took place. 
Police interrogated a dozen parents who expressed ignorance and told that they were informed that the admission was happening in a lawful manner.  However, they could not answer why their children were admitted under fake names. 
Joint commissioner (crime), Ravindra Yadav refused to comment saying the operation was ongoing and details would be confirmed after arrests were made.  He has reportedly pulled up the probe team for investigating at a snail’s pace. 
The probe team is contemplating to avail services of data analysis experts to detect anomalies or contradictions in the information furnished by schools.  Sources said the list of students who opted for change in quota after admissions has given crucial leads. 
An officer said that the kingpins of the north Delhi module, identified as Prince and Puneeta, had connived with some school officials and got the students’ quota changed.  The parents submitted an application to the school stating that their income had increased and they were no longer in the ambit of economically weaker section and, thus, their ward may be treated as general category student.  The school accepted the application and began charging fees. 
“Fake admissions have been detected at Raghubir Singh Junior Modern School (Humayun Road), DPS Vasant Kunj, DPS Rohini, DPS RK Puram, GD Goenka, Lancer Convent Rohini, Venkateshwara School, Dwarka, Ryan International School Rohini, and several others,” a senior officer told TOI.  An FIR has been registered and the number of cases is expected to increase beyond the 30 detected so far. 
Prince and Punita, educational consultants in Rohini area, have managed to throw police off their trail at least thrice in the last one month and change phone numbers frequently.  The couple’s phones were traceable in Haryana till last week, but are switched off since Saturday. 
A directorate of education circular admits to negligence in verification of students.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Delhi cops unearth 300 fake nursery admissions  NEW DELHI: Police have unearthed more than 300 fake nursery admissions through the quota for poor students in top Delhi schools and arrested four people in the racket. 
The principal of Bal Bharti School, Pitampura, has been examined and her office raided on Tuesday, as cops said school authorities could be involved and claimed that some schools took " unusually long"  to furnish admission data.  TOI was the first to report the scam, concerning admissions to the 2014-15 batch.  READ ALSO: FIR on fake EWS admission racket in top Delhi schools Police said the admission racket was highly organized.  The agents managed admissions in fictitious names under the economically weaker sections (EWS) quota and later got the names and quota changed in school records with the help of officials. 
" The schools where fake admissions have been detected are Delhi Public School (Rohini, Vasant Kunj, RK Puram and Mathura Road), Modern School (Humayun Road), Lancer Convent, Ryan International School, Montfort School (Ashok Vihar), G D Goenka (Rohini), Vikas Bharti (Rohini), Bal Bharti School (Pitampura) and Heritage School (Rohini).  Verification of the EWS certificates used for admissions in many other schools is still under process,"  joint commissioner of police (crime) Ravindra Yadav said. 
Those arrested have been identified as Anil Kumar, Sudama Singh, Sharam Singh and Mukesh Sharma, the kingpin of this module.  While Anil sent admission seekers to Mukesh, Sudama arranged the forged documents.  Dharam prepared and finalized the fake papers, police said.  READ ALSO: Schools say no way to verify, not in wrong " The gang charged Rs 3-10 lakh for each admission in prominent schools of Delhi, in collusion with the school administration,"  Yadav added. 
Cops started investigating the racket a few months ago after receiving information about certain irregular admissions. 
" A special team led by ACP K P S Malhotra was formed to develop this information and the database of students admitted under the EWS quota was obtained from the schools in question.  The EWS certificates, on the basis of which admissions were sought, were also verified from SDM offices and several of them were found to be forged,"  additional commissioner (crime) Ashok Chand said. 
It was also found that multiple admissions had taken place in different schools on the basis of the same certificates and names of the students later changed.  A case under the appropriate sections of the law was registered at the crime branch.  READ ALSO: Principal kept in touch with main accused During investigations, some of the parents revealed that several modules of touts were active across the city to facilitate fake admissions. 
" During the process of data collection from school authorities and verification of EWS certificates from the concerned SDM offices, who too took very long to respond, these touts were alerted and went underground,"  Chand said.  Minute scrutiny by the crime branch team yielded results, when a specific information was received regarding one agent, Anil Kumar.  READ ASLO: Future of 250 children hangs in the balance " Immediately, the team swung into action and a trap was laid near Budh Vihar.  Anil was apprehended by a team comprising inspector Kulbir Singh, SIs Ritesh and Neeraj among others.  From him, documents of parents who had got their children admitted in Bal Bharti School, Pitampura, were recovered,"  Chand said. 
Subsequenlty the other three were also arrested.  Documents, computers, printers, rubber stamps of various government officials and software used for making fake documents were recovered from them. 
The mastermind of the module, Mukesh Sharma, has disclosed that he had a masters in zoology and gave home tuitions.  While being involved in the admission process of someone known to him, he learned about the EWS quota in schools.  He then developed contacts in the school's administration and set up the racket, police said.  READ ALSO: Four arrested for fake nursery admissions in DelhiDownload The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Schools say no way to verify, not in wrong  NEW DELHI: School authorities are denying that they were involved in running the fake EWS admission racket.  They also reiterate that till mid-May this year when a circular with a web address was issued, they had no way of checking whether the certificates submitted were genuine.  A principal says she’d informed the district authority of possible violations, but no action was taken. 
“I can say with confidence that no one was involved,” states Manju Rajput, head of Raghubir Singh Jurnior Modern School on Humayun Road which has been mentioned by police.  “Before May, there was no mechanism to check,” she continues.  “I have sent teams to check out doubtful cases.  In one instance, there were several candidates with the same address.  I let applicants know that the school is authorized to cancel admissions and the draws are conducted openly in the presence of officials and recorded on video.  But it is simply not possible to verify.  This is a good opportunity for police to track down where these certificates are coming from instead of imagining that the management is involved. ”
“It is wrong to accuse the schools.  How can we be involved when they’ve got the fake certificates through people outside the school?” asks S Premlatha, principal, Vikas Bharati Public School—also on the list.  She adds that the nine fake admissions discovered at her school were cancelled and new students have been admitted against those vacancies already. 
Neena Kaul, principal, Heritage School, Rohini, says that the school “has from time to time informed the SDM of possible violations in EWS admissions but there was no response”.  She, too, says of her school that it’s not in any way involved. 
“We have followed every date list, every instruction.  Why was the website link circulated only last month and not two years ago? We would’ve done the needful like we always do. ”
Lawyer and activist Khagesh Jha believes that a particular provision in the Right to Education Act 2009—that made 25% quota for equally weaker sections and disadvantaged groups (EWS/DG) compulsory—is being exploited.  It requires schools to admit EWS students first from within a radius of one kilometre and, if there are still vacancies, from within three kilometers and finally six.  “Practically all the schools being named are located in places where they won’t have significant slum clusters within one kilometre.  We need to see if these certificates have addresses within a kilometre of the school.  If there are few applicants, there may not even be a draw and admission is practically assured; even if there is a draw, your chances are better,” he explains.  Modern’s main draw, for instance, is from Nizamuddin Basti which is within three kilometres but not one.  Heritage has no slum area close by at all but attracts students from villages and usually has enough applicants within a kilometre to merit a draw.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  'Why did NDMC collect conversion charges?'  NEW DELHI: The high court's remark that Khan Market traders should pool in resources to redevelop the market as it is private property has cheered New Delhi Municipal Council (NDMC) that is opposed to spending money on the much-delayed redevelopment project. 
While traders say the civic agency has gone back on its word, officials say NDMC never promised to redevelop the market but merely helped its two associations finalize a fire safety plan.  "  We got a comprehensive redevelopment plan made for the market, but it was never approved by any statutory body.  As for fire safety, NDMC facilitated the process of preparing a fire safety plan.  But we (government agency) can't implement the project and spend money on it, as it is private property.  Owners of these private properties have to pay for the implementation of the fire safety plan,"  said Nikhil Kumar, NDMC secretary, adding that the civic agency will abide by the court order in the matter. 
Khan Market Welfare Association (KMWA) had moved court seeking directions to NDMC for implementing the redevelopment plan.  "  How can they (NDMC) say they can' t spend money on private property? They have collected a huge amount from first-floor traders as conversion charges.  We pay extremely high property taxes,"  said Arjun Kapur, president of KMWA.  "  The civic agency had roped in an expert to prepare the redevelopment plan.  Now how can they say that traders will have to pay for it? The amount deposited as conversion charges was meant for the market' s redevelopment. " 
Sources say none of the first-floor shops has a no-objection certificate from Delhi Fire Service.  Fire safety is a major concern as the market is not equipped to handle a blaze.  A Supreme Court-appointed monitoring committee had also highlighted the issue of fire safety and had raised objections on the sub-division of shops in 2011.  Thereafter, the Union urban development ministry had directed NDMC to prepare a redevelopment plan. 
"  I was commissioned to prepare the redevelopment plan.  Based on that plan, NDMC got land for creating a parking facility and Amrita Shergill Marg was extended till Humayun Road.  Many more actions were also taken.  But the plan is yet to see the light of day,"  said Sudhir Vohra, urban planner and consultant architect for the project. 
In 2013, the civic agency and the two stakeholders—KMWA and Khan Market Traders' Association (KMTA)—had finalized the redevelopment plan.  The civic agency had also roped in IIT-Roorkee to study the structural stability of buildings.  In January 2014, Delhi Fire Service approved the plan to implement its fire safety plan.  But the civic agency didn' t implement it as the two traders associations could not come to an agreement.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Delhi HC questions NDMC on renaming Aurangzeb Road  NEW DELHI: The row over renaming Aurangzeb Road in honour of former President A P J Abdul Kalam reached the Delhi high court on Friday which sought to know procedures followed by NDMC while taking the decision. 
A bench of Chief Justice G Rohini and Justice Jayant Nath refused to stay the move or even issue notice on a petition challenging the name change.  However, it asked New Delhi Municipal Council (NDMC) to give the reasons on which it decided to change the name of the road.  “We need information on what basis you (NDMC) decided to change the name.  File an affidavit before September 22,” the bench said, while hearing a PIL seeking to restrain NDMC from issuing a notification regarding changing of the name. 
Filed by a lawyer, Shahid Ali, the petition claimed the decision “lacks understanding of history” and is against a 1975 notification, according to which names that are a part of history will not be altered.  The issue of the notification was also raised by AAP MLA Amanatullah Khan who wrote to chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Thursday, asking for a cancellation of the order. 
Defending the civic agency’s stand, additional solicitor general Sanjay Jain told the court that the road has been renamed after a “contemporaneous public icon who the country worships”. 
The senior law officer also dismissed the claim by the petitioner that norms were violated saying “this road comes under the domain of NDMC, giving unfettered power to the civic body to rename the road.  It is not the first time that any road has been renamed… the name of Humayun Road was also changed”. 
According to the PIL, NDMC’s move to change a historical name was bound to “adversely affect the image of India as a secular and justice-imparting country”.  The plea said the “act of altering the historical name is nothing but an outcome of sick and communal politics”. 
On August 28, the request to change the name of the road, made by BJP MPs Maheish Girri and Meenakshi Lekhi, and AAP’s trade wing secretary, was accepted by NDMC. Elderly bizman plays cop, chases and nabs snatcher  NEW DELHI: An elderly businessman played cop after two men snatched his bag at knifepoint near Khan Market on Monday afternoon. 
Around 11am, Surender Kumar Gupta and his son, Deepak, were returning home to Greater Kailash from north Delhi in their car. When they reached Golf Links road, their vehicle mysteriously got punctured.  They stopped the car to repair it.  As they were about to restart it, the two men on a scooter tried to open its rear door and steal their bag. 
“Though it did not have much valuables, I held on it One of them pulled out a kni fe and threatened to stab me if I resisted,“ said Gupta in his complaint.  He had a mi nor scuffle with the man ri ding pillion after which the duo sped off towards Khan Market.  Surendra and Dee pak chased them through Lutyens' Delhi till Humayun Road where they decided to overtake them.  However, the accused lost balance and their two-wheeler skid near a Metro station. 
The father-son duo nabbed the man riding pillion and called for help.  A few passengers exiting the Metro station helped them pin down the man.  In the meantime, the other accused picked up his scooter and fled. 
The PCR was informed and the man arrested.  He was identified as Sumit.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  School admission racket busted Four men were arrested for their alleged involvement in an organised racket that specialised in giving admissions in prominent city schools at exorbitant prices, the Crime Branch said on Tuesday. 
Ravindra Yadav, Joint Commissioner of Police (Crime), said as many as 250 admissions across Delhi schools, which were obtained on the basis of fake economically weaker section (EWS) certificates among other forged documents and priced between Rs.  3 and Rs.  10 lakh, had come to light so far. 
While many such modules were found to be active in Delhi, according to Mr.  Yadav, a home tutor, who was the brains behind one such racket, and three of his agents, identified as Anil Kumar, Sudama Singh and Dharam Singh, were arrested. 
“Mukesh Sharma, who holds a M. Sc.  degree in zoology and used to give home tuitions, decided to exploit the EWS quota to his advantage.  He developed contacts within a particular school’s administration, procured fake EWS certificates in addition to voter Ids, and charged between Rs.  3 and Rs.  5 lakh per admission depending on the profile of the family,” Mr.  Yadav said. 
The Crime Branch claimed schools where fake EWS certificates were found to have been used to procure admissions included the Delhi Public School’s Rohini, Vasant Kunj, RK Puram and Mathura Road branches, Modern School on Humayun Road, Lancer’s Convent, Ryan International School, Montfort School, Ashok Vihar, GD Goenka School, Rohini, Vikas Bharti School, Rohini, Bal Bharti School, Pitampura, and Heritage School, Rohini, among others.  Mr.  Yadav said information about the racket was received a few months ago. 
“The verification process revealed that many of the EWS certificates used were fake and forged.  Multiple admissions apparently took place in different schools on the basis of the same certificates with the names of the students getting changed later,” said Mr.  Yadav. 
According to Mr.  Yadav, Anil was the first to be arrested followed by Sudama, Dharam and finally Mukesh. 
The verification of EWS certificates used for admissions in many other schools is still under process. 
Mr.  Yadav said further investigation on the possible connivance of members of the school administration was being probed.  Obama's India visit: Traffic restrictions in place in capital NEW DELHI: Traffic restrictions have been put in place in the national capital ahead of US President Barack Obama's visit with roads around ITC Maurya Hotel being shut down for vehicular movement while those leading to Rajpath will remain out of bounds for general public from tomorrow evening. 	According to police, general traffic restrictions will remain in place in New Delhi area in view of Republic Day parade and other programmes.  It is advised to avoid New Delhi area, C-Hexagon India Gate on January 25 and 26.  On January 27, restrictions shall be made on August Kranti Marg and public is requested to avoid August Kranti Marg. 	" Part of Sardar Patel Marg (both carriageways) -- from Sardar Patel Marg-Panchsheel Marg till Dhaula Kuan -- will remain closed for general traffic from 9 AM.  No traffic will be allowed on C-Hexagon India Gate between Akbar Road and Copernicus Marg.  Traffic will also remain closed for a few hours on Kasturba Gandhi Marg and Ashoka Road,"  said Joint Commissioner of Police (Traffic) Anil Shukla. 	Police said the traffic will also be affected on Mathura Road-Bhagwan Das Road and Ring Road. 	No vehicle will be allowed to ply on Rajpath after 6 PM tomorrow till the closure of function on January 26.  No traffic will be allowed on Tilak Marg, B S Z Marg, Netaji Subhash Marg up to Red Fort after 4:00 AM on the Republic Day. 	Republic Day Parade shall start at 9:50 AM from Vijay Chowk and pass through Rajpath, India Gate, Tilak Marg, Bahadur Shah Zafar Marg, Netaji Subhash Marg and end at Red Fort Grounds.  There will be a related function at India Gate at 9 AM. 	The cross traffic on the route of the parade at Dr Dineshnandini Dalmia Chowk (W point) R C Aggarwal Chowk (A Point), Delhi Gate and beyond will be allowed depending upon the progress of the parade. 	On January 26, area bounded by Kautilya Marg-Kamal Ataturk Marg-Aurangzeb Road-'Q'-point-Humayun Road-Subramaniam Bharti Marg-Mathura Road-Bhagwan Dass Road-Feroze Shah Road R/A Windsor Place-Ashoka Road-Baba Kharak Singh Marg-Mother Teresa Crescent and Sardar Patel Marg up to Kautilya Marg will be restricted area and only labelled vehicles of the invitees and vehicles of bona fide residents of these areas shall be permitted on Monday from 6 AM to enter till conclusion of the Parade at about 12.30 PM. 	" Invitees are requested to follow routes and instructions printed on backside of label to reach the parking lots.  For the guidance of the visitors, directional boards for seating enclosures have also been erected at various locations,"  said Shukla. 	Police said that invitation cards have been issued for the invitees and other spectators. 	" People are requested to acquaint themselves with the location of their seating enclosures and the parking lots.  Enclosures No 1 to 17 are located on the Southern side of Rajpath, while enclosures No 18 to 35 are located on the Northern side of Rajpath,"  said Shukla. 	The Triangular labels are meant for parking lots 1 to 5 situated on the South of Rajpath behind the Water Channel.  Similarly, Square parking labels 6 to 9 are for parking lots on Northern side of Rajpath behind Water Channel. 	In addition, separate parking labels meant for " Park & Ride"  scheme on same pattern i. e.  square for parking at Palika Parking Connaught Place (North of Raj Path enclosures) and Triangular for parking at Central Civil Services Cultural & Sport Board Ground at Vinay Marg (South of Rajpath enclosures) have been issued.   	After conclusion of the ceremony, the officers may board the waiting buses from the same points where they alighted and reach their respective 'Park & Ride' locations where they had parked their vehicles. 	" No TSR and Taxi will be allowed to enter or ply in the restricted area after 6:00 AM.  Those visitors who are coming by auto/taxi may use 'Park & Ride' facility to reach the venue.  Traffic police arrangements are for the guidance of the public.  Motorists are required to have patience, observe traffic and road discipline and follow directions of Traffic Police personnel,"  said Shukla. 	Routes for inter-city and inter-state buses will also be either curtailed or diverted during the period. 	Police also said that invitation card has been issued by name and is not transferable. 	" This should not be transferred to anyone else.  Mobile phone will not be allowed in enclosures.  Do not bring electronic items like Laptop, Camera/Video Camera, Transistor, Digital Diary, Remote controlled Car-keys, etc.  Do not bring eatables, food packets, water bottles, cigarette lighter, match boxes, knives, arms, etc,"  the advisory said.

column1: Moulivakkam
column2:
Buyers prefer apartments over plots  TRICHY: The skyrocketing prices of land and individual houses in the city are prompting people here to go for aprtments.  The apartment promoters in the city are pinning their hopes on people from the middle-class sections who are looking to get a residence with the aid of housing loans offered by many banks.  Though apartments started cropping up in the city nearly 20 years ago, the trend of opting for such residences has only gradually picked up.  Despite the sluggishness in the real estate and construction fields for the past few years, apartment promoters are ready to take up new projects.  As many as 120 apartments are under construction in the city alone.  Apartments have mushroomed against a backdrop of skyrocketing costs of unapproved empty plots, making it impossible for most people to acquire an individual house of their own.  Besides, it is learnt that majority of the plot promoters do not even approach the local planning authority (LPA) because they are not ready to satisfy norms like broad roads.  To boost the demand for apartments, the Confederation of Real Estate Developers' Association of India (CREDAI) conducted a three-day 'Fairpro- 2015', an exhibition to attract people dreaming of owning a house.  The apartment promoters are focusing on developing flats within city limits, rather than constructing individual houses.  The price of apartments on the main roads in the city is higher than in the inner roads.  " Though many dream of owning an individual house in the city limit, these are not affordable.  So they switch to buying apartments which are available at reasonable prices.  This will give apartment promoters a boost,"  said V Gopinathan, co-chairman of Fairpro-2015.  There is a general perception among people that the price of apartments will not appreciate like individual houses.  However, N Anand, chairman of Fairpro, said that the resale value of apartments inside the city limit will be good.  " It is a wrong perception that apartment prices will not appreciate.  People can sell flats for marginally good prices and they will not face any loss,"  said Anand.  The promoters offer one-bedroom, two-bedroom and three-bedroom flats, which may cost anywhere from Rs 25 lakh to Rs 1 crore, depending on the area.  The collapse of a building in Moulivakkam in Chennai last year has created apprehension among some potential customers about the safety of multi-storey buildings.  However, promoters assured that safety was their prime concern in all their projects.  The promoters are predicting an increase in the price of flats in the next three month due to price hike in all construction materials, particularly cement. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Court blocks demolition of second bldg in Moulivakkam  CHENNAI: More than six months after one of the two 11-storied residential towers collapsed at Moulivakkam, killing 61 people, the Madras high court has quashed the Kancheepuram district collector’s order to raze the second building still standing at the site.  The first bench comprising Chief Justice Sanjay Kishan Kaul and Justice M M Sundresh gave the relief after it was revealed that the district administration passed the demolition order without giving an opportunity of hearing to the builder and furnishing details of materials relied on by officials to pass the order. 
The bench, passing the orders on a petition filed by the building’s promoter M Bala Gurusamy, who is the managing director of Prime Sristi Housing Private Ltd, said: “It is trite law to say that the material relied upon against the builder ought to have been handed over to him to facilitate him to take his defence.  This has not been done. ”
After P Wilson, senior counsel for DMK leader M K Stalin, argued that the authorities were trying to protect the surviving second building, the bench directed the collector to furnish relevant materials to both the builder and the association of flat purchasers, so that the latter could prepare their independent claims against the builder to whom they paid money.  The bench then adjourned matter to March 17 for further proceedings. 
During arguments, Wilson reiterated Stalin’s demand for a CBI probe into the issue.  To this, the bench replied that the court was monitoring the investigation.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  ‘Naming erring builders on website will benefit buyers’  CHENNAI: Chennai Metropolitan Development Authority’s submission before the high court on Tuesday, during a hearing of the Moulivakkam building collapse case, that it was willing to put building violations on its website, may go a long way in educating the general public on trustworthiness of developers in the city. 
Developers’ body, Confederation of Real Estate Developers’ Association of India (CREDAI) has welcomed the move.  CREDAI Tamil Nadu president N Nandakumar said it would help buyers take informed decisions while buying apartments. 
“It will control unauthorized developments, which have been hampering the growth of developers who stick to rules while promoting projects.  CREDAI as a body has made it clear that developers who violate building norms have no place in the organization,” he said. 
“Unhealthy price competition among builders has been a major bane for the industry.  Those who violate approved plans and construct additional space sell their apartments at prices much lower than what developers who comply with norms charge,” said Nandakumar.  Many customers end up buying from errant developers, unaware of the violations in construction. 
An insurance consultant, who booked an apartment from a developer in the city a few years ago, had a tough time raising a loan to register the apartment.  He said, “Only when I applied for a loan did I realize that my entire penthouse was a deviation from the CMDA approved plan.  I was primarily attracted by the high undivided share of land the builder offered me.  It was obviously a trap. ”
CREDAI Chennai president Ajit Kumar Chordia said publicizing building violations would help speed up the legal due diligence process.  But it would be a difficult task to post all past data on the website of the regulatory body, he said. 
Another concern is whether CMDA would be able to provide timely information to apartment buyers.  For instance, most buyers book apartments while they are under construction.  CMDA’s review of the project would be of help to such buyers only if the agency carries out periodical inspections during the course of construction. 
Many developers who have violated building norms at will in the past have gone scot-free because of the lackadaisical attitude of the regulatory agencies and the state government’s generosity in condoning such violations. 
Putting names of erring builders on CMDA portal will help buyers take informed decisions Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Why Moulivakkam report not tabled: HC  CHENNAI: The Madras high court on Tuesday cautioned the Tamil Nadu government that it would be constrained to hand over the probe into the June 28, 2014 building collapse at Moulivakkam to the CBI, if there is further delay in placing the one-man commission’s report on the matter before the state assembly.  The warning came from the first bench comprising Chief Justice Sanjay Kishan Kaul and Justice T S Sivagnanam, a couple of days after the city marked the first anniversary of the tragedy. 
Justice R Reghupathy, who was named to probe the collapse, handed over the report to chief minister J Jayalalithaa on August 25, 2014.  Such judicial commission reports are supposed to be discussed at cabinet, and then tabled in the assembly along with cabinet decisions and recommendations.  In this case, no action has been taken after it was handed over to chief minister in a sealed cover. 
Pointing out this anomaly, DMK leader M K Stalin, who had earlier filed PILs seeking a CBI probe into the matter, moved another petition in the court on Tuesday saying relevance of the report has lapsed as it was not tabled in the assembly within the mandatory six months.  His senior counsel, former additional solicitor general of India P Wilson, said: “As per Section 3(4) of the Commission of Inquiry Act, the report should be placed before the assembly with a government note within six months from the date of receipt.  Therefore, the report given by Justice Reghupathy on August 25, 2014 has lapsed and the government is barred from placing it in the assembly. ”
Advocate general of Tamil Nadu A L Somayaji, however, denied there was any anomaly or lacuna in government’s handling of the issue, and assured the bench that he would ascertain the status of the report and the government’s decision in a couple of weeks.  The case was adjourned to July 13 for further hearing. 
During arguments, the judges repeated displeasure at the delay in filing counter-affidavits by the government. 
The June 28, 2014 collapse of the 11-storied building under construction killed 61 workers, triggering a spate of PILs, including those filed by Stalin, demanding a CBI probe, demolition of the second tower still standing close to its collapsed counterpart, removal of danger-zone tag, action against CMDA and other enforcement authorities for dereliction of duty, clearance of debris and search for remains of more victims, if any, underneath the rubble. 
A special investigation team which had filed a chargesheet in the Sriperumpudur magistrate court has now taken permission from the court to conduct further investigation, amidst charges of attempt to dilute the prosecution case itself. The warning came from the first bench comprising Chief Justice Sanjay Kishan Kaul and Justice T S Sivagnanam, a couple of days after the city marked the first anniversary of the tragedy.

During arguments, the judges repeated displeasure at the delay in filing counter-affidavits by the government.

TN saw most building collapses among southern states last year  CHENNAI: Real estate boom may have changed cityscapes, but the breathtaking pace at which highrises are being constructed in the country has a fatal side effect; building collapse.  The latest National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB) report says an average of four people were killed everyday in building collapses in the country in 2014.  When it comes to southern states, Tamil Nadu leads the list with 132 deaths, followed by Andhra Pradesh (93), Karnataka (49), Kerala (46) and Telangana (26). 
Last year, as many as 1,833 building collapses left 1,821 people dead and 580 injured.  Nationally, Uttar Pradesh saw the highest number of fatalities due to building collapses with 348 deaths, followed by Madhya Pradesh (184) and Maharashtra (180). 
Experts say the high incidence of building collapse in the country can be attributed to hasty construction of buildings with substandard materials, driven by high real estate demand.  Poor monitoring by government agencies is also to be blamed, experts say.  Many municipal bodies do not have adequate staff to conduct frequent inspections to monitor building violations.  There are also allegations of corruption in issuing of plan approvals. 
On June 28, 2014, an 11 storey under-construction building at Moulivakkam in Porur collapsed, killing 61 people, mostly construction workers.  However, the state government is yet to table the one-man commission's report on Moulivakkam building collapse before the Assembly. 
Union minister of state for urban development Venkaiah Naidu recently suggested that local bodies should make the town planner, inspector or whoever is in-charge of that area accountable for unauthorized constructions.  But the plan is yet to be implemented. 
A member of the Madras high court's monitoring committee for building violations, M G Devasahayam said the NCRB report on building collapses in Tamil Nadu is not surprising.  " Political interference and corruption prevent enforcement officials from doing their duty,"  he said, adding that local level officials rarely conduct soil checks, especially on highrise buildings. 
Y Arul Das, state coordinator of Nirman Mazdoor Panchayat Sangam, a registered trade union of construction workers, said the actual number of deaths due to building collapses in the country is much higher.  For instance, more than 70 people died in building collapse in Moulivakkam and wall collapses in Tiruvallur.  " Migrant workers often get killed at construction sites, but these accidents often go unreported as builders often settle cases with money. "  He said most states, including TN, have failed to disburse the money collected from building cess to eligible workers. 
When contacted, a senior government official said there is a need to conduct fresh verification to check building violations.  " People often deviate from the approved plan and construct additional floors without taking permission.  It's difficult to prevent all violations with existing staff.  With the current strength we can identify only 20% of violations. "  Download The Times of India News App for Latest India News.  HC stays order marking danger zone at crash site  CHENNAI: A Kancheepuram collector’s order declaring a 50m radius of the 11-storied building that collapsed in Moulivakkam a danger zone was stayed by the Madras high court on Monday. 
The order does not refer to any provisions of law empowering the district collector to declare the area around the collapse site as danger zone, and people adversely affected by the declaration were not put on notice, said Justice M Sathyanaryanan, staying operation of the July 1 order of Kancheepuram collector K Baskaran. 
However, taking note of the condition of the second 11-storied building which is still standing 10m away from the collapse site, the judge said: “It is made clear that in the event of collapse of the adjacent multi-storied building, the petitioner has to take the risk and bear the consequences. ”
The June 28, 2014 collapse killed 61 people, besides displacing neighbour and rendering those who booked flats, homeless.  The present petition was filed by Arun Enterprises partner C Dakshinamoorthy who could not reopen his unit because two-third of the premises came within the 50m danger zone. 
He assailed the July 1, 2014 order of the collector saying there is no mention as to under which provision did the collector pass the order declaring it a danger zone.  “He has not even mentioned the number of people whose properties are coming within the territory of danger zone and the names of people who will be adversely affected by this order,” it said, adding that the authorities had not even chosen to send a copy of the order to the affected people. 
The danger zone order itself stood out for two reasons: One, it conceded that the real cause of the collapse was yet to be ascertained. 
Secondly, it said the second 11-storied building standing just 10m from the collapsed structure is in bad shape too.  “There is an uncertainty about its structural safety and stability due to soundness of Block-A,” said the order. 
As a remedy the order said, the entire campus must be cordoned off from public entry, and that people residing in the surrounding areas of 50m should be evacuated to a safe place.  It also said all further construction activities at the site should be stopped forthwith. 
Justice Sathyanarayanan has posted the matter to August 26 for the collector to file his counter-affidavit.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Building in Chennai's Teynampet tilts after owner digs for tank  CHENNAI: A three-storey residential building in Teynampet started tilting ominously on Monday evening and would have fallen had a similar-sized building next to its left not dramatically arrested the collapse. 
The tumbling structure crushed one of the neighbouring building's balconies. 
Police and rescue personnel said no one was injured.  Families occupied houses on each floor but there were only two people within when the building started to tilt.  They got out safely. 
Officials said there were several illegalities in the construction of the building, which came up five years ago on Bhaktavachalam Street near SIET College.  This could have caused it to lose its bearings, they said, adding that they would raze the structure. 
Officials started preparations for the demolition late on Monday. 
As gawking crowds gathered, police barricaded the street it to keep people at a safe distance from the building.  At the spot were large chunks of concrete from the crushed balcony of the neighbouring building and other debris was strewn all around.  But perhaps the most important clue lay in a mound of sand nearby. 
Corporation of Chennai engineers who visited the spot said the building's occupants had started digging a sump last week and that could have weakened the building's foundations. 
" The foundation pillars were most probably weak and, during digging for the sump, workers must have hit a spot that was bearing the load of the building,"  an engineer of corporation's Zone 9 said at the site.  Officials evacuated tenants of both buildings. 
The owner of the building, P Vellan, said he learned about what happened when neighbours telephoned him.  " The neighbours said they felt their buildings shudder like there had been an earthquake,"  he said.  " I rushed to the spot to see what had happened. " 
Vellan admitted that he did not employ an engineer to plan or construct the building.  " We used a contractor for the construction of the building,"  he said. 
" The buildings on the street have no set-back area.  There are several violations,"  the corporation engineer said.  " Buildings on this street can only have two storeys.  But most have more than two. " 
The city has hundreds of illegal buildings, with owners deviating from approved plans to add floors and increase built-up space, compromising their structural integrity and jeopardising the safety of their occupants. 
Monday's episode took place just a little over a year after a 12-storey building a developer was constructing in Moulivakkam collapsed, burying 61 people in its rubble.  Investigations showed Chennai Metropolitan Development Authority had given permission to build twin towers, Trust Heights, of six storeys each but developer Prime Sristi illegally added six floors to each building without strengthening the foundation or reinforcing their columns and beams. 
" The owners of most residential buildings do not engage engineers during construction and don't follow the approved plan,"  an official with Anna University's Centre for Disaster Management and Mitigation said.  " These structures make up roughly 80% of the buildings in the city.  They can collapse at any time. " 
" I find prima facie the exact role he, being the Union minister for communications and information technology, played in misusing his office for wrongful gain by obtaining telephone connections illegally in the name of BSNL officials under service category.  As such, I do not find any frivolity in the prosecution.  Allegations which were attributed to Maran are corroborated by the material and circumstances on record,"  Justice Vaidhyanathan said. Moulivakkam building crash: Probe panel gives clean chit to government  CHENNAI: The Justice R Reghupathi Commission of inquiry, which probed the collapse of a multi-storey building at Moulivakkam last year, has called for a legislation to make insurance mandatory for buildings under construction and fix responsibilities on various stakeholders, including developers.  It has also recommended restructuring of CMDA, the regulatory agency, to improve its technical competence.  But no government agency or official has been held responsible for failing to ensure that the building adhered to the approved plan and norms. 
Since the building was under construction and CMDA had not issued a completion certificate, the agency has gone scot-free.  The commission, in its report tabled in the assembly on Tuesday, said the builder had deviated from the approved plan and structural design.  He even knocked off pillars and increased the span of beams to accommodate driveways.  The report has recommended pulling down the second building at the Moulivakkam site by terming it a " near future calamity" . 
Construction firms executing mega projects should be made to keep a " sizeable sum"  in fixed deposit for a minimum of 10 years as guarantee for quality of construction, the commission has suggested.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Reghupathi commission recommends payment of compensation to apartment buyers  CHENNAI: Justice R Reghupathi commission of inquiry that probed collapse of an 11-storey building at Moulivakkam last year said the other surviving building at the site resembled the ill-fated block " in terms of all short-falls and deviations that contributed to the mishap" .  The soil is loose, sandy and watery and pile foundations were not laid for a depth of 18 metres.  On the reason for the collapse of the building, the report said it was built primarily with a raft foundation and pillars were knocked off to accommodate driveways.  Experts who inspected the building detected insufficient concrete settings, cracks and punctures in columns. 
The report said the " present tragedy is a self-speaking parable"  and said it was not known how many projects, both completed and under-construction, suffered from similar deficiencies.  " The present instance is the best example about the dark-side behind the real estate and construction business where money is considered to be the only ambition and aim, and lives of human beings and customers are put at stake to test the duration of the feeble constructions raised by them. 
Noting that regulatory agencies lacked technical experts the commission recommended sweeping changes in CMDA's functioning including setting up of a committee comprising technical experts from CMDA, legal officers and experts in soil investigation, foundation design and structural engineering to carry out field inspections at every stage of construction of mega projects.  The committee should inspect buildings at various stages including earth work stage, laying of foundation, basement and concreting of each floor, the report said. 
Even though Tamil Nadu government has a directorate of vigilance and anti-corruption, Raghupathi has suggested setting up of a vigilance wing to keep a check on hidden and underhand transactions between officials in the regulatory agency and developers. 
As regards the loss suffered by customers who had invested in the ill-fated building and neighbours, whose houses were damaged in the disaster, the commission has urged the government to set up a committee to assess the loss and pay compensation by drawing money from the state disaster relief fund.  Buyers were still repaying loans though their apartments were completely razed, the commission pointed out and said it felt the need to go beyond its brief and suggest ways of assuaging their sufferings. 
Reacting to media reports that the government and the regulatory agency flouted norms by giving permission for high-rise buildings on a narrow road, the report said, " Prima facie it appears there is no violation on the part of CMDA and the government in recommending relaxation (of norms). " 
While developers welcomed most of the recommendations of the commission, they have reservations against retaining money from contractors for 10 years.  " CMDA already retains a deposit from developers.  Blocking more money as surety will add to project cost,"  said a city developer.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Can’t order refund for buyers of Moulivakkam flats, says HC  CHENNAI: Dealing a body blow to those who had booked flats in the ill-fated Moulivakkam building that collapsed in June 2014, the Madras high court on Thursday said that it could neither order refund of the money nor compensation. 
“We are not inclined to entertain the writ petitions, as we are of the view that to fix liability in the state government for officers not complying with their obligation, a trial would have to be conducted,” said the first bench of Chief Justice Sanjay Kishan Kaul and Justice Pushpa Sathyanarayana. 
A total of 48 people, who had booked flats in the 11-storey ‘Faith’ at Moulivakkam in Porur which collapsed on June 27, 2014, filed the present writ petition seeking refund of 17.68 crore they had together paid, besides 2.6 crore as reimbursement and another 17.68 crore as compensation.  They had cited grave financial loss, mental agony and harassment suffered due to the arbitrary acts of officials of the housing department, CMDA, directorate of town and country planning and Moulivakkam panchayat union. 
It was the commissions and omissions committed by them while granting building permission to Madurai-based Prime Sristi Housing Pvt Ltd that led to the collapse, they said in the petition. 
Several PILs, including one filed by DMK leader M K Stalin, seeking a CBI probe into the circumstances leading to the collapse of the building, various statutory relaxations offered to the builder and an order to excavate the entire location to ascertain if there were more bodies lying trapped underneath the rubble had been filed in the high court, and are pending. 
The two petitions were jointly filed by 48 flat owners who never got to see their property and are running from pillar to post, seeking help from banks to relax the loan norms and asking the government to help them out of the mess. 
Dismissing both the petitions on Thursday, the first bench said, " It would be in the fitness of things that a decision is obtained only after trial. " 
Pointing out that the affected people had moved the consumer court also for compensation, the judges said: " We may also note that the petitioners have already filed claims before the consumer forum against the builders and their endeavour to rope in the state government was not successful before the forum on account of jurisdiction of the forum. " 
The petition was then dismissed with liberty for the petitoners to pursue civil remedy in accordance with law.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  HC directs TNHB to adhere to regulations  MADURAI: Madurai bench of the Madras high court on Monday directed the Tamil Nadu Housing Board to ensure that it followed rules and regulations while constructing block of flats. 
Justices R Sudhakar and V M Velumani gave the direction to the executive engineer of the board on a petition from R Nagarajan. 
The petitioner had submitted that the board was building a multi-storeyed building in Madakulam village without obtaining plan approval from the local planning authority (LPA) and sought to restrain it from putting up unauthorised constructions. 
The petitioner had submitted that the government organisation itself was not following rules and regulations and sought a direction to the member secretary of local planning authority to initiate action against the officials concerned. 
The judges said the apprehension of the petitioner appeared to be in good faith. 
Secretary of the LPA should inspect the building and take action if there were violations. 
As the issue had been brought to the notice of the officials, they should act promptly, in accordance with law and avoid untoward incident as in Moulivakkam in Chennai, where an under-construction building collapsed claiming 61 lives last year, the judges said. Wake up, act against illegal buildings, HC directs civic officials  CHENNAI: Illegal buildings do not spring up overnight, and there exists an unholy nexus between builders and officials of Chennai Corporation and CMDA, said the Madras high court.  It lamented that no lesson seems to have been learned even after the June 28 collapse of a multi-storey building in Moulivakkam that claimed 60 lives.  It asked the civic authorities to wake up from their slumber and act against violators. 
A division bench of Justice Satish K Agnihotri and Justice K K Sasidharan refusing to review its order against regularising a four-storied building, with 32 residential units, at Gerumbakkam village in Sriperumpudur taluk, the judges said it had been built without any planning permission, that too in the middle of an unauthorised industrial layout and it is surrounded by industries. 
The matter relates to a review petition filed by M D Varadharajan, who had purchased an unauthorised layout, which is part of an unapproved multi-industrial layout.  Without waiting for planning permission, the builder constructed stilt plus four floors, with 32 dwelling units.  His application for planning permission was rejected by CMDA, and the appeal was rejected by the government.  His writ petition, too, was dismissed in January 2014.  He has now sought review of the order, saying there are no red category industries in the vicinity and that the order was passed on a misconception. 
Rejecting the plea, the judges said: " It would not be possible for construction of such high rise buildings overnight.  Without the knowledge of the officials, it would not be possible to construct buildings illegally.  The applicant has put up 32 residential units without planning permission.  Though the government dismissed the appeal as early as on June 21, 2013, neither CMDA nor Chennai Corporation took enforcement action.  Even after the dismissal of the writ petition, officials had not taken any action against the offending construction.  The unholy nexus between builders and officials of CMDA and corporation is writ large.  Even after the tragedy like the one that took place in Moulivakkam, the officials have not learnt lessons. " 
Such illegal structures are a threat to the safety of occupants as well as public at large, the bench said.  Po
