Ali Prem Garden
column2:
Bangladeshi family detained in Ghaziabad Ghaziabad, Jan 17 (IANS): Five members of a Bangladeshi family were detained here on Saturday for staying in India without valid documents, police said. 
Mohammad Siddiqui (48), his wife Parveen Bano (38), their son Sazid (19), and daughters Asia and Alia, aged seven and three years respectively, were detained by Ghaziabad police from their house at Ali Prem Garden in Sahibabad area. Police acted on a tip off by an informer who said the family was staying in India since 1991. During interrogation, Siddiqui told police that before coming to India, he was in the Bangladesh army from where he was cashiered for indiscipline. After that he sneaked into India with his wife. In 2006, he was caught by Delhi Police and deported to Bangladesh but he again came back. All four of his children were born in India. Inspector Upendra Yadav of the Sahibabad police station they were detained as police did not find any valid document with them.  The family will be produced in a court later.

column1: Nangaguda
column2:
4 more farmers end life Farmer suicide cases continue unabated in the State with four more peasants ending their lives due to alleged crop loss and debt burden in Nabarangpur and Dhenkanal districts on Friday. 
The deceased were identified as Baladev Gond of Nangaguda village under Umarkote block, Chaituram Gond of Mouradehi village under Raighar block of Nabarangpur district, Prasanna Jena of Uansadhia village under Nadial gram panchayat in Dhenkanal district and Harendra Bindhani (50), a sharecropper of Jambani village in the Gorumahisani area in Mayurbhanj district. 
The body of Baldev was found hanging from a tree near a river. 
His family members said he had borrowed money from private moneylenders for cultivation.  But due to crop failure, he was under severe mental stress.  Unable to bear the burden, he might have taken the extreme step, they added. 
“He did not bring loan from bank.  He had borrowed money from private moneylenders and was in stress after crop loss,” said brother of the deceased. 
Chaituram, who had grown paddy and maze in his four acres of land after taking loan from the nearest bank and private agencies, was going through tension. 
“He had grown paddy and maze in four acres of land and borrowed money from bank and moneylenders for the purpose.  He committed suicide as scanty rainfalls battered the hopes of an expected harvest,” his family members said. 
Meanwhile, the local MlA staged a dharna with the body of Chaituram demanding compensation of Rs10 lakh for the family of the deceased and declaration of  Raigarh block as completely drought-hit. 
Unable to bear the crop loss due to drought and loan burden, Prasanna Jena of Dhenkanal also committed suicide by consuming poison.  He had been rushed to the Athagarh hospital, where he died. 
In yet another incident, a farmer committed suicide on Friday by hanging himself under pressure of crop loss and debt burden, alleged family members.  The deceased was identified as Harendra Bindhani (50), a sharecropper of Jambani village under the Gorumahisani area.

column1: Saipriya Beach Resorts
column2:
AP signs MoUs for projects worth over Rs. 1,200 crore The State government on Saturday signed MoUs with representatives of eight different business organisations interested in starting projects in the State. 
These projects would bring in investments to the tune of over Rs.  1,200 crore, according to a statement released by the CMO. 
After interacting with them, Chief Minister N.  Chandrababu Naidu said the proposed projects would be launched within a time frame. 
He said the prospective investors could directly interact and sort out if they came across a problem.  He said he would make sure that the single window clearance will work effectively to clear all possible hurdles in the way of implementation of the proposed projects. 
The proposals include setting up of an amusement park and water world parks at Vijayawada, Tirupati and Visakhapatnam by Vijayawada-based LEPL Ventures Pvt.  Ltd in association with Ms.  PAN India Paryatan Pvt.  Ltd. , at an estimated cost of Rs.  800 crore. 
The city-based Air Costa proposes to offer destination package tours within in Vijayawada, Visakhapatnam and Tiruapti.  The Fluer Hotels Pvt.  Ltd.  has come forward to promote hotels in Vijayawada and Tirupati. 
Besides, four investor firms have been given provisional registration certificates for their proposed hotel projects.  Saipriya Beach Resorts at Rushikonda in Visakhapatnam will set up a convention centre and a water park aligned with beach resort . 
VSS Estates Pvt.  Ltd.  proposes to build star hotels in Vijayawada, Ms.  Poli Suneeta proposed to develop wayside amenities in Kadapa while Bliss hotel has come up with an offer to build a five star hotel. 
Meditation centres
A representative of Vipasana International Medication Centre also presented her proposal to set up meditation centres at Paderu, Lambasingi, and Chintapalli in Visakhapatnam.

column1: Basheer Bagh Palace
column2:
Hyderabad's opulent palaces a pale shadow of their past  HYDERABAD: Hyderabad's rich and resplendent past is best reflected in its historic structures, especially opulent palaces located in the old quarters of the city __ some of which have, sadly, been razed to the ground over the years.  Turn the pages of history and one is sure to be awestruck by the tales of these sprawling palatial structures that housed not just members of the Nizams' family, but also feudal lords who made Hyderabad their home. 
Intricately designed and elaborately decorated, these palaces (or deodis like some of them are called) were once synonymous with the city that boasted of at least a few dozen such structures, until a few decades ago.  What remains now is a poor shadow of the affluent past that the royals of Hyderabad flaunted. 
However, some of them have now come alive in the pages of 'Images of Hyderabad' (Volume-II), a recently compiled book by Urdu daily Siasat that deals extensively with the city's once mesmerizing palaces.  The first volume was published in 2012. 
" This book is a continuation of the first part and highlights the palaces and royal buildings that Hyderabad once had.  The idea behind bringing out these books was to refresh the memory of people about the rich heritage that the city has always been known for,"  said Zahid Ali Khan, editor of Siasat, confessing that most of the monuments that find a place in the book, no longer exist today.  Living room of Basheer Bagh Palace.  " The only palace that still exists in totality is the Falaknuma Palace.  Though the Chowmahalla Palace too is better of the lot, what you see is only 50% of the original structure,"  rued heritage activist Sajjad Shahid listing out at least half a dozen such palaces that have either been demolished or are on the verge of falling apart.  Be it the Purani Haveli or the King Koti Palace or even the Mahbubnagar Palace __ all share the same fate.  " A palace cannot be considered a palace if the intervening space between its gate and the building seizes to exist.  It is the surrounding environment that makes a structure a palace __ complete with its gardens and the works.  But most of what remains toady is just a building,"  Shahid added. 
Other historians point to the area behind the Chowk in the Old City where once stood a chain of architectural beauties: the Moin-ud-Daula ki Deodi, the Khurshid Jah ki Deodi (only the entrance and the front room of this remains now), the Iqbal-Ud-Daula ki Deodi and so on.  Today, they are nothing more than an eyesore, old-timers lament.  A historical photograph of Chandulal Baradari.  " There are two reasons for their decay.  Firstly, members of the Nizams' family themselves neglected these palaces once they were built.  Later, the successive governments turned their back on them,"  explained historian and scholar Allama Aijaz Farruq, who recently assisted the Siasat in compiling a book that takes readers on a beautiful pictorial tour of the city's palaces.  British residency main building.  Of the many structures that find a mention in the book, only a handful still dot the city's landscape.  " The beautiful Basheer Bagh palace has been wiped out.  The Hill Fort Palace that housed Moazzam Jah and was later turned into Ritz Hotel now lies covered under blue sheets.  Even the Bella Vista that's become the Administrative Staff College premises now was a magnificent structure at one point in time.  Now its several shades paler,"  the historian said.  The Malwala Palace, Chandulal ki Deodi, Jahanuma Palace are some of the other structures which have fallen prey to the vagaries of time and neglect. 
Heritage lovers hope that the authorities wake up at least now and try and preserve whatever little still remains of Hyderabad's glorious history.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

column1: Iyyer Bungalow
column2:
Walk for health, pay with life  MADURAI: The recent murder of S Kasthuri, a 65-year-old widow who lived in the Iyyer Bungalow area, during her morning walk has once again placed the issue of morning-walk murders under the limelight.  Several times in the past, high-profile personalities and ordinary people like Kasthuri have been targeted during their daily walks, especially in the morning. 
A senior police official on the condition of anonymity said most of the murders that took place during morning walks were preplanned.  For one thing, due to relaxed security and the general absence of large number of people on the spot, politicians and other high-profile figures are comparatively more accessible during their walks.  There would hardly be any people on the road early in the morning.  The timing of the targeted person is predictable.  There is also a lax in the security checks by police, making it easier to get away. 
Many politicians have been targeted and murdered this way in the past.  In May, 2003, T Krishnan, DMK leader and former minister, was hacked to death near his residence in K K Nagar while returning from his morning walk.  He was the minister for highways department and a powerful figure in the district before the emergence of former union minister M K Alagiri. 
In Trichy, former DMK minister K N Nehru’s brother Ramajayam was kidnapped when he left his house for a walk at 5am in March, 2012 and then murdered.  His body was later found inside bushes at Ponni delta near Thiruvalarsolai-Kallanai Road. 
In yet another high-profile incident with similar circumstances, former law minister V Arunachalam aka Aladi Aruna, 70, was murdered by a gang near Alangudi in Tirunelveli district in January, 2005.  The gang struck when he was in a secluded area on Tirunelveli-Tenkasi highway after he left his house at 6.15 am. 
Recently, K Ezhumalai, 43, an AIADMK functionary who used to reside in Adambakkam in Chennai, was murdered while he was returning from his morning walk at around 6.45 am.  He was murdered near TNHD Colony Main Road in Velachery in December, 2014.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

column1: Khobramenda
column2:
Naxal beats up foresters on charges of corruption  GADCHIROLI : A forest guard and round officer were thrashed by senior Naxal cadres to protest alleged corruption by their department.  Senior Naxal cadre Vikas took an aggressive stance against foresters at Yedaskuhi village in north Gadchiroli to convey their dissent against the department. 
Sources stated that the Naxals were trying to mount pressure on foresters and also on the local population for dominance during the forthcoming Tendu leaves picking season in the district which is a multi-crore seasonal industry.  Naxals aim to collect substantial party funds from foresters, tendu contractors and transporters during this tendu season.  The rebels also collect donations for the party from the tribal population who engages in picking tendu. 
A senior police official stated that Naxals targeting foresters is nothing unusual on various issues, ranging from corruption to exploitation of tribals.  “Intelligence agencies have underlined the fact that a section of Naxals are trying to capitalize on the wrath of the tribal against foresters and are also trying to incite them to target the grassroots level personnel like forest guards and round officers,” said a senior officer.  He added that Naxals are targeting foresters on local issues like bamboo cutting and transportation, auction of tendu, allotment of stretches for farming and trading of the local forest produce. 
According to a reliable source, Naxals manhandled the two foresters protesting corruption in allotting solar powered pump machines to tribals for farming.  It’s also learnt that some goof-ups related to allotment of compartments led to destruction of substantial stacks of bamboo in Khobramenda.  The tribal population was deprived of daily wages too as the work allotment had come under scanner leading to major public loss, it was learnt.  The incident has left the senior Naxal cadre angry too. 
Police also stated that surrendered Naxal cadre Gopi, once a senior leader in the party, has also informed that top forest officials extended monetary favours to Naxals through their messengers.  The revelation has also tarnished image of the rebels, leading to their wrath. 
Sources said that Naxals are also targeting foresters for being hand-in-glove with teakwood smugglers in south Gadchiroli.  The rebels are learnt to be unhappy with foresters for allowing contractors to misuse sand and gravel from the forest and riverbeds for construction of roads and undertaking other activities.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Propaganda war over young Naxal cadre’s death  NAGPUR: The death of a young student leader-turned-Naxal commander in an encounter with police last year has been the cause of a fresh propaganda war between the Naxalite leaders and their opponents.  The top echelons of banned Communist Party of India (Maoist) have hailed the death of Raja Thakur, alias Comrade Krishna (27), as supreme sacrifice by a young visionary in the red rebels’ cause.  On the other hand, activists opposed to Naxalite ideology have slammed the efforts of CPI (Maoist) for trapping youngsters in their lost cause of armed revolution.  Both CPI (Maoist) and Bhoomkal Sangathan, have re-launched a fresh propaganda war by issuing pamphlets.  An earlier pamphlet, issued by Maharashtra state committee secretary Comrade Sahyadri during recently concluded ‘Martyrs’ week’, had underlined the unique blend of bravery and intellectualism in Krishna who was killed along with colleague Comrade Sonu on August 12 last year in Khobramenda jungle in a police encounter.  Arvind Sovani and Datta Shirke, both office bearers of Bhoomkal Sangathan, have blamed Naxals for roping in youngsters through front organizations in armed movement foiling their academic career.  Intelligence agencies view Naxals’ romanticizing of Krishna’s sacrifice during the Naxal’s martyr week, observed between July 27 and August 3, as an effective strategy to encourage urban youngsters to join the movement or support it.  Krishna, a former student of Rajura’s Shivaji College, was section deputy commander of Platoon 56 while Sonu held the same rank for Platoon 55.  The two, along with three others, were returning from Nadekal village to their den when security forces ambushed them.  The Naxals claimed that police eliminated the duo when they could have been arrested.  The rebels have extolled the qualities of Krishna in the movement citing that he carried out effective propaganda against displacement and industrialization whenever required in the remote areas and also fought bravely when faced with challenge from police.  The social activists too have upped their propaganda against the rebels warning youngsters to be wary of attempts to recruiting them through urban front organizations and that they would be deployed in the guerrilla zones to participate in the armed revolution.  Citing claims of Naxals that Comrade Krishna was a member of ‘Krantikari Vidhyarthi Sanghatna’ or revolutionary student organization, activists claimed the rebels misguided the former student into joining the movement that claimed his life.  Sovani and Shirke warned youngsters in Nagpur, Chandrapur and Gadchiroli not to fall prey to such attempts by the Naxals through so-called front organizations.  The activists have also warned that more such front organization, including one in Nagpur, are at present active.  Superintendent of police, Gadchiroli, Sandip Patil said government is already implementing several enactments for the tribals and their interest.  “The Naxals and their front organizations can help in better implementation of government schemes rather than ask youngsters to take up arms and ruin their life.  We can support surrenders but not one with arms,” said Patil. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

column1: Thangasseri
column2:
Transforming lighthouses into tourism destinations ochi has been chosen along with Chennai and Vishakapatnam by the Directorate General of Lighthouses and Lightships (DGLL), Ministry of Shipping, to host road shows for its ambitious programme to transform lighthouses into “unique tourism destinations”. 
The DGLL carried out a techno-economic feasibility study for 12 lighthouses, of which request for qualification has been issued for eight sites, including Kadalur Point lighthouse near Kannur. 
Kochi will host the first road show on October 14.  The road shows were being organised with the help of the respective Port Trusts and would culminate in an investors’ meet in Mumbai on October 29, said a release.  Chettuva, Vypeen, Manakkodam, Vizhinjam, Thangasseri, Kannur, Alappuzha and Kadalur Point were the lighthouses selected in Kerala for the tourism development programme, said the release.  Kadamat, Thinakaara, Agathi, Androth, West End, Kavaratti and Suhelipar are among the 10 lighthouses on the Lakshwadeep Islands selected for the programme. 
Lighthouses in the programme from other States include Aguada in Goa; Kanyakumari and Muttam in Tamil Nadu and Sunk Rock off Mumbai. 
“Though generally perceived as navigational aids, lighthouses are also symbols of history and icons of maritime heritage”, said the government document inviting the expression of interest. 
Primarily, the programme hinges on the historic value of the lighthouses. 
For example, the Vypeen lighthouse was first erected in 1839 and was replaced with an RCC structure in 1979.  The Thangassery lighthouse is 112-years-old and has an average tourist flow of about 5,000 per month. 
The Manakkodam lighthouse, near Cherthala, was commissioned in 1979 and has a scenic foreground with substantial beach area. 
The tourism facilities being envisaged at these sites include viewing galleries, information and souvenir centres, eco-resorts with camp sites, restaurants and food cafes, family entertainment centres, sound and light laser shows, art and craft villages and accommodation facilities. 
Though generally perceived as navigational aids, lighthouses are also symbols of history and icons of maritime heritage. 
Primarily, the programme hinges on the historic value of the lighthouses.

column1: Palani Hills
column2:
Seizure of leopard pelt raises concern  MADURAI: Seizure of a leopard pelt at Oddanchatram in the district on Tuesday has turned out to be a cause of concern for wildlife enthusiasts in the region as they suspect a network of poachers operating in the region. 
In September last year, forest officials seized two leopard skins and three Sambar antlers in Oddanchatram.  Five persons were arrested in this regard.  In Tuesday’s incident, Devathanapatti forest ranger, Karupiah and Tamil Nadu Green Movement joint secretary, S Jayachandran acted as buyers following a tip off.  After being led to various locations for the entire day, the kingpin M Ganesan and his accomplices showed up in the evening.  They were detained. 
“Though we don’t see any large scale mafia operating here, we suspect some network dealing with wildlife products.  The leopard skin seized on Tuesday was professionally tanned,” said Jayachandran.  Though it was coincidental that two seizures occurred in Oddanchatram, wildlife enthusiasts feel that it could be a transit point since the town is situated downhill of Palani Hills.  In both incidents last year, the big cats were poached in Palani Hills. 
“Oddanchatram could be a transit point of smugglers.  We learn that there is a gang of expert game hunters in Varusanadu region but they don’t operate in the locality.  Gangs operating locally could be from Tamil Nadu and Kerala”, said C P Rajkumar of Vaigai Association of Nature and Mountain Ranges (VANAM).  Wildlife activists feel that forest department with lack of manpower is no match for smugglers. 
Wildlife officials too suspect some small gangs operating in the region.  “There should be a thorough investigation to trace these gangs of poachers and their network of smuggling”, a wildlife official from Theni said.  “Most of the time, even if we spot some big cats in forests we maintain confidentiality because poaching mafia has got eyes and ears everywhere,” another wildlife official said.  But wildlife activists feel that Forest Department crippled with lack of manpower is no match to smugglers.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Traffic runs through MTR at night for temple fest  CHENNAI: Permission to allow vehicles through Mudumalai Tiger Reserve and the core forest areas at night for five days for a temple festival has shocked conservationists and wildlife lovers. 
Until last year, the temple festival was held for about two days.  This year, the annual festival of the Mariamman Temple in Bokkapuram village is being held from February 27 to March 3 and traffic restrictions on the road from Gudalur to Bokkapuram via Theppakkadu and Masinagudi have been lifted to benefit devotees.  Vehicles are usually not allowed through the forest between dusk and dawn to allow free movement of animals. 
Bokkapuram village is bounded by Mudumalai Wildlife Sanctuary and National Park in the north and by Nilgiris North forest division on the other three sides.  MTR is less than a kilometre from Bokkapuram and Nilgiris north division is ecologically similar to MTR and forms the sanctuaryâs buffer zone. 
âIt is a matter of great concern that the district administration has relaxed the restriction on night traffic on roads passing through Mudumalai Tiger Reserve and its nearby forested areas to facilitate the temple festival around Bokkapuram village.  Vehicles plying at speed on these roads will not only cause great disturbance to wildlife, but are also likely to maim or kill animals,â said wildlife filmmaker and conservationist Shekar Dattatri. 
Nilgiris district collector P Sankar said the restrictions on night-time traffic had been lifted temporarily to help pilgrims.  âPeople have been visiting the temple for years.  If the district administration did not permit vehicles to take pilgrims to the temple at night, it would become a problem,â he said. 
However, there are examples of officials and conservationists working with devotees to ensure that wildlife movement is not affected.  In Hediyala range in Bandipur Tiger Reserve in Karnataka, for instance, forest officials and conservationists spent time explaining how temple activities at night in the core forest affected wildlife.  D Rajkumar of Wildlife Conservation Foundation, Karnataka, who was part of the effort, said officials and conservationists should work with locals and resolve the issue amicably.  âShops would be put up for the temple festival every year within in the forest.  My team and forest officers explained the effects of shops in core areas to the residents.  Over the last two years, no shops were put up in the core areas,â he said. 
N Arun Sankar, secretary of Palani Hills Conservation Council, said the forest department lacked adequate manpower.  âIt will be very difficult to monitor the movement of visitors at night and ensure there is no harm to wildlife,â he said.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Dolmen a major attraction of Sirumalai  MADURAI: The stone structure could be taken for an ordinary boulder if one does not pay close attention, but the lone dolmen inside the Sirumalai forest in Madurai district is an ancient artefact pointing to possible human habitation in the area several centuries ago.  Situated some 2km above Kutladampatti Falls in an area called Thadagainachi kovil, the stone walls with a flat stone on top possibly dates back to prehistoric Iron Age, according to scholars. 
The dolmen was an accidental discovery, found when officials from the district forest office were charting out nature trails inside forest areas to promote eco-tourism and provide livelihood to tribal youth.  The department carved out four trails- Bison Trail, Deer Trail, Hare Trail and Snake Trail.  The dolmen was found on the 18km-long Bison Trail, which descends from upper Sirumalai to Kutladampatti falls. 
“It was an added feature on our Bison Trail,” said Madurai district forest officer (DFO) Nihar Ranjan. 
A dolmen in the middle of the forest means that there was human settlement in the area once, according to archaeologists.  Such structures were burial places in the prehistoric Iron Age.  The dolmens in the region are scattered across Palani Hills.  Thandikudi is a prominent site.  Dolmens were also spotted in Pandrimalai near Dindigul, scholars said. 
“There is every possibility for a dolmen in Sirumalai because there are many dolmens spread across the hillocks of the region,” said V Vedachalam, retired archaeologist in the city.  Such archaeological structures of anthropological importance should be protected well, archaeologists feel. 
The DFO said anyone who wants to pay a visit to the place should get prior permission from the department as it falls under protected area.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Gurunath, once CSK's face, takes another knock  CHENNAI: From being one of Chennai Super Kings' most visible faces to the ignominy that followed after being charged with placing bets and passing on team information - Gurunath Meiyappan's affair with IPL has been storied.  The Lodha Committee on Tuesday suspended Gurunath, former BCCI chief and India Cements director N Srinivasan's son-in-law, from being involved in any cricket-related activity for life. 
Gurunath is Grandson of A V Meiyappan, the founder of AVM Productions, but cinema did not hold his interest.  The fast lane to success caught his fancy and IPL perfectly suited his ambitions.  Not too visible in IPL 1, Gurunath since 2009 became known as a ringside monitor of the team.  " He used to be present during team meetings.  He was more friendly with the big boys like Dhoni and Raina,"  a team member said. 
In September 2013, the Mumbai police named Gurunath in a chargesheet, accusing him of cheating, betting, and conspiracy.  " We play to win but want to do so in the right fashion.  We were guided by what we wanted, while keeping an eye on the rest of the franchises,"  Gurunath is reported to have once said.  According to an insider, one evening, after he was named in the betting scandal, a family member castigated Gurunath for bringing disrepute and he broke down.  Srinivasan, according to sources, too was left seething and instructed his son-in-law to stay away from CSK matches.  The portion of AVM studios in Vadapalani, belonging to Gurunath's father AVM Balasubramanian, which was built to accommodate the lavish and opulent sets of MGR's 1966 runaway hit Anbe Vaa, was razed a few months back with Gurunath putting out the land for realtor friend Vikram Aggarwal with a plan of developing close to 600 apartments in its place. 
The portion of AVM studios in Vadapalani, belonging to Gurunath's father AVM Balasubramanian, which was built to accommodate the lavish and opulent sets of MGR's 1966 runaway hit Anbe Vaa was razed a few months back with Gurunath putting out the land for realtor friend Vikram Aggarwal with a plan of developing close to 600 apartments in its place. 
An overbearing love for the good life was manifest in most of Gurunath's choices, including a 5 crore yacht reportedly imported from Riviera's Gold Coast factory in Australia for which .  One such was a yacht, reportedly imported from Riviera's Gold Coast factory in Australia and he is believed to have paid 3 crore as customs duty as customs duty for the vessel which cost Rs 5 crore.  An avid golfer and a motor racing enthusiast, and has won the Palani Hills Open amateur golf tournament multiple times apart from competing in Formula Asia.  Gurunath once said, " In a day's golf, you can discover much about a man's character - how he is as a person, how he would do business.  Everything. "  In Gurunath's case though, cricket proved to be the revealer.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Woman killed in elephant attack in Oddanchatram With the destruction of the elephant corridor in Lower Palani Hills and in Oddanchatram area, conflicts between humans and wild animals, especially elephants, have increased in the district. 
On Wednesday, a lone wild elephant fatally attacked a woman, Pappa (40), at Pulikuthukadu on Pachalur Hills near Oddanchatram. 
The elephant caught hold of her and threw her away while she was going to a private farm in the early hours. 
Local people rushed her to Oddanchatram Government Hospital where doctors advised them to take her to Dindigul GH as her condition was very critical.  But she succumbed to her injuries on the way to Dindigul hospital. 
According to local people, attacks by wild animals were on the rise in Oddanchatram and Palani blocks.  Forest officials said that destruction of elephants’ regular path by local people for farm activities forced the animals to find new paths close to residential areas for food and water. 
Herds of elephants had been moving from Kudiraiyaru dam to Oddanchatram through Palar Porundalar dam area.  Attacks on humans were rampant at Thekkankottai, Kombaipatti, Sattaparai and Varadhapattinam in Palani block. 
With farmers in Kodaiakanal having constructed a small check dam and blocked the flow of water to Varadhamanadhi dam, elephants now had started climbing up to Anjuveedu area near Vilpatti in Kodaikanal Hills for water and feed. 
A herd of six elephants and a newborn calf had been camping near a residential area for the past one month. 
Farmers could not chase the animals away, they said.  The Forest Department deputed a 10-member team to chase the elephant herd into interior forests on Tuesday.  It would be difficult to chase the elephants as they were attracted by jackfruits. 
They reached the spot when the jackfruit harvesting season was at its peak in Kodaikanal last month.  With availability of sumptuous feed and water, they refused to leave Vilpatti area, they added. 
Local people say attacks by wild animals are on the rise in Oddanchatram and Palani blocks Activists oppose clearcutting of exotic species in Palani Hills Naturalists and environmentalists here have appealed to the government to be cautious while removing exotic species like wattle and eucalyptus which are spread in more than 200 square km in the Palni hills. 
The Forest Department has a proposal for clear cutting these two exotic species.  “Clearcutting will be an ecological disaster affecting the entire ecosystem of the watersheds across north and south of the Palni Hills,” says Pippa Mukherjee of INTACH. 
Instead, the department should let Shola (rainforest) species to grow and prosper in the wattle shade and finally overtake the exotic species.  This can effectively stop the spread of wattle in the grasslands, say activists. 
“In this process, the wattle will die of fungal disease naturally without sunlight,” says Ms.  Mukherjee. 
“We should understand that old wattle forest will act as a nursery for new shola [native species] growth because many of the shola species like shade to germinate and wattle lives on sun light,” she added. 
Using chainsaws to remove wattle would certainly worsen the situation, warn activists, emphasising that clearcutting wattle as part of forestry management or resource management could prove to have disastrous consequences.  World over, clear cutting is seen as detrimental to rain forest ecosystems, she said. 
After clearcutting of wattle, lantana camera (unni) and other exotic, bushy weeds would grow with the exposure to the heat and light in the open field.  Moreover, sunlight simply encourages regeneration of tonnes of wattle seeds that remain viable for germination for fifty years.  Indiscriminate felling of wattle and eucalyptus would also annihilate new shola saplings and other small trees, says R.  Kannan of Palni Hills Conservation Council (PHCC). 
A guided tour of the clearcut areas would certainly offer a first-hand experience of the irremediable devastation already wrought in the Palni Hills, he said, urging the government to take up a short term survey. 
Silviculture
“Movement of heavy vehicles into plantation areas would also destroy regeneration of native species.  Ultimately, it would lead to mini-ecological disaster.  Inhibit its spread from plantations into existing native grasslands through regular culling.  Allowing them to die naturally would be viable solution to wattle menace,” recommends P.  R.  Ashok Raj of ACT India Foundation. 
To restore Shola forests, Aalap Dikshit, Department of Natural Resources, TERI University, New Delhi, who did research on wattle in Kodaikanal, too opposes removing acacia plantations and to consider silvicultural options in the management of the plantations to enhance the nursing effect on shola tree species. 
Directing the State government to file a status report before on September 28, the Madras High Court made it clear that it was not issuing any direction to cut down wattle and eucalyptus trees from the Western Ghats.

column1: Old Rajarajeswaripeta
column2:
Culvert widening work to start soon It is a perennial problem.  In summer, trash and drainage overflow onto the roads from drains, and in rainy season, rain water from hill slopes reaches roads, as the existing culverts are too narrow. 
This has been the case at Nyzam Gate in Wynchipeta and Zero Bulbline in Old Rajarajeswaripeta for the past several years. 
Lack of a sound drainage system is causing severe inconvenience to residents of Wynchipeta, Gandhi Bomma centre, Abotu Appana Pakalaveedhi and old Rajarajeswaripeta. 
Drainage water from drains at Nyzam Gate and Zero Bulbline flows under the railway tracks towards Budameru. 
Since the drains were laid decades ago, and with the population rising, residents have been demanding that the Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) improve the existing infrastructure.  It was conveyed to VMC Commissioner G.  Veerapandian during his inspection of these localities recently. 
To widen the existing culverts and mitigate the problem, the VMC authorities have proposed box culverts to replace the decades-old masonry culverts. 
Deposit sought
Accordingly, the railway authorities have demanded a deposit of Rs.  10.30 crore, as the culverts have to be constructed beneath the tracks, said Vijayawada West MLA Jaleel Khan. 
Rs.  47 crore
sanctioned
Following several representations, the government sanctioned Rs.  47 crore towards the construction of major outfall drains, culverts across railway tracks, including Nyzam Gate and Zero Bulbline gate. 
Works are likely to commence in June, Mr.  Khan claimed. 
Lack of proper drainage system causing difficulty to residents of Wynchipeta, Gandhi Bomma centre, Abotu Appana Pakalaveedhi & old Rajarajeswaripeta City fringes stink as strike enters 10th day : The ongoing municipal strike, which entered the tenth day on Monday, is leaving the colonies and areas in Payakapuram, Kandriga and other areas on the city fringes stinking with garbage piling up on the streets. 
Ever since the strike commenced, things have gone worse in many areas beyond Ajitsinghnagar flyover, Vambay Colony, Old Rajarajeswaripeta and others.  All the corporation did was to deploy a few workers and clear trash in a few areas, while leaving others to their plight. 
“It is a typical problem here.  While, regular workers obstruct the private workers in clearing the garbage, residents keep complaining about the heaps of garbage on the streets.  Despite requests the self help groups are finding it difficult to mobilise workers,” says A.  Shailaja, Corporator of 59{+t}{+h}Division. 
On the other hand, Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) officials claim of initiating stringent action against officials and contractors, who fail to supply more workers and monitor the garbage clearing.  On Monday, VMC Commissioner G.  Veerapandian inspected the sanitary situation in Gulabithota, Government press, Madhuranagar, Bhavajipeta and others, he noticed garbage piling up on the street corners. 
When enquired, officials informed that there was delay in supply of trucks from vehicles depot to clear garbage.  Holding the depot assistant manager for the delay, the Commissioner instructed the officials to suspend him from duties. 
Meanwhile, political parties have extended their support to the ongoing municipal workers strike.  The leaders have decided to lay siege to all municipal corporations offices on June 22 and the Collector’s Camp Office on June 24 and have threatened to intensify the strike.  Addressing at the roundtable organised by the A. P.  Municipal Workers and Employees Joint Action Committee, former MP P.  Madhu said the CPI(M) would stand by the workers and pressurise the government in revising the workers wages. 
BJP Krishna Unit president R.  Venkatakrishna said it was high time for the government to negotiate with striking workers and address their genuine demands.

column1: Aghamkuan
column2:
In Bihar, 14 officers man food safety in 1.5 lakh shops  PATNA: Food safety is a matter of concern, thanks to a nationwide row over Maggi.  Biharâs food safety wing has, however, only 14 officers to man its 38 districts.  In contrast, the food safety officers number 554 in Tamil Nadu, 273 in UP, 178 in Gujarat, 169 in Madhya Pradesh and 87 in Jammu & Kashmir, according to the Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) website. 
Bihar food safety commissioner Anand Kishor candidly admits this wing is understaffed.  âBut the health department has accepted a proposal to create 625 posts of food safety officers.  The finance department will soon give its nod to it,â he said.  READ ALSO: Bold message in biggest food item recall The state food safety wing has been functioning with skeletal staff for long, and this has hit the departmentâs functioning adversely.  According to an official report for 2014-15, there are at least 1.5 lakh food business operators in the state.  But only 23,435 are registered and 8,678 are licensed.  That is, only 32,000 or so are on the radar. 
This is in contravention of the FSSAI guidelines according to which any food unit having an annual turnover of up to Rs 12 lakh has to be registered.  Those having a turnover of more than Rs 12 lakh have to be licensed.  The mandate to register or license such units lies with the food safety officers.  READ ALSO: Centre pulls plug on Maggi in 1st recall of food item in India Collection of samples for safety checks has also been poor in Bihar â for obvious reasons.  In 2014-15, only 1,763 samples could be collected from across the state.  Now that the state has banned all smokeless tobacco products other than raw âkhainiâ, the workload of the already-overworked 14 officers has upped. 
Worse, Bihar does not have a functional food safety lab.  The food safety wingâs lab at Aghamkuan in Patna has been defunct for four years.  The lab does not have a food analyst to conduct tests on samples.  Food safety wing lab not functional
âWe advertised the post twice, but we could not get anyone who fulfilled the eligibility criteria.  We cannot change the criteria because they are prescribed by the Centre,â Kishor says. 
The state food safety wing for now relies on a private Kolkata lab which is accredited by National Accreditation Board for Testing and Calibration Laboratories.  However, this arrangement has its own drawbacks.  As the Maggi saga unfolded, Bihar sent the first lot samples on May 23.  But till May 6, the test reports did not come, the state food safety wingâs repeated requests for expediting the tests notwithstanding. 
âThough test reports usually come within 14 days; at times they donât,â one official disclosed. 
Pendency of cases in courts adds to the woes of food safety wing which does not have a lawyer of its own.  The officers have to coordinate with government counsel concerned to pursue the cases.  Official records reveal no one was convicted in 2014-15 though penalties in five cases worth Rs 38,000 were realized and 16 cases were filed. JD(U) MLA Anant's guard arrested in realtor kidnap case  PATNA: Patna Police on Friday arrested an assistant sub-inspector (ASI) of police, who was deployed as bodyguard of JD (U) MLA Anant Singh.  The lawmaker was arrested last month in connection with a case of kidnapping of realtor Raju Singh from Bihta, on the outskirts of Patna, in November last year. 
" ASI Bipin Singh has been arrested in the same Raju kidnapping case.  Bipin is also named as an accused in an FIR lodged with the city's Aghamkuan police station in connection with an incident of extortion,"  Patna SSP Vikas Vaibhav said. 
Sources said Bipin was a constable before his promotion.  He was recently transferred out of Patna district and had got his movement order from the local Police Lines on July 1.  But he was arrested before he could proceed to join his new assignment, the sources said and added he had been deployed as the MLA's bodyguard for several years. 
Police are also investigating the property owned by Bipin.  " He allegedly owns a plush flat in S K Puri locality and some plots in Beur area,"  a police officer said and added he was being interrogated about his immovable property in Patna and other districts. 
Police, meanwhile, are gathering the MLA's property details sought by the Enforcement Directorate (ED).  " We are gathering details from the property registrar offices at the block level.  We hope to hand over the details to the ED in a few days,"  said the SSP. 
An ED official told TOI the agency could lodge an FIR and initiate its own investigation after receipt of the specific details and documents it has sought from Bihar police.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  In Bihar, 14 officers man food safety in 1.5 lakh shops (This story originally appeared in
on Jun 07, 2015)PATNA: Food safety is a matter of concern, thanks to a nationwide row over Maggi.  Bihar's food safety wing has, however, only 14 officers to man its 38 districts.  In contrast, the food safety officers number 554 in Tamil Nadu, 273 in UP, 178 in Gujarat, 169 in Madhya Pradesh and 87 in Jammu & Kashmir, according to the Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) website. 
Bihar food safety commissioner Anand Kishor candidly admits this wing is understaffed.  " But the health department has accepted a proposal to create 625 posts of food safety officers.  The finance department will soon give its nod to it,"  he said. 
The state food safety wing has been functioning with skeletal staff for long, and this has hit the department's functioning adversely.  According to an official report for 2014-15, there are at least 1.5 lakh food business operators in the state.  But only 23,435 are registered and 8,678 are licensed.  That is, only 32,000 or so are on the radar. 
This is in contravention of the FSSAI guidelines according to which any food unit having an annual turnover of up to Rs 12 lakh has to be registered.  Those having a turnover of more than Rs 12 lakh have to be licensed.  The mandate to register or license such units lies with the food safety officers. 
Collection of samples for safety checks has also been poor in Bihar - for obvious reasons.  In 2014-15, only 1,763 samples could be collected from across the state.  Now that the state has banned all smokeless tobacco products other than raw 'khaini', the workload of the already-overworked 14 officers has upped. 
Worse, Bihar does not have a functional food safety lab.  The food safety wing's lab at Aghamkuan in Patna has been defunct for four years.  The lab does not have a food analyst to conduct tests on samples. 
Food safety wing lab not functional
" We advertised the post twice, but we could not get anyone who fulfilled the eligibility criteria.  We cannot change the criteria because they are prescribed by the Centre,"  Kishor says. 
The state food safety wing for now relies on a private Kolkata lab which is accredited by National Accreditation Board for Testing and Calibration Laboratories.  However, this arrangement has its own drawbacks.  As the Maggi saga unfolded, Bihar sent the first lot samples on May 23.  But till May 6, the test reports did not come, the state food safety wing's repeated requests for expediting the tests notwithstanding. 
" Though test reports usually come within 14 days; at times they don't,"  one official disclosed. 
Pendency of cases in courts adds to the woes of food safety wing which does not have a lawyer of its own.  The officers have to coordinate with government counsel concerned to pursue the cases.  Official records reveal no one was convicted in 2014-15 though penalties in five cases worth Rs 38,000 were realized and 16 cases were filed.

column1: Navegaon Bandh
column2: From 5 in 2004, Gondia’s saras count is 35 now  Nagpur: Virtually facing extinction 10 years ago, sarus cranes, the tallest flying bird in the world, has shown dramatic revival in rice bowl of Gondia and Bhandara districts in the region.  From five in 2004, the population of these elegant birds has presently revived to 35 in Gondia district.  In the 90s, the entire landscape of Gondia was dominated by sarus cranes.  Sarus is protected under Schedule II of the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972.  As a reminder of the golden era of 90s, a host of events will mark the maiden ‘Sarus festival’ in the district which kicks off from December 20.  The tourism festival, organized by District Tourism Committee, Gondia, has been conceptualized in the name of sarus basically to showcase the species and the threats it is facing.  In India, these birds are commonly found in states like Uttar Pradesh and Gujarat.  However, in Maharashtra the birds are only found in Bhandara and Gondia districts, though there is sparse record of a couple of birds in Chandrapur district.  The birds, predominantly having grey plumage with a naked red head and long neck and long red pale legs, are considered as symbol of marital fidelity.  There are sagas told about love and affection of sarus for each other.  The birds are mostly found in paddy fields and spotted in Paraswada, Zhilmili and Ghattemani villages.  In February 2014, bird lovers sighted flock of 24 sarus cranes.  This was the biggest record after 1970, when 32 cranes were sighted by Madhavrao Dongarwar Patil in Navegaon Bandh.  However, the tall birds have completely vanished from Gothangaon, near Navegaon Bandh, where hundreds of tourists use to sight them regularly.  However, many birds died due to large-scale use of pesticides by farmers .  “Though the life cycle of these birds is 70-75 years, due to habitat destruction their numbers are dwindling drastically.  Our efforts are to revive their numbers by creating massive awareness among locals,” says Sawan Bahekar, honorary district wildlife warden of Gondia.  Bahekar said the month-long festival will focus on wildlife, adventurous, archaeological and heritage and religious tourism circuits in Gondia district. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

column1: Thaticheltapalem
column2:
Ganesha pandals come up with social messages to educate people  VISAKHAPATNAM: Theme-based Ganeshas with social messages seem to be gaining popularity among pandal organizers in the Port City.  So while the giant 111-feet and 80-feet Ganesha idols at Gajuwaka have been attracting thousands of devotees just to have a glimpse of their awe-inspiring stature, there are several pandal organisers that are trying to spread social messages with the help of their Vinayaka idols. 
One such Ganesha propagating the importance of the environment is the Teacup Ganesha made entirely of biodegradable paper cups that has been installed by the Yuva Seva Foundation of Thaticheltapalem in the city. 
" We wanted to spread the message about the need to stop using plastic and to safeguard our environment - especially after cyclone Hudhud ravaged our city last year.  So we decided to make a Ganesha from paper cups that are biodegradable.  We have used 2,525 teacups for making our Ganesha idol.  Apart from this, we are getting in touch with several other pandal organisors to plant saplings in their areas.  We plan to donate around 2,000 saplings as part of our drive, so that by next year we can have a greener Vizag,"  said Yuva Seva Foundation founder P Hariprasad. 
" Papercups are biodegradable, unlike plastic cups that harm the environment,"  said Prof PS Rajasekhar of Andhra University's environmental sciences department, adding that the public should avoid using plastic to protect the environment. 
Meanwhile, a group of youth from Ashoknagar in Kancherapalem have put up a nattily dressed Ganesha riding a bike wearing a helmet with his mooshak in helmet riding pillion.  N Venkatesh, the pandal organizer said they came up with this innovative idea to improve awareness about using helmets following the death of some friends a few months ago. 
" Two of our childhood friends died about four months ago when their two-wheeler was hit by a lorry.  We are hoping that youngsters will learn from this and be careful while riding as well as use helmets for their safety,"  he explained. 
Apart from these Ganesha pandals carrying messages of social responsibility, the Tollywood bug has bitten a group in the Old Town area, which has made a Bahubali Ganesha portraying actor Prabhas, replete with eight pack abs, carrying the Shivalingam.  " We never really expected to see the Bahubali type of Ganesha, but after hearing about it we came to see it all the way from Gajuwaka,"  said Prakash Rao, who said he watched the movie five times. 
Meanwhile, another Ganesha dressed in a football jersey with a football ground as the backdrop in the Old Town area, and a Vinayaka idol made out of vegetable at Kancherapalem also witnessed huge crowds over the last two days. 
A Ganesha in scuba diving gear with miniature fishing vessels in a water tank have been put up on display at the Fishing Harbour, whereas a Ganesha in a Kalasham and another in the form of Buddha has been set up near Kailaspuram.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

column1: Kuttippadom
column2:
Land sales in Perumbavoor touch new low  KOCHI: When the over 1,200 plywood units in Perumbavoor area attracted migrant workers by the hordes, local residents may not have anticipated such a fall out.  Nor would they have foreseen the pollution that came along with the plywood industry boom in the area that spelt prosperity. 
In Kuttipadom, a tiny village with a radius of less than 3km in Vengola panchayat near Perumbavoor, migrants now outnumber the around 3,000-strong locals.  Conversely, the socio-environmental issues created by around 25 plywood manufacturing units employing migrants in the village are forcing many residents to sell their land and leave the area.  But, in what can be called a double whammy of inverse development logic, there are no takers for their land. 
Many people in the surrounding panchayats and Perumbavoor municipality face a similar problem.  “There are around 1,200 plywood manufacturing units in Perumbavoor municipality and panchayats such as Rayamangalam, Asamanoor, Kottappady, Payipra, Okkal, Koovappady and Vazhakkulam panchayats.  People in these areas face high pollution from plywood units and socio-cultural issues arising from the migrant population.  In certain areas like Kuttippadom, the migrant population outnumber locals,’’ said Varghese Pulluvazhy, chairman, Action Council for Environmental Protection. 
“Urea formaldehyde, a chemical used for manufacturing plywood, is a known carcinogen that can cause cancer.  Inhaling the smoke from the plywood units can also cause cancer.  The number of cancer cases in these areas are on the rise,” he said.  The plywood units pollute water bodies in the area as well, he said. 
Officials with the registration department also admitted that there has been a dip in land deals in the area. 
“A year ago, we used to have 50 to 70 land registrations every day.  Now, it has come down to 15 to 30,” said K Anil Krishna, sub-registrar, Perumbavoor. 
“Though, we don’t have locality-wise registration details, we can certainly say that transactions in the areas where plywood units are mushrooming have dipped.  While conducting an inquiry into the decrease in transactions, many attributed the phenomenon to mushrooming plywood units with high migrant population,” he said. 
According to owners of the plywood manufacturing units, they follow all the norms set by the pollution control board (PCB). 
“There are certain problems that have risen out of concentration of such units in some areas.  That’s quite natural,” said M M Mujeebur Rahman, state president, Sawmill Owners and Plywood Manufacturers Association. 
“The complainants were the same people who gave their land at exorbitant rates to plywood unit owners when such units were set up,” he said. 
In 2013, a Central empowered committee (CEC), set up by the Supreme Court, had conducted a sitting in Perumbavoor to hear complaints regarding pollution in the area. 
“The CEC submitted its report to the state government last year.  It is learnt that the CEC’s report contains suggestions to ease the woes of locals,” Varghese said.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

column1: Manassery
column2:
A call to repeal draconian laws Yahya Khan aka Kammukutty who reached home at Mukkom in the district after he was released from Dharwad Central Jail, Karnataka, feels that draconian laws such as the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act should be repealed. 
“I spent seven years and three months in prison.  I am a victim of a misused law.  Even the trial commenced only after three years,” he said.  Yahya was one of the 17 persons acquitted by Additional Sessions and District Court judge Gopal Krishna Kolli last week as the prosecution failed to prove the charges against them. 
The case
The Bengaluru police had suspected them to be members of the banned Students Islamic Movement of India (SIMI) and charged them with involvement in terror activities across Karnataka and waging war against the country. 
While four persons, including brothers P. A.  Shadhuli and Sabit Shibli (Erattupetta) and Ansar Nadwi (Aluva) belonged to Kerala, others were from Karnataka, Madhya Pradesh, and Andhra Pradesh. 
An electronics and communication graduate from the National Institute of Technology- Calicut (NIT-C), Yahya Khan, had worked at two IT firms in Bengaluru before doing freelance work. 
He was picked up by the Bengaluru police from his residence on February 18, 2008, and his arrest was recorded only on February 22. 
“I don’t know why I was framed.  They said I had taken part in a conspiracy at Hubli.  Perhaps they were acting according to a script.  First they made a case of terror and then fixed all of us,” he said on Monday. 
The 40-year-old said he had attended meetings of SIMI while doing pre-degree at Mohammed Abdurahiman Memorial Orphanage College, Manassery.  But that was before the outfit was proscribed. 
“Initially, the police tortured me for two days.  After that, I was in judicial custody.  But I had to endure the sufferings all these years for no reason.  Now the real facts are out,” he said.  Yahya said he had to rebuild his career from scratch.  “I am happy to be home with family, relatives, and friends,” he said.  He is married to Fareeda and has four children with her.  Monsoon sea merciless on Chellanam Residents in the coastal panchayat of Chellanam continues to take the brunt of a rough monsoon sea with scores of houses under threat of periodic flooding, especially along stretches where seawalls have been damaged or been flattened by the waves. 
Residents in Malakhappady, Companyppady, Ganapatikkadu and Kandakkadavu are the worst affected.  Seawalls have been seriously damaged and sea erosion is severe in these areas. 
However, seawall repair is held up as no contractor was coming forward to take up the works, said Dominic Presentation, MLA.  “I am helpless”, he said about the repair works being delayed.  He claimed that allegations of corruption by an individual in the panchayat against contractors had kept them away from the tenders floated for the works. 
Restriction on granite quarrying during the rainy months was one reason for the delay in repairs, he said.  However, the Chief Minister’s attention was drawn to the plight of the people and orders had now been issued to build breakwaters at Cheriyakadavu, Companyppady, Bazaar and Saudi-Manassery, he said. 
Panchayat member V.  T.  Antony from Maruvakkad said that of the more than 430 families in his ward, at least 300 faced threat of flooding, especially during the rainy months. 
Mr.  Antony claimed that a piece of repair work was tendered nine times and no one responded.  Work on 50 metres of seawall and retaining wall between Bazaar and Velankanni was about to begin now after a big lapse of time. 
A.  J.  Jakson at Alunkal Kadappuram whose house was flooded by the sea early this week said that nothing appeared to be moving on the seawall repair front. 
He pointed to the house of Biju Edamukkil, precariously perched on the edge of the waters and constantly being lashed by sea waves. 
Though people living close to the sea face constant threat, they are not in a position to move out of their homes as they have nowhere else to go, he said. 
K.  X.  George of Ganapathikkadu, who has made allegations of irregularities in the maintenance of the seawall across the district of Ernakulam, claims that the basic problem with seawall repairs was that stones of the right size were not being used.  Deft strokes on a compassionate canvas aricatures drawn by K. R.  Ramesh, a degree student from Koodaranhi, always kindles laughter among his friends. 
However, this time, his works featuring around 50 persons, including his teachers, non-teaching staff and some of the management committee members of his college, will serve a different purpose. 
The income generated from this artist’s initiative will come to the aid of Irfan, a seven-year-old boy from the Palakkuzhi Government Lower Primary School.  Irfan hailing from a poor family, has been undergoing treatment for blood cancer at the Kozhikode Medical College Hospital. 
Of the 50 caricatures he made, most of them have already been sold out at the M. A. M. O campus at Manassery, where he pursues his final year B. Com course.   The total amount generated through this effort is now around Rs.50,000, which will be handed over to the boy’s family.  Additional fund sourced by Ramesh’s friends in various parts of the district and the college alumni association too is on its way to support Irfan’s treatment. 
Three-month work
“I couldn’t just ignore the appeal when it firstly appeared in the Whatsapp messenger seeking financial aid for Irfan.  Twice I met the boy before starting this three-month long caricature works featuring my teachers, non-teaching staff and others on the campus,” says Ramesh. 
“The boy needs at-least three years of continuous medication.  The amount we generated through the art work will be a big relief for the five-member family,” he adds. 
The base price Ramesh fixed for his caricature work is Rs.1,000.  “There were persons who contributed more than that as the intention was to help Irfan.  All of them had encouraged me much to go ahead with the attempt,” said Ramesh. 
M. V.  Brajila, Assistant Professor from the college, says there was a positive response towards Ramesh’s efforts to help Irfan.  “We mainly enlisted the cooperation of teaching and non-teaching staff as they would be able to contribute generously to the initiative.  Students too came up with voluntary contributions to support the cause,” she adds. 
The funds will be given to a
7-year-old boy undergoing treatment for blood cancer at Kozhikode Medical College Hospital.  Power supply Power supply will be regulated in the following areas in Ernakulam on Saturday and Sunday. 
September 19: Palarivattom section: BTS Road, Thampurattiparambu, P. J.  Antony Road, Nethaji Road, opposite Oberon Mall, Edappally High School premises – 9 a. m.  to 3 p. m. 
Girinagar: Chilavannoor – 9 a. m.  to 5 p. m. 
Palluruthy: Kumaraswami temple, Arpana Nagar – 9 a. m.  to 5 p. m. 
Eroor: Nair Samajam, Shari Junction, Pandathil Road, Eloomana Temple, Puthiya Road – 9 a. m.  to 5 p. m. 
Fort Kochi: Manassery Church, Mother Teresa, Society, Saudi – 9 a. m.  to 12 noon. 
September 20 (in view of the movement of heavy vehicles proceeding towards Kochi Refinery): Tripunithura: Petta, Vadakkekotta, Thamarakulangara, S. N.  Junction, P&T, Tripunithura Town, Kizhakkekotta, Statue, Aaliyar Bridge, Chathari – 6 a. m.  to 3 p. m.  Vyttila: Vyttila-Petta Road and nearby roads (partial disruption); and in Maradu-Petta Road (6 a. m.  to 3 p. m. ) Gold theft case: police collect evidence A police team led by Circle Inspector A.  Premjith took Krishna Rathidas, 29, the first accused in the recent Mukkom jewellery theft case, to various locations in the district as part of gathering further evidence in the case on Friday.  The man, a native of Jharkhand, had been in police custody for nearly a week after he was detained from West Bengal. 
During the evidence gathering process, the police team also identified a lodge at Manassery where the accused stayed with his close aides for planning the theft.  It was found that the lodge owner granted accommodation to the man without checking his whereabouts and the identity proof.  He was served a notice seeking all the available details of persons who were recently granted accommodation in the lodge.  Openbill’s nesting spot brings joy to birders The spotting of large nesting places of Asian Openbill Stork, a large wading migratory bird, at Thirunavaya in Malappuram district has brought cheers to wildlife enthusiasts and bird watchers here as it was an indication of their peaceful breeding and growing population in the region. 
The Openbill Storks were considered very rare in the State until late 1970s.  Their population began to spread to more wetlands throughout the State since 1990s. 
However, it was only very rarely that their nesting places were spotted from anywhere in the State. 
According to Jafer Palot, a zoologist with the Kozhikode regional centre of the Zoological Survey of India (ZSI), The Hindu had in 2004 reported about a group of Thiruvananthapuram-based bird-watchers recording a nesting and breeding place of Openbill in a sacred grove near Shoranur in Palakkad district.  The report he says, had also claimed that to be the first ever citing of the bird’s nesting place from the State. 
25 nests
The new breeding spot at Thirunavaya was discovered by C. P.  Babu from Manassery, a known bird-watcher from the district.  According to Mr.  Babu, there were around 25 nests on top of a bunch of screw pines bordering a large stretch of lotus filled water body near the railway-track at Thirunavaya. 
The place is very hard to reach for human beings, says P. T.  Muhammed, wildlife photographer, who accompanied Mr.  Babu to record the citing.  “We had to wade through nearly a km in the waist-deep water to get them photographed,” says Mr.  Muhammed, who used a 500 mm telelens to zoom on them from about a km distance. 
The Asian Openbill stork is predominantly greyish white with glossy black wings and tail that has a green or purple sheen.  Their beak is reddish black with arching mandibles, which do not meet except at the tip, and gives the species its name in Malayalam Cheraa Kokkan (meaning, beaks which do not meet). 
Mentioned by Salim Ali
The bird, which has been mentioned by the renowned ornithologist Salim Ali in his book Birds of Kerala as a local migrant, had also been described in detail in the book ‘Birds of Kerala: status and distribution’ co-authored by a group of people including Dr.  Palot. 
“The new citing of the bird’s breeding spot is a really significant,” he says.  Power shutdown Power supply will be regulated on Tuesday between 9 a. m.  and 5 p. m.  to the following places — Girinagar section: Gandhinagar Residence Park, EWF, LIG Kaloor Section: Canopy Building, St.  Martins Road, Puthanpurakkal Road, North janatha Junction; Vyttila section: Poonithura Palace premises and Poonithura road, Fort Kochi section: Manassery, Mother Theressa road, Fishermen Colony, Saudi Pally, Thommassery.

The sixteenth Captain Vikram Memorial Ever-Rolling Trophy Inter-School Quiz was held in the city on Tuesday, in memory of Captain P. V.  Vikram who laid down his life in the Kargil war in June 1999.  Following are the winners of the first four places (in that order) in the quiz: Anjal Muhammed and Jasmin M. S.  (Government LP and UP School, Manassery); Sanjeev.  M and Muhammed Rashid (St.  Joseph’s Boys HSS, Kozhikode); Ashwin G.  Ashok and Vasudev.  P (Government UP School, Vattoli) and Hari Shankar.  R and Miya V. T.  (Chinmaya Vidyalaya, Kozhikode). Cheenadathu Makham: Talk on ‘Vigil against drug abuse,’ Puthiyangadi, 6 p. m. 
KMCT Arts and Science College: Reception to P. K.  Syamjith – a tribal youth from Nilambur who secured M. Phil in Anthropology, Manassery, 11.30 a. m. 
Government School of Nursing-Kozhikode: 13th anniversary celebrations, Government general hospital premises, 10 a. m. 
Kerala Lalithakala Akademi: ‘ Aavishkar’- exhibition of photographs, Akademi art gallery, 10 a. m.

column1: Thiruvakkarai
column2:
Weekend Wander Residents of Chennai are currently enjoying weather that is on its best behaviour.  Chilly mornings give way to bright sunny days, and breezy evenings.  Starting around Deepavali - when the city's skyscape and weather becomes more pleasant - and through Christmas, there are plenty of holidays in store, with New Year's Eve followed by Pongal. 
This is probably the best time for residents to take a breather from the milling crowds and enjoy a holiday in the hills, or a family picnic at a seaside resort or at a dam.  Contrary to the popular perception that holidayers have to travel overnight to hill stations like Ooty and Kodaikanal, there are lovely places closer to Chennai that one, leaving after sunrise, can reach shortly after breakfast. 
Make the best of the extended weekend and the holidays this festival season, and head to getaway spots just a few hours drive away from Chennai.  There are hill stations, lagoons, mangrove forests, springs and waterfalls, parks and lush green meadows not very far from the city.  Here, we present a few places where a day can be spent and other locations that require a couple of days of travel.  Most of the places listed here are well connected by train and buses.  For people travelling by personal transport, it is easier, with the option of visiting other interesting locations on the way
Ginjee fort–Sathanur dam: (Distance: 155 kms)
Located 160 kilometres from the city, one of the most popular destinations in Villupuram district is Ginjee fort.  The massive, awe-inspiring facade of the fort is at the same time beautiful.  Not very far away from Ginjee, is Sathanur dam in Tiruvannamalai district. 
The dam, built across Pennaiyar river, is a delight for children, and an ideal picnic spot for families.  There is a crocodile farm on the dam.  There are buses throughout the day to Tindivanam and Villupuram, from where travellers can hop onto connecting buses.  There are a good number of hotels offering decent accommodation and quality food in Tindivanam, Villupuram and Tiruvannamalai. 
Yelagiri – Jamunamarathur – Jalagamparai: (Distance: 220 kms)
Yelagiri in Vellore district is experienced at its best between monsoon and the onset of summer.  There is a children’s park, a boathouse and a garden, where families can spend a delightful evening.  Do not forget to buy the hill produce — honey, herbs and spices—- procured and sold by government-authorised women self-help groups.  The Jalagamparai waterfalls are located near Thirupathur in the district, and are worth a visit.  Travellers should not miss the piping hot kuzhi puniyaram served with spicy chutneys. 
The Beeman falls in Jamunamarathur is probably the best kept secret of Tiruvannamalai district.  It can be reached from Vaniyambadi, from where the ascent begins, passing through Kavalur observatory and Alangayam.  There are hotels in Yelagiri, and one can also find accommodation in Vellore or Thirupathur. 
Tada falls – Pulicat: (Distance: 70 kms)
If you are looking to trek in a serene environment, the Tada or Ubbalamadugu falls, across the border in neighbouring Chittoor district, Andhra Pradesh, is the ideal choice.  A two-and-a-half-hour drive on NH5 towards Tada leads to Varadaiahpalem.  After Gummidipoondi, mango orchards and green fields dot the sides of the highway, before the turn into Varadaiahpalem. 
Ubbalamadugu is another six km away.  One has to trek a few kilometres to reach the crystal-clear waterfalls.  The Nagala and Koney falls, all situated on the Tamil Nadu–Andhra Pradesh border are also must-visits.  Pulicat in Tiruvallur district is a visual treat for travellers, especially bird-lovers.  Thousands of birds arrive here between October and March.  The brackish water lagoon here is dotted with a number of villages. 
Hogenakkal: (Distance: 330 kms)
Best known as the place where Cauvery enters Tamil Nadu from Karnataka, the river passes through gorges-like rock formations.  The drive through Pennagaram to Hogenakkal is a mesmerising experience, though slightly risky for those uninitiated in driving on hill roads. 
Tourists can reach early in the morning and purchase provisions and food, including fresh fish caught in the river.  Cooks can be hired to prepare meals, be it for a small group or big gathering.  In the meantime, you can hire coracles for the famous swirling rides in the Cauvery and land on the small river islands for an oil massage.  There are direct buses to Hogenakkal from Koyambedu, and plenty of accommodation on offer. 
Horsley hills: (Distance: 270 kms)
Cruising from Chennai city towards west for nearly six hours can take you to what seems like paradise.  Horsley hills, known as the Ooty of Andhra Pradesh, will surely be a soothing experience for travellers who want to spend a memorable weekend.  A little over 250 kilometres from Chennai, the scenic hill resort with views of misty mountains guarantees a relaxed time and, for those who enjoy a trek, moments of adventure. 
Make sure you book your stay at Horsley hills in advance, as weekends can be crowded, especially during the holidays, with people from nearby towns and cities flocking to enjoy the nippy weather.  For motorcycle riders, a trip through the rough terrain could prove a challenging and enjoyable experience.  In addition to private accommodation, the Andhra Pradesh tourism department runs a property for rent. 
Puducherry: (Distance: 160 kms)
A scenic drive down East Coast Road leads to the idyllic town of Puducherry.  For people who do not want to spend the entire weekend exploring the beaches of Puducherry and Auroville, there are places such as Oussudu bird sanctuary (Ousteri) to visit outside the town.  For heritage-lovers, a walk with INTACH around Puducherry, followed by a trip to Thiruvakkarai’s National Fossil Wood Park, around 30 km away, is a good option.  The Pitchavaram mangrove forest is a two-hour drive away, and is home to a number of exotic bird species.  You can also plan a trip to Cuddalore’s Silver Beach, or even a ride down to Chidambaram to visit the Nataraja Temple.  People driving down ECR should not miss a meal at the shacks in Vennangupattu.  Excavation in Auroville throws up Iron Age artefacts Burial sites, possibly dating back to the Iron Age, were unearthed during an archaeological excavation programme in Auroville. 
The artefacts found beneath granite slabs in urns include cups, vessels, cowbells made of bronze, beads and semi precious stone lapis lazuli.  Iron objects such as swords, spades, spears, sickle and axe were also found. 
According to archaeologist and assistant professor from Tagore Arts College Ravichandran, who has been leading the excavation, assisted by field supervisor Gopinathan and volunteers from the college, the three burial sites found are secondary ones and only partial remains could be found in such sites. 
The depth of the site is around three to four meters and 10 to 15 meters in diameter.  The cairn circle in the centre is made with limestones transported from Royapudupakkam and granite slabs from Thiruvakkarai, a few kilometres from the site. 
The team has been making several similar finds over the past two years in Auroville.  The excavation programme, which concentrated on an area very close to the Matrimandir, was aimed at finding evidence of a trading link between the ancient port city of Arikamedu and the site inside Auroville. 
“The significance of the excavations is in that they establish a once flourishing internal trade and commerce even before the Roman and Greek period,” Mr.  Ravichandran said. 
He surmises that the language used must have been Tamil but no evidence has been found so far.  Only graffiti marks can be found on the outer surface of the pottery.  According to the findings, the settlement must have been a cattle-rearing community and they must have had trade with Arikamedu. 
The site was first accidentally discovered by the locals while taking soil for Pongal celebrations.  Initially, it took time to get permission from the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI).  Surveys conducted around Puducherry and Auroville revealed Medieval Age and Stone Age materials. 
Gilbert Lachaux, an Auroville resident, recalls finding a granite slab about 60 cm below the ground level while digging holes to plant trees 30 years ago. 
The excavation is funded by the Auroville Foundation.  The team is collaborating with the Tamil Sembulam, a part of the Tamil Heritage Foundation (THF) for archaeological purposes. 
It is supposed to go on till September, depending on the availability of funds. 
“There is an immediate need to protect the site from being destroyed like Perambai near the Ousteri Lake, which was ruined by mineral excavation.  India has several archaeological sites that are not preserved and shares the same fate as Perambai,” said Mr.  Ravichandran. 
In the near future, the site will be turned into an archaeological park where the architecture can be studied and the excavated items will soon be exhibited in a museum at Bharathi Nivas in Auroville.
