A ‘new’ fossil tree trunk at Ooty botanical garden The Botanical Garden at Udhagamandalam got a new fossil tree trunk in place of the fossil tree trunk that was in place for more than three decades. 
It is said that the old fossil tree trunk from the National Fossil Park at Thiruvakkarai in Villupuram district was given to the botanical garden here in the year 1978 by the Geological Survey of India (GSI).  Joint Director of Horticulture N.  Mani said that replacement of the old fossil tree trunk was necessitated due to moss growth on the old fossil tree. 
India map
The Horticulture Department requested GSI to replace the old fossil tree and the new one was installed opposite the India map near the Tamil Nadu Tourism Development Corporation canteen and opened to the public from Saturday .  The fossil tree trunk is a tourist favourite and almost all of them have take a photograph of themselves along with the tree that existed about 20 million years ago. 
According to GSI, the old fossil tree and new one are 20 million-year-old trees that have turned into rocks. 
Inland lakes
Description of the fossil at the garden states that trees carried by rivers and deposited in inland lakes gradually transformed into fossils. 
More such treasures could be seen at the National Fossil Park at Thiruvakkarai in Villupuram. 
Additional Director of the botanical garden Umarani said that the old fossil tree continues to remain in the park and can be seen by the public over the next few days, before it’s future is decided by the senior horticulture and GSI officials, she said.

column1: Shahupuri Gymkhana
column2: Industria-2015 sees 40,000 visitors; third expo planned for next year  KOLHAPUR: More than 40,000 industrialists from the region visited the four-day expo Industria 2015 on its final day on Tuesday.  The event was organised by the Kolhapur Chamber of Commerce and Industries (Kin association with Centre's ministry of micro small and medium enterprises (MSME).  The exhibition showcased the technology and tools of over 120 industrialists from the region at the Shahupuri Gymkhana.  KCCI president Anand Mane, said, " The exhibition saw industrialists and technology lovers flocking to the city from southern Maharashtra and parts of Karnataka and Goa.  Despite the current recessionary trend, we saw growing entrepreneurial interests among youngsters.  We will see how much business the companies did during the exhibition.  The third expo will be held next year. "  The organisers have said that the exhibition helped brand the city with entrepreneurial spirit and a growing market.  The industrialists suggested that organisers should consider showcasing locally-made traditional goods in such exhibitions from next year.  The categories of the products displayed at the exhibition were textile, electric motors, packaging materials, gears, bearings, boilers, building materials and security systems.  " We are going to set up a mechanism to communicate regularly with the entrepreneurs who participated in the exhibition.  Also, with the help of various government departments we are going to ensure that industrialists from the region get first preference.  The plans to search new markets for the entrepreneurs have got the boost through the exhibition.  We are trying to attract multinational industries in the region with the help of the ties we have developed with government officials and entrepreneurs,"  said Mane. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Construction expo from January 29  KOLHAPUR: The city unit of the Confederation of Real Estate Developers Association (Credai) has planned a construction exhibition, called Dalan 2016, starting January 29 next year.  This will be the 27th year of Credai organising such an exhibition and it will be inaugurated at the hands of chief minister Devendra Fadnavis.  President of Kolhapur Credai Mahesh Yadav, said on Wednesday said that the exhibition will be held at Shahupuri Gymkhana.  " We have started setting up stalls for developers at the venue from Wednesday.  The exhibition will conclude on February 1,"  he added.  " Dalan is among the biggest real estate business shows in southern Maharashtra, and this time, 163 companies participating.  Our purpose is to bring the latest innovation in the business to Kolhapur, and so far, Dalan has achieved this goal.  Several competitions have also been arranged for the visitors, said Rajeev Parikh, vice-president of Maharashtra Credai.  TNNKolhapur: Kolhapur branch of Confederation of Real Estate Developers Association (Credai) has planned arranging construction exhibition Dalan 2016 starting from January 29.  This will be 27th year of Credai to arrange such an exhibition which will be inaugurated at the hands of chief minister Devendra Fadnavis. column1: Maneybhanjyang
column2:
Chill skips Kolkata but Hills gets snow  DARJEELING/KOLKATA: The winter chill kept eluding Kolkata, even as Sandakphu received heavy snowfall on Thursday. 
Kolkata’s temperature had gone up to 21C last week and on Thursday it went up to 25C.  The night temperature at 13.7C was normal.  The Met office does not expect the mercury to dip further immediately. 
“The night temperature will hover around the 14°C mark, while the day temperature will be around 25°C in the next few days,” said a source at the Regional Meteorological Centre. 
On the other hand, Sandakphu, 60km from Darjeeling town, received 4-5 inches of snow on Thursday.  Sandhakphu, the topmost point of Darjeeling at 3,636m, received heavy snowfall for almost an hour.  Officials of the tourist lodges owned by Gorkhaland Territorial Administration (GTA) could not be contacted, but drivers of the Manyeybhanjyang-Sandakphu route confirmed that it snowed for about an hour from 3.30 to 4.30pm. 
“Some of my fellow drivers who had taken a group of tourists to Sandakphu returned after going half of the way because of 4-5 inches of snow.  Some tourists walked down to Maneybhanjyang, which is the starting point towards Sandakphu,” said Chandan Pradhan, general secretary of the Singalila Landrover Association. 
In Darjeeling town, however, the situation was different.  Although the sky was clear in the morning, the weather turned chilly and clouds gathered overhead in the afternoon.  Around 3.50pm, a drizzle sparked anticipation of snowfall.  The anticipation however died just as fast since the rain subsided within five minutes, leaving the streets covered in slush.  Hope of snow on Tiger Hill at 2,560m, which normally receives snow, also faded. 
“The temperature in Tiger Hill is around 3-4 degrees, which is not conducive for snowfall.  But it could snow late in the evening or in the night.  Some tourists were here but had to go back disappointed,” said Pradip Lama, the Pavilion manager of Tiger Hill. 
Rashik Garg from Bangalore, who arrived in Darjeeling on Wednesday, said “I was looking forward to snowfall as my hotel manager had said that it could snow anytime because of the weather condition prevailing over the week.  I was ready to rush to Tiger Hill if it snowed.  The drizzle in the afternoon gave some hope but it faded with the sun that came out five minutes later. ”
It had snowed in Sandakphu even a week back, but had failed to accumulate.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  West Bengal: GNLF supporters assaulted for abusing Bimal Gurung DARJEELING: Gorkha National Liberation Front (GNLF) supporters blocked NH-55 near Ghoom station in Darjeeling in protest against the assault on them allegedly by cadre of Gorkha Janmukti Morcha (GJM), the police said today. 
Acknowledging the receipt a complaint against GJM cadre, Superintendent of Police of Darjeeling Akhilesh Chaturvedi said, " There was a confrontation between GNLF and GJM supporters at Ghoom yesterday.  We have assured the complainants of arresting those involved in the assault. " 
The incident took place around 3:30 pm when GNLF supporters were returning home after attending the death ritual of their party founder Subash Ghisingh, he said. 
The police said that the clash broke out when some GNLF supporters allegedly started to abuse GJM president Bimal Gurung who was returning home to Darjeeling from Maneybhanjyang. 
Subash Ghisingh died on January 29 in a Delhi hospital and was cremated in his ancestral home in Mirik.  As per Buddhist custom, his death ritual was held yesterday at his residence in Darjeeling after 21 days of his death.  GJM demands enhanced security for GTA chief Bimal Gurung DARJEELING (WB): The Gorkha Janmukti Morcha has asked the Superintendent of Police, Darjeeling Hills, to enhance the security cover for GTA Chief Executive Bimal Gurung whose rank is on par with a state cabinet minister and condemned the alleged attack on his convoy two days back. 
The memorandum, signed by GJM General Secretary Roshan Giri, alleged the convoy of GTA Chief Executive was " waylaid near Ghoom station by GNLF supporters who were drunk.  They abused the GTA Chief Executive and even tried to assault him" . 
The memorandum was submitted yesterday.  Wednesday's incident took place when GNLF supporters were on their way back from Darjeeling after attending the death rituals of Subash Ghisingh while the GTA Chief Executive was on his way to Darjeeling town from Maneybhanjyang after laying the foundation stone for a road project, Giri said. 
Additional SP Surya Pratap Yadav said a probe is on to ascertain what happened in Ghoom. 
" As for the GJM's demand for more security to the GTA chief executive, we will first review the situation,"  the ASP said. 
" We demand the immediate arrest of the GNLF cadre who attacked our President.  If they are not arrested within 24 hours, we will launch a bigger agitation,"  GJM Assistant Secretary Binay Tamang said. 
" The district administration and the police were both aware of Gurung's itinerary for the day.  The district police are responsible for ensuring proper security arrangements to enable the GTA chief executive to move freely, especially when a rival political party is holding a rally or function,"  Giri said after submitting the memorandum. 
The GNLF had called a strike in Pokhraybong on Thursday,demanding the arrest of the GJM cadre responsible for the alleged assault. 
It was called off after three GJM supporters, allegedly involved in the incident, were arrested. 
The three - identified as local residents Nikit Rai, Abit Rai, and Dharmadhoj Tamang - were produced before the chief judicial magistrate court yesterday and granted bail. 
Rubbishing GJM charges, the GNLF earlier said its supporters were assaulted by morcha men accompanying Gurung's convoy when the GNLF activists were returning home after attending the death ritual of GNLF founder Subash Ghisingh and the two sides came face to face. 
Gurung currently is entitled to have a security cover comprising an assistant sub-inspector and six constables round the clock, GTA sources said.

column1: Kasaiwada
column2:
Today, last CR train from CST at 11.30pm  MUMBAI: There will be no trains after midnight on Saturday.  A CR official said that a block would be undertaken to dismantle a foot-overbridge at Kasaiwada in Kurla for DC-AC conversion.  The block will cover all lines on CR—four on Main line, two on Harbour.  The block will affect early morning trains in both directions on Sunday.  While departure of long- distance trains from CST will be delayed, many long-distance trains will terminate at Dadar.  CR will not have any major block on Sunday. column1: Lingambudhi Lake
column2:
Lingambudhi Lake to be conserved as biodiversity hotspot The Lingambudhi Lake,a major bird habitat in the city, is set to see better days as the Forest Department proposes to develop it on the lines of the Karanji Nature Park and conserve it as a biodiversity hotspot.  In addition, the Malalvadi Kere near Jayanagar would also be beautified providing the much-needed lung space for the people in the area. 
A detailed project report has been submitted to the authorities concerned with a request to sanction Rs.  2 crore for each of the lakes. 
At Lingambudhi, the existing lake embankment will be strengthened and silt will be removed.  Besides, the bird islands would be strengthened besides planting locally endemic tree saplings. 
Deputy Conservator of Forests V.  Karikalan told The Hindu that the project details have been submitted to the higher authorities in Bengaluru who have promised to release funds this year. 
However, Lingamubhi Lake has a problem of untreated sewage being let to flow into it thus posing a major threat to its ecological integrity.  Hence the Forest Department has urged the Mysuru City Corporation and the Mysore Urban Development Authority to establish a sewage treatment plant there. 
“We have been telling the two local bodies to expedite the works but nothing has happened so far and hence the Forest Department is contemplating on outsourcing the construction of sewage treatment plant to private players”, said Mr.  Karikalan. 
Preventing untreated sewage from entering the lake is a must for its long-term conservation.  Lingamubdhi Lake is a major watershed and is full to the brim during the monsoon, and more than 3000 birds of nearly 200 species – both migratory and local- come to roost here during winter.  There is also a mantapa at the lake foreshore which would be renovated, Mr.  Karikalan said. 
Mr.  Karikalan said Lingambudhi had as much potential as the Karanji Nature Park if not more and could be turned around to harbour local biodiversity.  Spread over nearly 220 acres with a water spread of about 160 acres, Lingambudhi Lake has a history of citizen’s participation in its conservation.  When the alignment of the Outer Ring Road was laid across the lake, it resulted in widespread protest following which the road alignment was changed and the lake was saved. 
The lake has a catchment area of 40 sq.  The Malalvadi Kere in Jayanagar will be converted into an eco-park with walking path, island and a bridge.  About 250 tree saplings have been planted but there is no fresh water inflow into the lake, and hence rainwater would be harvested.  Mobile tankers to be stationed at various spots for idol immersion The Karnataka State Pollution Control Board (KSPCB) will operate mobile water tankers in the city to facilitate the immersion of idols in an environment-friendly manner. 
Three vehicles will be stationed at different places at specified times from September 17 to 20, according to the KSPCB.  Vehicle number 1 will be stationed close to Metagalli Police Station from 4 p. m.  to 5.15 p. m; near K. D. Circle at Vijaynagar 2{+n}{+d}stage from 5.30 p. m.  to 6.45 p. m; close to Chandramouleshwara Temple and Matrhu Mandali Circle at Vontikoppal from 7 p. m.  to 8.15 p. m; near Kukkarahalli main entrance from 8.30 p. m.  to 10.30 p. m.  The contact number of the vehicle in-charge is 9880164745. 
Vehicle number 2 will be positioned near Vikram Hospital at Yadavgiri from 4 p. m.  to 5.15 p. m; near Shantala theatre from 5.30 p. m.  to 6.45 . p. m. , at Chamundi Circle from 7 p. m.  to 8.15 p. m.  and near the main entrance of the Karanji Lake from 8.30 p. m.  to 10.30 p. m.  Contact number of the vehicle in-charge is 9900479002
The third vehicle will be near Jayamma Govinde Gowda Kalyana Mantapa at Kuvempunagar from 4 p. m.  to 5.15 p. m. ; near Jayanagar Raiway Gate from 5.30 p. m.  to 6.45 p. m. , near J. P.  Nagar Gobbali Mara Bus Stand from 7 p. m.  to 8.15 p. m.  and near the main entrance of Lingambudhi Lake from 8.30 p. m.  to 10.30 p. m. 
The contact number of the vehicle in-charge is 9845307419. 
The mobile tankers have been introduced to discourage people from polluting lakes and other waterbodies during the immersion process.

column1: Vitthal Ramji Shinde Bridge
column2:
MANS activists want probe into Dabholkar's death intensified  PUNE: Maharashtra Andhashraddha Nirmulan Samiti (MANS) on Sunday resolved to intensify its demand for a thorough probe into the Narendra Dabholkar murder case in order to nab the killers at the earliest.  At the end of the three-day convention, MANS activists decided to launch a series of activities so that the state and central government would be compelled to speed up the probe.  Dabholkar was shot dead by two unidentified men on Vitthal Ramji Shinde Bridge near Balgandharva Rangmandir on August 20, 2013.  " We have started a campaign against violence and we plan to send one lakh post-cards to the President of India seeking to know when Dabholkar's murderers would be nabbed,"  said Avinash Patil, executive president of MANS, while addressing the concluding session of the convention.  He added that MANS will take up the matter at every appropriate forum in order to expedite the probe.  On Sunday morning, MANS workers marched from Swargate to Vitthal Ramji Shinde Bridge demanding that Dabholkar's murderers must be nabbed without further delay.  As the rally reached the spot where Dabholkar was murdered, MANS leaders addressed a meeting and resolved to continue the fight for justice.  In the concluding session, Dabholkar's wife Shaila said that MANS workers must be proud that they are members of an organisation that is fighting to imbibe rationalism among common people.  " All of us have become like Dabholkar and we have to take his work forward,"  she said, adding that the huge response to the three-day conference was evidence that his work would continue, despite all hurdles.  Veteran activist Vidya Bal also participated in the concluding session.  She said that rationalist movements need to be more alert now since fundamental forces are gaining strength.  Communist leader Bhalchandra Kango mentioned that it is time for all progressive and rational movements to become more vigilant about mainstream politics so as to strengthen progressive political parties.  Senior scientist Jayant Narlikar, scholar A H Salunkhe, Datta Desai and others were also present at the convention. The written word finds many takers Organisers of the MANS convention said that, in the course of three days, books worth Rs 6 lakh were sold.  Tomes on subjects such as rationalism, superstition, Buddhism, women's movement and Muslim Satyashodhak Mandal were picked up in big number.  A booklet, titled Shivaji Kon Hota written by late Govind Pansare, was also in demand at the convention.  Shaila Dabholkar, the slain activist's wife, said that reading would strengthen rational thinking and MANS workers must engage in readings and discussions.  Veteran activist Vidya Bal added that reading enhances rationality. Corpus fund set up MANS has decided to raise a corpus fund in memory of Narendra Dabholkar.  The fund will be utilised to take the organisation's mission forward.  MANS workers and activists have contributed Rs 3 lakh towards the fund till date.  Volunteers from the organisation mentioned that people from various fields, medical practitioners, teachers, daily wage labourers and students, have been contributing to the fund. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  State govt lacks will to arrest killers, say activists, leaders  PUNE: The Maharashtra Andhashraddha Nirmulan Samiti (MANS) activists, leaders and workers on Thursday expressed apprehensions over the state government's will to probe into murder of rationalist Narendra Dabholkar and arrest his killers and the mastermind behind it. 
MANS and other organizations marked the day with a rally that started from Vitthal Ramji Shinde Bridge, where he was killed in 2013 and continued at Manohar Mangal Karyala near Mhatre Bridge. 
State president of MANS and veteran leader N D Patil said, " I doubt if politicians really want to probe into the murder cases of Dabholkar and Govind Pansare.  Be it the Congress-NCP government or the current BJP-led government, the approach is same.  They don't want to go into the roots of the case. "  It is hard to believe that the police force is completely in the dark about the killers,"  he said.  Congress party's Rajya Sabha MP Husain Dalwai said, " I am sorry that the Congress government in Maharashtra could not arrest Dabholkar's murderers.  I don't know about my party's stand, but I am with MANS.  It is not that police are inefficient, but they are unwilling to probe into the case. "  He also criticized former state home minister and NCP leader late R R Patil saying that the latter was not efficient enough to take a tough stand. 
Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) leader Subhash Ware said, " The government is not interested in the probe as they know where it will lead. " 
Avinash Patil, state executive president of MANS said, " We know we are being ignored, but we will continue to fight using constitutional methods. " 
Various speakers supported FTII students and accused the government of suppressing students by using police force.  Well-known Marathi film and theatre personalities including National Award winners Nagnath Manjule, Girish Kulkarni, actor Jitendra Joshi, Sonali Kulkarni, Kishor Kadam, Sunil Sukthankar, Sumitra Bhave and Atul Pethe came out in support of MANS. Shanmugam. 
On July 25 (Saturday)
There will be a power shutdown, due to monthly maintenance works at Chekkanoorani substation on July 25 (Saturday) from 9 a. m.  to 2 p. m. , in the following areas: Chekkanoorani, K.  Puliankulam, Panniyaan, Kinnimangalam, Mavilipatti, Moonandipatti, A.  Kokkulam, Karumathur, Kannanur, Sakkilipatti, Kovilankulam, Poochampatti, Jothimanickam, Vadapalanchi, Thenpalanchi and Palkalai Nagar areas, Executive Engineer M.  Ilango said in a press release issued here.  One more green initiative from Madurai blossoms For M.  Elango of Navarathinapuram, a third generation entrepreneur, dyeing and bleaching of fabrics is a business learnt hard, the traditional way.  Like him, hundreds of dyers and bleachers involved in micro and small businesses were hitherto not aware of the impact of their vocation on the environment, especially groundwater table, of Madurai.  They have been following crude manual methods without knowing how to dispose of the effluents. 
When the Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board (TNPCB) cracked the whip, insisting on zero discharge of effluents, the only option was to shut down shop.  This compulsion resulted in the birth of Southern Districts Textile Processing Cluster Private Limited (SDTPC), a special purpose vehicle floated by 36 units, for the promotion of a common facility with zero liquid discharge technology, claimed to be the first of its kind in the State. 
The common effluent treatment plant (CETP), to be constructed under the Union government’s Integrated Processing Development Scheme, will become operational at Pottakulam and Tamaraikulam in Kariapatti taluk of neighbouring Virudhunagar district with an investment of Rs.  167.3 crore by this time next year.  It will come up at an industrial estate to be created under the Private Industrial Estate Scheme of the State government over an area of 100 acres. 
For three districts
The CETP will cater to the needs of dyeing and bleaching units of Madurai, Sivaganga and Virudhunagar districts and can even perform outsourced work for Tirupur, Coimbatore and Erode.  It will even facilitate migration of textile processing units elsewhere in the State to south Tamil Nadu, says KR.  Gnanasambandan, consultant. 
Explaining Sequential Batch Reactor (SBR) Technology to be adopted in the CETP, the Managing Director of SDTPC, Ritan N.  Thakker, says that it will enable recovery of 90 per cent of water from effluents for reuse by units.  It will also recover used salts and provide them for reuse.  The technology conforms to Euro Standard and it will increase export potential.  A team from IKOS, France, led by Christophe, its Director, International, visited the site for the industrial estate recently and expressed its satisfaction.  A similar plant in Surat of Gujarat employs marine discharge of effluents by reducing their TDS and decolouring. 
To start with, 36 units attached to the SDTPC will shift to the industrial estate by providing direct employment to 60 to 70 persons per unit.  They will process textiles for bigger units in Tirupur, Rajapalayam, Aruppukottai and Madurai.  The CETP will be self-sufficient on the power front with a co-generation facility.  Its low processing cost is expected to give this green initiative a competitive edge over similar facilities spread across the country. column1: Bheemsamudra Road
column2:
Rs 1.5 Though sufficient quantity of drinking water is supplied to Chitradurga from Shanti Sagar, it is not reaching people owing to major leakages at more than nine points in the pipeline and technical snags at the machines in treatment plants. 
So the City Municipal Council is in the final stages of preparing a plan of Rs 1.5 crore to install new pipelines and rectify the loopholes in the treatment plant. 
According to City Municipal Council President B.  Kantraj drinking water is supplied to Chitradurga, Holalkere, Jagalur Town Panchayat and 22 villages from Shanti Sagar. 
Though the project is of 40 MLD capacities, major portion of the water is wasted owing to leakages in the pipelines. 
In a joint survey, conducted by officers of the City Municipal Council and the Karnataka Urban Water Supply and Sewerage Board Engineers, most of the water is wasted at leakages at Bheemsamudra Road, Haliyur railway gate, Hireguntnur, Hirekandwadi treatment plant owing to improper maintenance and low-quality work. 
In view of the people’s plight, the municipal council is preparing a plan to replace old pipelines and install new equipment at the treatment plants to ensure sufficient and safe drinking water to people. 
Work on the same would be started in next few months after completing the tender process. 
“Since the supply of drinking water would be affected during the project work, the council is planning to make alternate arrangements to supply water to city and a final decision in this regard would be taken shortly.  Once the project is completed, there will be no problem in supplying ample quantity of water to people in the city,” he added. 
Flouride
Since there are complaints about high fluoride content in water in some parts of the city, the council had already taken steps to install drinking water purification units at different places to ensure safe drinking water to the poor and middle class people who cannot afford RO plants at their houses.  There are also plans to install such plants at all places where there are complaints in the city in phased manner, he added. 
Water is getting wasted owing to leaks in the pipelines

column1: Palluruthy Veli
column2:
Kochi gets ready to celebrate Eid-ul-Fitr  KOCHI: Marking the end of month-long Ramzan fasting, believers in the city will celebrate Eid-ul-Fitr on Saturday with fervor, festivities and huge feasts. 
As the Muslim community gets ready to celebrate Eid, the Hindu community will begin observing âKarkidakamâ, the month of austerity. 
âEid is more like a huge family reunion.  My relatives from Kasaragod and Kozhikode are in town for the weekend.  Preparations for the feast have already begun.  My mother makes biriyani, payasam and her specialty, haleem, at home every year.  The process starts a day in advance.  Itâs going to be a big feast,â said Samah Mariam, a resident of Panampilly Nagar. 
Eid prayers will be held at eidgahs (open air spaces) and mosques across the city, including St Albert's College Ground, Marine Drive, Perumbavoor Municipal Stadium, Aluva Nochima, Parade Ground in Fort Kochi, Malipuram Maidan in Vypeen, and Palluruthy Veli ground among others. 
Meanwhile, prices of meat remained more or less stable through the month, according to vendors.  George Edathil, president of Ernakulam Market Stall Owners Association, said the price of chicken went up by Rs 10 over the last two weeks.  The price now stands at Rs 120 per kg in the city.  The price of beef has been varying between Rs 260 and Rs 280, while that of mutton stood at Rs 450.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  On a floral note of protest : When authorities turned a deaf ear to their protest against the reported reluctance of the civic authorities to remove garbage from the collection point near the Palluruthy Government UP School, local residents decided to take matters into their own hands.  Instead of raising decibel levels to show their protest, they discovered a novel way to get the attention of the authorities. 
After the putrefying refuse remained at the spot for close to 10 days, people decided not to allow the collection of garbage from there any more, said Mumtaz, the Corporation Councillor representing the area in the council.  The people got together and set up a garden there to avoid dumping of garbage in the area. 
It was also the case with some other areas in the west Kochi region. 
Though the civic authorities claimed that two trucks were allotted for collecting the refuse from west Kochi region daily, the removal of garbage has never been smooth, she alleged. 
The health issues posed by the irregular collection and removal of decaying refuse were repeatedly brought to the attention of the civic authorities at the Corporation council meetings.  Yet, no one acted on the complaint, said Ms.  Mumtaz, who had raised the issue at the Corporation council meeting last week also. 
She complained that officials of the Health wing of the Kochi Corporation were not keen in attending to the complaints of the general public.  Some of the officials were also irregular to the office thereby crippling the public health activities, she said. 
After ending the collection of garbage at one point, it has been decided to collect it at three different points in the region.  Decentralised collection and transportation of the refuse started on Monday.  The new collection points thus identified were at Palluruthy Veli near Kochi Corporation office, Madhura Company road and near Pashnithodu bridge, she said. 
Responding to the developments, T. K.  Ashraf, chairman of the Health Standing Committee of the Kochi Corporation, said the collection of garbage from the region was disrupted on one day as the Kudumbashree workers didn’t turn up on the day.

column1: Parimalam Mahal
column2:
Latest building materials on display at Build Expo 2015 Build Expo - 2015, the annual exhibition of a range of building materials conducted by the Erode District Civil Engineers’ Association (EDCA) and Erode Civil Engineers Trust, promises to feature 175 stalls displaying all materials that go into making a ‘dream home’. 
The organisers have coined a special term ‘Crystalennial Year’ for the celebration spanning four days from December 25 onwards at the Parimalam Mahal along Perundurai Road. 
The event envisages opening up new vistas in construction sector, Build Expo Chairman K.  Senthil Kumar said.  The exhibition has been successful all these years in projecting building materials, alongside promoting design, financial sector, and allied industries in the district, he said. 
Visitors
As a vital business hub attracting floating population, the construction sector in the region has been growing steadily.  Last time, there were in excess of 15,000 visitors every day, and this time, the footfall will be more, Mr.  Senthilkumar said. 
Representatives of the district units of EDCEA and Federation of all Civil Engineers Associations of Tamil Nadu and Puducherry (FACEAT) will take part, and gain from the stalls put up by builders, flat promoters, housing finance companies, steel industries, cement, artificial sand, interior and exterior decorators, modular kitchen promoters, decorative glass makers, electrical product manufacturers, wall and floor tile manufacturers, and granite firms. 
Awareness
The event, Mr.  Senthilkumar said, would create awareness about international-standard quality building materials and accessories that will not affect the environment. 
Souvenir
Sandeep Singh Sandhu, Assistant Vice-President, JSW Cements Limited, will inaugurate the event.  FACEAT State President R.  Sivalingam will release a souvenir on the occasion. 
Mr.  Sivalingam said the exhibition, scheduled for simultaneous conduct in a few other districts in the State, would provide a platform for consumers to take informed decisions.  It will be an opportunity for the consumers to analyse pricing and quality of products offered through very many companies under one roof, he said.

column1: Afzalgunj
column2:
Traffic curbs in Nampally for Numaish in Hyderabad  HYDERABAD: Traffic restrictions will be in force around Exhibition Grounds in Nampally to facilitate easy movement of visitors to the All India Industrial Exhibition (Numaish), which starts on January 1 and culminates on February 15.  The traffic restrictions would be in place during the 45-day extravaganza between 4 pm and midnight everyday.  RTC buses and heavy vehicles from Fateh Maidan heading towards Nampally would be diverted at A R Petrol Pump towards B J R Statue.  Also, buses and heavy vehicles heading towards SA Bazaar and Jambagh road would be diverted towards Abids at MJ Market junction. 
All heavy goods vehicles from Begum Bazaar would be diverted at Alaska junction towards Darussalam and vehicles from Goshamahal road towards Feelkhana would be diverted to MJ Market and Abids.  Apart from diversions, the city police have suggested alternate routes commuters can follow to avoid the traffic around the Exhibition Grounds. 
Motorists from Putlibowli can take an alternate route via MJ Market – Yousuf & Co - Abids – Nampally Station Road – A-1 Signal Point (Nampally T Junction); Motorists from Traffic Control Room, Fateh Maidan and Public Gardens side and heading towards Afzalgunj can take alternate route through Afzalgunj – BJR Statue – SBH Gunfoundry – Taj Mahal – Abids GPO - Yousuf & Co – M J Market – Afzalgunj; traffic from MJ Bridge towards Nampally can take Begum Bazaar Chatri– Alaska – Darussalam right turn – Ek Minar Mosque- Railway Station – Nampally route; traffic from Chaderghat Bridge towards Saifabad can proceed from DMHS, Koti - Sultan Bazaar - King Koti X Roads –– Basheerbagh – PCR – Saifabad; Motorists coming from Bahadurpura side are advised to take the Puranapul – Mangalghat – Aghapura – Darussalam – Ek Minar Mosque- Railway Station – Nampally route; traffic from Saifabad towards Rajendranagar side could take Ravindra Bharathi – Ayodhya – Masab Tank flyover – Mehdipatnam- Moghal Ka Nala – Attapur-Rajendranagar route; traffic from Madina could take Afzalgunj- M J Market – Yousuf & Co - Abids GPO- A-1 Signal Point or Abids- Chirag Ali Lane – Chermas- BJR Statue- AR Petrol Pump route towards Nampally; traffic from Mehdipatnam towards Charminar can take Asifnagar Road - Bhoiguda Kaman- Mangalhat-Puranapul- Moosa Bowli Road- Chowk-Khilwath-Charminar route.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Traffic curbs today for Milad-un-Nabi procession  HYDERABAD: In view of Milad-un-Nabi rally on Sunday and to maintain smooth flow of traffic, city police have imposed traffic restrictions in some parts of the city.  The restrictions will be enforced on the Himmatpura Madina Crossroad stretch.  The traffic coming from Afzalgunj side towards Madina Crossroad will be diverted at Nayapool towards SJ rotary and L&O PS Afzalgunj. 
Motorists coming from Nagulchintha / Shalibanda side and going towards Charminar will be diverted at Himmatpura Junction, towards Hari Bowli and Volga.  Vehicles coming from Kotla Alijah near Charminar will be diverted towards Bibi Bazaar. 
Traffic coming from MGBS Exit gate and going towards Nayapool and Darulshifa will be diverted at Shivaji Bridge. 
Motorists coming from Puranapool, Moosabowli side towards Charminar will be diverted at Motigalli towards Khilwath. 
These restrictions apply to RTC buses also and the ones going towards Charminar will be terminated at Afzalgunj.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Blood donation camps held to help thalassemia patients in Hyderabad  HYDERABAD: While many were out on the streets celebrating Milad-un-Nabi, the birth anniversary of the Prophet Muhammad, socio-religious organizations busied themselves with philanthropic activity, urging people to donate blood for a cause.  According to the organisers of the donation drive, as many as 2,800 units of blood were donated by around 3,000 people at various places across the twin cities. 
“We wanted to help those who have poor health.  That is why we began our drive to help patients suffering from thalassemia, a blood disorder,” said Sunni United Forum of Indian (SUFI) and former AP State Wakf Board member Syed Zaheeruddin Soofi, while speaking to TOI, on Monday. 
Organised by Forum for Cultural Upgradation and Social Service (FOCUS), Irshad ul Muslimeen and other organisations, the blood donation camps were held at the State Central Library (SCL) in Afzalgunj and Balamrai Eidgah in Secunderabad. 
“We collected 639 units at the SCL and around 440 at Balamrai Eidgah alone.  We estimate that over 1,200 donors arrived at the camp,” said Ahsan bin Mohammed al Hamooni, secretary of FOCUS and imam of the Shahi Mosque in Public Gardens.  The blood is being sent to various hospitals and blood banks, al Hamoomi added.  “We have sent it to Gandhi hospital, Durgabhai Deshmukh Hospital, Nilofer Hospital and Aarohi Blood Bank.  As we wanted to help thalassemia patients, we roped in the Thalassimia and Sickle Cell Society (TSCS) too, which is based in Purani Haveli in the Old City,” he said. 
Another blood donation camp at Quadri Chaman near Falaknuma was organised by SUFI where 936 units were collected.  “The blood will be given to Esra Hospital, Owaisi Hospital and the TSCS,” Soofi said. 
Further, around 50 units were collected at the Charminar Bus Station camp and 13 at Mahmoodguda. 
“The reason why organisers came forward to help TSCS is because thalassemia patients are not covered under the Aaryogyasri scheme that provides healthcare benefits to those who cannot afford it.  We have made several representations to the government to recognise this disorder and are hopeful that our efforts will bear fruit,” said TSCS joint secretary, Aleem Baig, father of two thalassemic daughters.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Two Inter students killed in mishap  HYDERABAD: A fun car ride by eight intermediate students in Old City ended in a tragedy when two of them lost their lives in a mishap that took place in the wee hours of Thursday.  Afzalgunj police said K Varun Raj,18, and Narender,18, and six others - Bhaskar, Akash, Prashant, Shiva, Bunny and Kaushik were speeding in their car from Kacheguda to Afzalgunj when Kaushik, the driver, rammed the vehicle to a wall near the Sai Baba temple in Chaderghat around 2.30 am on Thursday.  Varun Raj and Narender, who were seated in the front passenger seat, got crushed to death while the others suffered grievous injuries. 
According to police, the eight boys were intermediate students and out on a ride after a party.  Varun Raju was a resident of Kishangunj while Narender was from Habsiguda. 
A case was registered under 279 (rash driving or riding on a public way), 337 (causing hurt by act of endangering life or personal safety of others) and 304 A (rash and negligent driving) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Two held for assaulting OGH surgeon  HYDERABAD: Police arrested two foreigners from Sudan and Saudi Arabia for assaulting a house surgeon at Osmania General Hospital (OGH) on Tuesday.  The assault triggered an impromptu protest by junior doctors. 
Afzalgunj police arrested Hassan, 22, a Sudanese national pursuing engineering at St Mary’s College of Engineering & Technology at Hayatnagar, and Aziz, 23, a Saudi pursuing spoken English at a private institution in Dilsukhnagar. 
At around 5 am on Tuesday, the duo was walking near Vanasthalipuram when a bike hit Hassan.  Aziz then took him to OGH for treatment.  “In the casualty ward, a house surgeon named Ram Kishan attended Hassan.  The latter, however, picked up an argument with the surgeon accusing him of not treating him properly. 
During the argument, Hassan and Aziz assaulted Ram Kishan and created nuisance at the hospital,” Afzalgunj SI K Raghavender told TOI. 
Following the incident, all junior doctors boycotted their duties at OGH and staged a protest at the hospital demanding stringent action against the offenders.  Police arrested the duo under section 332 (voluntarily causing hurt to deter a public servant from discharging duty) of IPC. 
They were produced in court and remanded in judicial custody.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Traffic curbs in place today for Ram Navami Shobha Yatra  HYDERABAD: In view of the Sri Ram Navami Shobha Yatra, traffic restrictions will be imposed in Goshamahal and Sultan Bazar areas on Saturday. 
Ram Navami Shobha Yatra, will start at Mahakaleshwari mandir (Rani Avanti Bai function hall ), Dhoolpet 10 am. 
City police in a press release said that traffic coming from Mallepally X roads will not be allowed towards Boiguda Kaman, will be diverted towards Mallepally mosque and Priya talkies at Mallepally X roads. 
Traffic coming from Darussalam will not be allowed towards Boiguda Kaman, will be diverted towards Godeki Kabar and Charkandil lane at Aghapura X roads.  Vehicles coming from Puranapool will not be allowed towards Gandhi statue and Jummerat Bazar, will be diverted towards Puranapool bridge either towards Petlaburj or Karwan/Kulsumpura.  Motorists coming from MJ bridge will not be allowed to proceed towards Jummerat Bazar, will be diverted towards City College/Afzalgunj.  Traffic coming from MJ bridge towards Begum Bazar Chatri will not be allowed and will be diverted towards Afzalgunj side. 
Traffic coming from Malakunta will not be allowed towards MJ bridge, will be diverted at Alaska Hotel towards Darussalam.  Vehicles coming from Afzalgunj X roads will not be allowed towards S A Bazar, and will be diverted towards Shivaji bridge at National Lodge.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Vehicles diverted in Old City to ease traffic congestion  HYDERABAD: In a bid to ease traffic congestion in Old City, police on Wednesday diverted vehicles moving from Madina to Nayapul towards the high court road on the left.  The move is being taken up on an “experimental basis”, cops said. 
According to sources, commuters were caught unawares when they found the new traffic diversions.  Those who wished to go towards Afzalgunj had to take the HC road and travel to City College.  From here, they had to take a right towards Nayapul and then to Afzalgunj. 
Locals and businessmen from Pathergatti and Madina said that while the move may have increased travel time by a few minutes and the commute by a kilometre or so, it did in fact ease the congestion. 
“Autos in Old City usually contribute to traffic congestion to a great extent.  The auto drivers park according to their whims and fancies and efforts to have them move the vehicles often yielded no result.  At least now, there seems to be a breathing space,” a trader, who did not wish to be identified, said. 
Traffic cops said that the diversions were likely to stay for at least a couple of days more.  “Movements of vehicles are being studied.  It will take two or three days to completely understand the issue.  It is quite likely that the diversion will continue tomorrow as well,” a cop said. 
The traffic police earlier, had barred the entry of autos from Gulzar Houz to Charminar in a similar effort to ease congestion on roads.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Wakf board yet to reinstate suspended mutawallis  HYDERABAD: Inspite of a high court order, asking authorities to reinstate suspended mutawallis (managers of wakf institutions), including Syed Akbar Nizamuddin Hussaini and Mir Sharfuddin, the wakf board is yet to take any appropriate action. 
In fact, the inquiry report of APSWB investigation officer Mohammed Ahmed Ali, who is the fourth officer to probe the case, absolved former Dargah Hazrat Shah Khamosh mutawalli Syed Akbar Nizamuddin Hussaini of all charges. 
The charges levelled against him by the APSWB included allegedly failing to protect 865.37 acres in various parts of the city such as Maqata Sultanpur, Sabir Gulshan, along the Ring Road and Maqta Hassan Baig.  The other charges included alleged mismanagement of land parcels in Khanajiguda, Maqta Sultanpur and Ehata-e-Ameer Ali in Afzalgunj.  Further, the board also charged Nizamuddin with violating the mansha-e-wakf (purpose of endowment) of Sabir Gulsha spread over around 10 acres near the Ring Road. 
In the report, a copy of which is in TOIâs possession states that there is a disconnect between the documents provided by the complainants and the nature of land.  Finding that the charges could not be proved, inquiry officer Ali said, âThe documents (provided by the complainants) clearly reflect that the maqtas have not been incorporated in the Muntaqab No 360 while republishing the same in the official gazette.  As such, the very title of the maqtas is under cloud (sic). â On several occasions, they also noted that witnesses, including the complainants, had failed to establish facts during cross examination. 
Further, he concluded: âIn view of the oral and documentary evidence charges levelled against the respondent (Akbar Nizamuddin Hussaini) are not proved but on the other hand are found baseless.  Hence, I request to reinstate the respondent as mutawalli of the subject institutions by revoking his suspension. â
In another case, that of the suspension of Mir Sharfuddin Khan Charitable and Religious Trust mutawalli Mir Sharfuddin, the court issued a similar order.  According to Sharfuddinâs counsel Khaja Moizuddin, the court directed the APSWB to act on the inquiry reports which absolved Sharfuddin. 
âIn the case of my client, the court on June 16 has directed the APSWB to take steps according to the inquiry report, which was submitted to the board last February, within two weeks.  So far the board has not acted,â Moizuddin said.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  AP Dental Council accused of fund misappropriation  HYDERABAD: A year after bifurcation, division of funds of various regulatory bodies is still posing problems, and the latest to take centrestage is the alleged misappropriation of funds by the AP Dental council -- the body empowered to regulate the profession of dentistry under the Indian Dentist Act.  The council represents over 18,000 dentists in the two Telugu states. 
The suspicion of fund misappropriation by the council stems from the fact that it had no formally-elected board since 2000 when the tenure of outgoing president Dr K Mahendernath Reddy expired, say members of the Telangana Dentists' Association (TDA). 
" Since 2000, there is no elected body in the AP Dental Council.  So, nobody knows what's actually happening to the one-time registration fees and annual renewal fees being collected from an estimated 10,000 dentists in Telangana.  Since the body has been functioning for more than 40 years, we want the funds belonging to Telangana dentists to be separated,"  said Dr T Jayasimha Reddy, president of TDA. 
He added that they are awaiting the constitution of a separate Telangana Dental Council by the state government shortly. 
Presently, every dentist registered with the AP Dental Council has to pay a one-time registration fee of Rs 2,000, besides Rs 400 as annual renewal fees. 
What fuelled the suspicion of TDA members was when state information commissioner M Vijaya Nirmala pulled up the AP Dental Council and imposed a fine of Rs 25,000 for not furnishing crucial information about its members and president in answer to an RTI application filed by activist G Suresh more than a year ago.  The information sought included �audited account copies for the last 16 years' and questions like how long has the current president been enjoying the position, among others. 
This was soon followed by a complaint lodged at the Afzalgunj police station by Dr G Vivekananda Reddy, president of the Bhagyanagar chapter of Indian Dental Association, in which he alleged that the AP Dental Council had siphoned off funds on May 15, 2014, a month before the state bifurcation. 
" The case was closed three months later with the police citing it as a civil dispute,"  said Dr Vivekananda Reddy.  When contacted, Afzalganj police station house officer (SHO) C Anjaiah acknowledged the closure of the case and said they had to do so as the AP Dental Council registrar had agreed to look into the allegations leveled by the complainant. 
Vivekananda Reddy also questioned the propriety of the AP Dental Council members still continuing in their posts without any sort of election since 2000.  However, when contacted, Mahendernath Reddy, who continues to be the regulatory body's president, claimed he was still occupying the post 'by default' and not 'by choice'. 
" It is the state government's prerogative to hold elections for the state dental council.  They postponed elections to the body three times in a row, the last being in March 2014 citing the impending bifurcation of the two states,"  explained Reddy. 
Refuting all allegations of fund misappropriation, he added, " The AP Dental Council has no assets.  Even its office space based at Osmania General Hospital comes for free. "  He asserted that they are maintaining audited records.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Auto driver held for raping minor in Hussainialam  HYDERABAD: Hussainialam police arrested a 23-year-old auto driver for kidnapping and raping a 15-year-old girl.  At 6 pm on August 19, Md Shareef of Talabkatta picked up the victim, whom he knew for a few months, near Charminar when she went there on some personal work.  Shareef took her to Afzalgunj bus stop in his auto. 
After reaching Afzalgunj, Shareef handed over the auto to his friends and took the victim to Gulbarga in an RTC bus.  In Gulbarga, Shareef checked into a rented room with the victim, posing as pilgrims, and reportedly raped her after promising to marry her.  On August 22, Shareef brought the victim back to Hyderabad and dropped her near her house at Hussainialam. 
The same day, the victim's mother lodged a complaint with police and a case was registered against Shareef under sections 366 (A), 368, 376 and sections 4 & 7 of the Protection of Children from Sexual offences Act, 2012.  The victim was sent for medical examination and police arrested Shareef, when he was waiting near Charminar bus stand on Tuesday morning. 
Charminar ACP K Ashok Chakravarthy said Shareef has a criminal record.  " Shareef is accused in 14 theft and snatching cases registered at various police stations across the city,"  he said.  The accused was remanded in judicial custody.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Accountant injured in robbers’ attack in Jeedimetla  HYDERABAD: Robbers attacked a 58-year-old accountant with a blunt object at Jeedimetla on Tuesday night and snatched away his hand bag.  Though there was no property loss in the incident, the victim suffered a head injury and police also found a damaged live bullet at the crime scene, triggering speculation about the involvement of armed robbers. 
At 9.45 pm on Tuesday, Raghava Sharma, a resident of Ushodaya Towers apartment in Shapur Nagar, Jeedimetla, and who works as an accountant at Venkateswara Metals at Afzalgunj for a monthly salary of Rs 10,000, reached his apartment complex from his work place. 
“As he was about to get into the lift on the ground floor, two persons reached there and hit Sharma on the head with a blunt object.  The assailants snatched the hand bag of the accountant, joined their associate waiting on a bike outside and sped away.  Later, when we reached the spot, an unusable .22 mm bullet was found on the floor, but Sharma said he had not heard the assailants open fire,” in-charge deputy commissioner of police (DCP), Balanagar, B Srinivas Reddy said. 
Sharma told police that there was only an empty lunch box in the bag.  His condition was said to be out of danger and police registered a case under section 324 (voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons or means) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).  “We do not know how the bullet reached the location.  Some residents of the apartment complex said they heard a loud noise at the time of the offence, but others told us that nearby electric transformer exploded at the same time,” the in-charge DCP said. 
A CCTV camera near the crime scene was not working and police sent the bullet for forensic analysis.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  The other face of Dhoolpet  HYDERABAD: It's that time of the year again when the city, breaking away from its mundane routines, is set to immerse itself in exalted jubilation, complete with drums, deities, devouts and dandiya.  And as the festive bells start ringing, the spotlight, like always, is found flashing brightly on the narrow bylanes of Dhoolpet from where the celebratory season is usually flagged off. 
Home to a sizable population of the Lodha, Bundeli Rajput and Gangaputra communities, it is in Dhoolpet, a short distance away from Afzalgunj in the Old City, that idols of all gods and goddesses ­ prayed to during the one-month-long festivities ­ are conceptualized, Syed Omar designed and created.  The rows of Durga murtis in particular are the hardest to miss.  “There are lakhs of idols (Ganesha, Durga and Sherawali) that are made in Dhoolpet. These are usually carved out of Plaster of Paris.  And unlike those that are made in Kolkata, their structures are built on iron frames,“ said Manik Mukherjee, president of the adhoc committee of the Hyderabad Bengali Welfare Association that organizes an annual Durga Utsav in the Old City.  “These days, the artisans of Dhoolpet also bring craftsmen from outside and employ them during the festive season,“ he added. 
The towering half-finished deities apart, what's also conspicuous in the area is the pres ence of several vendors waiting impatiently to lure `clients' with their neatly packaged pouches of ganja.  Over the years, this pocket of the city has become synonymous with the sale of the contraband.  And this, despite the presence of a police outpost right in the middle of Jummerat Bazaar, a stone's throw away from here.  In fact, Dhoolpet is itself home to the Mangalhat law and order police station and the prohibition and excise station. 
Notwithstanding such barriers, this flourishing `trade' goes on uninterrupted, beginning as early as 10 am every day .  History has it that residents of this area had ancestors who migrated from north and central India in the 17th century to work for the Nizams.  They took up the sale of the contraband post Independence as a means to eke out a livelihood.  Some have accumulated a lot of wealth since. 
On any given day, as one takes a leisurely stroll through Dhoolpet, one is sure to notice men with `stoned' eyes perched on the chabutras and anxious to sell a `tola' of 'best quality' ganja for Rs 200 to any eager buyer. Try to bargain and the peddler, sporting an unkempt look, wastes no time to retort: “Pachas ka pudi bhi hai lekin dubara idhar nahi aaoge.  Doso ka lelo, phir se khojte hue aaoge. “ (I have packets worth Rs 50 also, but after that you will not come here again.  Take a Rs 200-packet and you'll come looking for me again). 
As night falls, business picks up further.  Even post-midnight, it is not uncommon to see young men and women in sedans and SUVs driving in to 'score'.  “As regulars, we know just when to go there and look for what kind of people.  Even the `sellers', with years of experience, easily identify prospective customers. If they realize you aren't an `interested party' or are generally loafing around, they won't entertain you,“ said a young professional on condition of anonymity.  He confessed that the `dope' available in Dhoolpet is usually of the finest quality . 
Turns out, that the ganja making its way to the city comes from districts such as Warangal, Nizamabad and Visakhapatnam.  The local dealers buy this in bulk for Rs 3,000 a kilo and make 10 times profit when they sell it on the street. 
In addition to ganja, Dhool pet is also notorious for the sale of arrack.  There are about 200 families that are involved in the production, transportation and sale of illicit liquor. 
Police authorities, while ad mitting to Dhoolpet being a den of illegal activities, claim tha such `businesses' are on the de cline in the area.  “Bootlegging and drug peddling are coming down due to stringent enforce ment activities.  In the past one month, we have booked five of fenders under the PD (Preven tion of Dangerous Activities Act and the process has been initiated to book repeat offend ers.  We are also conducting a lo of awareness campaigns in the locality to explain to people why they need to opt for alternative livelihoods,“ said Ujwala Reddy assistant prohibition & excise superintendent, Dhoolpet.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.   K Chandrasekhar Rao: A flip-flip chief minister?  HYDERABAD: Lack of adequate groundwork before announcing major policy decisions coupled with the absence of consultations with experts and officials, appears to be taking a toll on the image of the Telangana government, especially chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao.  In an attempt to leave his mark on the city in an unseemly hurried manner, the CM only ended up earning the sobriquet — a ‘U-turn CM’ — with many of his major announcements being given a quiet burial. 
The latest among a series of such about-turns is the apparent go ahead to construction of metro rail as per the original alignment in front of the legislative assembly building.  In the first session of the assembly last year, Chandrasekhar Rao announced that he would not allow the metro rail in front of the assembly, ostensibly to protect the heritage building from getting marred.  Larsen & Toubro then submitted about six months ago an alternative route diverting the line from behind the assembly and the office of the director general of police (DGP) building.  And a year later, the government now wants L&T go ahead with the original project plans.  The delay resulted in avoidable escalation which could have saved the state exchequer a few hundred crores of rupees. 
In yet another example of a hasty decision, KCR, who tried to drum up support for several months for sale of cheap liquor in the state claiming the demand came from public in the state, finally gave his nod to the ill-conceived move just before the new excise policy was announced last month.  But faced with an increasing opposition from civil society, women’s groups and political parties, the cheap liquor idea, with which the government hoped to fill its coffers, was given a reluctant burial. 
Among the decisions that received widespread attention and bitter criticism were the CM’s plan to build a new Secretariat complex in place of the Chest Hospital at Erragadda.  A GO was issued for shifting hospital to Vikarabad and a committee was constituted to hammer out the details of the secretariat building.  But with severe opposition from doctors and para-medical staff, legal wrangles and heritage status issues, the government has gone quiet on the move.  Later, he shifted his focus to a parade ground at Bison Polo grounds at Secunderabad for his new Secretariat building.  His fixation on moving the Secretariat was mainly driven by his belief that the existing Secretariat is not in accordance with Vaastu. 
The evident lack of thought is also reflected in a decision to ‘construct’ Vinayak Sagar in the Indira Park - one of the last remaining green lungs in the city - a pit deep enough to submerge the tens of thousands of Ganesha idols.  Clearly, the CM appears to have been of the belief that a fiat from his office would solve all problems, notwithstanding any opposition from the likes of Bhagyanagar Ganesh Utsav Committee or the traffic nightmare that would result from the narrow approach roads to the park jammed with vehicles carrying the idols for immersion. 
The controversial decisions on shifting of Osmania General Hospital (OGH) from Afzalgunj has since been put on hold despite Chandrasekhar Rao’s directions to officials to bulldoze the existing heritage structure and construct a new building complex for the hospital.  Opposition to this move mounted rapidly and, clearly taken aback, especially after his ally MIM differed with the government on the issue, the health minister announced in the assembly recently that any decision on OGH demolition will be taken only after consulting the heritage conservation committee. 
Among other decisions on which Chandrasekhar Rao had to eat the humble pie were denial of fee reimbursement to students from the residuary Andhra Pradesh last year, demolition of illegal constructions that have been confined only to the Ayyappa Society in the city as well as emptying of Hussainsagar lake. 
Analysts say major decisions are being announced without adequate study of related issues.  If he is indeed keen on making a difference, then he should be open to suggestions from different quarters and then take a decision on its merits and not just on whims and fancies.  Only such an approach may ultimately boost the government’s image.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest India News.  No books for TPSC aspirants at State Central Library  HYDERABAD: Hundreds of job-aspirants hailing from across the state are dismayed with the State Central Library in Afzalgunj. 
Their grouse is that the library does not have any of the prescribed textbooks that are required to crack the Telangana State Public Service Commission (TSPSC). 
The library currently has textbooks which are outdated for the exams, said aspirants. 
“Earlier the syllabus was based on the united Andhra Pradesh, but after the bifurcation of the state, the Telangana government came with its own syllabi and prescribed few textbooks.  Unfortunately these books are very hard to find in the open markets,” said, C Suresh, an aspirant from Mahboobnagar, who has been doing the rounds of the library for the last eight months, only to be disheartened. 
While officials in the library claim that they have all the textbooks in place, students fail to exude the same confidence.  According to the students the same is the case with the City Library in Chikkadpally. 
“We are left with no option but to come to this library every day.  The books published by the Telugu Akademi are prescribed for such exams.  But, they have no such books in the library.  The last series of books that they have from this publisher dates back to 10 years ago,” said Mohd Ghouse, who has been aspiring to get a prestigious government job for the last three years. 
Ghouse also said that he tried his hands at getting an admission into a minority study circle, but the government has been dilly-dallying on this matter as well. 
“The government says that the notification for the minority study circles will be issued only after the results of the Warangal bypolls come out.  Until that time we will have to wait,” he said. 
A menial glance of the library shows that there are more students snoozing inside the library, than those studying. 
However, the curators of the library say that they have received several written letters from the students about the books and are doing their best to procure them. 
“We have received three editions of these books, but there were mistakes in all of them so we had to return them.  All of these books had typographical errors, spelling mistakes and omissions.  Once the Telugu Akademi releases new books we will be the first to receive it,” said a librarian, requesting anonymity.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Poor feeding marks Milad Festive fervour marked Milad-un-Nabi, the birthday of Prophet Mohammed, on Sunday.  Processions and service oriented activities were witnessed across the city on the occasion. 
Blood donation camps and religious meetings were organised at various places in the city. 
At the State Central Library, Afzalgunj, a blood donation camp was organised by Forum for Cultural Up-gradation and Social Services (Focus) and Tanzeem Irshadul Muslimeen (TIM).  Similar camps were also organised at Charminar, Secunderabad and other places in the city.  Poor feeding camps were also organised on the occasion. 
Thousands of people visited the historic Mecca Masjid where holy relics of Prophet Mohammed were kept on display.  Religious meetings were also held at different mosques in the city.

in brief. ‘Allegations against IIM-R Professor false’
The Police investigating the allegations of sexual harassment by Prof Bijaya Mishra against Prof Sasadhar Bera have found them to be false.  The Court accepted the police report and the matter have been closed.  An independent committee against Sexual Harassment (CASH) constituted legally by IIM Ranchi also investigated the matter independently and absolved Prof Bera of all allegations made by Prof Bijaya Mishra against him.  The information was given by IIM-R Director’s office on Friday. 
CCl to organise free eye camp on january 19
The CCl would organise a free eye camp under ‘Operation Jyoti’ on January 19 at CCl, Gandhinagar Hospital of Kanke Road in Ranchi.  The coal company has appealed the interested persons to take advantage of the camp. 
SAIl observes ROAD SAFETY WEEK
SAIl Safety Organisation in association with Traffic Police, Ranchi organised Road Safety Week at vital locations like Albert Ekka chowk, Sujata Chowk, Rajendra Chowk and HEC sector on January 16.  Before this, the SAIl Safety collective carried out the campaign at MECON building wherein employees reporting to duty were counseled and made aware on Road Safety.  The campaign was joined by Anup Birthare, SP (City), Pramod Ranjan, Officer In-charge, Traffic Police Ranchi at Birsa Chowk. 
Pulse Polio Programme unveiled
The Pulse Polio programme was inaugurated at Doranda Hospital on Friday.  It will be organised in two phases.  The first phase will be held on January 18 and the other on February 22.  On this occasion, Health department Principal Secretary K Vidyasagar and NRHM Mission Director Ashish Singhmar were present on the occasion. 
Mecon participates in Vibrant Gujarat 2015
Mecon actively participated in Vibrant Gujarat – 2015 which was held in Gandhi Nagar from January 7 to 13.   This was a prestigious event and can be termed as one of the most enterprising summit in the recent times to be held in India.   There was a galaxy of participants from international and national companies, institutions, administrators, policy makers and other important dignitaries. 
two-day Workshop at BAU organised
A Two day workshop on Commodity Future Market for Agricultural Universities was inaugurated by RP Singh on Friday.  Scientists from Agricultural Science Centre were present here.  Singh denoted the workshop fruitful for the participating farmers. 
Taurian School gets CBSE(I) Affiliation
Taurian World School is now affiliated to CBSE (I).  A team from CBSE had visited the school on September 26, 2014.  Notably, selected international schools in India have this affiliation.  The information was given by School Principal DR Singh on Friday. 
Two-day ranchi  district Book Fair begins
Two-Day Ranchi District Book Fair started at Bal Krishna +2 High School, Upper Bazaar on Friday.  Ranchi DEO SC Marandi inaugurated the fair.  Books from various disciplines are available here.  The information was given by a press communiqué.  Efforts to brand Ramnavmi as Ganpati Fest in Maha, Gujarat Ramnavmi will be observed in Ranchi on the lines of ‘Ganpati Mahotsav’ in Maharashtra and Gujarat.  Appealing the devotees to take part in large numbers, Ranchi Mahaveer Mandal Committee has also requested them to carry ‘Bajrang Bali Pataka’ (flags) with them as carried by every individual taking part during Ganpati Procession.  Ramnavmi procession, starting from different parts of the city will converge at Tapovan temple near over-bridge on Saturday. 
“It is going to be a huge procession to be taken by at least 2 lakh people where showering of flowers will be done by helicopters during the day,” said procession in-charge of Ramnvami of Ranchi Mahaveer Mandal Uday Shankar Ojha.  We have also appealed the devotees taking part in the procession to carry at least one small Ramnavmi flags in their hands as carried during Ganpati Procession in Maharashtra and Gujarat, added Ojha. 
Besides that, Ranchi Municipal Corporation (RMC) has also made arrangements to properly lighten up the streets of the city during tableaux procession on Friday where the electricity supply of the entire city will be cut due as a precautionary measure.  RMC CEO Prashant Kumar has ordered the officials to make arrangements in this regard. 
On the demands made by the peace committee members, the RMC has directed to install as many as 300 halogen lamps on Mahaveer Chowk-Gandhi Chowk-Saheed Chowk road till Sujata Chowk on Friday with a back-up of over 50 generators. 
“Since, there will be no power supply for the whole night on Friday; we have arranged a back up of 50 generators throughout the Main Raod and Mahveer Chowk,” said an official of RMC. 
Meanwhile, the district administration has also made proper arrangement to avert any untoward incident during Ramnavmin festival.  “Over 1000 jawans of RAF, JAP and IRB will be deployed at all important locations of the state capital,” said Ranchi SSP Prabhat Kumar. 
In addition to that, efforts are also being made to install CCTV cameras at least on some of the vulnerable points in the city having maximum chances of anti-social activities, added the SSP.  “At 2-3 places will be properly equipped with the CCTV cameras to keep a close vigil on the anti-social elements,” said the SSP. 
For smooth and peaceful movement of processions, some changes in traffic arrangements have also been made on Friday and Saturday banning the entry of any vehicles to Upper Bazar as well as Mahaveer Chowk from 11 am on Saturday till 4 am on Sunday.  City buses begin operation under new dispensation The city bus service commenced from Sunday under new formula will charge fare on the basis of distance covered by the passengers.  It is like the process of fare applicable for diesel autos running within city.  Ranchi Municipal Corporation (RMC) in collaboration with M/s Kishore Mantri Travels, the new operator for bus service, has fixed different rates as per distance. 
“For zero to five kilometers the fare is Rs 5.  Similarly, for five to twelve kilometers passenger will have to pay Rs 10.  If it is between 15 to 18 kilometers, we will charge Rs 15 and for 18 to 25 kms the fare is fixed at Rs 20,” said Kishore Mantri, owner of the firm.  Mayor Asha lakra confirmed about the approval of the fare.  As many as 10 city buses which were earlier run by Jharkhand Tourist Development Corporation (JTDC) were renovated and flagged off to ply on the city roads today covering stoppages from Dhurwa to ITI bus stand, passing through Birsa Chowk, Hinoo, Sujata Chowk, Bahubazaar, Kantatoli, lalpur, Kutchery Chowk and Piska More.  The service is available from 7 am to 7 pm.  50 percent of the bus seats are reserved for ladies besides one separate seat for ward councilor, legislator and disabled person. 
Mantri said in the coming 10 days, 30 more city buses would be pressed into service in the city.  The routes of these soon-to-be started buses are yet to be finalised by the RMC.  Mantri has requested Traffic Police and RMC to include Albert Ekka Chowk, Dr Camil Bulcke Path (Purulia Road), Ranchi and Hatia Railway stations in the new routes for the convenience of passengers.  Also, he has asked for a proper shelter at Dhurwa where the buses can be kept safely.  Presently, the buses are kept in a rental space at Kamre.  The Mayor said she will hold a meeting with representatives of Jawaharlal Nehru National Urban Renewal Mission (JNNURM) possibly on May 5 for marking a depot for the buses. 
As of now, Mantri is looking forward to get the fitness certificate, tax papers and insurance of the 10 running city buses.  “Previously, JTDC had ignored these three documents required in a city bus.  We will get it done within this week,” he said.  Mantri has hired drivers and conductors who were associated with bus services under JTDC.  “Each driver and conductor is experienced.  We are paying them Rs 225 per day,” said Mantri. 
In order to involve newcomers with the service, Mantri is mulling to launch three months course for non-matriculation people who would be trained as cleaners and similar course for graduates as conductors at free of cost.  Meanwhile, Urban Development Minister CP Singh who underwent a bypass heart surgery in New Delhi last month and is currently on medical leave congratulated Mantri for beginning the city bus service on Sunday.  Inbrief.. RDCIS, SAIl bags five Metallurgy awards
Ranchi: Functionaries of RDCIS, SAIl won awards in many categories during National Metallurgist Day celebrations on Sunday.  RDCIS DGM Partha Bannerjee won Metallurgist of the Year award, Deputy Manager Somnath Kumar won Young Metallurgist Award, DGM In-charge (Iron) Dr SK Pan New Millennium Iron award and IIM Fellow Award for GM (Rolling Mills) PP Sengupta.  RDCIS ED BK Jha received the National Metallurgist Award (Industry) on Saturday. 
JPCC observes Birsa Munda birth anniversary
Ranchi: JPCC observed the birth anniversary of freedom fighter Birsa Munda at party offices on Sunday.  On this occasion, the speakers stated that Birsa Munda was an active revolutionary during Jharkhand Ulgulan.  The movement he started was later crucial in helping the people of Jharkhand establish their separate identity. 
lions Club fundraiser for cataract operations
Ranchi: A fund-raising called Diwali Meet event was organised on Sunday by lions Club of Ranchi East.  All the funds generated from this event will be used for cataract operations in Niramaya Hospital, Kokar, Ranchi.  The event was attended by 300 members of the lion Club who enjoyed several interesting activities. 
‘HEC Day’ observed on its foundation day
Ranchi: The Foundation Day of Heavy Engineering Corporation was observed as ‘HEC Day’ at Friendship Avenue on Sunday.  Children of HEC High School, medical staff and professionals, HEC employees and others joined the ‘March for Introspection’ flagged off by HEC CMD Avijit Ghosh.  The parade was accompanied by patriotic tunes from band of Cobra Training Centre. 
Chhatra Yuva Shakti distributes blankets
Ranchi: The members of Chhatra Yuva Shakti distributed 101 blankets among the footpath-dwellers on Sunday.  The drive was conducted on the birthday of head of the organisation Aniket Raj.  The drive covered Station Road, Overbridge, Sujata Chowk, Albert Ekka Chowk and Kutchery Chowk.  Commuters to get free  Wi-Fi access on MG Marg Travelling through the congested lanes of the MG Marg also known as the Main Road would become slightly less irritating as commuters’ sour experiences of careening on the busiest road of the capital would be mellowed down by providing free Wi-fi Internet access for the first 20 minutes. 
The initiative sanctioned by the Ranchi Municipal Corporation envisages using existing infrastructure as well as the under construction high-mast lED towers on the Main Road from Albert Ekka Chowk to Sujata Chowk.  The free access would cease after 20 minutes.  The municipal corporation has allowed Bharti-Airtel, Reliance Jio, Vodafone and another telecommunication company to use their infrastructure on rent. 
“They will put their machines on high-mast at Albert Ekka Chowk and will put up routers on light poles on the street.  There is no user charge however the company would pay us `12,000 for using high-mast tower,” said PRO of RMC, Naresh Kumar Sinha. 
Additionally, the four telecommunication companies have also been asked to maintain the lED lights on the high-mast and also to bear the electricity usage charge.  The service providers would also pay rent of `800 per pole for using the light poles to extend the Internet connectivity on the one-and-a-half kilometre stretch. 
Meanwhile, the RMC’s initiative is being projected as a step towards transforming Ranchi into a smart city and catapulting it into league of cities with uninterrupted Internet connectivity. 
“This is one of the components of smart city and it has to be done by the RMC with the help of private companies.  The proposal is in initial stage and later on other issues like security of the network and preventing its misuse will be our focus,” said Deputy Mayor of RMC, Sanjeev Vijaywargiya. 
The proposal moved by telecommunication service providers would bring other prominent streets under the cover in later phases and as part of the proposal the companies have also expressed their desire to provide free Internet access at Government offices in Ranchi.
