Now, Haryana cops booked for killing dalit boy over pigeon theft  CHANDIGARH: Barely two days after two dalit children were burnt alive in Haryana's Sunpedh village in Faridabad, a 14-year-old dailt boy was allegedly killed by cops, hours after he was questioned for stealing two pigeons in Sonipat's Gohana town.  The boy was picked up by cops on Wednesday.  His body was found hanging from a hook in the ceiling in an empty house owned by a relative right behind his own house in Govindpura locality of Gohana on Thursday morning.  In protest, angry people blocked the Gohana-Jullana road and also organised a sit-in on the railway tracks for about three hours with Govinda's body.  Not wanting another political grenade to explode as in the case of the Faridabad murders, the authorities quickly booked the two ASIs of Gohana police station, Subhash and Ashok, for murder.  Cops refused to give the surnames of the two accused.  Even Govinda's full name was not given in the FIR.  On the condition of anonymity, local police officials said it was likely that Govinda hanged himself after being accused of theft.  The victim's family has, however, alleged that the two ASIs killed Govinda despite taking a bribe of Rs 10,000.  They alleged that the boy was first killed in custody and his body was later hanged near his home to make it look like a suicide.  Govinda belonged to a family of daily-wagers.  His father, Rampal, had died a few years ago.  On Thursday, Ganaur deputy superintendent of police, Satish Kumar, who has been put in charge of law and order at Gohana after the incident, told TOI that the FIR has been registered against the ASIs on the complaint by the victim's brother Gautam.  Gautam had taken Govinda to the police station after members of the nomadic tribe of Gariya Lohar which had put up a temporary settlement in the neighbourhood accused Govinda of stealing their pigeons.  Police sources claimed that both parties had reached a compromise after they were brought face-to-face at the police station.  " They said they would release Govinda in a couple of hours on Wednesday after they accepted the bribe, but they didn't,"  alleged Gautam.  Protests in Gohana led to two passenger trains running between Rohtak and Panipat, being cancelled on Thursday while one train was delayed for few hours.  Sources said police tried to talk to the protesters and end the blockade but were chased away.  Family seeks arrest by 11am on Friday Govinda's family did not cremate his body on Thursday after the autopsy and demanded that the two cops accused of his murder be suspended and arrested by 11am on Friday.  They have threatened not to cremate the body until their demand is met.  Senior dalit leaders are expected to reach Gohana on Friday. Download The Times of India News App for Latest India News.  Dalit immolation: Maya man to meet kin in Faridabad village  LUCKNOW: Intending to rake up the Faridabad incident in which two children of a dalit family were burnt alive allegedly by people from the upper caste, Bahujan Samaj Party chief Mayawati on Saturday sent her emissary and former party MP Raja Ram to the meet the family and bring in every detail of the incident. 
BSP sources said Mayawati asked Raja Ram, an influential BSP functionary from Azamgarh district in UP, to project the incident as a case study on atrocities on dalits not only in Bihar but also in UP where assembly elections are due in 2017.  BSP sources said Mayawati may visit the family after Bihar assembly elections. 
Raja Ram confirmed to TOI that he will visit the village and meet the family.  “Whatever feedback we get would be sent to the party president for further directions,” he said.  “Our functionaries have been helping the aggrieved ever since the incident took place and a strategy is proposed on how to help the family, emotionally as well as financially,” he said. 
BSP state president in Haryana, Naresh Sarang said the atrocities on dalits were not new in Haryana with people of the lower caste in substantial numbers.  “Dalits are targeted in the state regularly,” he told TOI.  Narang said in Sunpedh village, around 40km from Faridabad, dalits, are in minority, therefore, prone to oppression.  Sources said dalits in the regions are essentially Jatavs, the caste to which Mayawati belongs. 
A day earlier, Mayawati had alleged the Faridabad incident happened in the presence of police.  She not only demanded resignation of Haryana chief minister Manohar Lal Khattar, she also sought action against minister of state for foreign affairs General V K Singh for his alleged ‘dog’ remark in the context of the Faridabad incident. 
Political experts insist the incident has given an opportunity to Mayawati to tighten her grip on her core dalit vote bank which otherwise slipped into the hands of the saffron camp during Lok Sabha elections.  “She has been silent on atrocities on dalits for quite some time and as a result her vote bank shifted, but now she wants to influence dalits,” said S R Darapuri, political commentator.  “Her action, however, is politically influenced.  During her stint as UP CM there were instances of dalit atrocities and she could not stop them,” he added.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Village in grief, Haryana Chief Minister orders CBI probe A day after four members of a Dalit family were set ablaze inside their house at Sunpedh village here, the Haryana government on Wednesday conceded all the four demands of the family, including a CBI probe into the incident. 
In a late-evening announcement, Chief Minister Manohar Lal Khattar said his government had decided to order a CBI probe and provide a government job to Jitender, father of the two children who died in the attack. 
Free treatment will be provided to Jitender’s wife Rekha, who is recuperating at Safdarjung Hospital in Delhi. 
The village erupted in grief and indignation on Wednesday when the bodies of two-year-old Vaibhav and 10-month-old Divya, wrapped in white shrouds, arrived for cremation. 
Wailing soon gave way to anger and scores of villagers, walking hand in hand and shouting slogans, carried the bodies and placed them on the Delhi-Agra Highway, blocking traffic.  They protested for more than two hours in support of the four demands. 
As villagers staged the protest, Union Minister of State for Social Justice and Empowerment and Faridabad MP Krishan Pal Gurjar, reached Sun Perh village in the evening. 
Mr.  Gurjar met the family and apprised the villagers of the government’s decision to concede all their demands.  The villagers then agreed to perform the last rites of the two children who died in the attack.  “The government has conceded the demands and the family has agreed to cremate the bodies,” Mr.  Gurjar told The Hindu. 
Haryana DGP Y. P.  Singal said the situation in the village was under control.  “They tried to block the National Highway [in Faridabad], but we made them understand that this will put thousands of commuters to inconvenience.  Then, they protested with the bodies on the outer road.  After persuasion, they agreed to conduct the last rites,” he said. 
One more accused, Sanjay, was arrested on Wednesday, taking the total number of arrests to four.  The Chief Minister ordered the police to arrest the remaining seven accused at the earliest.  “All efforts are being made to arrest the remaining accused.  Their family members have been rounded up.  Five Special Investigation Teams have been constituted under Deputy Commissioner of Police Puran Chand,” Faridabad Police Commissioner Subhash Yadav said. 
Meanwhile, four more policemen have been suspended for grave misconduct in discharging their duties.  On Tuesday, four policemen were suspended for dereliction of duty.  A regular departmental inquiry has been initiated against all eight policemen.  Those suspended include Sadar Ballabhgarh SHO, Inspector Anil Kumar, Assistant Sub-Inspectors Wali Mohammad, Hari Singh and Shri Bhagwan and constables Vikash, Sandeep, Satish and Ram Mehar. 
Kalindi Kunj-Faridabad bypass blocked by Dalit families.  Photo: Ashok Kumar
(With inputs from PTI) Amid outcry, Khattar visits Dalit family Amid sharp criticism from the Opposition over the Faridabad incident, Haryana Chief Minister Manohar lal Khattar on Thursday visited the family of the two Dalit children who were burnt alive at Sunpedh Village and said the incident should not be given a “political or casteist colour”. 
Khattar, who was expected to meet the family on Wednesday, had to defer the visit in the wake of protests by angry locals. 
Two toddlers, two-and-a-half-year-old Vaibhav and 9-month-old Divya died after their house was set on fire by members of an upper caste community on the intervening night of October 19 and 20.  Their mother Rekha is currently in hospital with 70 per cent burns while father Jitender also sustained injuries in the incident. 
During the 15-minute-long meeting with the family, the Chief Minister assured the family that the State Government would bear the cost of treatment of the injured mother, Rekha, who is recuperating in Safdarjung Hospital. 
He assured Jitender and his family members that the culprits would be brought to justice after investigation.  Khattar also handed over a cheque of `10 lakh to the aggrieved family. 
While talking to the mediapersons, the Chief Minister said that the CBI enquiry is already marked into this incident.  So far, six of the 11 accused have been arrested and the others would be nabbed soon.  Eight Police personnel who had been deployed for the protection of the victim family have been suspended for showing grave misconduct in discharging their duties, said he. 
“We want that the investigation is done properly.  But with great regret I have to say that some parties are trying to politicise this incident.  It should not be given a “political or casteist colour,” said Khattar slamming the Opposition. 
“I met the victim’s family today and handed them over a cheque of `10 lakh.  So far, what has emerged from the investigation is that the matter is not a caste-related dispute but appears to be fallout of a long standing family feud,” he added. 
The Chief Minister said, “I have been monitoring this case since the very beginning and when allegations came up against police officials, a Special Investigation Team (SIT) was formed.  later the case was handed over to CBI as the relatives of the victim demanded that. ”
Khattar also called Haryana a “peaceful” state and claimed that such incidents are not likely to happen again.  later, he travelled to outskirts of the village and met the relatives of the accused at a circuit house.  He had a ten-minute meeting with the wives of three persons who were allegedly killed last year by relatives of Jitender hence fuelling the family enmity further.  People from Rajput community from 12 villages also met the Chief Minister and demanded that narco-test of members of the both the families (accused and victim) should be conducted. 
Under attack from the Opposition and ally lJP, the Haryana Government had a day before recommended a CBI probe into the incident. 
After the gruesome incident came to the light, the politicians made a beeline for the village on Wednesday.  Congress vice president Rahul Gandhi had visited the village where he accused the Prime Minister, Khattar, the BJP and RSS of practising “politics of crushing” those who are weak which results in such incidents. 
Haryana Pradesh Congress president Ashok Tanwar, Haryana ClP leader Kiran Chaudhry, Congress leader Kumari Selja, BJP MP from Ambala Rattan lal Kataria, CPM’s Brinda Karat, AAP leaders Ashutosh, Sanjay Singh and Ramdas Athawale, MP from Maharashtra, also landed up at the village on Wednesday. 
This fresh attack on a Dalit family in Haryana has sparked a fresh bout of acrimonious exchanges between the Opposition and the ruling BJP.  Amid outcry, CM Khattar visits Dalit family Amid sharp criticism from the Opposition over the Faridabad incident, Haryana Chief Minister Manohar lal Khattar on Thursday visited the family of the two Dalit children who were burnt alive at Sunpedh Village and said the incident should not be given a “political or casteist colour”.

BJP accuses Congress of giving " caste colour"  to Dalit killing NEW DELHI: BJP today hit out at the Congress for giving " caste colour"  to the killing of two Dalit children in Faridabad, calling it " height of insensitivity"  that must be condemned. 
BJP secretary Shrikant Sharma said the incident was born out of enmity between two families and noted that three members of the other family were killed earlier. 
" It is nothing but frustration on the part of those who are giving this incident a caste colour.  This is height of insensitivity.  We condemn it,"  he said. 
Two children of a Dalit family died and their parents suffered burn injuries after their home was set on fire, allegedly by upper-caste Rajputs in Sunpedh, a village in Faridabad near Delhi, in the early hours of Tuesday. 
Congress vice-president Rahul Gandhi had visited the family yesterday and alleged that weak people were being suppressed under the BJP government. 
" It was time for such people to do introspection over how many Dalits were killed when they were in power,"  Sharma said, in a reference to incidents of violence against Dalits when Congress was power at the Centre as well as Haryana. 
BJP appreciates Chief Minister Manohar Lal Khattar's decision to refer the case to CBI for investigation, he said.

column1: Suchi Pind
column2: Birs gutted in gurdwara fire  JALANDHAR: Four Birs of Guru Granth Sahib were gutted at a gurudwara in Suchi Pind on Sunday afternoon.  It is suspected that the fire was caused due to a short-circuit in the air-conditioner fitted in a room where the Birs were kept.  It took around half an hour for the fire tenders to douse the flames, but, by that time, carpets and other items in the gurdwara had been destroyed.  In the evening, members of Guru Granth Sahib Satkar Committee reached the spot and demanded that a case be registered against the gurdwara managing committee president.  After talks, a 13-member committee was formed to decide on corrective measures and management of the gurudwara. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Makkar pulls up religious body for getting case registered against gurdwara management, granthi  JALANDHAR: Shiromani Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee president Avtar Singh Makkar faced piquant situation in Suchi Pind gurdwara, where four birs of Guru Granth Sahib were gutted in fire on Monday.  Representatives of around half a dozen gurdwara committees offered keys of their gurdwaras to protest against the case registered on Sunday late night against the managing committee and " granthi"  of gurdwara holding them responsible for the fire.  Makkar had to face angry reaction from area residents as he was trying to pacify them and criticized Guru Granth Sahib Satkar Committee members under whose pressure police registered the case of maliciously hurting religious sentiments.  Residents said they had built and decorated the gurdwara with their offerings over several years, and if they had to face such cases, when they also were very sad due to the fire, then it was better for them to stay away from running the worship place's affairs.  The case has also brought out the differences between Akal Takht Jathedar Gurbachan Singh and SGPC president as the former had reportedly advocated registration of a case against the managing committee.  SGPC preacher Tarlochan Kaur publicly announced amid hundreds on Sunday evening that the jathedar had asked her to get a case registered against the managing committee and " granthi"  of the gurdwara.  However, on Monday, Makkar pulled up Tarlochan in front of several Sikh leaders and activists and asked to communicate with SGPC only and not directly to the Akal Takht jathedar.  Though Makkar refrained from openly saying anything about jathedar's stand, he minced no words in criticizing the Satkar Committee, which enjoys backing of the jathedar.  Makkar had also rung up Kapurthala senior superintendent of police asking him to take strict action against Satkar Committee members who had thrashed three " granthis"  as the video of their act went viral.  The case was registered on Sunday night after Guru Granth Sahib Satkar Committee mounted pressure for action against the managing committee while alleging that they indulged in gross negligence even as they were warned about it.  On the complaint of one Kartar Singh, police registered the case against managing committee and granthi Gurpreet Singh under sections 295A and 427 of the IPC.  An inquiry committee of the SGPC also reached Suchi Pind and recorded statements of the villagers and managing committee members.  Makkar said it was an accident and it was wrong to get a case registered against the gurdwara committee or granthi. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

column1: Moolakadai
column2:
Funds unspent as state highways department loses steam  CHENNAI: With weeks to go for the next state budget, the focus is now on projects announced in the past few years and the funds for them. 
While grand and ambitious plans were unveiled in previous budgets of the AIADMK government, the rate of progress achieved by the highways department on long-gestation projects has been slow.  Officials say with limited manpower and an array of roadblocks, especially in the city, the pace of work has been extremely slow. 
The metro wing of the state highways department — which has the most projects pending — has not been able to spend more than 200 crore every year.  Each year, it is allotted around 450 crore.  “Flyover projects at Tirumangalam, Porur and Moolakadai have been going on for years and yet in terms of progress, there is little to show,” said an engineer.  “If it is about road laying, we can spend up to 20 crore overnight.  But with flyovers, the work is slowed down by land acquisition, shifting of underground utility lines and protests by residents,” he added. 
The slow pace of work is clearly a sore point with residents, especially those living on the outskirts where the surge in real estate development and vehicle population is not matched by expansion in infrastructure.  “I’ll save at least 20 minutes if the Moolakadi flyover is completed.  It gets worse in the evenings when the traffic comes to a standstill,” said R Chandru, a driver who commutes between Moolakadai and Perumbur every day. 
The metro wing is also burdened by the task of preparing feasibility studies and project reports since many of them involve long-term planning, traffic projection and coordination with other agencies.  Some of the pending works include flyovers on Grand Southern Trunk (GST) Road, East Coast Road and widening of Inner Ring Road and Pallavaram — Thoraipakkam Road.  An L-shaped bridge is also in the works near the Madipakkam-Velachery junction.  The government is also mulling over building expressways along GST Road and Old Mahabalipuram Road. 
Across the state, while the department was supposed to spend to 4,095crore in 2013-14, it managed to spend only around 3,300 crore.  Similarly, while 5,812crore was allotted for the financial year 2014-15, the department has spent only about 3,500crore and has just a few weeks left. 
Given the sheer backlog of projects, the highways department may choose not to announce any major new proposals when the budget is unveiled this time. 
Usually, officials say, the maximum number of proposals and announcements are made just before the election year.  “But right now the department is understaffed and there is simply no money for new proposals.  There is no point sending new proposals as they have to be followed with feasibility studies, DPRs (detailed project reports) and tenders,” said an official.  “We have only proposed road widening along Inner Ring Road in Retteri,” said an engineer from the department. Dr RK Nagar bypoll: High turnout for a Chennai constituency  CHENNAI: With a 74% voter turnout, the R K Nagar bypoll is an endorsement of sorts of the AIADMK’s strength in this urban constituency.  While factors like opposition boycott and the fact that AIADMK chief J Jayalalithaa herself had contested here besides this being a bypoll, could not be discounted, rarely has a constituency in Chennai district recorded such high turnout in recent years.  Voter apathy has always been a discouraging trend in urban constituencies. 
In R K Nagar on Saturday, however, it was a carnival of sorts.  For voters here had never seen such a high profile candidate.  Hopes soared that the constituency would finally get attention.  After days of high-voltage campaign by ruling partymen, voters turned up in huge numbers to cast their voters.  The polling stations of Tondiarpet, Korukkupet and New Washermenpet were crowded with auto-rickshaws ferrying voters to the booths even for shorter distances.  The trouble-free and brisk polling in most of the booths took the polling percentage to 53.1% at 2pm.  “But things went out of hand after that,” CPI senior leader and candidate C Mahendran alleged.  He accused the AIADMK partymen of barging into polling booths and casting bogus votes . 
The election commission may have embarked on an authentication drive a few months ago to eliminate “defects, errors and multiple entries” in the electoral rolls, but some “outsiders” gleefully cast votes using their old voter identity cards.  A Tamilarasan and R Meena, residents of Thideer Nagar in the constituency, some six years ago moved to Aminjikarai.  But they managed to vote in Chennai Middle School in Pudumanaikuppam.  “Our houses were damaged in the tsunami and we wish to hold the same voter ID until we get new houses,” they said. 
Observers pointed to the presence of the entire cabinet and party functionaries from districts in the constituency from early June.  Several of them rented houses for a brief stay to canvass for votes.  DMK spokesperson T K S Elangovan alleged that money was freely circulated along with goodies.  “What else could have been the reason for the high turnout?” he asked. 
The opposition alleged that goodies were distributed to voters despite the election commission deploying 28 flying squads and 100 close circuit cameras to monitor the constituency.  Some of the voters of Kasipuram, Vinayagapuram and YMCA Kuppam off Jeevarathnam Street said sarees and sartorial material were freely distributed.  “A water tap was provided for us two days ago and we have been promised pattas in the coming months,” said S Ramashree, a resident of Kasimpuram.  At a corporation primary school in New Washermenpet, R Mahalakshmi, who recently shifted to Moolakadai, said she collected her goodies from a neighbour. 
Voters hoped that the arrival of ‘Amma’ would put an end to water woes in the constituency, which got only ‘smelly’ supply in taps for several decades “We purchase two pots of water at Re 1 from water supplied by a street tanker.  Amma will ensure good supply,” said S Rajinikumari, a Korukkupet resident.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  The meat you eat: How safe is it  Ill-equipped, unhygienic and unmonitored, the corporation's makeshift abattoir in north Chennai's Pulianthope is posing health risks to the public. 
While the newly-built modern abattoir next door remains closed over political differences, meat lovers will have to contend with the abysmal conditions under which goats are slaughtered and transported to butcher shops, restaurants and hotels.  Poor or rich, all are at risk, as the Pulianthope slaughterhouse supplies meat to almost the entire city.  It slaughters about 2,000 goats on weekdays and nearly 6,000 on Sundays. 
While corporation veterinarians have been appointed for daily inspection at the abattoir, they are rarely to be seen, say butchers.  Under corporation norms, one veterinarian is required to be on duty for every 500 goats slaughtered. While slaughter begins as early as midnight on Sundays, it starts around 4am on weekdays. 
Goats procured from as far as Rajasthan, after days of transit, are offloaded from trucks into the abattoir pen. They are led into the slaughterhouse early morning in herds; they are killed and piled on top of another.  The cruel treatment is unavoidable as the slaughterhouse is not large enough to handle the city's meat supply , remarks a butcher. 
Overcrowding inside the abattoir, which compounds risk of infection, has led corporation authorities to remove a part of the roof of the hall.  With monsoon expected in a month, the corporation officials said they are working on putting fixing the roof and installing an industrial ventilation system. 
Outside the slaughter hall, illegal vendors sell meat fat and other animal organs.  " A lot of these vendors sell discarded sick animal parts,â said a butcher.  This practice poses risks as carcasses are loaded onto vehicles just a few feet away.  Corporation officials had assured these vendors would be regulated, but to no avail. 
Butchers at the abattoir have been demanding extension of the 30,000 sqft facility.  " A 10,000 sqft space lies vacant next door.  We hope the authorities will allow us to use it. " 
With no proper drainage system, the abattoir is overrun with blood and animal waste. 
" The effluents are channelled to the Kodungaiyur treatment plant where they are cleared before they are let out into the environment,â a corporation official said. 
The temporary slaughterhouse was erected four months ago as the modern abattoir failed to open as planned.  About 1,000 butchers feared they would lose their employment with the opening of the new mechanised slaughterhouse. 
General secretary of the city's Mutton Merchants' Association, Moolakadai Anshu said, " What we want is an abattoir in all 15 zones.  This will lessen the load as smaller abattoirs will be easier to monitor. With lesser animals to screen, it will enable a more sanitary approach.  We have been making this demand to the corporation, but they haven't paid any heed to us. "  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Respite ahead for Velachery, tenders out for twin flyovers  CHENNAI: The Velachery-Vijayanagar junction — which comes to a standstill during peak hours as commuters from Taramani, Tambaram, Guindy and GST Road converge — could have streamlined traffic if the state highways department’s plan to construct twin flyovers at the major crossing falls in place.  The department has floated tenders to build twin-flyovers that will cross over the busy junction. 
Estimated to cost around 73 crore, the flyovers will give a smooth passage to commuters on Velachery Main Road, Velachery Bypass Road, Taramani Link Road and GST Road. 
One flyover will start on Velachery Bypass Road and end near Velachery MRTS station.  The other will connect Taramani Link Road to the bypass road.  It will go over the first one at a height of 13m at the junction.  Both flyovers will have two lanes and will be unidirectional.  “The flyovers will end on either side of the median on Velachery Bypass Road,” said an engineer from the metro wing of the department. 
For those residing in Velachery, the project could ensure less congestion.  “Traffic is clogged for most parts of the day.  During rush hours, it takes at least half an hour to cross the junction,” said V K U Udayavel a graphic animator residing in Velachery. 
Government wants contractors to complete the work in 33 months.  Bids will be accepted till August 12.  “Though we have quoted 73 crore for the project, contractors always ask for 20-30% more.  This has to be scrutinised before money is released,” said the engineer.  “This will take at least a month,” he added. 
Following delays that are now plaguing flyovers at Moolakadai, Thirumangalam and Porur, it has been decided that construction will start only after acquiring land.  “We have acquired about 50% of the land.  The rest are in the final stages.  We are confident that full acquisition will be complete before construction,” said the engineer.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Metro rail looks north, west  The expansion of metro rail is expected to get a move-on with surveys set to begin for a Detailed Project Report (DPR) on three new lines under phase II that is aimed at linking the northern and western suburbs to the city's south. 
Public sector engineering consultancy firm Rites has been identified for preparing the report and the contract will be awarded in a day or two, said senior Chennai Metro Rail Ltd (CMRL) official on Thursday . “They can start work in two weeks.  The exercise is expected to take six to eight months. “ A tender to identify a company for the work was floated early this year. 
After an initial study on the traffic pattern, need for connectivity and feasibility for construction, the state government identified the Madhavaram-Light House (17km), Koyambedu-Injambakkam (27km) and Madhavaram-Perumbakkam (32km) corridors under the second phase.  When complete, the metro rail network will be spread over 121km, while the ideal size is 200km.  “After the report is ready , it will be submitted to the state government for approval and then referred to the Union ministry for sanctioning of funds,“ he added. 
The report will look at the topography and geotechnical details, including soil condition, layout of stations, alignment of the line, requirement of land and suggestion for intermodal connection between metro and other modes of transport, train operation plan and financial features.  Contractors will take up construction based on the inputs provided. 
Sources said CMRL was going ahead with the expansion plan despite phase I work being mired in delays.  “It is high time phase II is also sanctioned because the city should have had an extensive network of metro lines by now going by the population growth and the number of vehicles on the streets,“ said an official. 
The proposal to extend metro rail line from Washermenpet to Thiruvottiyur is yet to be cleared for funding.  “A DPR was prepared and the state govern ment approved it two years ago.  But, we cannot take it forward till the Union ministry gives clearance for funding pattern.  The work will be taken up as extension of phase I which is being constructed,“ he added. 
The initial idea was to study three corridors totalling 63km -Moolakadai to Thiruvanmiyur via Perambur, Thousand Lights and Mylapore; Moolakadai to Thirumangalam via Ambattur and Mogappair; and Mylapore to Poonamallee via Iyyappanthangal -under phase II.  Delhi Metro Rail Corpn, prime consultant for CMRL, was assigned to do a DPR.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Metro slows down Tirumangalam flyover work  CHENNAI: Tirumangalam flyover, which has been in construction since 2011, may be delayed by another two months.  Officials from the metro wing of the state highways department say that the tunneling work under one of the flyoverâs ramps has slowed the progress of the work.  The flyover was scheduled to open this month. 
The Rs60crore flyover being built as part of Inner Ring Road and will go over the junction of Anna Nagar 2nd Avenue and Mogappair Road.  The flyover will make commute easier for residents of Koyambedu, Ambattur, Red Hills and Avadi. 
Each flyover has two ramps - the portion before the pillars of the flyover start â that are heavy and engineers are careful on how much pressure it exerts on the ground as metro railâs tunnel is just 9m below the surface.  âThe ramp at the Anna Nagar end of the flyover is right above the tunnel.  We have kept load cells which record the weight of the structure,â said an engineer.  âFor every one metre addition of the structure, we have to wait for up to 15 days for the weight to dissipate before we can continue work,â said a highways engineer.  The department is getting technical support and advice from IIT-Madras. 
Engineers earlier expected the construction to be completed by July, but 2.4m of construction is still left.  âWe placed the load cells on January 2,â said the engineer.  When completed, it will be the first flyover by the metro wing of the state highways department.  Gemini flyover and the ones at Kathapara and Maduravoyal were built by the National Highways Authority of India before they were handed over to the state for maintenance.  The smaller flyovers are all built by Corporation of Chennai. 
The rest of the work has almost been completed.  âWe have finished constructing all the pillars and some 90% of the work is complete,â said the engineer. 
The flyover was proposed in 2010.  Construction began a year later and the deadline kept shifting due to numerous delays since the first deadline of March 2013.  Some of the issues that caused the delays are land acquisition â for which Rs19 crore of the total budget of Rs 60 crore was spent â and shifting of underground utilities like Metrowater pipes and TNEB lines. 
Commuters hope the flyover is completed before the onset of north-east monsoon which usually sets in around October 20.  âAs it is, it takes about 15minutes to cover 1km from Koyambedu flyover to Shanti Colony.  When it rains, it gets worse.  Hope the flyover is completed and opened before that,â said M R Udaya, a resident of Maduravoyal. 
More flyovers are under construction at Porur, Moolakadai and Anna Nagar.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  MTC told to pay Rs 8 lakh after man slips and dies while boarding bus  CHENNAI: More than two years after a passenger died because of a bus driver's rash and negligent driving, a motor accident claims tribunal here has slapped the managing director of Metropolitan Transport Corporation with a fine of Rs 8 lakh. 
Sekar died in an accident while boarding a bus at Moolakadai junction near Mahavaram on December 6, 2012.  According to the petition filed by his family, the driver started the bus before ensuring that all the passengers had boarded the vehicle.  Because of the sudden movement, Sekar fell down from the bus and came under its wheels.  He died on the way to hospital.  As the death occurred solely because of the rash and negligent driving of the bus driver, the MTC was liable to pay compensation, the petition said. 
Denying the arguments, MTC said Sekar was trying to board a running bus.  Despite being warned by the conductor and other passengers, he continued to run along the bus.  Suddenly, he slipped near a pit and sustained fatal injuries, MTC said, adding that Sekar himself was responsible for the accident and, it was not liable to pay compensation. 
Sub-judge J Chandran said according to a witness, who narrated the sequence of events in the court, the accident occurred because of rash and negligent driving of the bus driver.  There was nothing before the court to doubt " credibility of the evidence" , the judge said, and pointed out that GNT Road traffic investigation wing police had registered a case against the bus driver under Section 279 (driving on a public way so rashly or negligently to endanger human life) and 304 (A) (causing death by rash and negligent act) of the IPC. 
He said the driver and the bus conductor were not examined before the court. 
The judge said the accident could have been averted had the driver drove the bus in a slow and cautious manner.  Being the administrative head of the MTC, its managing director was liable to pay compensation, the court said.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  Auto driver, 3 ‘passengers’ rob man in Madhavaram  CHENNAI: An autorickshaw driver and his three associates robbed a 26-year-old crane operator of Rs 1,500 in cash and a mobile phone worth Rs 15,000 at Moolakadai near Madhavaram on Friday night, police said.  The gang later pushed the victim out near an arts and science college on Madhavaram-Red Hills High Road and sped away. 
M Naresh of Kannappar Samy Nagar near Puzhal, who suffered injuries to the hand in the incident, walked about 1 km to the Madhavaram police station and lodged a complaint.  A case was registered and team of police personnel took Naresh in their vehicle from Moolakadai to Puzhal and nearby areas to trace the suspects but failed. 
Naresh told police that the incident occurred when he was returning home from work.  He saw an autorickshaw parked near the Moolakadai junction on Madhavaram-Red Hills High Road and approached it.  When he mentioned his destination, he was asked to get in.  “I saw a man sitting next to the driver and two others on the back seat.  One of them on the back seat got down and after I got in, he sat next to me,” he was quoted as saying. 
Soon after the journey began, Naresh told police, the two men sitting next to him landed a couple of blows on his face and he lost memory.  When he came to, the auto was passing by the Madhavaram police station but they held him tight and continued their attack.  Around 11pm, after snatching his cash and phone, they pushed him down on the road near Kanagachathiram Nagar and fled, he said. 
On Thursday, Manikandan of Mathur-MMDA was returning home in an auto when he was robbed of Rs 2,000 and four grams of gold jewellery near Koyambedu by a gang that adopted a modus operandi similar to the one a gang used to rob Naresh was on Friday. 
In an incident on December 3, 2012, Mallika of Mathur-MMDA, wife of retired sub-inspector Sadasivam, was kidnapped and murdered for her gold jewellery when the 50-year-old woman was returning home in a share autorickshaw from the Koyambedu bus terminus.  The killers dumped her body in the Vadaperumbakkam lake and escaped.  Police solved the case by arresting autorickshaw driver Venkatesan, 33, of Kodungaiyur, Parthiban, 26, a Tasmac employee, and Sudhakar, a tanker driver. 'Whichever party wins in 2016, it'll have a tough time'  DMK spokesman T K S Elangovan, in a freewheeling interview to TOI, opened up on a range of issues including coalition possibilities, family rule, the state of Tamil Nadu's economy, and the effect of a possible third front on DMK's prospects in the forthcoming assembly elections.  Excerpts:DMK appears to be reaching out to DMDK.  Are you in talks with Vijayakanth's party for an alliance? Last time we sought DMDK's support was before the 2013 Rajya Sabha elections when I met L K Sudheesh to get his party MLAs' votes for Kanimozhi.  They didn't support us thenâ¦we are not looking for too many allies now.  We may approach Left parties as they are a natural choice.  We will be comfortable working with Left parties, Congress, DMDK and MDMK, but we haven't talked to anyone so far.  PMK is trying to shed its casteist image and project Anbumani as a leader of the youth.  Won't PMK pose a threat to DMK's chances? PMK has attacked non-Vanniyars for over 25 years.  They can''t shed their Vanniyar tag.  They unleashed violence against other groups in Villupuram recently.  What are the major issues confronting the state? Whichever party comes to power in 2016, it will have a tough time.  Finances are in a poor shape as public debt has mounted to Rs 4 lakh crore.  And with our promise to impose prohibition, it will make things more difficult.  There is unemployment.  Every section of society, be it weavers, realtors, construction workers or farmers, has problems.  How is the agricultural sector doing? For the fourth successive year, owing to water shortage, most farmers have not been able to carry out cultivation of the short-term Kuruvai crop.  We toured nine districts and interacted with farmers.  All of them complained of poor maintenance and lack of desilting of water bodies.  But hasn't the agricultural output gone up in the last couple of years?
I don't think so.  How was it under DMK? When Kalaignar was the chief minister, without making much noise, he used to send emissaries to meet the Karnataka CM to get water released from Cauvery.  Karnataka used to oblige till it gained political overtones. 
What are the main poll issues for 2016? Lack of livelihood is the biggest issue.  Isn't corruption an issue? But given DMK's own record, you would not be in a position to talk about it, would you? Corruption is an issue and DMK can talk about the inaction due to corruption.  Government has failed to implement a single infrastructure project or attract a single industry.  Three flyover projects in North Chennai, - at Vyasarpadi, Moolakadai and Ennore - started in 2010 when I was an MP, they have not yet been completed though no land acquisition is involved.  Instead of completing infrastructure projects, Chennai Corporation is wasting time and money on constructing Amma theatres.  Port-Maduravoyal elevated road work is stuckâ¦power is available in the state because we purchase more than 3,300 MW from private suppliers at rates higher than our generation cost.  As a result, our power bills have gone upâ¦crimes have also gone up in recent years.  Many go unreported as police refuse to register complaints.  But opposition is in a state of disarray? Does DMK stand a chance without strong allies? We expect a share of AIADMK vote bank to shift loyalties to DMK.  We are also confident of roping in some alliance partners.  Won't formation of a third front hamper DMK's chances more? DMK suffered losses in 2014 Lok Sabha elections because of the third front.  But now BJP has lost its base, people have come to know that the Modi government is full of promises and no action.  There won't be a strong third front in the coming elections.  Will DMK field A Raja, Kanimozhi and Maran, who are accused of corruption, as campaigners? If we keep them away, it would mean that we admit they are guilty.  When we know they have not done anything wrong, why should we isolate them? Within the party we had this debate.  CAG's assessment of Rs 1.76 lakh crore loss in 2G is a myth.  Moreover, Raja attracts crowds wherever he goes.  If 2G verdict comes before the polls, it will help us.  Has promotion of Karunanidhi's family in the party and government affected the party's image? Family members of many DMK leaders including V R Nedumchezhian, K Anbazhagan and K A Mathiazhagan were legislators.  I was also groomed by my father.  DMK is full of people who have come from families who are aligned to the ideology.  Stalin has risen from the ranks.  He has been involved in political activity since 1969.  He was arrested during Emergency.  Alagiri and Kanimozhi, of course, are later entrants.  What do you think of TNCC president E V K S Elangovan's leadership? Elangovan is keeping the Congress alive in Tamil Nadu.  It is a marginalized force in the state, but it has the capacity to return to power at the Centre.  Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.  82-year-old robbed in share auto by driver  CHENNAI: In the third such incident in two months, a share autorickshaw driver snatched three sovereigns of gold chain from a woman passenger in R K Nagar on Thursday night. 
Narayani, 82, boarded the share autorickshaw in R K Nagar and was headed to IOC.  The driver, who had an associate, snatched the chain from the woman at knifepoint.  When they stopped the vehicle, the woman cried for help and passersby rushed in and caught them. 
Narayani had gone to her daughter’s house in Korukkupet to celebrate Vinayaka Chaturti.  She was on her way back home to Ezhil Nagar when the incident took place. 
When Narayani saw the auto had driven past Ezhil Nagar, she asked the driver to stop.  However, the autorickshaw driver and his associate, who sat next to him, threatened her at knifepoint and snatched her gold jewellery. 
After nabbing the accused, passersby also retrieved the stolen gold jewellery.  They handed over them to police, who identified the autorickshaw driver as Subagir, 34, of Washermenpet, and his friend as Sekar, 28, of Tondiarpet. 
The R K Nagar police have registered a case and arrested Subagir and Sekar.  They were remanded in judicial custody. 
In an incident on August 28, a crane operator, Naresh, boarded an autorickshaw in which two teenagers were travelling.  They attacked him and snatched 3,000 and his mobile phone.  They pushed him down on the road near Kanagachathiram Nagar near Moolakadai. 
On August 27, Manikandan, a resident of Mathur-MMDA, was robbed in a similar fashion by some men, who escaped with 2,000 and gold jewellery when he was returning home in a share autorickshaw from Koyambedu. Man hires gang to âabductâ girlfriend, nabbed  CHENNAI: A 38-year-old man who hired a gang to âabductâ a woman so that he could ârescueâ her ended in police custody on Tuesday after an accident. 
Police said Madhavaram resident Karthik promised four thugs Rs 5 lakh to âabductâ the woman, whose husband works in Saudi Arabia.  According to the plan, the gang would intercept the woman in Moolakadai and take her away.  Karthik would then intercept the getaway car, âbeat upâ the men and rescue her. 
The gang suggested that all of them meet in an SUV before the kidnap.  Karthik got in and the gang members drove away with him.  They demanded Rs 5 lakh to free him.  When the car neared Guindy, Karthik grabbed at the steering.  The driver lost control and hit a biker who blocked the car.  Karthik came out and cried for help.  Some passersby nabbed one of the gang and called police.  A team arrived and handed Karthik and the gang member over to the Madhavaram police. Man hires goons to kidnap wife’s boyfriend, 2 held  CHENNAI: Police on Friday arrested two of three men hired by a man employed in Saudi Arabia to kidnap his wife’s boyfriend in Chennai.  The case came to light when the abducted man, S Karthik of Madhavaram, managed to flee from his tormentors and lodged a complaint.  The Madhavaram police registered a case and are looking for two more men, including Sultan who ordered the kidnapping. 
A court has remanded the arrested men, P Ravi alias Ravikumar, 24, of Thiruchengode in Namakkal district and K Appu alias Vikramadityan, 25, of Red Hills, in judicial custody. 
Police said Sultan worked as a civil engineer in Saudi Arabia, while his wife Fathima* lived in Madhavaram.  A year ago, she approached Karthik, who worked with a private mobile service provider, in connection with a SIM card.  Soon, the two began a relationship and often met at her house.  However, Fathima broke off the relationship when Karthik, a resident of Natesan Nagar in Madhavaram, began insisting that she divorce her husband Sultan and marry him. 
Meanwhile, Sultan learned of the intimacy between Karthik and his wife and decided to kidnap Karthik.  He hired Ravi, Appu and Mahesh for the job.  The three men, however, met Karthik and struck another deal to reunite him with Fathima.  Karthik agreed and promised to pay them Rs 5 lakh. 
The gang members called him for a few rounds of talks where they suggested that they would kidnap the woman when she was walking on the road and cruise along slowly so that Karthik could intervene and rescue her.  This would definitely impress the woman and he could regain her confidence, they said.  The gang suggested they conduct a recce before the actual kidnap and told him to hire an SUV. 
A few days ago, the four of them went on a trip to Moolakadai when the gang members changed direction and headed towards Guindy.  The men told Karthik that they had kidnapped him as ordered by Sultan as he promised them a larger sum. 
As the SUV was on the Kathipara flyover in Guindy, Karthik grabbed at the steering.  The driver, later revealed as Appu, lost control and the vehicle hit a two-wheeler.  The biker and other passersby blocked the car and dragged Appu out. 
Taking advantage of the melee, Karthik got out and cried for help.  While the others managed to flee, Appu was handed over to the Guindy police and later handed over to the Madhavaram police.  Based on the information provided by Appu, police nabbed Ravi and the two were arrested on Friday.

Tribal women farmers in Tamil Nadu hills manage weather stations KOLLI HILLS: Women tribal farmers are helming many community managed automatic weather stations at various agro-ecological zones here that could be game changers for the region in providing timely and accurate forecasts and ensuring food and nutrition security.  Of the seven automatic weather stations in the hill ranges here
column4: four are run by women and three by men with all of them being tribals and farmers. The AWS provide meteorologic information with a local focus to support agriculture.  "" We at the automatic weather stations collect data on temperature
column10: a 23-year-old tribal woman and a small farm holder managing the weather station at Thuvarapallam here
column11: told PTI.  The primary purpose of AWS is to support farming and related activities
column12: the source of livelihood for people here who are predominantly "" Malayali""  tribes.  Malayali is the name of the tribe
column13: meaning dwellers of hills and weather stations
column14: and are run with the community participation.  The weather stations were set up by M S Swaminathan Research Foundation (MSSRF) with the support of Bioversity International and The International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD)
column15: a UN agency.  Vijayalakshmi moved to Thuvarapallam in Namakkal District following her marriage and studied upto 12th standard.  "" I was trained on fundamentals related to weather conditions
column17: and in managing the information system
column20: the data gets fed automatically into the system.  The first AWS was set up at Moolakadai in Kolli hills last year.  This year
column21: six other such stations were established in Navakadu
column25: Vendalappadi and Puliampatti.  These places fall under different agro-ecological zones and are dominated by tribal communities.  The 24-year-old Parameswari
column26: who manages the Keeraikadu AWS says young tribal men and women like her who run the weather stations do it voluntarily
column28: they are given an incentive of Rs.1
column29: 500 per month by MSSRF.  A farmer
column30: she went to school up to eight standard
column31: and now is "" happy to be part of an initiative which will help our farming besides the community. ""  Jaya unveils new bridges

Respect sentiments of people: DMK A large number of Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam (DMK) volunteers, including women, staged demonstrations at the headquarters here and Sivaganga, demanding that the government impose total prohibition, heeding to the public outcry. 
Former Ministers Suba Thangavelan, V.  Sathyamoorthy, former MP Bavani Rajendran and former MLAs Murugavel and Thisaiveerran took part in the agitation organised in front of Aranmanai here as part of the party’s State-wide agitation, demanding total prohibition in the State. 
District secretary Suba Tha Divakaran led the agitation, in which a large number of women participated and raised slogans against the State government and demanding the immediate closure of the liquor ships.  Addressing the stir, Mr Divakaran said the State government should respect the sentiments of the people, especially the womenfolk and close down the liquor shops. 
At Aranmanaivasal in Sivaganga, DMK district secretary and former Minister K. R.  Periya Karuppan led the agitation.  Former Minister M.  Thennavan and DMK office-bearers joined the agitation and shouted slogans against the government for maintaining a stoic silence on the issue even after the death of ‘Gandhian’ Sasi Perumal, who had been fighting for prohibition. 
Before staging the demonstration, the DMK volunteers observed silence for a minute as a mark of respect to Sasi Perumal and conveyed their condolences to the bereaved family. 
Dindigul
Despite a series of agitations against Tasmac outlets being staged across the State, the State government has not made any clarification on the issue, according to DMK’s deputy general secretary, I.  Periasamy. 
Addressing a meeting organised by the party demanding implementation of total prohibition in the State here on Monday, Mr.  Periasamy said that unlike the previous DMK Government that worked for the people, the present government did not bother about the common man.  “The DMK government worked for the welfare of women in particular.  But, now, the people are shocked to see separate rooms set up in bus stands for the benefit of lactating mothers, very near liquor shops,” he said. 
Stating that the people of the State have now realised that the DMK president would fulfil all his promises, he said that former Chief Minister M.  Karunanidhi would keep his words of implementing total prohibition on coming back to power in the State. 
The cadres, including district secretaries, A.  Chakrapani (West) and P.  Senthilkumar (East), took part in the agitations.

column1: Padmavathy Street
column2:
Kidnapped boy rescued by police A boy who was kidnapped for ransom while on his way home from school on Thursday was rescued in a covert operation by police on Friday night.  The alleged kidnapper, an engineering graduate, has been apprehended. 
Police sources said the boy Arvind Raj, a class VI student of a private school on Padmavathy Street in Madanandapuram near Porur, did not return from school on Thursday afternoon.  “Around 4 p. m.  on Thursday I got a call on my cellphone from a man who claimed he had kidnapped my son and demanded a ransom of Rs.  50 lakh for his release.  Shocked on hearing this, I informed my husband and we soon approached the city police,” Suganthi (37), the boy’s mother recalled the agonising moments at a press conference at the Commissionerate on Saturday.  The kidnapper had obtained Suganthi’s number from her son after taking him away in his car as he was walking to his house. 
Suganthi and husband Balaji, an L&T employee here, approached Commissioner of Police S.  George, who formed 16 special teams lead by two Additional Commissioners, to rescue the child.  “We tutored the mother to respond to the kidnapper and she did a good job by convincing him on giving him Rs.1.5 lakh for the safe return of her child,” said an investigating officer. 
Suganthi took a train to the Avadi railway station on Friday evening and finally reached a bridge near Pattabiram.  When an unidentified man approached the mother to take the money, the police team that was providing cover, swooped in on the suspect. 
He was identified as Bala alias Balamahendran (26), a resident of Brindavan Nagar, Avadi, who is unemployed. 
Arvind Raj was seated in Bala’s car that was parked near a bridge close to the Hindu College railway station.  He was reunited with his parents around 9 p. m.  on Friday.
